title: METRO DIARY
description: WITH all the publicity Britney Spears has been getting, Nancy Cascella was reminded of an exchange she had with Robbie, her 6-year-old son, as they drove home from summer camp. At one point, he said, ''Mom, you know, Britney Spear and Jake Spear have the same last name.'' Mrs. Cascella said that seemed to be true, but she wasn't quite sure who Jake Spear was. Was he another camper? she inquired. Silence from the back seat, then Robbie was heard mumbling to himself, ''Jake Spear, Jake Spear, if it's not Jake, then who is it?'' Moments later, the light dawned. ''I mean Shakespeare, Mom,'' he said. ''Britney Spear and Shakespeare have the same last name.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PORETTA, JAMES WILLIAM
description: PORETTA-James William. Age 48, of Route 23A, Palenville, died Thursday evening, December 28, 2000, at home, after a long illness. He was born August 14, 1952, in Philipsburg, NJ, the son of Mary Bracken of Philipsburg, NJ, and the late Joseph Poretta. Mr. Poretta earned his BA in English from Seton Hall University in 1974. He also earned a MA in English Literature from Montclair University in 1978, and an Associates Degree in computer programming from Bergen Community College in 1980. Mr. Poretta taught English, Business, and coached wrestling at Englewood High School from 1974 to 1983. He subsequently worked as a technical writer at Timeplex, Inc, in Hackensack, NJ, from 1983 to 1986, and as a software engineer at Candle Corporation in White Plains, NY, from 1986 to 1993. James was the co-owner of the Palenville House Bed and Breakfast in Palenville since 1990. James was active in many volunteer organizations and was recognized for his services by Volunteer Services for Children in 1991. He was a member of the Laurel House in Stamford, CT, at the time of his death. Mr. poretta is survived by his companion, James F. Forster of Palenville; a brother, Joseph Poretta of Doylestown, PA; a sister, Mary Eleanor Bradley of Bethlehem, Pennsylvania; a niece, Gabriella Poretta, and a nephew, Joseph Poretta, both of Doylestown, PA. Relatives and friends may call at the Traver & McCurry Funeral Home, 234 Jefferson Heights, Catskill, on Tuesday from 2 to 4, and 7 to 9 PM. Funeral services will be held 10:15 AM, Wednesday, from the funeral home, followed by an 11 AM Mass of Christian Burial at Sacred Heart Church, Route 32A, Palenville. Fr. Kieran Monahan, Pastor, will officiate. Interment will be in Palenville Cemetery, Palenville, NY. Contributions in his name may be made to the Laurel House, 1616 Washington Blvd, Stamford, CT 06902.

title: A Clean, White Slate
description: Somehow, it seems appropriate that 2000 should have ended with a winter storm worth remembering, a walloping northeaster drawing snow down in heaps from a solid ceiling of clouds. This was the kind of storm that is preceded most richly by anticipation, by the heraldry of radar and rumor, bringing in advance a seasonal glibness to almost everyone in its potential path, everyone, that is, who was not required to travel. On Saturday morning, the weather drew people to their windows again and again to see how fast the snow was falling, then to see if the fire hydrant had disappeared, then to worry whether the plows were coming. And as always when a storm of this dimension crosses New York City, what it brings in greatest abundance is a muffled hush, the sound of nothing doing.

description: SCHUSTERMAN - Charles. The Hillel family extends its profound sympathies to our dear friend Lynn Schusterman and her family on the tragic passing of her beloved partner Charles. Charles, the co-chair of Hillel's International Board of Governors, was a philanthropic visionary who believed passionately in the renaissance of Jewish life in the United States, Israel and the former Soviet Union. title: New Debates for a New Year
description: New Year's Day is the traditional time for gazing, Janus-like, both forward and backward. After the great millennial celebrations of last year, the first months of 2000 had a celebratory feel. But for Americans, the election season at year's end saw the aura of continual celebration replaced with a pervading sense of uncertainty and conflict. Coming out of that political whirligig into the first peaceful hours of 2001, we have now tipped over into the rest of history in a way that no one could have predicted. Seeing a new administration go through the rituals of cabinet appointments and inauguration planning has brought, as it ought to, a calming sense of reassurance. Yet when work resumes tomorrow, in Washington and in all branches of the nation's vast economy, no one should doubt that this particular new year could be the threshold of a new era of contention over protecting the security of the nation, shaping the daily lives of the citizens and guarding the very land upon which we live.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDMAN, SIDNEY JAMES
description: LANDMAN-Sidney James. Customer Service Representative for Villeroy and Boch in New York and a retired professor of English Literature, died in his apartment in Park Slope, Brooklyn, December 18. He was 66. Born August 5, 1934, in Fort Worth, Texas, he was the only son of Sidney Landman and Kathlyn Parker Landman. He earned the Bachelor's Degree from Baylor University and the Doctorate in English from Vanderbilt University before beginning a thirty-year teaching career as a specialist in Shakespeare and Renaissance literature. He taught at Vanderbilt, Texas Christian University and Louisiana Tech University, from which he retired 11 years ago. While teaching at Louisiana Tech, he also earned a Master's Degree in Dramatic Arts and performed in numerous theatrical productions there. Upon his retirement, he moved to Brooklyn and began a second career in retail at the Villeroy and Boch store on Madison Avenue. With an encyclopedic knowledge of historic architecture, interior design, antiques and fine tableware, he rapidly became one of the most successful sales associates, developing a large following among the company's customers. A devotee of the opera, classical music, and theater, he pursued the cultural life of New York with gusto. Mr. Landman was a member of the Empire State Society of the Sons of the American Revolution, the National Association of Watch and Clock Collectors and a benefactor of the National Trust for Historic Preservation. He leaves some cousins and many, many friends. Graveside rites will be conducted on Friday, January 5, at 11:00 A.M. in the Beth-El section of Greenwood Cemetery in Fort Worth. In lieu of flowers, friends may wish to make a donation in Mr. Landman's name to the National Trust for Historic Preservation, 1785 Massachusetts Avenue NW, in Washington, D.C. 20036. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHUFORD, ADRIAN LAFAYETTE JR.
description: SHUFORD-Adrian Lafayette Jr., 90, industrialist and philanthropist, died Saturday. A former NC State senator, county commission chairman and town mayor, his career in the manufacture of socks, gloves, and abrasive equipment spanned most of the 20th century. Shuford, who maintained a residence in Manhattan, was a supporter of the performing arts in New York City. He was married to international concert pianist Dorothy Lewis-Griffith, who survives. A memorial service will be conducted Wednesday at 11 A.M. at Trinity United Church of Christ in Conover. A private interment was held today at Conover City Cemetery. Before his death Shuford had designated that memorials in his honor should be directed to Trinity United Church of Christ, 217 Second Avenue NE, Conover, NC 28613; The YMCA of Catawba Valley, PO Box 280, Conover, N.C. 28613; or Catawba College, 2300 West Innes Street, Salisbury, NC 28144. Shuford became a statewide figure of prominence in North Carolina while serving as a state senator. A life-long Democrat, he was elected to two terms in the Senate in the 1960's. During that period he was chairman of the Committee on Higher Education and helped spearhead the expansion of the University of North Carolina system. On Monday, NC Governor Jim Hunt issued a tribute to Shuford when he learned of his passing: ''I am sad to learn of the death of my friend Adrian Shuford. Senator Shuford was an exceptional leader of North Carolina and a true gentleman. Much of North Carolina's progress today in education and economic development has come because of his leadership in the state Senate. I am grateful for his life and extend my deepest sympathy to his family.'' Shuford served as mayor of Conover and as chairman of the Catawba County (NC) Board of Commissioners. At the time of his death he was trustee emeritus of Catawba College in Salisbury, NC. First elected to the Board of Trustees in 1944, he served as secretary of that board and was its chairman 26 years, from 1951 to 1977. Catawba College honored him with a Doctor of Humanitarian Service degree. In addition, the performing arts center on that campus was named from him and his wife. In his native community Shuford was honored in 1999 by the City of Conover by the establishment of the Adrian L. Shuford Jr. Conover Citizenship Award. He was cited for his contributions toward creation of the municipality's downtown park and town center. Shuford was the instigator of the founding of what is today the YMCA of Catawba Valley. He gave the property that is the site of the Adrian L. Shuford, Jr. YMCA Conover branch, established the endowment fund and was the first president of the YMCA. Educated at Cornell University and UNC-Chapel Hill, he returned to Conover in 1932 to become associated with the textile industry as president of Conover Knitting Mill and secretary of Warlong Glove Company, family businesses. Later he was a director of Riegel Textile Corporation and was a director of the Southern Hosiery Manufacturers Association and chairman of the National Association of Hosiery Manufacturers. While a young man Shuford was associated with Conover's first bank, Citizens Bank. He became president of Shuford National Bank and was a director of First National Bank of Catawba County and First Union. During World War II he was a Navy lieutenant, 1943-45. In 1959 he established Jackson Buff Corporation, which manufactured buffing and abrasive equipment, by buying several buffing equipment businesses around the country and moving them to Conover. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro of Marble Collegiate Church in New York City wrote Mrs. Shuford several weeks ago to inquire about her husband's health and declared: ''I have never met a more gentle, humble or sweeter human being. He is a very dear man, truly a beautiful soul.'' His first wife was the late Dorothy Cilley Shuford, who died in 1984. In addition to his second wife, he is survived by a son, Adrian L. Shuford, III of Newton, NC; a daughter, Dorothy Anna Shuford of Newton, NC; three sisters, Betty S. Yount of Winston-Salem, NC; Mary S. Palmer of Ann Arbor, MI; and Annie S. McBride of Laurinburg, NC and a brother, Dr. Wade Henry Shuford of Atlanta, GA; a stepdaughter, Dorothy Griffith of Banner Elk, NC & two step-grandchildren, Cole and Locke Curtis. Drum Funeral Home and Cremation Service is serving the Shuford family.

description: Le CLERCQ-Tanaquil. She was, above all else, an artist of singular gifts-what Edwin Denby called a ''Heavenly Radiance.'' Peter Martins, the New York City Ballet, and the School of American Ballet, profoundly mourn her passing. Tanny was one of New York City Ballet's first great ballerinas, originating roles in such ballets as George Balanchine's ''The Nutcracker'', ''The Four Temperaments'', and ''Western Symphony'' and Jerome Robbins's ''Afternoon of a Faun'' and ''The Concert''. Balanchine choreographed at least 21 ballets on her, using her poignant wit and brilliant technique to expand his own work. Taney was Balanchine's student, his wife and his trusted friend. She was also a fine portrait photographer, an author and an ardent advocate for Balanchine's choreography, always encouraging companies around the nation and the world to perform his works. She leaves behind a wide audience of admirers who will never forget the magic of her dancing or the daring nature of her spirit. Tanny will be remembered not only for her remarkable gifts, but also for her astounding courage in the face of debilitating illness, her keen intelligence, her beauty and her humor and her exceptional generosity. She was a vibrant and creative woman who will continue to be an inspiration to generations of dancers, as well as to her devoted friends. Peter Martins School of American Ballet New York City Ballet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GELLERT, PETER JOSEPH
description: GELLERT-Peter Joseph. Died on Dec. 23, 2000 from complications resulting from aplastic anemia. Born on August 6, 1926 to Greta (Petschek) Gellert and Oswald R. Gellert in Prague, Czechoslovakia, he attended The Lawrenceville School, Harvard College, and Yale Law School. He served in the US Army during World War II, including a tour in the Pacific theater. For over 40 years, he was a senior executive at United Continental Corporation, managing the affairs of the Gellert & Petschek families. He was an amateur radio enthusiast, using the call sign W2WSS & published a monthly newsletter. He is survived by his wife, Anna (Monser) Gellert; his children, Alexander G. and Anthony E.; his brothers, Martin F., Michael E., and Hubert J.; his sister, Catherine G. Ross; his grandson, Alexander G.; and numerous nephews, nieces, & cousins. A funeral service will be held January 3, 2001 at 2:00PM, The General Theological Seminary, 175 Ninth Ave. between 20th and 21st Streets in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd. In lieu of flowers, contributions should be sent to New York-Presbyterian Hospital (Attention: Dr. E. William Davis, Room F-172, 525 East 68th Street, New York, New York 10021), or to the Harvard College Music Library (C/O Eda Kuhn Loeb Music Library, Harvard University, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02138).

title: Eat Your Vegetables! But Choose Wisely
description: Let's start the real new millennium with some good news: Americans are eating more fruits and vegetables than they did a decade ago. Nearly half now meet the recommendations of the National Cancer Institute, Department of Agriculture and other health agencies to consume at least five servings a day of fruits and vegetables.

description: Cutting tobacco consumption in half may not yield any health benefits, a new Mayo Clinic study suggests.

title: Witch Hunts in Java Called a Cover for Murders
description: In this verdant farm belt of West Java, where sorcery and superstition have deep roots, few were surprised last September when an angry mob decapitated a 70-year-old woman accused of casting spells that made people ill. Before lopping off her head, witnesses said, the crowd gouged out her eyes and severed some of her limbs, which they tossed into the street.

title: Medicare Shift: Doctors' Errors To Be Disclosed
description: Reversing a policy that has kept medical errors secret for more than two decades, federal officials say they will soon allow Medicare beneficiaries to obtain data about doctors who botched their care.

title: Watchful Eyes On a Violent Giant
description: Popocatepetl, Mexico's magnificent and mystical 17,945-foot peak, has been called the world's most dangerous volcano. Nearly 30 million people live within view of it, most of them in Mexico City, 40 miles west, and Puebla, 30 miles east. More than 300,000 people living in the danger zone directly under the volcano regard it as a living thing, a magical man-mountain, a geological god giving rain and rich land. On Dec. 18, when it erupted in what some scientists said was its biggest explosion in a millennium, they came to regard it with a little more fear than awe.

description: Could the reason Americans eat so few health-protective fruits and vegetables be that the very same plant chemicals that are deemed healthful do not taste very good?

description: Twenty-five years ago, Battery Park City was little more than a barren riverside landfill and a dream. Today, its copper-roofed office towers, 25 upscale condominium and apartment buildings and finely manicured riverfront parks have become some of the most valuable real estate in New York City.

title: Testing: Caution on Pap Smears After Menopause
description: After menopause, Pap smears produce so many false alarms that they should not be given routinely every year to healthy women whose results were normal before menopause, an article in The Annals of Internal Medicine suggests.

title: Russia's Health Care Emergency
description: One of the most devastating social consequences of Russia's mismanaged passage to a market economy over the last decade has been the virtual collapse of its health care system. Soviet-era conditions were poor, with long waits, brusque bureaucracy and uneven standards of care. But today's problems are more fundamental. Public hospitals and clinics lack the most basic medicines and equipment and are nearly overwhelmed by an increasingly sick population.

title: Students Pursue One of the Ocean's Slimy Mysteries
description: Not even a mother could love a hagfish. Eyeless, gray-pink and sinuous, hagfish look and writhe like overgrown earthworms. They are known to enter other fish through their mouths or digestive tracts and eat them from the inside out. And when stressed, they exude gobs of transparent slime, which is why they are also known as slime eels, or worse.

title: Front Row; With a little help from weed whacker cord, Zandra Rhodes expands her range. She also learns quite a bit about opera.
description: One day back in the 1980's, two spirited young women out for a day of girl-bonding, wandered into Zandra Rhodes's store off Bond Street in London. As is often the custom among shopping friends unburdened by financial constraints, one bought a little something for the other. The one feeling especially flush that day was Diana, Princess of Wales; the beneficiary of her largesse was the royal family's lesser-known fashionista, Sarah Ferguson. ''It was a flowing dress in black chiffon,'' Ms. Rhodes recalled of the gift. ''It had a red underslip and was printed with the Manhattan skyline.''

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''Some consumers will be able to tell, but you'd be hurt a lot more if you changed the price. Then every consumer would notice.''

title: You Loved Me for My Subsidiary?
description: Rarely has the stock market been as insulting to a company's management as it was for a time this year to the people running 3Com, the technology company perhaps best known for having its name on the stadium where the San Francisco 49ers play. Early in the year, 3Com shares soared on investor enthusiasm for its Palm subsidiary, the leader in the market for hand-held organizers. But after 3Com sold a stake in Palm to the public, 3Com's shares traded as if the whole company were worth less than the value of its remaining stake in Palm, which it later spun out to 3Com shareholders. Palm eventually faded, ending the year at $28.31, 25 percent less than the $38 offering price and far below the $165 reached on its first trading day.

title: Follow the Bouncing Bach
description: The commemoration of the 250th anniversary of Johann Sebastian Bach's death brought many benefits to the concert world during 2000, the last and not least of which was a New Year's Eve in which Bach's sublimely involved counterpoint wrested the spotlight from the vacuous waltzes and polkas of the Strauss family.

description: American consumers lost little last week when the Clinton administration scuttled a drug-import bill passed with much fanfare last year by a Congress facing an election. title: SIPS; A Kick of Ginger to Battle an Image Problem

It's a fruity mixture of equal parts lime juice, triple sec and vodka, often served in little plastic cups at places advertising a happy hour. A friend recently described it as something that ''no self-respecting man would drink in a bar.''

title: NAPSTER IN DISTRIBUTION DEAL
description: Napster gained a new ally from the traditional music industry yesterday as Edel Music, a large independent record label based in Germany, said it would allow its music to be traded through the Internet music-swapping service after Napster implements a new fee-based system. Last October, the Bertelsmann Music Group loaned Napster more than $50 million to develop a service that would allow customers to easily find and acquire music but that, unlike the current service, would also compensate record labels and artists. Bertelsmann promised to make its large music library available over the service and invited other labels, which along with Bertelsmann are suing Napster for copyright infringement, to join. All have so far declined. Amy Harmon

title: Metro Business Briefing; AD COMPANY PLANS CUTBACKS
description: 24/7 Media, a Silicon Alley online advertising company, decided last week to lay off about 100 workers and announced that it had lost its chief financial officer, company officials said yesterday. In a conference call with shareholders and analysts last Thursday, officials cited the slowing online advertising market. In recent months, 24/7 Media, which has its headquarters on Broadway at 31st Street, has laid off 300 workers. In December 1999 filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company said it had 470 employees. The cutbacks are expected to save about $30 million in annual expenses, officials said. 24/7 Media's chief executive, David Moore, said it would consider selling off units to raise money. He also announced that the company's chief financial officer, Andrew Johns, would be leaving to spend more time with his family. Jayson Blair

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BIRNBERG, MONROE (MONTE)
description: BIRNBERG - Monroe (Monte). Ageless-dearly beloved soul mate of Ann Andersen-Birnberg, father to Jeffrey, Vicki, Jill and Jackie; grandfather to Spencer, Erika, Samantha, Michael, Ashley and Jonathan; great-grandfather to Julian and Jonah departed this life on December 30, 2000 after a three month illness with cancer. Monte was a graduate of New York University who served in the Marine Corp in WW II making the landing in Okinawa to retire as a full Major. In 1961 he founded Great Atlantic Insurance Co acting as both CEO and President. He ran four major companies for Frank B. Hall. Monte who traveled extensively around the world in his business was also well respected by Lloyd's Syndicate in London. While one of the most prestigious figures in the insurance industry Monte found time to lecture on insurance at Princeton University as well as being an adjunct professor at The College of Insurance in New York City. When he and his wife Ann moved to Miami Monte was still involved in the insurance field and at the time of his passing was President of the United States Underwriters in Bay Harbor. Monte was a true Renaissance man who wrote inspired children's stories and was in the process of writing an as yet unfinished novel at the time of his death to be completed by his adored wife Ann. There will be a memorial service in New York City to be announced at a later date. If you wish to offer a donation Monte's expressed wish was that you give to his beloved Florida Philharmonic Orchestra to be sent to the attention of: Mrs. Ann Andersen-Birnberg (The Florida Phiharmonic Orchestra) 12000 North Bayshore Drive #

title: SITESTAR WITHDRAWS FASHIONMALL.COM BID
description: Sitestar, an Internet holding company, said yesterday that it had withdrawn its $23.6 million cash offer to acquire Fashionmall.com. Sitestar said in October that it would pay $3 in cash for each of Fashionmall's 7.5 million outstanding shares, a 39 percent premium at the time. Last week, however, Fashionmall's stock jumped more than 49 percent over two days to $4.12 after two rival bidders, Narex and GenesisIntermedia.com, made back-to-back offers for Fashionmall. Narax offered $3.50 a share, or about $26.2 million, and GenesisIntermedia offered cash and stock worth about $52.5 million. A connection between key executives at Sitestar and Narax raised questions on the part of securities regulators. Frederick T. Manlunas, chairman of Sitestar, until last year served as a director of a separate company run by Michael M. Savage, president of Narax. In a statement, Clinton J. WebMD, which links doctors, patients and health insurers on the Internet, will cancel plans to issue 8.3 million shares to the News Corporation. WebMD is scaling back its consumer-health Web site to focus on providing software and electronic processing of health insurance claims.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LE CLERCQ, TANAQUIL
description: Le CLERCQ-Tanaquil. She was, above all else, an artist of singular gifts-what Edwin Denby called a ''Heavenly Radiance.'' Peter Martins, the New York City Ballet, and the School of American Ballet, profoundly mourn her passing. Tanny was one of New York City Ballet's first great ballerinas, originating roles in such ballets as George Balanchine's ''The Nutcracker'', ''The Four Temperaments'', and ''Western Symphony'' and Jerome Robbins's ''Afternoon of a Faun'' and ''The Concert''. Balanchine choreographed at least 21 ballets on her, using her poignant wit and brilliant technique to expand his own work. Taney was Balanchine's student, his wife and his trusted friend. She was also a fine portrait photographer, an author and an ardent advocate for Balanchine's choreography, always encouraging companies around the nation and the world to perform his works. She leaves behind a wide audience of admirers who will never forget the magic of her dancing or the daring nature of her spirit. Tanny will be remembered not only for her remarkable gifts, but also for her astounding courage in the face of debilitating illness, her keen intelligence, her beauty and her humor and her exceptional generosity. She was a vibrant and creative woman who will continue to be an inspiration to generations of dancers, as well as to her devoted friends. Peter Martins School of American Ballet New York City Ballet

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUSTERMAN, CHARLES
description: SCHUSTERMAN-Charles. The Officers, Board of Trustees, and staff of United Jewish Communities mourn the passing of Charles Schusterman, whose lifelong involvement in philanthropy on so many fronts touched countless lives the world over. A true visionary, Charles' leadership was evident in funding a broad range of programs that enchanced Jewish life in the United States, Isarel and the former Soviet Union. His dedication to Jewish renaissance and renewal, especially among Jewish youth, has benefited many through the Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation, whose generous giving helped establish the first Hillel in the FSU. Charles also served with great distinction as co-chair of Hillel International Board of Governors, a member of the JDC Board of Trustees, member of the Board of Governors for Technion, and much more. As a founding partner of STAR, Synagogue Transformation and Renewal, Charles pursued his passionate commitment to the revitalization of the synagogue community in North America to stem assimilation and attrition. Honored in his community of Tulsa and the State of Oklahoma as an outstanding philanthropist, Charles championed numerous institutions and causes. Among them were the University of Oklahoma, the Parent Child Center, Planned Parenthood, and Anytown USA, a week-long residential program for high school students from throughout the state that enhances leadership development and human relations skills. Charles was also a man of extraordinary bravery and inspiration, whose positive attitude allowed him to thrive in his tireless commitment to Jewish faith, culture and family. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Lynn, and the Schusterman family. Charles R. Bronfman, Chairman of the Board Joel D. Tauber, Chairman, Executive Committee Stephen D. Solender, President and CEO

Last night, Tennessee and Rutgers, two of the better teams in women's college basketball, bumped and bumped at Madison Square Garden in a game that was sloppy, ugly and, not surprisingly, a 58-51 victory for Tennessee.

title: Dick Cheney, the 101st Senator
description: With the 50-50 split in the Senate making Dick Cheney, as tie breaker, effectively the 101st senator, some observers are asking whether he will be so tied down on Capitol Hill that he won't have enough time to participate in the new administration as an active vice president. A different question, however, may be more important: Are we about to see a blurring of our traditional separation of executive and legislative powers?

title: THREE SOFTWARE MAKERS ANNOUNCE LAYOFFS TO CUT COSTS
description: Three software companies separately announced layoffs on the first business day of the new year, all to cut costs at a time when sales are slowing. Pegasystems Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., which makes customer-service software, said it would eliminate 75 jobs, or 13 percent of its work force, and take a charge of $1 million, or 3 cents a share, in the fourth quarter of 2000. Viador Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., which makes software for creating corporate Web sites, said it would eliminate 87 jobs, or 36 percent of its work force, and take a $500,000 charge, also in the fourth quarter. CommTouch Software Ltd., an Israeli maker of Web-based messaging software, said it would shut its electronic- commerce and small-business e-mail services units, and that it expected to reduce its work force by one-fifth in 2001.

title: KOREAN BANK DEAL FIZZLES
description: The Hana Bank said it had ended merger talks with the KorAm Bank because KorAm shareholders were too slow to respond to its proposal. Analysts speculated that KorAm, 40 percent owned by a group that includes J. P. Morgan Corsair, Prudential Asset Management and the Carlyle Group, might have balked over bad loans on Hana's books; KorAm declined comment. Both banks now need new partners as the government pushes its struggling banking sector to consolidate.

title: The 107th Congress
description: While President-elect George W. Bush was in Austin settling on his cabinet, a new Congress arrived at Capitol Hill yesterday to prepare for something that few in Washington have ever experienced. Republicans will control the White House, the Senate and the House for the first time in nearly a half-century. But they should know that any Republican attempt to muscle through a hard conservative agenda would lead to two more years of acrimony and paralysis. To govern across party lines, Mr. Bush and his Republican allies need to begin this week with new Senate rules establishing fairness to the Democrats and priority for bills on education and other issues with bipartisan support.

title: MAKER OF SPORTING GOODS WILL SELL ITS BICYCLE BUSINESS
description: Brunswick, a maker of sporting goods and fitness equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its bicycle unit to Pacific Cycle L.L.C. for $60 million. Brunswick sold the unit, which includes the Mongoose, Mongoose Pro and Roadmaster brands, for $48.5 million cash and $11.5 million in notes. Pacific Cycle is based in Madison, Wis. Brunswick, based in Lake Forest, Ill., said the company would focus on marine engines, boats, fitness equipment, bowling and billiards.

title: BRIDGESTONE RECALLS SMALL BATCH OF SPORT UTILITY TIRES
description: The Bridgestone Corporation, whose Bridgestone/Firestone unit has been plagued by failures and recalls of millions of tires for sport utility vehicles, said yesterday that it had voluntarily begun a recall of yet another small batch of similar tires. The company is calling back about 8,000 P265/70R16 Wilderness LE tires made at its Cuernavaca, Mexico, plant during the week of April 23, because about 150 of them might have the wrong kind of rubber in and around one of their steel belts, making it possible that the tire would come apart at that point. The tires were installed on GMC Yukon XL 1500 and Chevrolet Suburban 1500 vehicles built in Mexico.

title: FORD WILL INCLUDE TIRES IN WARRANTY COVERAGE

The move ends a century-old arrangement under which tire makers took responsibility for tire warranties. General Motors began covering tires under its warranties in 1996.

title: APPLE CUTS COMPUTER PRICES
description: Apple Computer cut prices up to $1,000 on its desktop and portable computers yesterday. The company made the changes quietly, by posting the lowered prices on its Web sites with no public announcement. A spokeswoman said the company was currently in a quiet period and would have no comment. The company said last month that it was planning to make a series of moves to reduce inventory, and a person close to the company said recently that Apple was hoping to reduce its inventory drastically to put its business problems behind it quickly. The company reduced the price of its entry-level G4 tower computer by $300 to $1,299, while the price of its G4 Cube computer, which has met disappointing demand, was lowered to $1,499 from $1,799. Apple's retailers said it had also reduced prices on portable systems, and its G3 Portable now sells for as little as $2,199. Prices were not lowered in either the iMac desktop or iBook portable systems. Apple is expected to introduce new computers at its annual Macworld event next week in San Francisco and several weeks later in Tokyo. John Markoff

title: TELMEX AGREES TO DEAL THAT WOULD FOSTER COMPETITION
description: Telefonos de Mexico, Mexico's dominant phone company, signed an agreement yesterday with two long-distance rivals to allow more competition in Mexico's $12 billion telecommunications market. In the agreement with Alestra, 49 percent owned by AT&T, and Avantel, partly owned by WorldCom Inc., Telmex agreed to charge competitors 1.25 cents a minute for access to its network for long-distance calls. Mexico's regulators had established that rate last October, but Telmex had appealed the decision. Yesterday's agreement follows a move by the United States trade representative to bring Mexico before a World Trade Organization panel for doing too little to foster fair competition. Graham Gori

title: Bitter Cycle Of Love And Loathing Interrupted
description: The 1991 Australian film ''Proof'' begins with a series of photographs that are sensual shards, pictures that reveal only pieces of a world and convey a desperation that the rest of the film sets out to explore with economy, intelligence and humor. The inventive and extraordinarily satisfying feature-film debut of the writer and director Jocelyn Moorhouse is so good that it provokes a question: Whatever happened to her? Her career trajectory in the years that followed seems to prove that the American mainstream movie establishment has no place for a woman capable of such beguiling and spare work.

description: LEVY-Steven J. Passed away suddenly at his home on December 31, 2000. He was 34 years old. He is survived by his parents Herb and Ina Levy, his brothers Jeffrey and Aaron Levy, and his sister Debra Bank. For further information, please call Hellman Memorial Chapels, 845-356-8600.

title: MANAGEMENT: THE BOSS; Dirty Nails 80 Hours a Week
description: Since I knew nothing about securities, I decided to go into the stock brokerage business. At age 23, I went to Minneapolis, the first stop for anyone trying to get out of North Dakota, and I interviewed with everyone: Merrill Lynch, PaineWebber, Dean Witter. I got a job at PaineWebber.

title: Sips: A Kick of Ginger to Battle an Image Problem
description: AS a drink, a kamikaze does not have a very heroic profile. It's a fruity mixture of equal parts lime juice, triple sec and vodka, often served in little plastic cups at places advertising a happy hour. A friend recently described it as something that "no self-respecting man would drink in a bar."

title: Arafat Accepts Peace Plan, But Violence Erodes Hope
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 - The White House said today that it was moving forward with President Clinton's Middle East peace plan after accepting the word of the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, that he would abide by the proposals as a basis for further talks.

title: When an Illness Afflicts the Brain
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Shortages Become a Worry At Hospitals Around the Country
description: Doctors, pharmacists and federal regulators are increasingly concerned about what they say is a growing number of drug shortages, particularly at hospitals. Where a few years ago a hospital might experience a shortage of one or two critical drugs a year, the number in the last year has been closer to two dozen at some hospitals, doctors and pharmacists say.

title: Palestinians Outline Objections to Clinton Peace Plan
description: The Palestinians have issued their first detailed public reaction to President Clinton's peace proposals, concluding that the plan neglects the Palestinian need for a viable state and the rights of refugees.

title: Yahoo to Try Harder to Rid Postings of Hateful Material
description: After months of pressure from human rights groups like the Simon Wiesenthal Center, Yahoo said yesterday that it would try more actively to keep hateful and violent material out of its auctions, classified sections and shopping areas.

title: Four Days in the Bahamas
description: The 700-room Radisson Cable Beach Resort in Nassau, the Bahamas, has a four-night package that includes air fare from New York starting at $799 a person, based on double occupancy, if booked by Jan. 31 through a Liberty Travel branch. Travel may be any time through Feb. 13. The prices include all meals, drinks, greens fees on the resort's course, nonmotorized water sports, bike tours, tennis and nightly entertainment. Taxes, tips and airport transfers are also included. Rates are for midweek departures; book with an American Express card by Jan. 12 and an extra $150 per couple will be deducted. Information: (888) 271-1586 or www.libertytravel.com .

title: Labeling Foods With Designer Genes
description: MUCH of the processed food in this country contains genetically engineered ingredients. And while surveys show that many Americans would like to decide for themselves whether they want to consume altered foods, they can't, because the federal government does not think such labeling is necessary.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JAMES, NORA
description: JAMES-Nora. Of Georgetown, Guyana who resided in Dunedin, FL. and Stamford, CT, formerly of Brooklyn, NY passed away on December 31, 2000. Nora is survived by her loving daughter Juanita James, grandson Dudley Williams III, son-in-law Dudley Williams Jr. two sisters Lucille and Norma, two brothers, Dennis and Frederick and many nieces, nephews, great nieces, and great nephews. For information White Memorial Chapels, 519 Clinton Ave, Brooklyn, NY 718-783-3737. Homegoing service Thursday January 4, 2001 6-8PM. Funeral service Friday January 5, 2001, 11 AM at the Church of St. Luke and St. Matthew, 520 Clinton Ave., Brooklyn, NY. Memorial service Saturday January 13, 2001 at 11AM at First Presbyterian Church, 1101 Bedford St, Stamford, CT., 203-324-9522.

title: 4 Will Be Inducted Into Hall of Fame
description: The American Advertising Federation in Washington has selected four executives to be inducted into the Advertising Hall of Fame in 2001.

title: Continuing Investor Worries Keep Stocks Sliding in 2001
description: Stocks began 2001 the way they finished 2000 -- plunging -- as investors continued to worry about the impact of slowing economic growth on corporate profits.

title: Ray Walston, Broadway Star And TV Martian, Dies at 86
description: Ray Walston, who won a Tony Award for playing the Devil opposite Gwen Verdon in the Broadway musical ''Damn Yankees,'' repeated his role in the film version and went on to a long career playing eccentric, oddly endearing characters in movies and on television, died on Monday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 86.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RAMIREZ, JUDGE GILBERT
description: RAMIREZ-Judge Gilbert. The family of Judge Gilbert Ramirez, retired State Supreme Court Justice, husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend sadly announces his passing on December 23, 2000. He died in Aventura, FL of complications from Alzheimer's and non-Hodgkins Lymphoma.

title: Will Congressional Web Learning Report Gather Momentum or Only Gather Dust?
description: Capitol Hill insiders and educational analysts are hopeful that several of the key recommendations made in a Congressional panel's report on web-based learning will be acted upon this year.

title: Corrections
description: The Antiques column in Weekend on Friday, about White House decor, misstated the given name of the first Union officer killed in the Civil War, whose body lay in state in the East Room. He was Elmer Ellsworth, not Ephraim.

title: On the Run to the Halls of Boardroom Power
description: IT was nearly noon on a wintry day, the Midtown traffic was snarled, and Kathryn S. Wylde was running a few minutes late for a meeting involving the financier Henry R. Kravis. Ms. Wylde, however, had recently been named the chief executive of an organization of 200 chief executives, and she did not get the job by keeping powerful men like Mr. Kravis waiting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GAYNES, MIRIAM
description: GAYNES-Miriam. On January 1, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Seymour. Devoted mother of Paul and the late Steffi. Dear sister and sister-in-law of Joyce and Arnold, and the late Haskell. Adored grandmother of Seth and Taylor. Loving aunt of David, Karyn and Mark, Julie and Michael, and great aunt of Sophia. She will be greatly missed by her extended family as well-Janis and Jeff, Donna, Rita, and her wonderful family of friends. Services on Wednesday, January 3, 12:30 PM, at Riverside Nassau North, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck.

title: The long-suffering and lonely Maytag repairman will get a new look and a new mission in 2001.
description: THE ''lonely'' Maytag repairman, who has become one of the best-known characters in advertising since his introduction in 1967, is being recast and rethought for a new generation of consumers. For one thing, he will stop hanging around that empty office.

title: Metro Business Briefing; GRAND UNION PENSIONS COVERED
description: About 500 employees of the bankrupt Grand Union supermarket chain in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut will go on receiving their pensions despite a shortfall in the company's pension fund, the company and the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation said yesterday. Most of the chain's 17,000 nationwide employees receive pensions through unions, said Gary Duncan, a Grand Union spokesman. But, he said, about 225 store managers and assistants in the metropolitan area, plus 275 workers at Grand Union's headquarters in Wayne, N.J., are covered by a company-financed fund that now has assets of just $183 million to cover benefits worth an estimated $205 million. The P.B.G.C., a federal corporation, will cover the rest, said its spokesman, Gary Pastorius. Steve Strunsky

title: INTEL OFFERS AUDIO PLAYER
description: Intel introduced a digital-audio player and said it would show off two wireless computing systems at a trade show this week, strengthening its line of consumer gadgets. The pocket-size player, which begins selling next month for $299, runs on two AA batteries and holds four hours of music, said John Middleton, marketing manager for the project. The chip maker has added a line of digital cameras, home-networking devices, toys and PC peripherals.

description: To the Editor:

title: Tax-Law Shift Gives Investors Tricky Choice On Asset Sales
description: This is the year when the government thinks many investors will decide to voluntarily pay taxes that they do not owe.

title: EXPECTATIONS LOW AS CLINTON PUSHES PLAN WITH ARAFAT
description: President Clinton met at the White House with Yasir Arafat this afternoon and again this evening to explore ways of overcoming the Palestinian leader's objections to the president's down-to-the-wire proposals for a Middle East peace deal.

title: City Move Against Lofts Is Aborted
description: Two weeks after promising a moratorium on forcing tenants out of illegally converted loft apartments, the city made an abortive attempt yesterday to evacuate about a dozen tenants from their lofts onto the freezing sidewalks of the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, officials and residents said.

title: Warren Rediscovers Freedom In the Philadelphia Backfield
description: As first impressions go, this was not one that Chris Warren wanted to make. Plucked from the discard heap in Dallas in early December, polished, sanded and given a new coat of paint by the Philadelphia Eagles, Warren got his chance on Christmas Eve, only to fumble twice against the Cincinnati Bengals. If Buddy Ryan had still been the head coach here instead of Andy Reid, Warren would undoubtedly have been ripped and tossed away like gift wrapping on Christmas Day.

title: Accounts
description: * Turnstylz, New York, a new company marketing plus-sized apparel for teenagers, to Strategics Advertising, Westbury, N.Y., and an interactive affiliate, Invisible.Ink, Westbury, to handle its first account. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

title: 'Bull' in the Bank
description: TNT, the cable network, had been planning to begin the second season of ''Bull,'' its first original dramatic series, this month. But with the looming threat of writers' and actors' strikes, executives at TNT said they had decided to postpone ''Bull,'' the story of Wall Street traders that made its debut last summer, at least until after the broadcast television season ends in May.

title: Stalwart Hero vs. Devious Europeans
description: More than a decade after his 1877 novel, ''The American,'' appeared, Henry James decided to make his reputation as a playwright and adapted that book for the stage. Turning to drama was so bald an attempt to gain money and fame that he even added a crowd-pleasing happy ending. Yet the play struggled, and closed after a merely respectable 70-night London run.

title: Getting Homework Checked (and Teeth, as Well)
description: New York City schools now offer so many services that on a typical morning at Intermediate School 143 in Washington Heights, Wilbin Heredia, 11, might be studying math in Room 229 or having his teeth checked in Room 114.

title: Corrections
description: A note in Weekend on Friday with a review of ''The Fine Art of Letters: The Work of Hermann Zapf,'' at the Grolier Club in Manhattan through Feb. 10, misstated the address. The club is at 47 East 60th Street, not West.

title: New Liaison For Chicken
description: CHICKEN with dried apricots is hardly a new idea, but I had issues with its most common interpretations. For one thing, they were almost always cloying; the routine addition of cinnamon and cloves does nothing to offset the apricots' sweetness and makes the dish taste more like dessert than dinner. For another, they were usually stewed rather than braised, turning the chicken skin sodden. This is a shame, as most such preparations begin with careful browning.

title: People
description: * Mark Gault, executive vice president and director for worldwide accounts at McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising, New York, was named regional director at McCann-Erickson North America, succeeding Tony Miller, who was named to the new post of vice chairman at a sibling, World Group Marketing Communications. McCann-Erickson is part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies.

title: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: NEWS ANALYSIS; Conservative at the Core
description: With the completion of his cabinet selections today, President-elect George W. Bush has put forward a governing team every bit as ethnically and racially diverse as President Clinton's. At the same time, he has chosen for the most critical domestic policy posts figures who are acceptable to his party's conservative wing.

title: Lewis Wins Defense Award
description: Baltimore Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis was named the National Football League's defensive player of the year yesterday after helping his team hold opponents to 165 points, the fewest in N.F.L. history for a 16-game regular season. Lewis, 25, had a team-high 187 tackles, with 3 sacks and 2 interceptions while starting all 16 games. The 6-foot-1-inch 245-pounder helped the Ravens end the regular season with seven straight victories for a 12-4 record, one game behind first-place Tennessee in the American Football Conference Central.

title: After Rout Of Irish, One Goal For Beavers
description: The Oregon State defender Eric Manning popped through Notre Dame's boxy front line with the slippery speed of a soap bar as he flattened the grass with a tackle of running back Terrance Howard for a 2-yard loss.

title: British Regulators Overturn Interbrew Acquisition of Bass
description: LONDON, Jan. 3 - In a decision that will probably curtail the expansion plans of Interbrew S.A. and cost it hundreds of millions of dollars, British regulators overturned the company's $3.5 billion acquisition of Bass Brewers today.

title: William Pierce Rogers, Former Secretary of State, Dies at 87
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3  William P. Rogers, a suave and well-connected Republican lawyer who was secretary of state in the White House of President Richard M. Nixon and attorney general in the Eisenhower administration, died on Tuesday at a hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 87.

description: Fires Tied to Anti-Sprawl Fight

title: Ruling on Rates Of Auto Insuers
description: A California appeals court has upheld the right of auto insurers to use customers' post office ZIP codes to set rates, saying that where a motorist lives is the most important factor in determining risk.

title: The Strange Double Life of Chenin Blanc
description: THE Rodney Dangerfield of grapes, at least in this country, is chenin blanc -- it gets no respect. What's more, its name is redundant; all chenin is blanc. Would anyone ever speak of cabernet sauvignon rouge?

title: LOW BOWL RATINGS
description: The first two Bowl Championship Series games, played New Year's Day, posted lower television ratings than last year.

description: WHEN Naoko Takahashi flew to a record-breaking victory in the women's Olympic marathon in Sydney, Australia, last September, she had the power of tiny wings working for her.

description: The Devils are doing well against just about every team in the National Hockey League this season.

description: EARLY-Ruth. Passed away at Woodhull Hospital in Brooklyn, New York on December 25, 2000 after an extended illness. She is survived by her godson Jerry Thompkins and many friends and associates at Harlem Hospital where she worked for many years as a Registered Nurse.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RUBIN, HELEN
description: RUBIN-Helen. Park East Synagogue mourns the passing of our devoted member Helen Rubin, beloved wife of Harold Rubin, of blessed memory. Deepest sympathy to her son Michael, our dedicated member, and her daughter Bayla, and their families. Rabbi Arthur Schneier Michael Scharf, President Jerry Forst, Vice President Jack Rosen, Vice President

title: Sports of The Times; Carthon Deserves A Chance
description: SOMETIMES, a guy's got an instinct, a feel for something, a strong notion, say, that that restaurant with two letters out in the neon sign will serve a great pesto with the pasta, or the exact moment to whisper a sweet nothing, or if now is the time to try to usurp the throne or just let sleeping dogs lie.

description: To the Editor:

title: Stock Market Slump Carries Over Into '01
description: Stocks began 2001 the way they finished 2000 -- falling, as investors continued to worry about the effect of slowing economic growth on profits. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 7.2 percent yesterday, its worst percentage decline since April 14 last year and the seventh worst daily percentage drop in history. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.3 percent, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slumped 2.8 percent.

title: Tennessee's Suggs To Join Georgia Tech
description: A.J. Suggs, a freshman quarterback at Tennessee, will transfer to Georgia Tech this semester, Volunteers Coach Phillip Fulmer said.

title: BANKING CONSOLIDATION IN MALAYSIA
description: Fifty of Malaysia's 54 financial institutions complied with a government-imposed year-end deadline to combine into just 10 banks. The largest, however, Malayan Banking, was among the four that missed the deadline. Malayan was given an extra three weeks to finish taking over the PhileoAllied Bank, owned by a company linked to Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad's son; another merger of two banks collapsed. The delays led to a steep sell-off in Malaysian stocks. Wayne Arnold

title: Last Decker Leaves Power Tool Company
description: For the first time in its 90 years, the Black & Decker Corporation is without a Decker. Alonzo G. Decker Jr., son of the co-founder, former chairman and chief executive, and a company director for 60 years, retired at the end of 2000, the company said.

title: THE 43rd PRESIDENT: Woman in the News; Linda Chavez
description: Once a liberal Democrat who worked for the American Federation of Teachers, Linda Chavez, President-elect George W. Bush's pick as labor secretary, is now a staunch conservative who supports school vouchers.

title: Broad Field, No Standout in Grammy Nominations
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 3  The 43rd annual Grammy Award nominations, announced here today at the Beverly Hilton, lacked one outstanding trait of the previous two years' Grammys: a clear front-runner. Lauryn Hill swept up 10 Grammy Award nominations in 1999 and Santana returned with a vengeance last year, also with 10 nominations; the top nominees this year are the rapper and producer Dr. Dre and Beyonce Knowles of the harmonizing female R&B group Destiny's Child, who each got five.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GERSON, DORA JOELSON, MD.
description: GERSON-Dora Joelson, MD. Practiced medicine for many years in Paterson, NJ. Widow of Stanley Gerson, MD. Mother of Bernita & Ben. Funeral Thursday, 12:30 PM, Schoem Funeral Home, Route 4, Paramus, New Jersey.

title: Little Screen, Big Ambition; Serious Films by Cable Networks Fill a Void Left by Hollywood
description: Mike Nichols is directing Emma Thompson in the film adaptation of the 1999 Pulitzer Prize-winning drama ''Wit.'' Another filmmaker, Norman Jewison, is directing ''Dinner With Friends,'' the comedy-drama that won a Pulitzer last year. An adaptation of F. Scott Fitzgerald's ''Great Gatsby'' is set to be shown this month, and Neil Simon's autobiographical comedy ''Laughter on the 23rd Floor,'' about writers in the golden age of television, will be revived on the screen later this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TUMELTY, JOSEPH P.
description: TUMELTY-Joseph P. The Alumni Association of Columbia University's Mailman School of Public Health mourns the untimely passing of a loyal alumnus of the College of Pharmaceutical Sciences, Joe Tumelty '70. Through his untiring efforts, a new entity was formed: The Alumni Association of the Mailman School of Public Health and the College of Pharmaceutical Sciences for which we are deeply indebted. We will miss having benefit of his leadership and we extend to his family and friends our heartfelt condolences. Allan Rosenfield, MD, Dean James T. Harden '83, Chair Board of Advisors LaVerne Mooney DrPH, '94 Pres. Alumni Association Howard L. Nadel 'CPPS '74, Vice President

title: Metro Business Briefing; LAYOFFS AT SPACE.COM
description: Space.com, the Silicon Alley multimedia company founded by Lou Dobbs, the former CNNfn president, and once headed by the first American woman in space, Sally Ride, said it was laying off employees. Company officials declined to say how many employees were being laid off, but an executive close to the company said that at least 12 would be laid off. The layoffs were first reported in yesterday's Silicon Alley Daily and New York Post. Space.com, which has partnerships with the Gannett Company, said the layoffs were intended to eliminate duplication caused by the recent acquisition of the Space News newspaper, spacenews.com and Florida Today's Space Online Web site. In September, Space.com laid off 22 of its 108 employees in a restructuring. Jayson Blair

title: FEDERAL RESERVE, REACTING TO SIGNALS OF A SLOWDOWN, CUTS KEY RATE HALF A POINT
description: Confronted with increased evidence that the economy is stalling, the Federal Reserve slashed its benchmark interest rate by half a percentage point yesterday, stunning investors and sending a powerful signal that the Fed is worried about the prospects for keeping the decade-long expansion alive.

title: Negotiating Against the Clock
description: Israel and the Palestinians have now both conditionally accepted President Clinton's Mideast peace proposals as a basis for further negotiations. But Yasir Arafat's acceptance yesterday appeared so strewn with reservations that reaching a final compromise in the next two and a half weeks may prove beyond reach.

title: NORTHPOINT COMMUNICATIONS IN TROUBLE, LAWYER SAYS
description: The NorthPoint Communications Group is on the ''brink of disaster'' because Verizon Communications abruptly called off a November agreement to acquire it, a NorthPoint lawyer told a California state court yesterday. The lawyer, Douglas Sullivan, urged a state judge in San Francisco to let NorthPoint proceed with a lawsuit that seeks more than $1 billion in damages from Verizon, or a court order that the merger be completed. NorthPoint, which provides high-speed Internet connections, has laid off about 19 percent of its work force since Verizon pulled out of the agreement on nine minutes' notice, Mr. Sullivan said. NorthPoint's stock, which peaked at $33.38 last year, rose 5 cents yesterday to close at 42 cents a share.

title: Taking Care; Another Reason To Sit Up Straight
description: ACCORDING to Dr. Alan Hedge and other ergonomics researchers at Cornell University, children need to adhere to the same ergonomic rules as adults. The angle formed by the back and thighs should be greater than 90 degrees, as should the angle formed by the shoulder, elbow, and wrist and the angle formed by the hips, knees and feet.

title: A Wait Pays Off At Merrill
description: In a matter of minutes yesterday, hundreds of stockbrokers at Merrill Lynch & Company swung from complaining about the firm's administrators to thanking them and Alan Greenspan for a timing difference that could be worth $40 million.

title: These Are the Faces of the Bush Team
description: To the Editor:

title: Economic Scene; Now is the time to reform unemployment insurance -- before it's really needed.
description: THE unemployment insurance program was neglected during the steady stream of good economic news in the 1990's. States usually add to their unemployment insurance trust funds in prosperous times, so they can draw them down in weak times. Perhaps believing the good times would never end, however, many states have failed to replenish their unemployment insurance funds or make other fundamental changes that would strengthen the system.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LE CLERCQ, TANAQUIL
description: LE CLERCQ-Tanaquil. Services at Church of Saint Ignatius of Antioch, 552 West End Ave, entrance on 87th Street, Friday January 5, 2001, at 10 A.M. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Meals On Wheels or other charity.

title: A Sony Mouse That Can Read Memory Sticks: One Fewer Cord
description: With so many peripheral devices available for computers these days, the back of the machine may resemble a snarl of spaghetti, with all the entwined cables snaking from the ports. Perhaps with a nod to cord congestion, Sony recently introduced an optical mouse with a built-in card reader that will cut down on at least one cord for users who need to copy data between the computer and Sony's Memory Stick data-storage cards.

title: Giving Few Details, the Governor Nevertheless Creates a Stir
description: Barely 10 minutes into a 68-minute speech, Gov. George E. Pataki stepped into dangerous political territory today, pledging to simplify the way the state gives most of its roughly $13 billion a year in aid to local schools.

description: Contestant Needs Higher Authority

title: Singapore Delays License Sale For New Cellular Networks
description: Singapore said today that it would delay an auction of licenses to operate cellular-phone networks capable of high-speed Internet access. Analysts said the move reflected mounting concern in the wireless telecommunications industry about the cost of moving to its so-called third generation of services.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  NELSON, PETER DOWD
description: NELSON-Peter Dowd. On January 2, 2001. Beloved and best friend of Bette. Loving and devoted father of Michael. Father-in-law of Jennifer. Adoring grandfather of Jake and Katharine. Close brother of Robert and John and sisters-inlaw Lyntha and Eileen. Commercial real estate broker, executive director at Cushman & Wakefield for over 39 years. Active member of the Board of the Greater New York Councils Boy Scouts of America with over 25 years of service. He was a friend to all who met him; a gentle and caring man. He will be profoundly missed. Memorial service on January 8th at 11 AM, Middle Collegiate Church, 50 East 7th Street, NYC.

title: INDUSTRIAL GAS DEAL IN GERMANY
description: Allianz, Germany's biggest insurer, and the Goldman Sachs Group will buy Aventis's 67 percent stake in a German industrial gas company, Messer Griesheim G.m.b.H., for 1.6 billion euros ($1.5 billion) in cash and assumed debt, Bloomberg News reported, citing unnamed sources. The deal signals that Paul Achleitner, Allianz's finance chief and a former Goldman executive, has begun using proceeds from the sale of holdings in Munich Re and Siemens A.G. for new acquisitions.

title: Martin Makes a Suggestion, And Maybe Comes of Age
description: Kenyon Martin was tired of hanging back like an outsider waiting for his rookie season to happen. This was not the way he did it at the University of Cincinnati, back in his glory days.

title: Domestic Worker's Suit Seeks Pay From Ex-United Nations Official
description: A recently retired United Nations official from Zambia who is an adjunct professor at Columbia University is being sued by a man he employed as a domestic worker who says he was paid less than one-eighth the minimum wage.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBSON, ETHEL
description: JACOBSON-Ethel. Devoted wife and homemaker, died January 3 in New York City. She is survived by three daughters Shelby Greene-Zarlin of New City, NY; Diane Mota of Trumbull, CT., and Marlee-Jo Jacobson of New York City, four grandchildren and two sisters. Graveside services will be Friday, January 5, at Beth Hillel Cemetery, Walden, NY at 11 AM.

title: New Bias Lawsuit Is Filed Against Microsoft
description: Seven former and current employees of the Microsoft Corporation filed a lawsuit today contending that the company had engaged in racial discrimination in its employment practices, and seeking certification as a class action on behalf of all former and current black Microsoft employees.

title: ETOYS SHUTTING BRITISH UNIT
description: EToys, the beleaguered online retailer, said that it would shut its operations in Britain, its only foreign outpost. The site is selling off its inventory at deep markdowns and will close entirely on Jan. 19. All 74 employees will be let go. The move, analysts said, reflects an effort to preserve the company's dwindling supply of cash. EToys never broke out the sales of the British unit, but analysts said they were small. Last month, eToys said its sales in the fourth quarter would be $120 million to $130 million, about half of what it had previously expected. It further said that it had only enough cash on hand to stay in operation through March 31 and that it expected to lay off some employees. EToys has hired Goldman, Sachs to find it more money or to help sell the company. Earlier this year, in fact, EToys tried to find a partner for the operation in Britain, but none emerged. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZARKIN, CHERYL LINDA (NEE LEVINE)
description: ZARKIN-Cheryl Linda (nee Levine), 54, of New Rochelle, NY, died suddenly Monday, January 1. Beloved wife to Norman. Adored mother of Douglas and Seth. Devoted sister to Jacqueline Levine of Swampscott, MA, Alan Levine of Newton, MA., & Howard Levine of Stamford, CT. Services will be held Thursday January 4, 12noon at Westchester Reform Temple, Scarsdale, New York. Interment will follow immediately at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, New York. Donations in her memory may be made to the American Heart Association.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  INSALL, JOHN, M.D.
description: INSALL-John, M.D. The Board of Trustees, Medical Staff and Administration of the Hospital for Special Surgery mourn with profound sorrow the death of John Insall, M.D. As a former member of the Attending Staff at HSS, he provided the very finest in orthopedic care. Renowned for his groundbreaking work in total knee replacement, Dr. Insall was greatly admired as a teacher to young orthopedic surgeons and for his contributions to orthopedic medicine. He will be greatly missed and remembered always. We extend our prayerful condolences to his wife Mary and their family. Richard L. Menschel, Chairman Aldo Papone, Co-Chairman Board of Trustees John R. Reynolds President and CEO Russell F. Warren, MD, Surgeon-in-Chief Stephen A. Paget, MD, Physician-in-Chief Philip D. Wilson, Jr., MD, Surgeon-in-Chief Emeritus

description: About 1,200 orphaned pieces of luggage stood in ranks against the wall in the luggage claim area of Newark International Airport's Terminal C today, blocking foot traffic and adding a frenzied air to the airport's post-holiday chaos.

title: Digital Photos: Easy to Take, Not So Easy to Take Care Of
description: TO say that Margo Hochuli-Wallman is a photography enthusiast would be an understatement. Ms. Hochuli-Wallman, a 49-year-old math tutor in Pittsford, N.Y., has been taking pictures since she was 10, chronicling her life and that of her family through the years.

title: Neither Side Is Game to Block Mideast Peace
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 4  For a land where racquet sports are rare, tennis metaphors certainly get a workout. A key theme in the peace negotiations concerns whether the ball is in the Israelis' court or the Palestinians'.

title: Hard Times for TV Documentaries; Lack of Money Limits Smaller Serious Films
description: On paper, Steven Okazaki was a filmmaker who should not have been scrounging for money.

title: Creating a Generation of Slouchers
description: AS schools around the country push to increase students' use of computers, a small but growing number of educators and researchers say that children are risking injury because they are not being taught sound ergonomic practices along with basic computer skills.

title: Mummies and More in an Antiquities Roadshow
description: IT used to be that big art museums were arranged chronologically, and you went in and turned right, and the fight started because . . . they hit you with the mummies. Which was really unfair, because Mom wanted Van Gogh and teacher wanted the Old Masters and the nuns headed for the Renaissance, and all you wanted was to be left alone with . . . mummies.

title: A Mosaic of Cultures From Africa Via Paris
description: Aline Matsika, far right, a former model for Pierre Cardin and a collector of African textiles, brought something new to Louis XVI-style sofas and 1930's armchairs. Instead of upholstering them in damask, she used African fabrics. And she opened two shops called Concept Ethnic in Paris. Last month, she brought her designs to Manhattan. She chose not to call her American store Concept Ethnic, but Mosaic. ''In France, ethnic means tribal,'' Ms. Matsika said. ''Here, it is not as specific. So I chose mosaic, for a mosaic of cultures, of people, of objects.'' The chaise she is sitting on is in a Senegalese cotton-and-raffia fabric, which feels like heavy linen ($6,000). A 30's-style armchair, above, is upholstered in Senegalese diamond-pattern cotton and raffia ($1,900). Also available are Kuba cloth hangings and African cotton place mats and napkins. At 122 Hudson Street (North Moore Street); information: (646) 613-8570.

title: Other Windows On the Web
description: ARE you a geek? Take this enjoyable self-test in the comfort of your own home. Just answer a single question: How many Web browsers can you name?

title: Layoffs and Cutbacks Expected at News Corp.s Internet Unit
description: News Digital Media, the leading Internet unit of the News Corporation, has decided to abandon its ambitious efforts to provide original content on its Web sites and will instead lay off several hundred workers within the next few weeks, according to three executives close to the decision.

title: Owner of 17 Luxury Hotels Buys Carlyle for $130 Million
description: Nearly two years after discreetly offering itself for sale, the Carlyle Hotel -- that soigne preserve of presidents, prime ministers and popular legends on the Upper East Side -- has been sold to a private investment group that owns 17 other luxury hotels.

title: NEW CHIEF AT NETWORK ASSOCIATES
description: The prominent computer security company Network Associates said that it had appointed a former I.B.M. executive, George Samenuk, as its chief executive. He succeeds William L. Larson, who said he would step down after the company acknowledged that its sales for the fourth quarter would be only about $65 million and that it was likely to report a $140 million loss. In October, the company forecast sales of $250 million and a profit, but it changed its accounting methods to more accurately reflect sales. Mr. Samenuk said he would focus on customers and work to ''restore investor confidence in the company.''

title: Jury Selection in Embassy Bombing Case Faces Hardship Challenges
description: Jury selection in the trial of four men charged with conspiring in the 1998 bombings of two United States embassies in East Africa opened yesterday amid the challenge of finding jurors who can endure the personal hardships that come from setting aside their lives for at least 10 months. The trial, the first in the United States stemming from the embassy attacks in Nairobi, Kenya, and Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, is being held in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Barber Set to Shed Bulky Cast for Game
description: Tiki Barber spent two hours today practicing with a heavy cast enveloping his left arm from wrist to elbow. And although he caught passes downfield and tosses in the backfield, when the workout was over Barber declared: ''I'm definitely not wearing that on Sunday. I couldn't feel my arm. It was like a block.''

title: SCHERING SUES IMPAX TO STOP GENERIC CLARITIN
description: The Schering unit of the Schering-Plough Corporation sued Impax Laboratories in federal district court in Newark yesterday over Impax's application to market a generic allergy drug similar to one version of Schering's best-selling Claritin. Impax, based in Hayward, Calif., applied to the Food and Drug Administration in November for permission to market tablets combining loratadine and pseudoephedrine sulfate in a formulation that Schering said closely matched that of its Claritin-D 24-Hour Extended Relief tablets. Schering's suit disputes Impax's contention in its application that two Schering patents for Claritin are invalid or unenforceable, or would not be infringed by its generic drug. The patents expire in 2004 and 2012.

title: Governor Pataki's Wish List
description: Gov. George Pataki offered New Yorkers a broadly appealing menu of promises yesterday on education, the environment, gun control and reform of state drug laws. But as veterans of Albany wisely cautioned, the governor's seventh State of the State address is simply a speech, perhaps even the launching of his campaign for re-election in 2002. His state budget, which should give dimension to these proposals, appears with all its promise -- or potentially deflating details -- in the next few weeks.

title: Weinbrecht, at 35, Would Like to Be Over the (Moguls) Hill Again
description: If you have ever wondered what makes elite athletes different from the rest of us, here is a window into their thinking.

title: Isles' Parrish Apologizes To the Fans
description: Mark Parrish of the Islanders apologized yesterday on the team's Web site for remarks he made about the team's fans after a 3-0 loss Tuesday night to Montreal, the fifth loss in the team's seven-game homestand.

title: Vehicle Sales Fell Sharply In December
description: Auto sales slowed precipitously last month, with domestic automakers reporting plunges of up to 18 percent from year-ago levels. Foreign automakers, though, escaped almost unscathed and gained market share.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Metro Briefing column on Tuesday about a teenager who the police said was wounded by officers in Brooklyn after he pointed a gun misspelled his given name in some copies. He is Frasier Lavel, not Frazier.

title: Call for Good Will Opens Narrowly Split Congress
description: As President Clinton, spouse, looked on from the Senate visitors gallery, the 107th Congress came into session today so closely divided that the Democrats were able to take control of the Senate, however tenuously, for 17 days until the new Republican administration is sworn in.

title: Polishing the Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: Holiday Sales Were Weaker Than Expected
description: Despite some hopes held almost to the last minute that tardy and post-season shoppers would bring them cheer, the nation's merchants finally acknowledged today that they had a spectacularly unmerry Christmas this year with weak December sales.

title: Rowland Offers His Plans On Transit and Education
description: In a State of the State address that was ambitious but short on specifics, Gov. John G. Rowland kicked off Connecticut's 2001 legislative session today by proposing to overhaul the state's transportation system, expand mental health services, increase spending on public education and cut party leaders' influence in selecting candidates for public office.

title: Lockheed Martin Begins Review
description: The Lockheed Martin Corporation said yesterday that it had begun a review for its account, which has been handled since August 1996 by the New York office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group. The agency said that it had declined an invitation to take part, thereby resigning the account.

description: STAHL-Shirley M. Congregation Rodeph Sholom mourns the death of Shirley M. Stahl, beloved wife of the late Earl (Buster) Stahl and devoted mother of Gina and Rabbi Robert Levine, Trudi and Neal Epstein, Eric and Elizabeth Stahl, Marcia and Joseph Rosen and her eleven grandchildren. May her memory be a blessing. The funeral will be held in Springfield, Mass. at Sinai Temple on Friday, January 5, 1PM. Shiva will be observed at the Stahl residence 413-567-5623. We extend our deepest condolences to the entire family. Clergy, Board of Trustees, Staff and Members of Congregation Rodeph Sholom

title: Housing Plan For Inmates Is Called Off After Protests
description: Faced with an avalanche of local opposition, federal officials said yesterday that they were shelving plans for a halfway house for inmates in Washington Heights.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LANDON, GARDNER F.
description: LANDON-Gardner F. Delray Beach, Florida, and Lake Placid, N.Y. died at his home on Monday, January 1, 2001. He was born in Washington, D.C. on August 6, 1916, the son of Chauncey L. Landon and Jane Gardner Landon. On December 25, 1941, he married Dorothy A. Dodge, who predeceased him in 1997, after almost 60 years of marriage. They lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y. for over 40 years. His sisters Jane L. Fairchild and Betty L. Dietz also predeceased him. He attended Bronxville High School and graduated from Pawling School, now Trinity Pawling School, in Pawling, N.Y. He entered military service with Squadron A of New York in 1940 and was discharged as a Captain of the Air Corps in 1945. From 1946 to 1950 he was part owner and vice president of the W.P. Woodall Co., as well as a vice president and partner of The Universal Vise & Tool Company until it was sold in 1965. In 1951 he was the owneroperator of the Thomasville Baseball Club in Thomasville, GA, and made many lifetime friendships in the baseball world. He joined Thompson Publishing Company in 1952, eventually becoming president. In 1961 the company merged with Technical Publishing Company where he became executive vice president. Mr. Landon was instrumental in the sale of Technical Publishing to the Dun and Bradstreet Corporation in 1978. He served as a trustee at Flower Fifth Avenue Hospital, Northwood School, and N.Y. Medical College; from 1964-1975 he was trustee and then president of the Lake Placid Company, owners of the Forest Press and publishers of the Dewey Decimal System. In 1983 he entered the thoroughbred racing business and established Cobble View Stables. Some of his most notable horses were Groomstick, Kiri's Clown, and Arthur L. He is survived by his daughters, Deborah D. Landon, Joan L. Gignoux, and Judith A. Landon; his grandchildren, Gardner Case Newberry, James W. Newberry, Jesse L. Tron, and stepgrandson Christopher Gignoux; and many nieces and nephews. The family requests that contributions in his name be made to the charity of one's choice. A private graveside service will be held in Lake Placid, N.Y. on Saturday, January 6, followed by a gathering for his friends and relatives.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RENEHAN, MARY K. (NEE HANLON)
description: RENEHAN-Mary K. (nee Hanlon), on January 2, 2001, of Bergenfield, NJ. Wife of the late John P. Renehan. Mother of Robert J., John R., and the late Richard Renehan. Grandmother of James, Vincent and Elizabeth. Funeral liturgy at St. John's R.C. Church, Bergenfield, NJ, Friday, at 11:15 AM. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. Visiting at Riewerts Memorial Home, 187 So. Washington Ave., Bergenfield, NJ, Thursday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM.

title: Making a Mark in the Fine Points of Trash
description: MARTHA HIRST'S job is to think deeply about something that most people don't want to think about at all -- garbage. That requires an overhaul in definitions. Trash, by this turning of the semantic screw, is not something to be thrown out, but rather a powerful and valuable lens for analyzing what civilized society is supposed to do.

title: California Board Proposes Increase in Electric Rates
description: Under enormous pressure to bring some relief to California's struggling utilities, the state's Public Utility Commission proposed a roughly 10 percent increase today in what consumers would pay for electricity, but financial analysts said it was too little and that the state's energy crisis was likely to grow far worse.

title: St. John's Is Playing Better, Just in Time
description: Never mind that Virginia Tech was making its debut in the Big East. Nine St. John's players were playing their first conference game last night. And after a horrific month of December, St. John's has emerged with momentum for Saturday's matchup at Connecticut.
