description: January 3, 2001

title: The Neediest Cases; From Addiction to Helping to Save Lives
description: Inside his father's office at a West 37th Street truck garage, James Addison Jr. felt his knees became weak, and he sat down in a swivel chair and covered his face with his hands as he digested the news.

title: Editors Note: New Science and Health Sections
description: Beginning today, The New York Times on the Web presents an improved Science section a new area dedicated to Health .

title: Working World Grows For Orthodox Women; New Fields and Strict Judaism Coexist
description: When Yitta Halberstam Mandelbaum was growing up in Borough Park, Brooklyn, in the late 1950's, she figured there were two careers for Orthodox Jewish girls: teaching and social work. But Yitta's father, a traditional Hasidic man whose dark curls dangled from beneath his black hat, planted his daughter in the biography section of the local public library and encouraged her to dream.

title: Out of Africa or Bust, With a Desert to Cross
description: On the windswept outskirts of this desert outpost, where the Sahara unfolds to the end of the horizon, a big truck came to a dusty stop the other day. A couple of dozen African men swarmed around the truck, trading sharp words and elbows, as they jostled one another to reach the driver's side.

title: A Day of Record-Breaking Gains and Trading Volume
description: Wall Street got back its rose-colored glasses yesterday when the Federal Reserve unexpectedly cut interest rates after six rate increases. The move sent the Nasdaq composite index to the biggest one- day percentage gain in its history and led to a record day of trading volume on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Donations Help Voters' League Stay Alive in City
description: The New York office of the League of Women Voters, which was on the verge of closing because of financial troubles, was back on its feet yesterday after an influx of cash donations.

title: A Long Night's Journey Into Day at the Bowls
description: To watch college bowls, you need to suspend a normal sense of time.

title: Similar Cuts Made in the Federal Funds Rate in 1989 and 1998 Produced Divergent Results
description: When Alan Greenspan cuts rates a lot, the markets usually love it. But sometimes the love doesn't last.

title: The Recession We Need
description: There can be no mistaking the message of the Federal Reserve's New Year's surprise, a reduction yesterday of one-half of a percentage point in the benchmark interest rate. If the United States economy is not already in recession, it is on the brink of its first downturn in a decade. Why else would the Fed move with such urgency?

title: Charlie Lourie, 60, a Founder of Mosaic, a Distinctive Jazz Reissue Label
description: Charlie Lourie, a co-founder of the jazz reissue label Mosaic, died on Sunday at his home in Stamford, Conn. He was 60.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about Lai Chang xing, a Chinese fugitive in Canada, misstated the English-language name of the company he headed, which was at the center of a smuggling scandal. The company, the Yuanhua Group, uses the name ''Fair Well,'' not ''Fare Well.''

title: For Gore, a Day of Poignant Partings
description: It was a bizarre cap to an improbable presidential campaign and a bittersweet moment after 24 consecutive years in public office.

title: Free-Form D.J. Loses Weekly Radio Show
description: The last installment of ''Idiot's Delight,'' Vin Scelsa's long-running radio show, ended at 3:25 a.m. on New Year's Day with the sounds of ''Over the Rainbow'' played on a music box that his producer had given him for Christmas. Mr. Scelsa had been on since 10 p.m., spinning diverse tunes -- from the Velvet Underground to Julie Andrews to ''The Blue Danube'' -- and telling stories that sometimes would go on for 15 minutes or more, his trademark for more than 30 years.

title: Construction Spending Is Down
description: Construction spending fell in November, the first drop in four months, but remained at a level suggesting that builders have escaped the economic slowdown, government figures showed today.

title: Once a Rectory, Now It Jumps Off the Street
description: In February, when students will begin using the 30,000-square-foot Lucent Technologies Center for Arts Education, part of the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark, they won't mistake it for yet another red brick schoolhouse. The building is its own billboard, with words painted in letters as high as 10 feet. Inside, the building is a riot of bright colors. Linoleum tile floors, in combinations of red, yellow, green, black and gray, are laid out in diagonals, checkerboards, stripes, chevrons and right angles. Radiators and fireplaces are painted in the same palette. One wall is yellow with a red door. Lawrence P. Goldman, the president of the arts center, decided to convert a 1940's rectory for the use of the arts, but he was uninspired by the renovation. Last June, he asked Paula Scher, a partner in Pentagram Design, international graphic designers, how much sizzle she could deliver for $100,000.

title: A Little Stock Exuberance
description: The Fed move was just what stock investors needed to get back into a buying mode. But some warned it was a signal that the economy was worse off than suspected. Page C1.

title: Collapse of Atlanta Talks Keeps Road Builders Idle
description: When environmental groups last month reached a tentative agreement with the state that would allow road building to resume in the Atlanta area after two years of legal delays, one could almost hear the revving of the paving machines.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CROWLEY, CATHERINE M. (NEE KAMMERER)
description: CROWLEY-Catherine M. (nee Kammerer), 78, died peacefully on January 2, 2001 after a long illness endured with grace and dignity. Beloved wife of the late Thomas J. Crowley, Jr. Devoted mother of Patricia Ann Hyland, fond motherin-law of Michael S. Hyland. Adored grandmother of Catherine, Michael, Courtney, Thomas and Christopher Hyland. Sister of the late Anthony J. Kammerer, James V. Kammerer and Albert F. Kammerer. Dear friend of Jane and Mary Hyland and Camille Wilson. Friends may call on Thursday, January 4th at John J. Fox Funeral Home in Larchmont, NY from 2-4 P.M. and 7-9 P.M. Mass of Christian burial at Sts. John and Paul Church, Friday, 10 A.M. Donations in her memory may be made to the Sarah R. Newman Nursing Home, 845 Palmer Ave, Mamaroneck, New York 10543

title: INTERNET MERGER TALKS CONFIRMED
description: LibertySurf S.A., a French Internet service provider, said it was in talks with telecommunications companies, including Belgacom S.A. of Belgium, that might lead to a merger. Seventy percent of the company's stock is controlled by Europatweb, an investment fund run by Bernard Arnault, and by Kingfisher P.L.C. of Britain; their holdings may not be sold until March 15, 2001.

title: RENAULT SEES RENEWED GROWTH
description: By reintroducing a midsize car and ramping up production of diesel-powered vehicles, Renault S.A. expects to recoup the market share it has lost in Western Europe this year, according to the company's vice president for sales and marketing, Francois Hinfray. Renault's share slipped to 11 percent last year from 11.3 percent in 1999, but the decline was ''purely mechanical,'' Mr. Hinfray said. The company will add a new minivan, the Avantime, and a large luxury car, the Velsatis, over the next year.

title: Take the A Drive: Duke, Monk and Miles Online
description: The center of the jazz world in the 1940's was a two-block stretch of West 52nd Street in New York, where musicians could play at several spots in one night. Jack Teagarden used to take his trombone to other clubs between sets at his regular gig. When the owner complained, Mr. Teagarden said he was ''just being neighborly.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREGORY, CHON
description: GREGORY-Chon, 73, Chappaqua, NY. Beloved father of Susan, Judith and Pamela and loving grandfather of Patrick, Molly, Dorothy and Solomon, died peacefully on Sunday, December 31, 2000. His cherished wife Dorothy died on December 9, 2000. A memorial service to honor Chon and Dorothy will be held on February 17, 2001 at 1 PM at the Community Center in Chappaqua, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made in memory of Dorothy and Chon Gregory to Doctors Without Borders, 6 East 39 St, 8 Floor, NY, New York 10016, 1-888-392-0392.

title: WILLIAMS SAYS ITS EARNINGS MAY BEAT ESTIMATES
description: The Williams Companies, a natural gas pipeline company that has become a big energy trader, said yesterday that its earnings in 2001 might exceed analysts' estimates of $1.26 a share because of robust profits in its trading operations. The company said it might be able to record trading profits of at least $500 million a year even if prices in California do not repeat the surges of 2000.

title: Brightening Up the Mood
description: WALL sconces have entered the modern age. Bigger, bolder and giving off much more light, some can now illuminate a whole room. ''Many modern sconces have halogen bulbs and throw off as much light as a standing torchier for general ambient illumination,'' said Stephen Bernstein, a lighting consultant with Cline Bettridge Bernstein Lighting Design in New York. ''And they add a decorative object to the wall.''

title: Broad Field, No Standout In Grammy Nominations
description: The 43rd annual Grammy Award nominations, announced here today at the Beverly Hilton, lacked one outstanding trait of the previous two years' Grammys: a clear front-runner. Lauryn Hill swept up 10 Grammy Award nominations in 1999 and Santana returned with a vengeance last year, also with 10 nominations; the top nominees this year are the rapper and producer Dr. Dre and Beyonce Knowles of the harmonizing female R&B group Destiny's Child, who each got five.

The new section will appear in all copies of the paper sold in Japan. Publication is expected to begin in the second quarter.

title: DEVILS-COYOTES RESCHEDULED
description: The league yesterday rescheduled Sunday night's game between the Phoenix Coyotes and the Devils at Continental Arena to Wednesday night to avoid a conflict with the National Football League playoff game between the Giants and the Philadelphia Eagles at Giants Stadium. The stadium is adjacent to the Devils' home and shares parking facilities.

title: New Jerseys Roukema Turns Down Offer to Become U.S. Treasurer
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4  Representative Marge Roukema of New Jersey was offered the post of United States Treasurer in the administration of Gov. George W. Bush, apparently in an effort to salve her disappointment at being passed over for a committee chairmanship, but has turned it down.

title: METRO BRIEFING
description: NEW YORK

title: IMC GLOBAL SAYS IT WILL MISS FOURTH-QUARTER PROFIT
description: IMC Global , a major fertilizer maker, said yesterday that the high cost of raw materials, especially ammonia and natural gas, had eroded its fourth-quarter profits. The company, based in Lake Forest, Ill., said it expected earnings of about 12 cents a share for the quarter; analysts had forecast 20 cents. Two phosphate plants in Louisiana will be closed indefinitely, the company said.

title: CABLE GIANT NAMES ACCESS CHIEF
description: Time Warner named its general counsel, Christopher Bogart, left, to head its unit that sells high-speed Internet service over cable television lines. Mr. Bogart will be president and chief executive of Time Warner Cable Ventures after America Online completes its $94.4 billion acquisition of Time Warner, the company said. Mr. Bogart, 35, succeeds Glenn A. Britt, who became president of Time Warner's cable division in 1999. Mr. Bogart will be responsible for negotiating agreements with competing Internet service providers, the company said. Time Warner agreed last month to let other Internet companies offer online access over its cable lines.

title: The Look of Traditional Rugs, and That's Just for a Start
description: For nearly 20 years, Thomas Woodard and Blanche Greenstein, Manhattan antiques dealers, have designed cotton rugs adapted from 19th- and early-20th-century American rugs and textiles. ''In the 70's, we bought old rag carpets, and we could only find odd pieces, or runners, but not a room-size rug,'' Ms. Greenstein said. So they designed their own. Three new patterns, woven in India, are, from left, Great Barrington, Robin Square and Berks County, available as runners (27 to 30 inches wide, $14.75 a square foot), area rugs (4 by 6 feet, $354) and room-size rugs (9 by 12 feet, $1,593). Woodard Weave, 506 East 74th Street; (212) 988-2906.

title: The First Cut is Not Taxes
description: In using his power over interest rates yesterday, Alan Greenspan found himself in the middle of a debate over whether his move would help or hinder President-elect George W. Bush's push to enact a big tax cut.

title: In Patakis Address, School Financing Plan With Implications
description: ALBANY, Jan. 3  Barely 10 minutes into a 68-minute speech, Gov. George E. Pataki stepped into dangerous political territory today, pledging to simplify the way the state gives most of its roughly $13 billion a year in aid to local schools.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''There's a simple message. The Fed will do whatever it takes to keep the U.S. economy from going down the tubes.''

title: Women Play Games Online In Larger Numbers Than Men
description: A recent survey of Internet and video gamers may shoot a hole through some male-centric stereotypes: Women now make up the majority of online gamers by a slim margin, according to PC Data Online, a market survey company in Reston, Va.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about efforts to attract a wider audience to the Brooklyn Museum of Art misidentified the London institution that first showed the ''Sensation'' exhibition. It was the Royal Academy of Arts, not the Tate Gallery.

title: Jury Awards $2.25 Million In '95 Death
description: A federal jury awarded more than $2 million today to the children of a Long Island man who was fatally shot on the street five years ago by a Nassau County police officer.

title: Airline Blames Computer System for Delays
description: Spirit Airlines, a discount air carrier that has left hundreds of its passengers stranded and furious at La Guardia Airport since Saturday's snowstorm, said yesterday that the problems were caused by a new computerized scheduling system that had failed to match flight crews with airplanes during one of the airline's busiest weeks.

title: Harold Rhodes, 89, Inventor of an Electronic Piano
description: Harold Burroughs Rhodes, who invented an electric piano that became indispensable to jazz, funk and pop musicians, died on Dec. 17 in Los Angeles. He was 89.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: QUEST DIAGNOSTICS INC., -- Teterboro, N.J., a medical laboratory test provider, agreed to pay $13.1 million to settle allegations that Nichols Institute, a unit it bought in 1994, overbilled government health-care programs between 1989 and 1995 for tests that were not medically necessary.

title: Undefeated Oklahoma Is No. 1 Football Team

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAMPFLE, FELICE
description: STAMPFLE-Felice died Sunday, December 31, 2000 in Kennett Square, PA. She was 88. Born in Kansas City, MO., and educated at Washington University and Radcliffe College, she was the Charles W. Engelhard Curator Emeritus of Drawings and Prints at the Pierpont Morgan Library in New York City and had been in charge of the Library's drawings from 1945 until her retirement in 1984. During her tenure as curator, Ms. Stampfle was responsible for a number of catalogues focusing on aspects of the Morgan's collection, in particular, Drawings by Giovanni Battista Piranesi, Rubens and Rembrandt in Their Century, and the 3-volume series, in collaboration with Jacob Bean of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, Drawings from New York Collections. From 1963 to 1984, she also served as the first editor of the journal, Master Drawings. Subsequent to her retirement, she published the first of two volumes: Netherlandish Drawings of the 15th and 16th Centuries and Flemish Drawings of the 17th and 18th Centuries. The second volume, devoted to Dutch drawings of the 17th, 18th and 19th centuries, is forthcoming. Ms. Stampfle was preceded in death by her parents, Harry and Grace (Suiter) Stampfle, a niece Susan Felice Corrigan and her brother, Robert B. Stampfle, and is survived by nieces, Margaret Farrell of Acton, MA., and Mary Troutman of Bethlehem, PA. Burial services will be private. The family suggests contributions in her memory be made to: National Endowment for the Arts, 1100 Pennsylvania Avenue Washington, D.C. 20506.

title: BERKLEY RESISTS HUNT BID
description: The Hunt Oil Company is running into stiffening resistance to its $694 million cash offer for the Berkley Petroleum Corporation of Calgary, Alberta. The offer is Hunt's third takeover bid for a Canadian oil company in the last year. Berkley, which adopted a temporary ''poison pill'' defense, said it had succeeded in attracting the interest of other bidders, with whom it would share data next week. Hunt said its offer would remain open until Feb. 6, longer than the customary 21 days, to give Berkley time to sort through any competing offers. Expecting a bidding war, investors pushed Berkley's stock price above the 10 Canadian dollars a share bid by Hunt, which is privately held. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: INKTOMI'S RESULTS MISS FORECASTS
description: The Inktomi Corporation, whose software speeds the flow of Internet content, said fiscal first-quarter sales and earnings missed forecasts. Revenue for the period ended Sunday was $80 million to $81 million, Inktomi said, less than analysts' average forecast of $89.5 million. Profit was break-even or a penny a share, missing the 3-cent average estimate. Concern about slowing economic growth prompted customers like telephone companies and Internet-service providers to delay or scale back plans to buy its software, Inktomi said. Inktomi shares traded as low as $13.88 in after-hours trading following the company's announcement. They had risen $3.94, to $18.50, in regular trading on Nasdaq before the report.

title: Metro Business Briefing; FOREIGN REALTY INVESTMENT
description: For the second year in a row, foreign investors have chosen New York City as the best place to buy real estate, according to an annual survey by the Association of Foreign Investors in Real Estate. After New York, the association's members favored San Francisco, Boston and Washington. The survey also found that foreign investors have little concern about a slowing economy, with 90 percent of the survey's respondents saying they would either increase or maintain their investments in United States real estate this year. Office buildings were the preferred property type for the sixth year in a row. Rents have risen even as the high-technology-related companies that have fueled the office market in recent years are giving up space or slowing expansion plans.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WINEAPPLE, MAXINE B.
description: WINEAPPLE-Maxine B. Died peacefully in her sleep early Wednesday morning, January 3, 2001 after a long and courageous ordeal with Alzheimer's disease. Born in Boston, Massachusetts, she lived in Scarsdale, NY then Manhattan. and most recently in DelRay Beach, FL. Maxine is survived by her son John, daughter Patty, brother Arthur, grandsons Andrew and James. Maxine graduated from Wheelock College in Boston and received her M.A. from Columbia University. Maxine will long be remembered for her style and elegance coupled with her beauty and brains. Maxine's life will be celebrated with a private memorial service with her immediate family.

title: GOLDMAN SACHS IS TOP FINANCIAL ADVISER, FIGURES SHOW
description: Goldman, Sachs was the top financial adviser for announced worldwide mergers and acquisitions in 2000, according to figures from Thomson Financial Securities. Goldman represented $1.28 trillion worth of announced deals, followed by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. with $1.13 trillion, and Credit Suisse First Boston, with $945 billion. For United States deals, Goldman also ranked first with $807 billion of announced transactions, well ahead of Credit Suisse First Boston and Morgan Stanley, though Credit Suisse First Boston was involved in many more deals, 436, than Goldman, with 242, or J. P. Morgan, with 222. Considering worldwide transactions completed -- not simply announced -- Goldman led with $1.63 trillion, followed by Morgan Stanley with $1.37 trillion and Merrill Lynch with $1.16 trillion. Andrew Ross Sorkin (NYT)

title: OFFICE DEPOT TO CLOSE STORES AND CUT JOBS
description: Office Depot Inc., the top American retailer of office supplies, said yesterday that it planned to close 70 stores in 18 states and Canada, eliminate 1,590 jobs and take a fourth-quarter pretax charge of up to $300 million related to the cutbacks. The chain will withdraw entirely from Cleveland and Columbus, Ohio; Phoenix; and Boston. It will close other less-profitable stores, including five in New York, three in New Jersey and two in Connecticut. The chief executive, Bruce Nelson, said the company had expanded too aggressively to compete with rivals like OfficeMax and Staples and that some markets had become saturated. The company also said it would invest $110 million to spruce up some of its 818 surviving stores in North America and to install new inventory-tracking systems at warehouses.

title: Metro Business Briefing; PLUMBING FIXTURES PLANT CLOSING
description: The future is in doubt for 274 employees of the American Standard Companies after it announced yesterday that it would begin closing its 75-year-old plumbing fixtures plant in Hamilton, N.J., in June. The plant is now operating at half capacity. Under a consolidation plan announced on Dec. 28, American Standard plans to move the plant's operations to Ohio, Mexico City and Costa Rica, said Lisa Glover, a company spokeswoman. The company, which is based in Piscataway, N.J., is negotiating with the Glass, Molders, Pottery, Plastics and Allied Workers International Union on possible relocation or severance pay for the workers who will be affected, Ms. Glover said. She said the closing would not affect 700 employees at American Standard's Trane air-conditioner factory in Hamilton, N.J. Hamilton's mayor, Glen Gilmore, said he was angry that the company would lay off workers in favor of cheaper foreign labor. Steve Strunsky

title: U.S. Joins California in Bid To Lift State Power Squeeze
description: Alarmed by the rapidly deteriorating financial condition of California's power utilities, top state and federal officials took urgent steps today to solve the state's energy crisis, including an emergency 90-day increase in the rates charged consumers and plans for senior state and federal officials to meet at the White House on Tuesday.

title: SMITHFIELD SELLS MORE THAN A THIRD OF ITS STAKE IN IBP
description: Smithfield Foods, the leading pork producer, whose bid to acquire IBP Inc., the leading beef producer, failed on Monday, sold more than a third of its stake in IBP on Tuesday and Wednesday, according to a regulatory filing. Tyson Foods, the leading chicken producer, won the bidding for IBP with an offer of $30 a share, half in cash and half in stock; Smithfield's $30-a-share offer had been all stock. Smithfield had accumulated 6.96 million shares in IBP, it said in its filing; 2.56 million shares, or about 37 percent of its stake, were sold Tuesday and Wednesday for an average of $28.11 a share, a profit of about $1.15 a share after taxes, analysts estimated.

title: McCain Challenges Bush, Promising Early Effort to Overhaul Campaign Finance
description: George W. Bush's one-time primary rival, Senator John McCain, tossed down a new challenge to him today, pledging an all-out battle to force the Senate to consider an overhaul of the campaign finance law right after the new president is inaugurated later this month.

title: MERCATA IS LATEST ONLINE CASUALTY
description: Mercata Inc., an online merchandise auctioneer that is majority owned by the Microsoft co-founder Paul Allen's Vulcan Ventures, said it was closing its doors after failing to raise more money. Mercata.com, its Web site where consumers can team up to buy specially advertised products at a discount and bid on products to make the price cheaper, will accept orders until Jan. 31 and returns if they are postmarked by Jan. 20, said Rosanne Marks, a spokeswoman. News of the closing came a day after Mercata canceled a $100 million initial stock offering.

description: The chief rabbis of Israel declared today that Jewish law forbids giving up Israeli sovereignty over the Temple Mount, the plateau in Jerusalem holy to Jews and Muslims that is at the center of the conflict between Israelis and Palestinians.

The Health Department expressed outrage at the decision, one made by its own hearing committee, and said it would try to prevent the doctor from resuming practice.

title: PARK PLACE SHARES FALL 16% ON NEWS OF WEAKER PROFIT
description: Park Place Entertainment, the world's largest casino operator, said yesterday that, on an operating basis, it would break even in the fourth quarter because of lower casino winnings in Las Vegas and poor weather in other markets. Analysts had expected Park Place to earn 12 cents a share in the quarter. The warning caused the company's stock to fall sharply, closing down $1.94, or 16 percent, at $10. Park Place also said that a planned sale of the Las Vegas Hilton to Ed Roski Jr., a real estate developer, for $365 million was falling apart because Mr. Roski had not made a deposit by the date required.

title: THAI GAS IMPORTS STEPPED UP
description: Thailand's state-controlled oil company, PTT Exploration and Production, said yesterday that it expected to begin receiving additional gas from a project in neighboring Myanmar that it co-owns with three foreign oil companies -- Petronas of Malaysia, Premier Oil of Britain and Nippon Oil of Japan -- and with interests in Myanmar, whose ruling junta has been accused by human rights activists of using forced labor to build gas pipelines. Thailand is obliged to buy gas from the project and another in Myanmar involving TotalFina Elf and Unocal, even though the power plant it was meant to fuel is unfinished; a new pipeline that opened last month carries the gas elsewhere. Wayne Arnold (NYT)

title: How the Movie Year Suddenly Got Better
description: IT'S that time again: the silly cinematic season of proliferating 10-best lists, critics' polls and movie ads bloated with hyperbolic quotations, all aimed at creating ''Oscar buzz'' as the countdown begins for the Academy Awards on March 25. Once again, after a year of producing largely dreary commercial product, Hollywood has put on its straightest face to pretend that all it has ever really cared about is quality. And once again it can point to a (very small) handful of films that almost justify the chest-thumping pomposity.

title: BBDO Chicago Office Gets Vodka Account
description: Allied Domecq Spirits and Wine North America is expanding its ties to the Chicago office of BBDO Worldwide, a unit of the Omnicom Group, by naming the agency to handle the Stolichnaya vodka account. Billings were put at $25 million. Jack Shea, a spokesman for Allied Domecq in Westport, Conn., said the decision was based on BBDO Chicago's work for two other brands, Beefeater gin and Kahlua. Allied Domecq recently acquired the United States distribution rights to Stolichnaya.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: NATURAL GAS CLIMBS. Natural gas rose on concern that some distributors may run short before the end of winter. In New York, natural gas for February delivery rose 77.7 cents, or 9.5 percent, to $8.966 per million B.T.U.'s.

title: First-Class Letter Rate Rises on Sunday
description: The cost of mailing a letter will rise by one cent starting on Sunday. First-class postage for letters weighing up to one ounce will cost 34 cents, under a proposal approved last month by the United States Postal Service's board of governors.

title: EBAY KNOCKED OUT FOR 11 HOURS
description: EBay, the Internet's most popular auction service, suffered a severe technical problem that brought down its service for nearly 11 hours yesterday. The crash stemmed not from a single problem but from a series of hardware failures compounded by a database malfunction, the company said. A series of technical problems plagued the eBay system last fall, causing numerous shutdowns. A spokesman for eBay, based in San Jose, Calif., said the company had been aware for some time that its system was at risk, but rather than interrupt service to fix it during the busy holiday season it chose to use a variety of work-around solutions. EBay said it would automatically extend all affected listings by 24 hours. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

Wedged beneath the beautiful wood-ribbed ceiling of the center's annex space on West 22nd Street is ''The Aeromodeller,'' a giant translucent zeppelin that was constructed, mostly with plastic and tape, from 1969 to 1971 by the Belgian artist, scientist, poet, inventor and dreamer who calls himself Panamarenko.

title: LOCKHEED MARTIN TO CUT 675 JOBS AT GEORGIA PLANT
description: Lockheed Martin said yesterday that it would eliminate about 675 jobs at its plane-assembly plant in Marietta, Ga., to save $25 million a year. The plant assembles F-22 fighter jets and C-130J cargo planes and employs about 7,000. Layoffs will begin in June, the company said. Analysts said that the company, worried about a promised review of all aircraft programs by the new administration, was rushing to complete testing of F-22 prototypes so the Air Force could authorize production of 10 of the jets before President Clinton leaves office Jan. 20. Shares of Lockheed Martin fell 25 cents, to $33.40.

title: MORE NTT SHARES TO BE SOLD
description: The Japanese Ministry of Finance, which owns 45.9 percent of the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation, said it planned to sell one million shares, or 6.2 percent of the company, in the year beginning April 1. It will be the seventh time the ministry has sold shares in Nippon Telegraph since 1986. The government said it hoped to reap 730.7 billion yen ($6.4 billion) from the sale, which will be used to shore up the country's bank deposit insurance system and clean up losses at failed banks.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WARD, JOHN OWEN
description: WARD-John Owen. On New Year's. At age 81. A graduate of Dulwich College and St. Edmund Hall at Oxford University, he was a gifted linguist. He fought at Trobruk and was later attached to the French Foreign Legion and British Army Intellgence during W.W. II. After working as an antiquarian music dealer in London, he became manager of the music department, Oxford University Press (NY), Director of Serious Music at Boosey & Hawkes (NY) and President of the Music Publishers Association (USA). Beginning in 1957 he edited the Oxford Companion to Music under Dr. Percy Scholes as well as other Scholes books for 20 years, and wrote Careers in Music. A kind and generous friend, a true and learned gentleman, he will be greatly missed. Survived by a sister, Betty June Huxtable and two nephews, all in England.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALKINS, SARAH ANNE
description: CALKINS-Sarah Anne, 42. On December 23, 2000 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York; from leukemia. Sarah grew up in Falls Church, VA, and was graduated from J.E.B. Stuart H.S. in 1976. She studied architectural history and was graduated with honors from Smith College in 1980. After earning her degree in 1984 from Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture and Planning, Sarah opened her own architecture practice in New York City, specializing in residential design. She was a member of the American Institute of Architects (AIA), lectured on architecture at Smith College and Parsons School of Design, and wrote and illustrated travel articles. Sarah leaves her fiance, Dr. Antonio Beltramini, and his son, Roberto. She is survived by her parents, G. Nathan and Susannah Calkins of Falls Church, her sisters, Margaret Calkins Van Auken of Akron and Abigail Calkins Aguirre of Philadelphia, her brother-in-law, Francisco Aguirre and her three nieces. Her oldest sister, Helen Calkins, died in 1978. Sarah's family and her many devoted friends will miss her wit, intellectual curiosity, insight and generosity of spirit. She was like no other. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, Amsterdam Ave. at 117th St. on Thursday, January 18th, 2PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Smith College for a scholarship fund to be established in Sarah's honor.

title: Thad Cochran Joins Up
description: President-elect George W. Bush spoke during the campaign about restoring integrity in Washington, and the effort to do just that got a big boost yesterday. But it came from the Senate, not Mr. Bush. In a remarkably important development for the cause of clean elections, Senator Thad Cochran of Mississippi announced that he would join Senators John McCain and Russell Feingold as a sponsor of campaign finance reform. The addition of a respected conservative Republican to the reformers' ranks, along with the new Senate makeup, means that there may be the 60 votes necessary to break the anti-reform filibuster and bring the legislation to a vote. title: Fixing the Drug Import Bill

She had no choice. Under the law, passed earlier this year, she was required to demonstrate that re-importation would pose no health risk and would significantly reduce drug costs for American consumers. Because of loopholes and obstacles built into the law, she could make no such demonstration. Now it is up to Congress to plug the loopholes so that the next secretary can quickly institute the program.

description: The Hartz Mountain Corporation, a leading maker of pet supplies, said yesterday that it had been acquired by its management group, J. W. Childs Associates. Financial terms were not disclosed. The company said in a statement that the transaction gave it cash to develop new products, to expand internationally and to make acquisitions. Hartz, based in Secaucus, N.J., had been closely held by the family of its founder, Max Stern, since 1926, and was most recently run by the founder's grandson, Edward J. Stern. The company's president and chief executive, Robert Devine, will retain his position after the purchase, the company said.

title: BIDDING WAR FOR AUSTRALIAN CARRIER

title: The Battle for Czech TV
description: When Soviet-bloc troops invaded Czechoslovakia to crush the Prague Spring in 1968, the biggest battle of the invasion was to control the country's radio headquarters. The anti-Soviet tone of the medium with the widest reach had been a prime irritant to Moscow. Today Prague's state television station is a battle site, this one a political struggle that underscores not only the media's importance in former Communist nations but also the dangers of coziness between politicians and the press.

title: ENGAGE TO CUT STAFF BY HALF

The company, based in Andover, Mass., is a majority-owned operating company of CMGI. It provides software and services to help Web publishers and marketers manage online advertising campaigns. CMGI, once a leading incubator of Internet companies, has faced its own troubles recently, with the closings of two business units last fall and management departures and layoffs at other CMGI companies, including the search site Alta Vista. Engage's stock rose 5.6 percent while CMGI slipped 4.2 percent. Susan Stellin (NYT)

title: CHRYSLER TO END PRODUCTION OF JEEP CHEROKEE
description: Production of the Jeep Cherokee, the off-road vehicle that ignited the sport utility vehicle craze when it was introduced in 1984, will end this summer, the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler A.G. announced yesterday. A new vehicle of similar size, the Liberty, will replace the Cherokee; Grand Cherokees will remain in production. Chrysler said last year that it would sell the Cherokee and Liberty side by side as long as Cherokees remained popular, but sales of the older vehicle, which has not been substantially updated in 16 years, slid sharply last year. The softening car market in 2001 did not look strong enough to support both models, a company spokesman said. Keith Bradsher (NYT)

title: TEXAS SUES EXXON MOBIL OVER DRILLING ON STATE LAND
description: The Texas attorney general, John Cornyn, said yesterday that the state had sued Exxon Mobil for ''tens of millions of dollars'' for extracting oil and natural gas from state land without authorization. The suit, filed in United States District Court in Houston, said the company, which obtained permission from the state in the 1970's to drill on a parcel of land called Hawkins Field in Wood County in eastern Texas, had strayed onto adjacent state-owned land not covered by its permits. Exxon Mobil spokesmen could not be reached immediately for comment. In December, an Alabama jury ordered Exxon Mobil to pay $3.5 billion in damages after it found the company guilty of defrauding the state of royalties owed on natural gas from wells in state waters; the company is appealing the verdict.

title: Metro Business Briefing; XEROX LAYS OFF 200

The layoffs affect both union and salaried workers, said Christa Carone, a spokeswoman. The move will be completed in six weeks, she said. In December, Xerox laid off 625 workers in the United States and announced 665 additional cuts in Germany. Xerox plans to cut $1 billion in costs and sell up to $4 billion in assets. It has exhausted a $7 billion credit line to finance operations because it has been unable to sell commercial paper, or short-term i.o.u.'s. Competition and a botched reorganization caused the company to report its first quarterly loss in 16 years in October.

description: SULLER-Elsie. Long time director of Camp Kinderland, died on Wednesday at her home in Manhattan where she lived for 45 years. She was 86. Mrs. Suller spent the greater part of her adult life involved in childrens' camp and spoke passionately about the value of a progressive Jewish camp experience for children. As director, she saw the camp through often difficult political and economic times. She never forgot a child and often surprised young men ad women visiting their own children by remembering their names and when they had been at camp. She was beloved by countless friends and neighbors and will be greatly missed. She is survived by her brother Irving Lerner and sister Ruth Ackerman of East Meadow, NY, her daughter, Dina Bray of Hopewell, NJ, and her grandchildren David Silberman of Livingston, NJ, Samantha Bray of New York City and Isaac Bray of Hopewell, New Jersey. The funeral will be held on Sunday, January 7th at 11AM at New Montefiore Cemetery in Long Island. Memorial will be held in Elsie's honor in April. In lieu of flowers, the family has ask that donations be sent to Camp Kinderland at 16 Court Street in Brooklyn, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROGERS, WILLIAM P.
description: ROGERS-William P. Cornell University mourns the loss of a distinguished graduate of its Law School and an exemplary public servant, William P. Rogers. Throughout a remarkable career that embraced a successful private legal practice and government service at the highest levels under Presidents Eisenhower, Nixon, and Reagan, he brought honor to his alma mater. A man of impeccable ethical standards, he became a champion of civil rights and freedom of the press, his actions helped shape the fabric of American life in the second half of the 20th century. At the Cornell Law School Library he met Adele Langston, a fellow law student who would become his wife. He and his family honored Mrs. Rogers by naming the Adele Langston Rogers Atrium and Teaching Wing in Cornell's Lincoln Hall. He served Cornell as a Presidential Councillor, a member of the Law School Advisory Council, and former President of the Cornell Law School Association. The Cornell community will miss his friendship, loyalty, and kindness. We express our sincere condolences to William Roger's wife, Cornell trustee emerita, Adele Langston Rogers, and their children Anthony, Jeffrey, Douglas Rogers and Dale Rogers Marshall, also a trustee emerita of Cornell University. Harold Tanner, Chairman of the Board of Trustees, Cornell University Hunter R. Rawlings, III President, Cornell University

A memorial service is being planned at Barnard for a future date. Judith Shapiro, President of Barnard College

Mr. Fraleigh had been vice president for marketing of colas for the soft-drink and snacks company, a G.M. spokeswoman, Peg Holmes, said. He will start his new job on Monday. Mr. Fraleigh, 37, succeeds Philip Guarascio, who retired in May, and will oversee marketing, planning and media buying for G.M., Ms. Holmes said. title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE GERMAN FACTORY ORDERS SLIDE German manufacturing orders fell 0.9 percent in November from October, the second decline in three months and the latest sign that the euro zone's economic expansion is slowing. Orders for goods ranging from toys to trucks dropped at three times the pace forecast by economists, after rising 3.1 percent the previous month, Finance Ministry figures showed. Germany is the largest economy in the European Union, and the slowdown there makes it likely the European Central Bank will reduce rates in coming months.

title: INTERNET COMPANY TO PAY MORE FOR LOAN

CyberWorks, controlled by Richard Li, above, the son of the Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing, needs the money to help repay a $9 billion loan maturing in February that it used to buy Cable and Wireless HKT in August.

title: BORDERS, THE BOOKSELLER, SEES DOWNTURN IN ITS PROFIT
description: The Borders Group Inc., the second-largest bookseller in the country, said yesterday that its fiscal fourth-quarter profit would be lower than forecast because of price cuts and sales that fell below estimates. The company also said it planned to sell the money-losing All Wound Up toy business. Excluding this unit, profit in the quarter ending Jan. 28 will be 10 percent less than the $1.37 a share that was the average estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial, Borders said. Sales at Borders Books and Music stores open at least a year are forecast to rise 1 percent for the quarter, less than the 3 percent previously estimated. The All Wound Up unit, which sells toys at stores and kiosks in shopping malls, lost $2.4 million in the third quarter.

The company also announced that it would remodel fewer stores next year, spending about $37.5 million on 20 to 25 stores, instead of the $350 million it had planned to invest in 140 stores. Sales last month fell less than the analysts' forecasts of a 5 percent to 10 percent drop because of demand for DVD players and digital cameras, the company said. Circuit City is undergoing its biggest makeover in a decade to quit the appliance business and focus on electronics.

title: VODAFONE DEAL IN MEXICO
description: The Vodafone Group of Britain, the world's largest wireless company, plans to buy a 35 percent stake in Grupo Iusacell, the No. 2 wireless telephone company in Mexico, for $973 million. According to a Iusacell statement, Vodafone reached an accord with the Peralta family and other individual investors to buy their stakes in Iusacell, which is controlled by Verizon Communications, the No. 1 United States local telephone company. Further details of the transactions, which require approval by Mexico's antitrust regulators and shareholders of both Vodafone and Verizon, were not disclosed. Mexico's wireless market is growing fast. The number of wireless users alone doubled last year and is now close to 11 million.

It has become a green refuge where children can discover that ''carrots and beets and collards don't come from the Frigidaire,'' said Verna Lee Judge, one of the original gardeners.

description: With a federal grand jury continuing to investigate collusion between the auction houses of Sotheby's and Christie's, a federal judge yesterday postponed the scheduled sentencing of Diana D. Brooks, the former president and chief executive of Sotheby's Holdings Inc. Ms. Brooks pleaded guilty on Oct. 5 to conspiracy to fix commission rates for auction customers from at least April 1993 through 1999 and agreed to become a government witness against her former superior, A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman and controlling stockholder of Sotheby's. Mr. Taubman, who has denied wrongdoing, has not been charged. Ms. Brooks, 50, faces up to three years in prison and a fine of at least $350,000. Ralph Blumenthal (NYT)

Verizon has total bids of $5.3 billion, the highest among all the auction participants. The government is selling 422 licenses for airwaves that can be used to offer voice and data services.

title: LLOYDS SEEKS CLEARANCE FOR ABBEY DEAL
description: The Lloyds TSB Group filed a proposal with British regulators seeking clearance for its $29.7 billion takeover of Abbey National P.L.C. Abbey National has already rejected Lloyds's overtures twice on grounds that the offer is too low and that the deal will run afoul of regulators. Abbey National is negotiating with its preferred partner, Bank of Scotland, and the pair placed their proposal before regulators in late December. The Lloyds filing is an attempt to hurdle competition issues in the hope that Abbey will be forced to abandon a zero-premium merger with Bank of Scotland in favor of its offer, which values Abbey shares at $:13.85, or 8 percent over the current price. The Office of Fair Trading has until Feb. 2 to decide whether the deal will undermine competition.

title: CANADIAN UNEMPLOYMENT FALLS
description: Canada's unemployment rate dropped to 6.8 percent in December from 6.9 percent in November, as the economy added 31,000 jobs, more than most economists had expected. Manufacturing accounted for most of the gain, but employment in the sector is expected to decline in the first quarter because of cutbacks in the auto industry. In the last year, the Canadian economy added 319,000 jobs, an increase of 2.2 percent, compared with a 3 percent gain in 1999. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: SULZER MEDICA OF EUROPE ADDING INTRATHERAPEUTICS
description: Sulzer Medica A.G., Europe's biggest maker of orthopedic devices, agreed yesterday to pay $145 million in cash for IntraTherapeutics Inc. of the United States to move into the fast-growing market for peripheral stents. The closely held IntraTherapeutics, based in St. Paul, makes the metallic tubes or coils that prop open clogged blood vessels. It reported sales of about $20 million last year, Sulzer Medica said in a statement. The United States market for peripheral stents -- which are used in the legs, trunk, neck or shoulders -- is expected to grow more than 25 percent a year from about $300 million in 1999, it said. Over the last three years, Sulzer of Winterthur, Switzerland, has spent around $840 million on acquisitions in North America.

title: MUSIC; A Faust Story That Resists Goethe's Hold
description: THE story of Faust -- the ambitious scholar who sells his soul to the Devil in exchange for love, experience, knowledge and power -- is an irresistible mirror in which many writers have found their own reflections. The original 16th-century legend, an embellishment on the life of an obscure historical figure, has been retold by Christopher Marlowe, Gotthold Lessing, Nikolaus Lenau, Heinrich Heine, Paul Valery and Thomas Mann, among others. But by far the most famous and influential version is the verse drama by Johann Wolfgang von Goethe.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Lancelot Lionel Ware, b. 1915; The Smarty-Pants King
description: In 1946, Lancelot Ware and Roland Berrill founded the High-I.Q. Club, an association of the very smartest people in Britain. Membership in the organization, soon christened Mensa -- the Latin word for table, since the Latin word for mind, ''mens,'' sounded too much like the name of a dirty magazine -- was open to anyone with a score in the top 2 percent of a standard intelligence test. Initially the group's aims were rather grand. The founders planned to forward a list of the 600 brightest Britons to the government, which could thus have easy access to the best minds in times of crisis.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Expert Opinion on: Robert Trent Jones Sr., b. 1906; Course Work
description: When you ask Jack Nicklaus to choose his favorite hole designed by Robert Trent Jones Sr., his choice is both unsurprising and contentious. ''I'd have to say the fourth at Baltusrol,'' Nicklaus says, the Springfield, N.J., course being the place he captured two of his four United States Opens, in 1967 and 1980. The fourth is a picturesque but almost sinister par 3 that Jones created when he redesigned the course for an earlier Open, in 1954: 195 yards of pure carry over water to a two-tiered green that slopes toward the water and a spiteful little green-side bunker. Standing on its tee, thousands of wary golfers have broken into flop sweat.

Early on a crisp Saturday morning in October, the windowless, womblike room was already packed with students who had marked their places with brightly colored mats. I squeezed into a spot in a back corner underneath an altar to Shiva and beside a tattooed fellow in a black muscle-T who had a kind of Travis Bickle menace.

title: SCHOOL FOR SPECIAL NEEDS
description: A group of parents is raising funds for a new school to meet the needs of students with attention-deficit (hyperactivity) disorder without relying on medication. The school, called the Round Peg School, will be for kindergartners through fourth graders, and is expected to open in September. Classes of no more than eight students will be taught by a special education teacher and an aide. ''We wouldn't turn away a child who's medicated, but we think there are many different techniques, like behavior modification, breathing exercises and yoga that can be helpful for these children,'' said Cathy Sinclair, a parent and one of the school's founders. ''The goal is to get these children back to traditional school.'' Merri Rosenberg

title: As Search Continues for Plane, Skepticism About Crash Grows
description: A day after witnesses said they saw a small single-engine airplane go down into the Hudson River and sink, searchers last night still had found no evidence of a crash and had not received any report of a missing plane.

title: Tonna Again Will Lead Suffolk Legislature
description: Extending a bipartisan coalition in the Suffolk County Legislature, Paul J. Tonna, a West Hills Republican, was elected last week to a second one-year term as presiding officer of the county body.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHINE, BRUCE
description: SHINE-Bruce. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Bruce Shine, associated with The Times from 1981 until 1997.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GORDON, IRVING
description: GORDON-Irving. Retired Senior Operating Engineer of The New York Times. On December 31, 2000 at 92 years in Monroe Township, N.J. Dedicated and loving husband of his late wife Rose and his late partner Gertie. A strong and loyal workingman and a sensitive listener who provided thoughtful counsel to those he loved, lived and worked with. Devoted father to sons Martin, Donald and Allen and daughters-inlaw Lenore, Patricia and Christina. Loving and caring grandfather of Beth, Wendy, Stacey, Peter, Brian, Rachel and Alice. Great-grandfather of Matthew, Zachary, Katy and Noah. Faithful brother to Jenny, Meyer and Celia. Services and burial took place in Delray Beach, Floriada on January 3, 2001.

title: Religious Right Made Big Push To Put Ashcroft in Justice Dept.
description: Within days of Senator John Ashcroft of Missouri's narrow re-election defeat by a candidate who died three weeks before Election Day, religious and conservative leaders began promoting him for a major position in a Bush administration.

title: Not Quite the Last Picture Show, But Owners Are Seeking Capital
description: These days, in the popcorn-scented lobby of the Brooklyn Heights Cinema on Henry Street, a painted scene from the Bruce Willis film ''The Last Man Standing'' is a reminder of the theater's own position as the neighborhood's only movie house standing, as well as of its uncertain future.

title: A Nominal Role for Lipper
description: A. Michael Lipper, a leading voice in the mutual fund industry, has been pushed out of Lipper Inc., the mutual fund research and tracking firm he founded in the 1970's. In 1998, Mr. Lipper, 65, sold his firm to the Reuters Group. Since then, he has had considerably less to do.

title: The Nation; The High-Stakes Politics Of Spending the Surplus
description: PRESIDENT-ELECT GEORGE W. BUSH spent much of last week building support for his tax-cut plan, meeting here with like-minded business executives and asserting that a dose of fiscal stimulus would neatly complement the Federal Reserve's surprise interest rate reduction in the effort to reverse the economy's downturn.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POSSNER, BERNARD MURRAY
description: POSSNER-Bernard Murray. We regret the passing of Bernard Murray Possner of DelRay Beach, FL on Wednesday, January 3, 2001. ''Bernie'', as he was affectionately called, was a resident of the Marine Park section of Brooklyn, NY where he helped found ''The East Highway Little League'' and ''The Kingsway Babe Ruth League.'' He was a distinguished member of the Madison Jewish Center of Brooklyn NY for many years, where his three sons were bar mitzvahed. His memberships in many charitable organizations included the Presidency of the Margorie Bregman Mandel League of the Kingsbrook Medical Center. His affiliation with the Knights of Pythias lasted over 50 years. He is survived by his beloved wife of 59-1/2 years Sylvia, his three sons Harvey, Stuart and Ivan, his ''daughter'' Donna, his two daughters-in-law Sandy and Fran, his seven grandchildren David, Ilana, Marrah, Jamie, Scott, Michelle and Billy, his sisters Henrietta and Sylvia, his beloved brother-in-law Phil, his five nieces Estelle, Joanie, Ronnie, Barbara and Beatrice, and his nephew Steven. He will surely be missed. Rest in peace, sweet prince. Graveside services held today, at 10 AM at Mount Ararat Cemetery, Farmingdale, New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOMON, IRVING
description: SOLOMON-Irving. Age 86, formerly of the Bronx, died January 5. The founder of LEGI Jewelry. He had a smile for and brought a smile to all who knew him. Predeceased by his wife Evelyn. He is survived by his son Lawrence, his daughter Gail and three grandchildren Rachel, Peter and David. Services will be held at noon on Monday, January 8, from the Garlick Riverside Funeral Chapel, 1439 Unionport Rd, Bronx, NY.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: THE 1950's have never looked more elegant -- not to mention bright, shiny and new -- than in Robert Redford's QUIZ SHOW (1994), the story of the decade's television quiz show scandals as experienced by two very different contestants. Ralph Fiennes is glamorous and complex as Charles Van Doren, the gold-boy son and nephew of prominent academics who has qualms about accepting the answers in advance but talks himself into going along with the fix. John Turturro is equally complex as Herb Stempel, the less educated, less dashing outer-boroughs guy who is forced to take a fall, giving up the qui show's championship because his ''ratings have plateaued.'' Paul Scofield is outstanding as Van Doren's father. Paul Attanasio's script is so thoughtful and intelligent that you wonder how it ever made its way, unscathed, into a main stream film -- Thursday at 8 p.m. on Showtime.

title: A New Entree to Bonds
description: Investors may soon have a new way to move into bonds, via exchange-traded funds, or E.T.F.'s. They are similar to mutual funds but trade throughout the day, as stocks do. The dozens of E.T.F.'s now available to United States investors track a variety of stock indexes.

title: GOOD MORNING IN PERU'S 'LOST CITY'
description: HIRAM BINGHAM was not looking for Machu Picchu when he found it. When Bingham, an ambitious Yale archaeologist and future United States senator, led his mule train through the dense jungles of the Peruvian Andes in July 1911, he was searching for Vilcabamba, a legendary stronghold of Inca resistance against Spanish rule.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  OXENBERG, ETTA
description: OXENBERG-Etta. Died peacefully on January 1, her 103rd birthday. Mother to Elliott and Muriel. Grandma to Julia and Ruth. Great grandma to Clea, Ted, Charlie and Tristan. Also survived by Cynthia and Rob. Her optimism, wisdom and humor inspired us all.

title: Missed Connections
description: THE WHITE MAN IN THE TREE And Other Stories. By Mark Kurlansky. 301 pp. New York: Washington Square Press/Pocket Books. $23.95.

title: A Naturalist Takes His Career From Backyard to the Outback
description: WHEN he was a boy growing up here, Edward Kanze had dreams filled with kangaroos, and he would wake up feeling intrigued and pleased.

title: God's Work
description: To Redeem One Person Is To Redeem the World

title: The Nation; Learning the Wrong Lessons -- Again
description: SINCE losing the White House last month, many prominent Democrats are now looking to Bill Clinton as the party's savior, its leader in opposition. Capitol Hill Democrats and many state party chairmen have declared that President Clinton will remain a powerful political player after he leaves office. Even Tony Coehlo, Vice President Al Gore's campaign chairman, predicted that Mr. Clinton ''will be the one the party will depend on to raise money and to be a major force in whatever they're doing across the country.''

title: Help for the Blind and Dyslexic
description: Technology will be enhancing the lives of the 90,000 members of Recording for the Blind and Dyslexic (www.rfbd.org) with digital talking books.

title: CRITICAL BLOOD SHORTAGE
description: The metropolitan area is facing its worst blood shortage in two decades as a result of snowy weather and a sharp drop in donations during the holiday season. Linda Levi, a spokeswoman for the nonprofit New York Blood Center, said the greatest shortages were of Type O-positive blood, with barely a half-day's supply at the blood center. Anyone 18 or older, more than 110 pounds and in good health is eligible to give blood. Walk-in donors are welcome at Hudson Valley Blood Services, 525 Executive Boulevard, Elmsford, on Tuesdays and Thursdays from noon to 6:45 p.m. and on Wednesdays and Saturdays from 7:30 a.m. to 2:15 p.m. Call (800) 933-BLOOD (800-933-2566) to make an appointment. Elsa Brenner

title: FROM THE SCRUB COMES A BEHEMOTH
description: IT'S the next Cancun. The label has stuck on Punta Cana. In the travel trade press. On the tongues of agents. Even in the popular press, it's all you hear about the formerly barren eastern tip of the Dominican Republic. That, and phrases like ''hot spot of the Caribbean'' and ''top emerging international destination.''

title: An Early Fellini Is on Disc; If Only Others of His Were
description: LATE in ''Il Bidone'' (''The Swindle''), Federico Fellini's stark 1955 portrait of confidence men who bilk the poor out of what little money they have, the group's leader, Augusto (Broderick Crawford), begins addressing the matter of his conscience, which had never troubled him until recently, when by chance he ran into the daughter he had abandoned.

title: Hunker Down for Winter
description: Plants that thrive in windows facing east or west in spring and summer will languish if left there at this time of year. Move them to south-facing windows or supplement weak winter light with full spectrum artificial light.

title: Battling the Cheats
description: Early in the fall semester, a professor of American studies at Cornell found a three-page paper on the Internet analyzing a poem by Anne Bradstreet. A student in his course had just handed in that very paper. Accused of plagiarism, the student confessed that she had taken the paper from an Anne Bradstreet Web site. She had locked herself out of her apartment the night before the paper was due, she said, and without access to her notes had panicked.

title: Off the Stage and on the Screen, Stories With Rhythm
description: IN a dance lover's perfect world, dance films would turn up on television and at movie theaters as regularly as comedies and thrillers. After all, they're equally engrossing -- at least to most people in the field. The challenge is making everyone else see the light.

title: L.I.R.R. Chief's Rude Welcome: Safety Concerns; Fire and Crime Issues Steal Attention From Bauer's Focus on Customer Comfort
description: FIRST came the fires on the Long Island Rail Road's new locomotives, then the report that the East River rail tunnels were little better than firetraps. Finally was the announcement that crime on L.I.R.R. trains, platforms and parking lots was soaring.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MANTELL, MAY
description: MANTELL-May. 86, died peacefully December 28, while she slept. A perpetual teacher and student, fascinated by the world around her, her infinite curiosity and zest would always have made it seem too soon. Wife of the late Seymour Mantell, survived by her son Alan Mantell married to Laura Lewis Mantell, sister Dina Metraux, sister-in-law Jane Otten married to Alan Otten, six nieces and nephews and countless friends. At her request, no funeral is planned. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Planned Parenthood.

title: Hotel in Angkor
description: To the Editor: The article brought to mind the experiences we had in October 1991. The Grand Hotel d'Angkor was pretty run down. The electricity was turned on only twice a day, one hour in the morning and one in the evening. The rest of the time, guests had to use candles or a flashlight. There was no air-conditioning and you could not open the windows for fear of mosquitoes or other insects.

title: Illegal Immigrant Lived With Chavez
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7  For at least a year in the early 1990's, Linda Chavez, President-elect George W. Bush's choice for labor secretary, had an illegal immigrant from Guatemala living in her home, Bush officials said today.

title: An Old-Fashioned Leather Bar Looks for a Good Home
description: The Eagle Open Kitchen has anchored the corner of 21st Street and 11th Avenue since 1931, first as a pub for longshoremen seeking cheap drinks and instant company, and since the 1960's as a leather bar for gay men seeking much the same. At its height in the 1970's, the Eagle was considered the best of a string of S-and-M spots on the block, including the Spike Bar and the Glory Hole. Its popularity even sparked more than 30 imitators across the country, with Eagles still thriving in Tampa, Milwaukee and elsewhere.

title: In Defense Post, Infighter Known for Working the Means to His End
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 7  Donald H. Rumsfeld, the Bush choice for secretary of defense, will come to the job with a history of having filled it once before, a history marked by sharp disputes with a forceful secretary of state. So one of the most tantalizing questions about the new national security team is whether Mr. Rumsfeld will collide again, this time with the four-star general who is the Bush choice for secretary of state, Gen. Colin L. Powell.

description: REED-Kurtis. On January 5, 2001, at age 96. Beloved husband of Clara and the late Mary D. Reed. Loving father of the late Catherine Reed King. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Sunday, 1-5 and 7-9 PM, with service on Monday at 1:30 PM. Interment to follow at Ferncliff Cemetery.

title: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; Farewell, Doomed Dome
description: The Millennium Dome has closed, and probably the only people not celebrating are the editors of Britain's opportunistic press, who may have to wait another thousand years to find a target as inviting as this gargantuan government project that was ill conceived, overhyped and underattended. ''The media demon pranced hysterically and gleefully over its roof each day of the year,'' said Simon Jenkins, a columnist for London's Evening Standard. The $1.2 billion project pulled in less than half the 12 million customers forecast. ''Final Act in Dome's Year of Disasters,'' The Daily Telegraph said. Warren Hoge

title: Britain Follows the Exploits of a Folk Hero
description: At one time there was only one person in the world who was universally recognizable to sailors everywhere by just his first name: Dennis. But in Britain, at least, the America's Cup veteran Dennis Conner now has first-name-status competition from a slight, enthralling 24-year-old woman whose name is on everyone's lips.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: The Rev. Jesse Jackson; The Moviegoer
description: THE Rev. Jesse Jackson is well known for his role as social activist, less so as film critic. But the former morphed on Wednesday night into the latter, then the former again, as Mr. Jackson switched parts adroitly, even passionately -- and in the process exposed his inner Roger Ebert.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01; What He Saw
description: Jan Karski, b. 1914 In the summer of 1942, Jan Karski, a Polish-Catholic diplomat, went under cover to investigate conditions in the Warsaw Ghetto on behalf of the Polish underground and provided some of the first eyewitness accounts to reach the West. The excerpt that appears below was first published in March 1943. Karski died in July.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Mark R. Hughes, b. 1956; Death Be Not a Punch Line
description: Any writing teacher worth her or his salt might advise a lighter touch with the story of Mark R. Hughes, the founder of Herbalife, the hugely successful nutritional supplement corporation. Must this guru of natural health, a man who gained the trust and support of millions of people worldwide, really succumb at the barely middle age of 44 from an accidental and lethal combination of alcohol and the antidepressant and sleeping aid Doxepin? As for the life before the death -- the Beverly Hills mansion named Grayhall, the additional 157-acre parcel of land in Benedict Canyon purchased from none other than Merv Griffin, the glamorous 35-year-old widow who counts among her other erstwhile spouses the action-movie star Jean-Claude Van Damme -- it seems more the province of the evening soaps than the everyday. The accretion of all this too-perfect detail threatens to tip over into mere glibness.

title: The Tupperware Queen
description: When Tupperware parties were last in vogue, women drove station wagons and served guests Coke in bottles. Fifty years on, parties are still the main sales channel for Tupperware, and there are over 70,000 sales agents. (Consultants, please; never Tupperware ladies.) One of them, Brini Maxwell, just happens to be a drag queen. For a Tupperware party at the apartment of Chad Evans, a clothing designer, Ms. Maxwell donned a polyester shirtdress and a flippy blond wig and trilled to a group of mostly gay men: ''Look at this marvelous pitcher in mint green. It's so cleverly designed.'' She praised Tupperware's ''brilliant modular mates that stop cabinet clutter'' and encouraged the crowd to order products. The party netted $199 in sales, with Mr. Evans receiving $15 in free Tupperware for serving as host and Ms. Maxwell earning a 35 percent commission. Ms. Maxwell, the alter ego of Ben Sander, got her Tupperware start two years ago at a benefit for the Lesbian and Gay Community Center. Ever since, she has sold Tupperware at bridal showers and gatherings in apartments and bars. Hosts book her online at brinimaxwell.com. ''People like Tupperware parties because they're fun and silly,'' she said. ''They remind you of your youth, when your mother or aunt had them. Besides, everyone could use Tupperware.'' KAREN ROBINOVITZ

title: In the Region/Long Island; A Spate of New Projects for Those Age 55 and Older
description: AS the first of the nation's baby boomers prepare to celebrate their 55th birthdays, a number of developers are seeing an opportunity in the growing market geared to older people looking to downsize their homes yet maintain an upscale way of life.

title: Just Like Old Times, Raiders Thump the Dolphins
description: In a stadium box overlooking a mass of Raider fans dressed in Hell's Angels attire, peering through eyeglasses left over from the early Elton John era, Al Davis must have been reveling in the revival playing out in front of him.

title: Commack Still Won't Share With Smithtown
description: In 1984, the Commack Public Library began barring residents of neighboring Smithtown from borrowing its books because they were overrunning the library. A decision late last month by Richard P. Mills, the state education commissioner, will keep that ban in effect for another year.

title: Let 70,000 Canvases Bloom in the Art World
description: IMAGINE that you are a retailer with products to sell. You display them in the most intimidating environment possible, staffing each of your imposing outlets with a single, icy concierge dressed in regulation black. Customers with the temerity to venture inside will typically find the goods priced beyond their means -- if they can muster the nerve to ask for price sheets.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SAMUELS, JUDITH
description: SAMUELS-Judith. The Men's Club of Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York expresses deep sorrow at the untimely death of our administrative assistant, Judy Samuels. She will be missed but never forgotten. Martin A. Danoff, President

title: For Sale: Stabilized Rental Unit
description: Q During the apartment conversion craze in the 1980's, I bought two occupied apartments in Queens. Both are rent-stabilized, and the occupants pay their rent to me. As my children are now ready to attend college, I need to sell these units to help to pay tuition. The occupants are not ready to move since the rents are low compared with others in the area. What would be the most prudent course to take to sell these apartments? . . . Garry O. Kosteck, Dunellen, N.J.

title: BLACK BOARD: Lessons for Life Through the Arts; College Students Find Who's a Good Macbeth Among the Fifth Graders
description: Children who have waded through their fair share of comics and cartoons probably know the phrase, ''double, double toil and trouble.'' But few can trace those words to the witches in ''Macbeth.'' Not so for fifth graders at the Bache Martin School in the Fairmount district of Philadelphia.

title: Selling Advice in a Down Market
description: This would not seem like an opportune time to publish a book on the stock market, much less one with ''Internet'' in the title. But Dave Kansas, editor in chief of TheStreet.com, the investing Web site, disagrees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DALL, MARK HEALEY
description: DALL-Mark Healey. Of Leeds Mass and Sedona Ariz. Died December 28, 2000 in his 86th year. Husband of Pauline Kingsland Dall, father of Hester, Whitney, Eliza and Sara. Also survived by nine grandchildren. Services private. Interment Mount Auburn Cemetery, Brookline Mass. in June. Memorial donations may be made to the Alaska Natury Conservancy, 421 W. 1st St, Anchorage, Ak. 49501.

title: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; Health Care Losses and Gains
description: Hundreds of thousands of Medicare beneficiaries were left in the lurch by health maintenance organizations pulling out of the program. Some elderly and disabled patients have enrolled in other H.M.O.'s. Many returned to Medicare's fee-for-service program, but lost prescription benefits and cannot easily afford private insurance to fill the gaps.

title: City Guides by Phone Or Handheld Computer

Wcities, a privately held travel information service based in London, in late November began providing wireless users with a simpler version of the data on its site, wcities.com. The company has information on 245 cities worldwide.

description: THE work of 35 recipients of grants from the New Jersey State Council on the Arts makes up an exhibition now at the Hunterdon Museum of Art. For all the diversity that necessarily characterizes such a show, looking at it is a pleasurable experience -- in part because the museum's curator, Kristen Accola, has installed it with plenty of room around each work. It's a condition that encourages contemplation.

title: FIVE QUESTIONS for CHARLES S. GIAMBUSSO; Delta's Labor Troubles: View From the Cockpit
description: THE storms that jolted much of the country over the New Year's holiday hit Delta Air Lines particularly hard. Because many of its pilots have declined to fly voluntary overtime, Delta said it was forced to cancel hundreds of flights, stranding thousands of passengers.

title: A Tonic For the Harried

title: Murders Touch a Town's Soul
description: GUILFORD, a quiet town along the state's shoreline, has had to deal with a type of event that hasn't happened in town since about the time President John F. Kennedy was killed. Two days after Christmas, a mother and two of her young children were found murdered in their home, stabbed repeatedly.

title: Sophisticated Newcomer in Huntington
description: RED says city. This sophisticated new Huntington restaurant has the Manhattan look down pat. The butter yellow dining room is ringed with high back, royal blue banquettes. Framed mirrors sail above the seating. The restaurant's namesake color is used as an accent: bright buttons on the banquettes, tomato-hued glass holders for votive candles and fire-engine-red wooden wine bins, which form a whole wall.

title: ANCIENT SYMBOLS IN THE SAND
description: IN the southern desert of Peru there exists a puzzling expanse of hundreds of geoglyphs, or earth drawings, known as the Nazca lines. They cover a 200-square-mile area and consist both of geometric designs and a varied group of huge figures that depict animals, birds, fish and insects. Because of their size -- the smallest animal figure is 80 feet long, while the largest, a stylized heron, is 900 feet -- the designs are best seen from the air. Though they are presumed to have been created by the Nazca Indians around 2,000 years ago, little is known about their purpose or meaning. And because of the lack of an agreed upon, credible explanation, the Nazca lines have ascended to the pantheon of the unexplained to join ranks with the face on Mars and the Loch Ness monster.

title: Hotel in Angkor
description: To the Editor: My wife and I recently visited both the Grand Hotel d'Angkor and Angkor Wat. A few points: the bustling airport was basically a runway and a shack; the immigration officers were three people armed with AK-47's, who inspected bags. There is a horde of drivers outside clamoring for your luggage, and it is wise to call ahead for pickup service.

title: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; Quick Getaways
description: What is it about the Jets that makes coaches flee? Bill Parcells left the job to become general manager a year ago, handing off to his designated successor, Bill Belichick. But he lasted little more than 24 hours on the job, spooked toward New England by worries about who the next owner would be. Enter Al Groh, another Parcells lieutenant, who made it only 11 months, resigning suddenly to coach at his alma mater, the University of Virginia. With Parcells' future with the franchise undecided, there is no new coach in sight. The next will be the seventh since 1990. Perhaps candidates should be asked to leave their E-Z Passes at the door. Judy Battista

title: OUT THERE: Los Angeles; Youth and Beauty With Your Drink, Sir?
description: IN a city obsessed with appearances, it is not enough to give a party in your dazzling home in the hills above Hollywood, complete with power guests. Now, even the help must be camera-ready. ''They want beauty, they want attractive young people behind the bar, passing the trays, and that's what I give them,'' said Ana Gallegos, the president of Beautiful Bartenders, which supplies servers and hostesses for parties to the likes of Paramount Studios, Warner Brothers and the actress Jennifer Lopez.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURSTEIN, JUDGE BEATRICE S.
description: BURSTEIN-Judge Beatrice S. Born on May 18, 1915, died in the early hours of January 6, 2001, of natural causes after a long life of distinction and grace. Widow of the accomplished attorney Herbert Burstein, she was greatly loved and is deeply grieved by her daughters and sons, Karen, Ellen, Patricia, Jessica, John and Judd Burstein, her grandchildren Devin and Lucas Burstein, and her sister Helen Deutsch. After a private graveside funeral service on Monday, January 8, her children will sit shiva at 62 Causeway, Lawrence, NY, the family home. A memorial service will be held at 1 PM, on Sunday, January 14, 2001, at Temple Israel of Lawrence, 140 Central Ave, Lawrence, NY.

He was born in England, not Ireland.

Many works by Tchaikovsky have earned a place in the orchestral pantheon: think of his fourth, fifth and sixth symphonies. His violin concerto and his piano concerto are universally familiar, and the ballets -- ''Swan Lake,'' ''Sleeping Beauty'' and ''The Nutcracker'' -- are definitive scores. title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Making It Neu
description: Germany was a center of modern advertising, typography and book production between 1900 and 1933. Before the rise of the Nazis, German graphic arts were the most progressive of any industrialized nation and the most influential elsewhere in Europe. Designers ''sought to raise the standards of printed culture by integrating experimental ideas from avant-garde art,'' Jeremy Aynsley writes in GRAPHIC DESIGN IN GERMANY, 1890-1945 (University of California, $60), the first comprehensive study of German commercial graphics. The field of graphic design (which includes logo, poster, typeface, magazines and books) owes its stature to three German designers. Peter Behrens, the father of modern corporate identity, developed the first standardized corporate logo system for AEG, the leading German electrical company. Lucian Bernhard invented a new advertising method known as the sachplakat, or ''object poster,'' which emphasized the simple eye-catching rendering of a product rather than the turgid texts and uninspired images so common in advertising at that time. Jan Tschichold codified the neue Typographie, or ''new typography,'' characterized by asymmetrical composition, the use of bold, sans-serif letter forms and primary colors. These ideas forever altered commercial art's form and function through the rest of the century and led directly to the International style after World War I. The Bauhaus, the innovative design academy the Nazis would close down in 1933, flourished, and contemporary design styles were adopted by German industry. Germany was a magnet for iconoclastic applied artists from Russia, Eastern Europe and Italy. And Aynsley artfully details the rise and fall of the German graphic profession from the early period of decorative jugendstil (art nouveau) to the introduction of Nazi propaganda, which assailed progressive design as ''degenerate art.'' Steven Heller
