title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Fred Kelly, b. 1916; Teaching Ike to Tap
description: During the winter of 1944, the company of ''This Is the Army'' returned to London to perform for General Eisenhower. Except for Irving Berlin, who had conceived and written the music and who sang his World War I hit ''Oh! How I Hate to Get Up in the Morning'' at the end of the second act, all of the singers, dancers and musicians who performed in the show, as well as the stagehands and technical crew, were soldiers. Before the war, they had been hoofers and chorus boys and set-builders and radio stars; now they were a commissioned company of the United States Army. As they toured the theaters of the war, boosting Allied morale, they traveled like soldiers, on troop trains and in the cold bellies of C-47's. They were housed in barracks and tents. Nevertheless, theirs was, militarily and theatrically, a pretty unusual unit. It was integrated -- the only integrated company in the Army. And all of the gal parts in the show were played, with considerable gusto and art, by men.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Tito Puente, b. 1923; The Mambo King
description: In 1966, at the age of 15, I was a member of a rock group in the South Bronx. There were five of us -- three Puerto Ricans, a Polish drummer and me, a quiet, somewhat music-stricken Cuban-American who played a cheap Kay electric guitar. We used to practice our songs in the basement of a tenement off 169th Street and Third Avenue. Our leader was a quite handsome and rail-thin fellow from Ponce, a dapper dresser given over to an Elvis Presley conk, white, golden-buckled shoes and tight black chinos, which his mother or sister had adorned with sequins. His name was Santiago, and although he had recently arrived from the island and did not speak much English, he seemed to know the lyrics to the three-chord songs in which we, with our limited musical knowledge, specialized -- songs like ''Do You Love Me?'' and ''Hang On Sloopy'' and ''La Bamba.''

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01
description: This is the seventh edition of ''The Lives They Lived,'' the magazine's annual tribute to remarkable lives that ended over the course of the previous 12 months. Some years are defined by the famous figures whose passing unites the country and even the world. But this past year was perhaps more memorably defined by the passing of certain ideas: the eschatological promise of the Y2K bug, the supposed invincibility of the dot-com revolution, the limitless trajectory of Clinton-era prosperity, the pristine certainty of the electoral process. And the people whose stories united us were ones we'd never before heard of: the 17 victims of the U.S.S. Cole bombing; the 7 employees of Edgewater Technology, where Michael McDermott opened fire; the 118 sailors of the doomed Russian submarine, whose fading distress signals went unanswered as the world counted down their final days.

description: To the Editor: Like the author of your Angkor article, Mark Landler, I have returned from Angkor, but I must point out there are ways to experience Cambodia other than staying in the two luxury hotels. My travel partner and I stayed at a clean and friendly guest house just off of Siem Reap's main thoroughfare. There I met some people who were visiting Angkor and others who were helping to rebuild Cambodia's infrastructure after years of tumult and destruction. Our accommodation put us in the middle of daily Cambodian life, and we were able to soak up all of that local flavor for $20 per night.

description: IF Samuel Johnson were to rise from his tomb and repeat his claim that a man who is tired of London is tired of life, he could expect a clout on his eminent head. The good doctor didn't have to cope with traffic jams, a failing subway system and the other life-denying things that make modern metropolitans yearn to be ploughmen or milkmaids. Yet one can be tired of London and excited by ''Life x 3.'' This new play by Yasmina Reza at the National Theater is tough, vivid stuff, as fine as anything the French-Iranian author of ''Art'' and ''The Unexpected Man'' has written.

title: NEWARK APPOINTMENT

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Ella Goldberg Wolfe, b. 1896; A Tale of Three Centuries
description: Ella Wolfe, who died last January at the age of 103, was the last survivor of the generation that brought the American Communist movement into existence, convinced they had found the gateway to an earthly paradise. They were mistaken, of course, and many a penitent true believer would lapse into morbid atonement. But Ella and her husband, Bertram D. Wolfe, chose a different route, becoming avid chroniclers of the cause they had served so long. Bert wrote books on Communism that are models of energetic scholarship, while Ella, his indispensable partner for six decades, emerged in her last years as a staunch Reaganite as well as a walking archive of the Old Left.

title: The Impenetrable That Leads to the Sublime
description: THE German artist Wolfgang Laib is very sure that art is a mystical experience, and that it has the capacity to change mankind. He says so at every opportunity, quietly and insistently. And his work makes the point with astonishing modesty at the Hirshhorn Museum in Washington, where ''Wolfgang Laib: A Retrospective'' is on view through Jan. 22 before traveling to five cities in the United States and Europe.

title: A Composer Ready to Paint the Town Red
description: MICHAEL HERSCH writes music in the shape of an arch. Typically, he begins a piece slowly, on a long-held note or chord. One by one, methodically and deliberately, another is added and another, like new layers of stone. Soon an idea of structure is in place, and the odyssey begins, punctuated with bursts of intensity the composer idiosyncratically calls ''codas,'' arranged on a curve of mounting intensity. At the far end, after manifold adventures, the material turns back on itself, coming home to a hard-won calm, steeped in recollection.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Peggy McMartin Buckey, b. 1926; The Devil in The Nursery
description: When you once believed something that now strikes you as absurd, even unhinged, it can be almost impossible to summon that feeling of credulity again. Maybe that is why it is easier for most of us to forget, rather than to try and explain, the Satanic-abuse scare that gripped this country in the early 80's -- the myth that Devil-worshipers had set up shop in our day-care centers, where their clever adepts were raping and sodomizing children, practicing ritual sacrifice, shedding their clothes, drinking blood and eating feces, all unnoticed by parents, neighbors and the authorities.

On New Year's Eve at Trenton's War Memorial Theater, Mr. Tuozzolo played a 12-bar solo of Glenn Miller's ''In the Mood,'' then dropped his trumpet and collapsed, suffering a heart attack, said John Peter Holly, director and conductor. Craig Smith, principal French horn player, called 911 on his cell phone while Donald Brodie, a doctor and cellist in the orchestra, tried resuscitating Mr. Tuozzolo, 57. ''He passed at a young age, but he went in a way that was most appropriate for him,'' said his wife, Jacquie. The orchestra's next performance, on March 18, will be in remembrance of Mr. Tuozzolo. title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Eating Her Way Out
description: Nothing surprises us in dreams, Jean Cocteau said. But LEFT-HANDED DREAMS (Delphinium, $20), Francesca Duranti's new novel, is both full of surprises and a dream of a book; it never stops awakening you to the world. It begins in Italy, the country where Martina Satriano was born and to which she has returned to visit her ailing mother. Alas, at the very moment Martina's plane from New York touches down, her mother dies and Martina spends the rest of the novel pondering what she calls ''destiny's perfect timing.'' Ponder, in fact, is pretty much all this troubled soul does. A college professor, Martina is so fond of abstraction that she turns chaos into curlicues, formlessness into philosophy. Unable to form a satisfactory relationship because of her obsession with a long-dead affair, she would be a dreadfully unsympathetic character were it not for the fact that her self-absorption is tempered by self-awareness. Even as Martina laboriously records her dreams for her college research, it is clear that she wants out of this entropic reverie. One of her favorite routes of escape is food, and the book is larded with culinary detail (in a kind of appendix, Martina even gives us a few of her favorite recipes; I can vouch for the gteau des adieux). Duranti's otherwise unruffled prose stirs itself into action as it describes a cluster of mushrooms, a whiff of mint or even Julia Child preparing a tarte Tatin on TV -- evanescent, rapturous moments that turn life and dreams inside out and, finally, pull Martina through. Christopher Bray

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Julie London, b. 1926; The Echo Chamber
description: All the lights were out in Julie London's Encino house on the day, two years ago, when her housekeeper ushered me in. As my eyes adjusted to the darkness, I saw a woman glaring at me from a wheelchair in the next room. London had suffered a stroke, but she still looked beautiful. Her tawny hair, streaked with gray, lay in soft, neat waves on her shoulders. Her nails were perfectly manicured. Her posture was straight and regal. I told her I wanted to interview her. In an achingly slow, deliberate motion, she picked up her Carlton Menthol 100's and shook the pack until a filter tip extended toward me. I had quit years ago, but I took it. I wasn't about to tell her no.

title: 'The Constant Gardener'
description: The news hit the British High Commission in Nairobi at nine-thirty on a Monday morning. Sandy Woodrow took it like a bullet, jaw rigid, chest out, smack through his divided English heart. He was standing. That much he afterwards remembered. He was standing and the internal phone was piping. He was reaching for something, he heard the piping so he checked himself in order to stretch down and fish the receiver off the desk and say, "Woodrow." Or maybe, "Woodrow here." And he certainly barked his name a bit, he had that memory for sure, of his voice sounding like someone else's, and sounding stroppy: "Woodrow here," his own perfectly decent name, but without the softening of his nickname Sandy, and snapped out as if he hated it, because the High Commissioner's usual prayer meeting was slated to start in thirty minutes prompt, with Woodrow, as Head of Chancery, playing in-house moderator to a bunch of special-interest prima donnas, each of whom wanted sole possession of the High Commissioner's heart and mind.

title: T-Bone and Sympathy
description: For the near-sighted and the cold-blooded, there is physical comfort at Azul, a restaurant that opened in December at the Mandarin Oriental, a Miami hotel. The staff offers people who cannot read the fine print on the menu reading glasses in four degrees of magnification -- 1, 1.5, 2 and 2.5. Women shivering from the air-conditioning or the breeze on the terrace can wrap themselves in a silk and pashmina shawl, also supplied by the restaurant, in red, black, champagne, pink or blue. ''You can match the shawl with your clothes,'' said Alain Ricci, the manager of Azul, who had the bright idea of offering the glasses and shawls.

title: Yuletide to Just Plain Tide
description: What to do with that dried-out, drooping Christmas tree? The shore towns of Margate and Wildwood Crest, under a program initiated by the state Department of Environmental Protection, take trees picked up curbside, strip them of ornamentation and ''replant'' them on the beach. In Margate, trees are driven trunk down into the sand, where they act as a bulwark against beach erosion. In Wildwood, the trees are tied into clumps that rapidly fill with wind-blown sand and create dunes that form a natural barrier against storms. ''It helps protect the beachfront,'' said Wildwood Crest's public works superintendent, Don Twist. ''The natural grass covers them, and the effect is quite nice. You'd never know the dunes were man-made.'' This month Mr. Twist expects to distribute bundles of more than 100 trees in four locations along the 1,000-foot-wide Wildwood Crest beach. Bill Kent

title: CHERRY HILL: VLASIC PICKLES

Vlasic, which markets pickles under the Vlasic and other names and also makes Swanson TV dinners and Open Pit barbecue sauces, was spun off from Camden-based Campbell Soup Company in March 1998. Vlasic has lost money since being spun off and last monthr announced a first-quarter loss of $148.9 million. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TONKONOGY, EUGENE
description: TONKONOGY-Eugene. On December 30, at age 95. Admired and mourned by family and friends. Born in Brooklyn, one of ten siblings including publisher-philanthropist George T. Delacorte and playwright of Broadway comedies Gertrude Tonkonogy. Graduated Cornell University and Columbia Law. Husband of Ruth Horowitz. Resided in Manhattan and East Hampton. Founding member of East Hampton Tennis Club and prominent in social scene. A real estate specialist with prescient eye for real estate gems in Hamptons and Virgin Islands. Attained his dream island, Marina Cay, in British Virgins, previously the subject of ''Our Virgin Island'' by Robb White and subsequently of film starring Sidney Poitier and John Cassavetes. A voracious reader, talented writer of verse, long time Macy's parade clown until age 88, he loved dancing (Fred Astaire style), playing tennis and lightheartedness. He's survived by daughters Susan and Peggy and granddaughter Chloe. Memorial service Thursday, January 11 at 11 AM, Campbell's, 81st St. and Madison Ave., New York City.

title: Food; Raw Power
description: Since this is the first column you read in the Sunday paper (or should be), it is possible that if you act right now -- not when you finish this literary morsel, but right now, midparagraph, dropping everything where you stand, yes, the whole tome, even though it may be a Saturday midnight, 12 degrees below, or a Sunday morn with visions of brunch dancing in your head like sugarplums -- and yard it over to a produce supplier, there's a good chance you can still just barely get one or a dozen of nature's most electrically colored and yet subtly flavored fruits, the persimmon. And not incidentally, you will be able to get a healthy dose of Schadenfreude by leaving in the dust your friends who foolishly turn to The Week in Review section first. If your greengrocer is out of persimmons, demand that he or she get a pile by sunup tomorrow (or an equally melodramatic time line) because their season ends this month -- may end . . . right NOW! -- unless you're on the West Coast, where it ended last month.

When it was over, he had tied the world record. ''He won the race in 1:49,'' said Catello (Catman) Manzi, his veteran driver. ''And I'm sure that day he could have gone in 1:48 and a piece. He was winning by so many I just let him ease up in the end. He did it all completely on his own.''

title: Together Again
description: The end of a marriage is bound to leave someone unhappy. Orpheus Chamber Orchestra fans in New Jersey did not know what to expect when the ensemble's longtime relationship with the Montclair-based Unity Concerts ended in 1999. But the conductor-less orchestra never totally abandoned its ties to the area and has presented premieres of programs in New Jersey before taking them to New York, as it did last month with the flute soloist James Galway. It is the Morristown Community Theater's turn to welcome Orpheus (right) this Thursday at 8 p.m. The newly renovated space a jazz musician once described as a hug from the audience plays host to the intimate ensemble in a potpourri of Viennese-flavored works from Beethoven's ''Symphony in C Major'' to Webern's ''Five Movements for String Orchestra'' plus a Copland dessert, his ''Three Latin American Sketches.'' The English pianist Imogen Cooper plays Mozart's ''Concerto for Piano and Orchestra in G Major'' in her first appearance with the orchestra. The program will be repeated at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 20. title: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; Ferry Diplomacy
description: Taiwan tried mollifying China by letting a couple of boatloads of people, liquor and peanut candy sail across the few miles of choppy water that separate the tiny islands of Quemoy and Matsu from the Chinese mainland. The gesture was a far cry from the artillery shells the two sides traded over the islands in the 1950's. But China, which wants the main island of Taiwan to open its ports to the mainland, merely sniffed. Taiwan is worried that fuller direct links could eventually subjugate its economy to the mainland's and undercut Taipei's independence. Beijing has already made the next move in this decades-old chess game: it has invited a delegation of Taiwan's opposition lawmakers to discuss broader trade and travel links. Craig S. Smith

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Frederic Cassidy, b. 1907; A Man Of Many Words
description: Although Fred Cassidy -- linguistic historian, detective and bard -- was a colleague of mine, I didn't really know him. When I first arrived at the University of Wisconsin 16 years ago as an assistant professor, soon dividing my year between the futon on a friend's Madison sun porch and a sparsely furnished Hell's Kitchen rat shop 900 miles east, Professor Cassidy had long been a distinguished figure in the English department. Already officially emeritus, an eminence, a spritely and regal widower who lived atop a hill in a stately brick home coveted by a perennially househunting friend of mine, he presided over what the department called DARE well before the acronym took on its current drug-awareness meaning. DARE -- the Dictionary of American Regional English -- was a gargantuan decades-long project then housed several offices down from mine and always spoken of in astonished and reverential tones. My first week of teaching, I was shown the closed door of the busy DARE office and told solemnly, ''They are still only on C.''

The obvious answer is no, because the instant patrons sit down at their tables 8 or 10 bowls of rustic, garlicky starters are plunked down before them. Crunchy broccoli; aromatic escarole; mussels posillippo; plump meatballs; stuffed shrimp; deep-fried rice balls; garlic-flecked roasted red peppers; stuffed artichokes; olives; three-bean salad; sweet-potato strips; an onion, pea, mushroom mix; soft oniony potato salad with walnuts; and marinated, dilled zucchini are among the 12 or 15 rotating possibilities included in this automatically served Roman antipasto.

title: Elegant Movement In Hot Surroundings

Fierce lime green edges generic white kitchen cupboards, while sunburst yellow and mellow burgundy play on the walls of the simple little apartment in a trendy section of central Montreal, reminders of the surrealistic contrasts in his choreography for his company, Flak.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Screamin' Jay Hawkins, b. 1929; Papa Was A Rolling Stone
description: In February, the rhythm and blues singer Screamin' Jay Hawkins died in Paris of complications from an aneurysm. Shortly before his death, he revealed to his friend and biographer, Maral Nigolian, that he believed he had fathered at least 57 children, and asked her to find them. In an effort to do so, in March she started Jayskids.com. To date, she has been contacted by hundreds of people who claim that Hawkins is their father; she has confirmed that 33 of them are indeed his offspring, and in February she plans to hold a family reunion for them. Here, Alix Spiegel talks with Nigolian and two of Screamin' Jay's kids, Deborah Roe, 46, and Sookie Hawkins, 50, Screamin' Jay's first child by his first marriage.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: John V. Lindsay, b. 1921: Pierre Elliott Trudeau, b. 1919; When Charisma Was King
description: John Vliet Lindsay, the mayor of New York City from 1966 to 1973, who died at the age of 79 on Dec. 19, was never what he appeared to be. He looked rich, but he wasn't. He also looked smarter than he actually was. He seemed the most vulnerable and accessible of men walking the mean streets of his time, but that was an act -- a noble act, but still an act. He was a cool and distant man, the kind who could understand wit but not humor. He was the ultimate WASP, and he proved it by insisting that the acronym should be ASP because all Anglo-Saxons are white.

title: QUICK BITE/Highland Park; Good Spot for Doughnuts, Bad for B.L.T.'s
description: Under the heading ''Lunch Sandwiches'' behind the counter at the Dunkin' Donuts shop on Raritan Avenue in Highland Park, there are empty spaces where once were listed ''tuna salad'' and ''egg salad,'' and before that, ham, bacon and sausage. This Dunkin' Donuts is kosher; everything is prepared under strict supervision. Ramesh (Ray) Patel bought the franchise in 1988, and when he tried to sell it in 1991, found no takers. He conferred with local residents and realized that his was mainly a Jewish neighborhood, a largely observant one at that. So he did what any good businessman does: having found the need, he filled it. That meant serving only kosher food, hence no meat (as the place served dairy), and certainly not bacon, ham or sausage. But there still were kosher bagels, coffee, doughnuts, muffins and egg and cheese sandwiches. Then he introduced kosher tuna salad and egg salad. They were big sellers, but the Dunkin' Donuts corporate hierarchy stepped in and forbade him from buying the salads because they did not come from company-approved vendors. Mr. Patel is awaiting the outcome of the legal challenge of the same edict by kosher Dunkin' Donuts in Elizabeth and Teaneck. Mr. Patel, who spends his afternoons as a civil engineer in Woodbridge, says that 1,100 to 1,200 people are served daily in the 24-hour operation. The shop also sells kosher dougnuts, bagels and other food to Jewish schools and institutions. Norm Oshrin

Who was unmoved at Anna Karenina's despair? But things have changed, and this deep engagement is now rare. Passion is largely absent from our books: an icy chill has crept across the writer's landscape.

title: Watching 'Jazz' for Its High Notes and Low
description: For the filmmaker Ken Burns, the history of jazz and American history are inextricable -- the nation's triumphs and defeats, joys and sorrows have all found echoes in the music. Mr. Burns explores these intertwined histories in ''Jazz,'' his 10-part, 19-hour documentary, which will be broadcast on PBS this month, beginning tomorrow. Is the Burns series a fair representation of jazz? The question was put to musicians and others in the jazz world, who were provided with tapes of the series. Following are their responses.

title: Graduates; Saying No to Public Service
description: Robert L. Hutchings, who as a member of the National Security Council and as ambassador at large to Eastern Europe had the ear of Presidents Ronald Reagan, George Bush and Bill Clinton, has one of the most difficult jobs in academia today.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLENN, RUTH (NEE ROSENBLUM)
description: GLENN-Ruth (nee Rosenblum). On January 4, 2001, of Rocky Point, LI. Formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved wife of Abraham. Loving mother of Paul and his wife Laura Eisen; Sara Glenn-Levin and her husband Jeff; Joseph and his wife Susan; Philip and his wife Karen; and Adam and his wife Mrinalini Rajwar. Cherished grandmother of Jacob, Melanie, Naomi, Samantha and Matthew. Adored sister of Blanche Weiss of San Diego. A life-long feminist and lover of animals, she will be dearly missed by her extended family and all her friends in New York, Bethlehem, NH and Barbados. Burial private at Calverton National Cemetery.

title: Back Pain? Arthritis? Step Right Up to the Mouse
description: SNAKE-OIL salesmen used to travel the country in wagons demonstrating miracle-cure tonics and ointments. Nowadays, the Internet is being used to help peddle what the federal authorities and nutrition experts say is a rising number of suspect vitamins and supplements, some of which carry the same kinds of outlandish medical claims as in years past.

title: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; Not Quite Like the Old Gore
description: Al Gore may have lacked a theme during his presidential campaign, but he is forging one now.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POPP, ROBERT A.
description: POPP-Robert A. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Robert A. Popp, associated with The Times from 1973 until 1988.

title: An Icon 66 Years Young
description: What is Gloria Steinem, that icon of 1970's feminism, doing on the cover of Bust, a magazine that calls itself the Voice of the New Girl Order? After all, the magazine's co-founder, Debbie Stoller, once referred to Ms. Steinem as a dinosaur. And Bust's readers might not be old enough to remember when Ms. Steinem, gal about town and author of a silvery volume called ''The Beach Book,'' was criticized for wearing Pucci and seducing powerful men.

title: Culpepper and the Vikings Bury the Saints With Big Plays
description: He went to bed on the eve of his first National Football League playoff game still not sure whether he could play. Indeed, Daunte Culpepper's injured ankle and bout with a virus threatened to derail the Minnesota Vikings as much as their sickly defense did.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  YAMINS, FRIEDA K.
description: YAMINS-Frieda K. Artist, teacher, President of Italia Adagio Ltd., at age 76 at home on December 18, 2000, after a long illness. Loving mother of Robert. Sister of Leah Bonovich. Cousin of Roslyn Balk, Shirley Rubinstein, Ruth Peterkin. Aunt and caring friend to many. Service, January 14 at 2 PM, South Nassau Unitarian Universalist Congregation, 228 S. Ocean Ave., Freeport, LI, NY. Memorial contributions may be made to North American Association for the Study of Obesity, 8630 Fenton St., Suite 412, Silver Spring, MD 20910. Inquiries: 718-622-6770.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LERNER, MARILYN ROTHMAN
description: LERNER-Marilyn Rothman. On December 31. A very special lady, Marilyn endowed family and friends with unconditional love, sensitivity, determination and gusto. Her spirit lives on in Joe and Jesse, adored husband and treasured son and her ''kids'' at PS 321. Daughter of the late Rae Sandomirsky, she is also survived by Alfred and Joy Amsel, siblings Shari, Heidi, Nachum and families.

title: Justice for Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: BLACK BOARD: Lessons for Life Through the Arts; An Appreciative Home for That Lovely Noodle Collage
description: Children's art is one of those renewable resources that most parents hate to throw away. But youngsters are so prolific with their crayons, markers and paints that posting their creations on refrigerators with magnets will go only so far. So choices between clutter and the wastebasket must be made.

title: Giving the Teacher Balm for Burnout
description: The two teachers descended on the fieldstone compound in the Great Smoky Mountains like weary soldiers in desperate need of rest and relaxation. Sylvia Averette, who has been teaching kindergarten for 15 years in a small town southeast of Charlotte, displayed the scars of her profession on her scalp: peaking out from the part in her long blond hair were dots from felt-tipped markers, inadvertent tattoos from students whose young hands had slipped as they tugged on her for assistance. She could not remember the last time she had had more than five minutes to herself to eat lunch, which she always took with her students anyway.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARRISON, STAN
description: HARRISON-Stan. Age 70, died peacefuly on January 2, 2001, after a long illness endured with courage, tenacity and a zest for life. Beloved husband of Toni Heris, adored father of Mallory Harrison Gerstein, loving grandfather of Renee and Arielle Gerstein, caring brother of Sheldon Harrison, cherished uncle to John, Susanne, Steven, Bill, Kathy, Suzy and David. Stan leaves behind family and friends forever inspired by his gentleness, humanity, generosity, wit and intellectual curiosity, love of music, adventurousness in travel and absolute love of life. After a 25 year career in advertising, he received his doctorate in psychology from NYU along with advanced analytic training from the National Institute for the Psychotherapies, and began the most exciting and satisfying phase of his work life as a psychotherapist. A private memorial service will be held January 13.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Barbara Cartland, b. 1901; She Spoke Volumes
description: Barbara Cartland was a romance novelist. She was the undisputed queen of the genre, the regent before whom all other pretenders must bow. In her 98 years on earth, Dame Barbara produced more than 700 romance novels. She wrote about only one topic: love. For instance, ''The Cave of Love,'' ''The Devil in Love,'' ''Love Is Innocent,'' ''Love Is Dangerous,'' ''Love Is a Maze'' and even ''Love Is Contraband.''

title: Hotel in Angkor
description: To the Editor: The Grand Hotel d'Angkor in Cambodia, (''Ruins by Day, Luxury by Night,'' Nov. 26) is indeed luxurious. But it would be a shame to visit Cambodia and not stay at least one night in the Grand's sister hotel, Le Royal in Phnom Penh. Also a project of the Raffles group from Singapore, Le Royal is more sophisticated than the Grand and every bit as charming.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Charles Schulz, b. 1922; Strip Mind
description: If you try to imagine, say, three kids sitting against the side of a suburban house on a summer afternoon, something interesting happens. What were originally three generic placeholder children will gradually, via the process of imagination and reimagination, evolve into three distinct children. One child, who first leapt into your imagination as a seated amorphous blob with a sack of marbles, is soon seen to be somewhat overweight and fixated on those marbles, and on his face is a look of pleased ownership, and he is wearing an expensive blue shirt, and suddenly he has morphed into the very manifestation of Greedy Self-Satisfaction. Meanwhile, the child on his left, staring off into the distance, poor but clean, not the least bit interested in those marbles, is seen to represent Healthy Independent Renunciation. On the other side of Mr. Self-Satisfied Marble-Owner, a thin dirty kiss-up of a boy in high-water pants gazes hungrily at the marbles, the embodiment of Covetous Resentful Poverty.

title: Corrections
description: The Frugal Traveler column on Dec. 10, about Houston, misstated the name of a magazine in which the author found a map to guide her to folk-art sites. It is Texas Highways, not Texas Highway.

title: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; A Few Last Hurrahs
description: Quite a few executive decisions are emerging from the White House just before President Clinton is forced to move out. Most recently, they include signing a treaty calling for a world court for wartime atrocities and an order putting nearly a third of the national forest land off limits to road building and logging.

title: Hope Soars in Russia For an Earthbound Bird
description: AS Nikolai Lugin, a regional agriculture official, entered his barn and stomped the snow from his boots, he expounded on the economic future of Sakhalin Island.

title: Yonkers Revives Barbed-Wire Ban
description: THE steady drop in crime here has city officials hoping to lure new home and business owners. But certain areas still have a lingering ''war zone'' look. So, over the last few years, officials have begun cleanup initiatives, including fining property owners for failing to keep their properties graffiti-free and banning metal roll-down gates.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JACOBY, WILLIAM K.
description: JACOBY-William K. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of William K. Jacoby, associated with The Times from 1969 until 1980.

title: QUOTATION OF THE DAY
description: ''The drug companies are helping us out some. But they're in this business to make money. It's the people with power who get heard here, and our children don't.''

title: A Custom Fit, A Well-Tailored Price
description: IT could be that we got a little carried away with tailoring in New Delhi. My boyfriend, Harry, got 2 suits and 10 shirts made and I got 6 shirts, 3 skirts and 2 pairs of pants. This endeavor in February took us to three different tailors, in three different parts of town and involved four fittings, countless phone calls and mad taxi rides to pick up clothes on the way to train stations and parties.

title: A Vote for a Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: Hot and Heavy: Stews Fight Winter Chill
description: WHEN it's winter, the menu turns to casseroles and stews. And coming up with new tastes and variations is a matter of cruising the spice and condiment aisles in the supermarket -- or doing the same in the home pantry. Try some fresh vegetables like winter roots, some grain perhaps, and you're on your way.

title: Packing a Cell Phone
description: Now that cargo pants have come and gone, men are again faced with the conundrum of where to stash their gadgets. Designers are coming to their rescue with suits, sport coats and outerwear with specialized nooks and crannies. At Bergdorf Goodman, a blue canvas jacket by Mandarina Duck ($395), right, offers two hidden panels of pockets for wallet, cell phone, handheld computer and keys. Suits by Ermenegildo Zegna ($1,595) and Cerruti ($1,285), both at Saks Fifth Avenue, also include cell phone pockets -- a slit above the inside breast pocket. American Eagle's cotton Shoreline jacket ($59, at American Eagle Outfitters stores) has a double-entry pocket on each sleeve suitable for a cell phone. And this spring, almost all Kenneth Cole outerwear will include a pocket for a minidisc player.

title: Thomas Hardy in a Cloak of Snow
description: IT is still one of the great and most frightening openings in literature. I remember it from radio as a child, on the BBC's Sunday night serials, and I can still feel the horror in what happened (and the threat to my own family), as well as the control with which Thomas Hardy let nothing get in the way of the shock.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAKER, VIRGIL D.
description: BAKER-Virgil D. 82, passed away at the Guild Home for Aged Blind in Yonkers January 5, 2001. Former resident of Nanuet, NY, and Dobson, NC. Beloved husband of the late Mary Blasko-Baker. Father of Robert J. Baker, Troy, MI, and Father Richard D. Baker of St. Eugene's Parish, Yonkers, NY, daughter-in-law Chrys Ward-Baker, Sister Carrie-Ruth Holt, NC. Former Army veteran of WWII, serving for five years in Europe and North Africa in the Medical Corps. Retired from Lederle Laboratories in Pearl River after 34 years as Supply Manager. Former President of Local 143 International Chemical Workers from '57-60, and Clarkstown Democratic Committeemen from '60's to '80's. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to: The Sisters of Life, 198 Hollywood Ave., Bronx, NY 10465. Visiting Monday, 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 PM, Joseph W. Sorce Funeral Home, 728 West Nyack Rd., West Nyack, NY. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 10 AM, St. Anthony's R.C. Church, Nanuet. Burial in Brick Church Cemetery, Wesley Hills.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COLE, THOMAS M.
description: COLE-Thomas M. On January 5. Beloved husband of Yvette. Devoted father of Nancy Wallach, Alice and Sammy Williams, Sarah & Steve Strasser & Amy & Paul Rosengard. Brother of Carol Rothenberg. Cherished grandfather of Jeremy, David, Joanne, Karen, Jeffrey, Lisa, Danny, Jillian, Ellen & Joey. Services for immediate family only, Sunday, January 7.

title: BREATHLESS IN A COLONIAL PERCH
description: LAST April, at the suggestion of a Peruvian friend, I visited the lovely colonial town of Ayacucho, in the central Andean region of Peru. The area is one of the least traveled parts of the country and Ayacucho especially so. In the 1980's and early 90's it was the center of the guerrilla movement known as the Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path). Not until the terrorist leaders were captured in 1992 did Ayacucho again become a safe place for tourists.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JORDAN, JOHN THOMPSON
description: JORDAN-John Thompson. Died suddenly at home in Chestertown, MD, December 26, at 75. Beloved father of Sabrina of NYC, caring friend to many. Raised in Indianapolis and a graduate of DePauw University (1948-Delta Upsilon), John began his career in advertising at General Electric in Schenectady, NY. In 1955 he came to NYC to co-found Muller Jordan Herrick -later Muller Jordan Weiss-which he led as Chief Executive Officer until his retirement in 1989. Always a kind and caring man, John devoted his later years to helping others through his church, the Peninsula United Methodist Homes, the Lions Club, and personal deeds. Memorial services: In Chestertown, First United Methodist Church, January 13 at 10:30 AM. In NYC, Unitarian Church of All Souls, January 20 at 2:00 PM. Contributions may be made to: John T. Jordan Scholarship Fund, DePauw University Development Office, 300 East Seminary Street, Greencastle, IN. 46135.

title: A New Setting for 'Tabletop'
description: RESUSCITATE. Please.

title: The Latest Artillery in the War Against the Flu Virus
description: HEALTH officials strongly urge -- even at this late date -- that people get flu shots, especially those 65 and older or those with weakened immune systems and chronic ailments like heart disease, kidney disease and severe asthma.

title: A 4 or 5 Percent Solution For Retirement Spending
description: For many years, you heeded the advice of the financial experts and managed to put together a tidy nest egg for retirement. So now what?

title: Everybody Out of the Pool? A New Path on Mergers
description: THE funny thing about most big mergers and acquisitions is that they don't cost anything. Yes, they are free. PepsiCo may have agreed to pay $13.4 billion for Quaker Oats as the newspaper headlines will attest, but Pepsi's balance sheet will not show the $13.4 billion cost.

title: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; A Thank You Note
description: If anyone deserves a Good Soldier Award in Democratic politics in New York, it has to be Nita D. Lowey, the congresswoman who stepped out of the Senate race to make room for a certain first lady of the United States. The sacrifice paid off. In addition to winning points with the first family, Ms. Lowey became a national figure as she helped campaign for Hillary Rodham Clinton. So it was an easy choice when it came time to name someone to run the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee. Ms. Lowey is the first women to hold the position, a crucial one given the party's eagerness to regain control of the House in 2002. Adam Nagourney

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: KENSINGTON; Wheelchairs and Cruisers Mix Cautiously on a Block
description: Terry Rodie, district manager of Community Board 14, calls it ''an accident waiting to happen.''

title: On a Slow Train To Fast Times
description: For William Shelby, who has been punching tickets on New Jersey Transit's Atlantic City rail service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City since it began in 1989, the daily mix of poker-playing gamblers, casino employees, commuters, conventioneers and college students, ''is a community that's always celebrating something -- weddings, birthdays, raises on the job. We all know each other and, believe me, these people would be devastated if the service was to stop.''

title: Who Will Lead The Public Schools?
description: American education has entered a new era in which academic achievement has moved to the center of what is publicly expected of schools. What is far from clear, however, is who is going to lead America's public schools in this new learning era. Big cities seem to be enamored of unconventional leaders in education -- business moguls, lawyers, politicians and retired military officers.

title: New Rulings On Fuel Tax And Parking
description: IN the last several months, there have been a number of developments relating to the way co-ops and condominiums must deal with the collection and payment of local and state sales taxes on goods and services provided to their shareholders and unit owners.

title: The Young And the Fundless, Ignored by Marketers
description: THE mutual fund business was booming during the early days of Green, a personal finance magazine for young adults -- think 22 to 35 years old -- that I started in 1994. Fund managers like Peter Lynch, Michael Price and Donald Yacktman practically had their own bubble-gum cards as the 2 percent trickle of the Dow industrials of 1994 gave way to the 33 percent torrent of 1995, with more gains to follow. With a truckload of glowing press clippings and a hornet's nest of buzz, Green's advertising sales force (my high school pal, the co-founder) set out to honor the mutual fund industry with the chance to buy real estate in our pages.

title: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; Man Won't Bite Dog
description: Taiwan has banned the consumption of dog meat, hoping, as one lawmaker put it, to show the world that its 23 million people have entered a more civilized era.

title: Salary Arbitration and Free Agency and the Road to Riches and Ruin
description: The myth has lived for years. Once and for all, Marvin Miller is happy to kill it. No, the players' estimable former labor leader said, once the players gained free agency, the union was not about to give up salary arbitration, which its negotiators had won three years earlier.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: The Stone Woman

title: A Millennium Worthy Of the Angst Is Dawning; Political Upheaval And Extreme Football
description: With the benefit of hindsight, it is finally safe to declare that the world did not come to an end in the year 2000. The apocalyptic prophecies, the threats of terrorism, the warnings of catastrophic computer bugs all came to naught. But perhaps all the millennial hype was just a year early after all.

title: Lilian Shackelford, Daniel Murray
description: Lilian M. Shackelford and Daniel Buntin Murray were married on Monday by the Rev. Julie Norton at All Saints Episcopal Church in Keswick, Va.

title: MARTY GLICKMAN: 1917-2001 -- The Snub, the Voice, the Heart; A Precise, Animated Diction That Captivated the Listener
description: Marty Glickman had one of the last big voices, one that alerted a listener to hang in, something extraordinary could happen. And if it didn't, well, you wouldn't be wasting your time listening to Glickman demonstrate his passion for sports, scrupulous sense of how to speak well and fidelity to the facts.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, LILLIAN
description: HOFFMAN-Lillian. On January 5, 2001, at age of 93. Beloved wife of the late Irving Hoffman. Devoted mother of Donna (Hoffman) Bilgrei and Michael Bilgrei and Ellen (Hoffman) Lieberman and Robert Lieberman. Loving sister of Adeline Bodner and adoring grandmother to Jeremy, Allyson, Rachel and Joshua. Dedicated NYC school teacher for 25 years and world traveler. The family mourns the loss of our wise, witty, and brilliant tower of strength. She will be greatly missed. May she rest in peace. Funeral on Sunday, January 7, 1:30 PM at Schwartz Bros.Jeffer Memorial Chapel, Queens Blvd. and 76th Rd., Forest Hills.

title: Ratify, But Review
description: Much media attention has been focused on cabinet selections and partisan politics. But it has become clear that any legislative success in the 107th Congress will require a coalition of centrists from both sides of the aisle.

title: Attacking Noises, Large and Small
description: LOW-LEVEL noise problems in rooms can often be controlled by using sound-absorbing materials on the walls, floors and ceiling. Plumbing noises can often be softened by isolating noisy appliances with mounting kits and installing water-hammer arrestors.

title: A Dark Fable Escapes Shakespeare's Shadow
description: LIKE one or two other societies we could name, Londoners of the Elizabethan and Jacobean eras preferred real-life sex, murder and scandal to the made-up kind. With ''The White Devil,'' the playwright John Webster gave them what they wanted.

title: Cigarette Crackdown Proposed
description: COUNTY Executive Andrew J. Spano has proposed new measures to make it harder for minors to get cigarettes, including a proposal to limit access to cigarette vending machines.

title: In a New Age, Can Retro Be Relevant?
description: CONCEPT cars are supposed to offer glimpses of the future, but those to be unveiled this week in Detroit are still mostly looking back. The shining recent examples of design success in the marketplace remain the Volkswagen New Beetle, a reinvention of a classic shape, and the Chrysler PT Chrysler, a more generalized evocation of past shapes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  AWN, ELIAS J.
description: AWN-Elias J. Age 88, on January 5, 2001. Of Florham Park, NJ, formerly of Brooklyn, NY. Beloved husband of Isabel Awn (nee Owen). Loving father of Claudette A. Maraziti of Chatham, NJ, Dr. Peter J. Awn of Manhattan, Louise E. Crowley of New Milford, CT, Richard P. Awn of Larchmont, NY. Devoted grandfather of nine grandchildren in whom his legacy lives on: Jacqueline Maraziti, Michele Maraziti, Jeremiah Crowley, Jennifer Crowley, Sarah Crowley, John Crowley, Richard Awn Jr., Susan Awn and Peter Awn. Elias (Louie) Awn and his brothers were proprietors of Awn's Specialty Shop, a fixture in the Wall Street area for over 50 years. Viewing from 7-9 PM, on Sunday, January 7, at Bradley and Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St, Chatham, NJ; 973-635-2428. The Mass of Resurrection will be celebrated at 9:30 AM, on Monday, January 8, at St. Vincent Martyr Church, 26 Green Village Rd, Madison, NJ. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions maybe made to St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, PO Box 50, Memphis, TN 38101-9929.

title: First Rate On Second Avenue
description: CAFFE MED +

title: Same Yardstick, Different Races
description: AS any track coach knows, a mile is nothing like a marathon. Many runners who do well over short distances lack the endurance for long ones.

title: A Manager's Fight to Keep a Winning Streak Alive
description: ON April 4, when William H. Miller III visited a class at the Columbia Business School, he sounded like the old-school value investor that his critics say he is not. Technology holdings had helped power his Legg Mason Value Trust to an unmatched, nine-year winning streak against the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.

title: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Julian Carsey, b. 1935; Starting Over and Over and Over
description: There used to be a comforting anonymity about Tom's Place, a smoky and moderately seedy bar on the waterfront in Jacksonville, Fla., where the barstools were invariably occupied by men and women who liked to drink a little and forget a lot. Corinne Silverton, who was studying to be a stockbroker after years as a part-time teacher in a series of nightmarish public schools, was a more-than-typical customer -- divorced, tired, unhappy and broke, she had a liking, entirely understandable, for nursing three quiet beers in an evening, hoping that while she was doing so the world that she felt had treated her so ill would leave her well alone. A companionable bartender named Doug helped to see that this was so: he made sure that Corinne's stool was always empty and ready for her, and that any unsavory characters -- who might well relish the prospect of an evening with an unhappy and vulnerable divorcee -- were kept at bay, or at least at a respectful distance.

title: Fund-Raisers Rush To Save Treetops
description: SEVENTY-FIVE DAYS and counting.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLMAN, EDWARD G.
description: WELLMAN-Edward G. 82, died at home on January 6, 2001. Beloved husband of Estelle. Loving father of Ronnie Berish, Jeri Wellman and Nick Bryan, and Scott and Jackie Wellman. Grandfather of Adam, Josh, Alissa, Joshua, Jonathan, Jeremy, Kate, Eric, and Michael. Great-grandfather of Matthew and Jack. This most compassionate man taught us how to live and to love. He will remain in our hearts forever. Memorial Service will be held today at Schwartz Bros. Chapel, 114-03 Queens Boulevard at 4 PM.

title: A Farcical Perspective On Love, Sex and Pain
description: A FEW years ago, the playwright Kathleen Tolan decided she needed smoother legs. ''So I went to this wax person,'' Ms. Tolan recalled recently, ''and I just found it hilarious to lie on this slab getting my hair torn out by the roots -- and paying for it! The woman who did it happened to be Russian, and we had this amazing conversation about Chekhov and Tolstoy while she was pulling. I thought, 'I've got to put this in a play.' ''

title: Lady-in-Waiting
description: THE TALE OF MURASAKI

title: Crossing the Moral Boundary
description: A model employee of the French public transport authority, according to his chiefs and workmates, the Parisian bachelor Amnon Chemouil, who is now 48, discovered one of Thailand's tourist attractions in 1992. Not its tropical landscape or its ancient civilization and Buddhist temples, but cheap and easy sex, one of the country's flourishing industries. At the resort of Pattaya, near Bangkok, he could have sex with very young prostitutes. He vacationed there again in 1993 and 1994.

description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEHR, FLORENCE (NEE BERGER)
description: BEHR-Florence (nee Berger). 78, on January 5, 2001. Beloved wife of Dr. Irving Behr. Devoted mother of Joan and Donald Schaeffer and Tami and the late Dr. Bruce Behr. Cherished grandmother of Andrew Schaeffer and Brittany and Joshua Behr. Loving sister of Dr. Herbert Berger and Marilyn Berger. Dear sister-in-law of Sylva Altschul and the late Dr. Ruth Berger. Much loved aunt of bj Altschul, Dr. Diana Berger and David and Melissa Berger. Services today, 10 AM at ''Riverside Memorial Chapel'' 180 W. 76 St., NYC.

title: No-Count Guests at a Census Bash
description: THE Attack of the Number Crunchers has begun, but don't worry. Even those of you who are intimidated by statistics -- which is to say, virtually all of you -- can survive it, using the simple system delineated here.

title: Atlantic City Journal; One-Armed Bandits and 2 Tired Legs: Burning Fat (and Cash) at the Casino
description: Truth be told, Bernice Ryan did not suffer two hours on a packed, overheated bus so she could shvitz while parting with the better part of her weekly pension check. But before she knew what hit her, Mrs. Ryan, 68, a retired teacher from Queens, was working up a sweat at the Tropicana Casino and Resort, dropping quarters into a slot machine while she pedaled away on a recumbent exercise bicycle. That irresistible pop hit, ''Macarena,'' poured forth from overhead speakers while the machine's frenzied lights went through their own workout.

title: The World; Make Way for the Vatican's X-Man: Il Papa
description: IT'S a bird, it's a plane no, it's the pope. A Roman Catholic children's magazine, Il Giornalino, put the pope's life story into comic book form to celebrate the Holy Year, which ended on Saturday. The four-part series, tucked in alongside puzzles, nature stories and less pious comic strips, turns the 80-year-old pontiff into a comic book superhero -- one who relies on faith, not magical powers, to help the needy and combat evil (in this case, Communism).

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: But Will It Buy Happiness?
description: THE VIRTUE OF PROSPERITY

title: Confidential Hot Line Helps Troubled Youths
description: ALISHA TUCKER is still in high school, yet recently she has helped a pregnant girl from Mount Vernon looking for prenatal care and another teenager who, fearing she had a sexually transmitted disease, was seeking medical testing.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISBERG, SHIRLEY
description: WEISBERG-Shirley. On January 5, 2001. Beloved wife of I. Daniel Weisberg. Loving and devoted mother of Lisa and Marc, and Christina. Dear sister of Ethel Hochberg and Ben Balin. Service Sunday, 9 AM, at ''The Riverside,'' 76th St and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Dec. 31 - Jan. 6; Who You Gonna Call?
description: Alan Greenspan to the rescue. With the economy showing signs of crumbling after a long run of prosperity, the Federal Reserve stepped in with an unexpected and substantial cut in interest rates. The half-point reduction is likely to be the first in a series of cuts in coming months. While the move will take some time to be felt throughout the economy, it was an immediate pick-me-up for Wall Street, which had entered the new year in a state of despair over weakened corporate earnings and the end of the technology-stock bubble. Richard W. Stevenson

title: Children at Hotels
description: To the Editor: The article ''At Some Hotels, It's Adults Only,'' (Dec. 3) did not address how difficult it has become to travel with small children. Any experience we have had with our young children over six years has been a poor one because so many hotels don't provide cribs.

title: Episcopalians Inaugurate Alliance With Lutherans
description: After more than three decades of debate, the Episcopal Church and the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America inaugurated an alliance today that will allow them to share clergy members, churches and missionary work.

title: Bowling With the Boys Team Poses Problems for Talented Girl
description: TO qualify for the girls' sectional bowling championships last year, one had to average 145 for a girls' high school team. Sandra Maresca, bowling for the Mamaroneck High team, averaged 191. She didn't qualify.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SATZMAN, PAUL
description: SATZMAN-Paul. Professor of Music at Suffolk Community College, died on December 25, 2000. Professor Satzman enjoyed a teaching career for 15 years in the high schools of Long Island. He was among the first to take high school choirs on singing tours of Europe (Brentwood in 1970, Locust Valley in 1976). As Director of Choral Arts at Suffolk Community College, he was awarded the Chancellors's Award of Excellence In Teaching in 1995. A gifted teacher with an infectious love of music, he will be missed by many. He leaves a wife Sarah, two daughters Rebecca and Rachel, a grandson Robert and a sister Carole Henning. A memorial service will be held on January 28, 2001 at 3PM in the Shea Theater on the Selden Campus of Suffolk Community College. In lieu of flowers, a scholarship in Paul's name has been established to continue his encouragement of music students at Suffolk. Donations can be sent to Suffolk Community College Foundation, Paul Satzman Memorial Scholarship, The Cottage, 533 College Road, Selden, NY 11784

title: LESS WANTED

Arthur Lee Washington Jr., of Neptune wanted for attempted murder for shooting at a New Jersey State Police officer after being stopped for a traffic violation there in 1989, left the list because there had been no reports of criminal activity or other tips since 1993. The F.B.I. will continue to look for him. Mr. Washington is being replaced by Eric Franklin Rosser, of Bloomington, Ind., and Bangkok, Thailand, a concert pianist and jazz musician wanted on child pornography charges. Karen DeMasters

title: INSPECTION SYSTEM
description: Parsons Infrastructure and Technology Group, the company that runs New Jersey's enhanced auto inspection system, will get more money and be subject to smaller fines under a deal it recently reached with state officials. The deal calls for the California-based Parsons to get an additional $5.5 million for construction work above the $63 million included in its original bid. The company also can perform thousands of inspections that were reserved for privately owned garages. Parsons will be fined $500 a day for each station where motorists must wait more than 30 minutes for tests. The old deal called for $500 fines for every two-hour period that the wait standard was exceeded. Steve Strunsky

'' That's how Comfort would have preferred his obituaries to begin, and perhaps end. No doubt he would have been distressed by the obits that actually ran in newspapers worldwide, all of which began with a variation on, ''Dr. Alex Comfort was the author of a sex manual that became a pop-culture icon and made him millions. . . . ''

title: Formality and Funk Leave Their Mark
description: It's unmistakable when a band hits its stride, and the bassist Dave Holland's quintet arrived at that point a few years ago. The group's set at Birdland on Friday was full of music that seemed to play itself: it was dynamically controlled. It was light, in the aerodynamic sense, and built of sleek lines from the horns in front that sometimes came together and then forked off into elegant counterpoint. And it was settled by the leader's strong, thick bass lines, in vamps that repeated and repeated until it was time for solos that virtuosically made their case.

Adoring mother of Nancy and Laurette, loving mother-in-law of Roger and Edward. Cherished grandmother of Brooke and Randy, Julie and Evan, Eric, and Eve. He has done so in a manner likely to reassure New Yorkers who may have worried that their famously prickly mayor had mellowed. The flare-up over the Port Authority's stewardship of New York City's airports -- ostensibly over its slowness in clearing runways during and after the recent snowstorm -- is vintage Giuliani. The mayor's theatrical prosecutorial spectacle this time was based on photographs he took from a helicopter.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BOGDANOFF, DAVID
description: BOGDANOFF-David. A loving husband, father and grandfather passed away peacefully on January 5, 2001, in his 89th year. He was born in New York City and graduated Evander Childs High School and City College of New York. There he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Philosophy and English Literature. He moved to Westchester County in 1930 and was a vanguard, providing affordable housing opportunities for people of Westchester and throughout New York State. Through his various Yorktown based companies including Montrose Construction Co. Inc., Montrose Management Associates, Inc. and Jefferson Village Corporation, he effectively built over 5800 affordable units. His warmth and compassion for people led to his founding of not-for-profit housing agencies, including Community Housing Management Corp., and Westhab, Inc. and to his public service. He served as Chairman of the Westchester Housing Implementation Commission, a member of the Westchester Housing Forum, the Regional Plan Association and the Advisory Board of the Bank of New York, County Trust Region. He was also a member of the Board of Directors of the Builders Institute of Westchester and the Mid-Hudson Region. Funeral arrangements were conducted privately. For more information call Zion Memorial Chapel, 914381-1809. Donations may be made in his memory to ''Friends of Osborn,'' c/o Mr. Mark Zwerger, CEO, The Osborn, 101 Theall Rd., Rye, NY 10580.

He leaves behind his wife of 53 years, Mari (Corroon), four children, sons James, of Indiana, Douglas Jr. of Rhode Island, and Michael of California, and a daughter Nancy Calcagnini of New York. He is also survived by seven grandchildren and one great-grandchild. Family and friends are invited to a Mass of Christian Burial, Tuesday morning, 10:30 AM, at St. Joseph on the Brandywine Catholic Church, 10 Old Church Rd, Greenville, DE. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALKINS, SARAH ANNE
description: CALKINS-Sarah Anne, 42. On December 23, 2000 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York; from leukemia. Sarah grew up in Falls Church, VA, and was graduated from J.E.B. Stuart H.S. in 1976. She studied architectural history and was graduated with honors from Smith College in 1980. After earning her degree in 1984 from Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture and Planning, Sarah opened her own architecture practice in New York City, specializing in residential design. She was a member of the American Institute of Architects (AIA), lectured on architecture at Smith College and Parsons School of Design, and wrote and illustrated travel articles. Sarah leaves her fiance, Dr. Antonio Beltramini, and his son, Roberto. She is survived by her parents, G. Nathan and Susannah Calkins of Falls Church, her sisters, Margaret Calkins Van Auken of Akron and Abigail Calkins Aguirre of Philadelphia, her brother-in-law, Francisco Aguirre and her three nieces. Her oldest sister, Helen Calkins, died in 1978. Sarah's family and her many devoted friends will miss her wit, intellectual curiosity, insight and generosity of spirit. She was like no other. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, Amsterdam Ave. at 117th St. on Thursday, January 18th, 2PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Smith College for a scholarship fund to be established in Sarah's honor.

title: The Nose Has It
description: The 40-year-old Fragrance Foundation, run from the start by Annette Green, is known to most in the fashion world as the benefactor of the Fifi Awards, an annual gala for makers and marketers of perfume. For the last 20 years though, the Fragrance Foundation has also worked to finance research into the ways in which odor affects behavior. One study, conducted at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, showed that the smell of vanilla reduced stress by 62 percent during magnetic resonance imaging exams. At the time, 1994, Ms. Green dubbed vanilla ''the new musk.''

title: ALLEGHENY ENERGY TO BUY MERRILL LYNCH ENERGY UNIT
description: Allegheny Energy Inc., an East Coast utility with three million customers, agreed to buy Merrill Lynch & Company's energy-trading unit for $490 million and plans to create a separately traded power-generation and trading company. Allegheny's 2001 profit may rise to $3.80 to $4.10 a share if purchases of the Merrill unit and of power plants from the Enron Corporation close by midyear, the chief executive, Alan Noia, said on a conference call. The average profit estimate of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial is $3.52 a share. Allegheny owns electric utilities in Maryland, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia and West Virginia. Shares of Allegheny, based in Hagerstown, Md., rose $3.31 to $45.38. Merrill fell 31 cents, to $71.25.

title: CEMENT ACQUISITION
description: In a transaction that will create the world's largest cement company, Lafarge, the French building concern, confirmed that it would pay $4.6 billion for the British cement maker Blue Circle Industries. The deal ends Blue Circle's yearlong attempt to fend off a hostile approach from its French rival. The acquisition, announced yesterday, was helped by Lafarge's willingness to raise the price to 495 pence a share from the 450 pence that Blue Circle's shareholders rejected last May, and 8 percent higher than Blue Circle's stock price on Jan. 5, the last day of trading before the deal was announced. Lafarge and its adviser, Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein, own a 32.2 percent combined stake in Blue Circle as a result of that earlier attempt. Lafarge estimates it can realize $95 million in cost savings from the transaction, which will expand its operations in Europe and Asia. ''This is a major step for Lafarge's development,'' the Lafarge chief executive, Bertrand P. Collomb, said at a news conference in Paris. ''We're very happy that this offer became friendly.'' Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: NETZERO GETS COURT ORDER AGAINST RIVAL JUNO
description: NetZero, one of the last remaining providers of free Internet service, was granted a temporary restraining order against Juno Online Services, its chief competitor. The order temporarily prevents Juno from displaying third-party ads on a floating advertising window called the Juno Guide because NetZero contends the Guide infringes on a NetZero patent. The NetZero version is called the ZeroPort, an on-screen window that serves as a navigational tool and displays advertisements and messages while the user is online. The restraining order lasts until mid-March, and a trial over a lawsuit that NetZero file against Juno over the same patent is set for July. Laurie J. Flynn (NYT)

title: EGGHEAD SAYS NO CARD NUMBERS WERE STOLEN
description: Egghead.com, the online software merchant, said yesterday that after two weeks of looking into a computer intrusion that the company initially said might have resulted in the theft of as many as 3.5 million credit card numbers, it concluded that none were taken. ''Our security systems, though breached at the periphery, did their work,'' said Jeff Sheahan, chief executive. Although some 7,500 credit card users whose accounts were stored on Egghead's computers have reported potentially fraudulent activity, Mr. Sheahan said that the number, at two-tenths of 1 percent of those stored, was statistically insignificant and could have been compromised elsewhere. John Schwartz (NYT)

title: Making a Meal of the Hands That Feed Her
description: Except for the lips, which are as plump as a pair of cocktail wieners waiting to be wrapped up in their flaky little triangles of dough -- mmm, so delicious, so . . . trashy -- there is nothing about the way Sandra Bernhard looks, up close, to explain her status as a glamour puss. She has been in Harper's Bazaar, snuggling with her daughter, Cicely, who is 2 1/2. She has been in Vanity Fair, surrounded by showgirls of the bare-bottomed, Casino de Paris genre. Last June, she was host of the annual Council of Fashion Designers of America awards gala, an event that, until Ms. Bernhard teased the audience with lines like ''I love you. I hate you. Hold me,'' was solidly on its way to becoming another New York evening of petrified gaiety.

title: CALIFORNIA EDISON SUIT ON POWER COSTS TO PROCEED
description: Southern California Edison, California's No. 2 electric utility, can proceed with a lawsuit seeking to charge customers $2.64 billion for its losses on open-market power purchases, a federal judge said. Judge Ronald Lew refused a request by the California Public Utilities Commission to dismiss the suit by Edison, a unit of Edison International. The utility wants to charge customers the difference between what it paid for electricity in the open market and the capped price it charged customers from June through October.

title: MVP.COM FIRES 36 MORE WORKERS
description: The closely held Internet sporting goods retailer MVP.com, which is affiliated with Michael Jordan, Wayne Gretzky and John Elway, said yesterday that it laid off 36 more employees last week, just a few weeks after announcing that it would cut 79 employees. The 11-month-old company, which now has 43 employees, has fired more than three-quarters of its staff in the last few months as it tries to cut costs and reorganize its operations in an increasingly competitive market. ''It's a very challenging business environment,'' said Paula Davis, a spokeswoman for MVP.com, which is based in Chicago. ''We were in an expansion path and now we're in a maintenance path.'' The company, which postponed a public offering last year, has also had trouble meeting its commitments. In late November, SportsLine.com, a popular sports Web site, said it had ended its multimillion-dollar relationship with MVP.com because the retailer had breached an agreement and missed at least one payment. David Barboza (NYT)

title: Reviving the Test Ban Treaty

The incoming Bush administration has now been offered a timely opportunity to revisit the treaty issue. Last week, at the request of President Clinton, Gen. John Shalikashvili, a former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, proposed a set of practical steps that the next administration could take to address the Senate's concerns about the treaty and make it possible for George W. Bush to resubmit it for a successful ratification vote in the near future.

ServerWorks' chips are used in computers made by Compaq, Dell and I.B.M. Unlike previous companies that Broadcom has purchased, ServerWorks has revenue, $190 million last year, and is profitable.

title: GLIATECH HALTS DISTRIBUTION OF MEDICAL PRODUCT
description: Gliatech shares fell 38 percent after the company voluntarily halted distribution of its anti-scarring gel because a supplier recalled a raw material used to make the product. Shares of Gliatech, based in Cleveland, fell $2.31, to $3.75. In the last 12 months, the shares have dropped 77 percent. Gliatech said the supplier recalled the material because it might contain particles from an aluminized-paper lid liner. Gliatech said there had not been any reports of particles in Adcon-L gel, which is used to prevent internal scarring and pain after spinal surgery.

title: Little Worlds, Etched With Passion

But the song, from the 1936 musical ''Red, Hot and Blue,'' actually has five choruses that carry the happy lovers into marriage and parenthood of a son so drop-dead gorgeous he ends up a movie star.

title: Metro Business Briefing; RADIO REVENUE GROWING
description: Radio station advertising revenue in the New York region grew at a much faster rate than in most markets nationwide over the last five years, but the increase did not place it within the top 20, according to a report released last week by Duncan's American Radio, a Cincinnati research group. New York's radio market -- the nation's largest and second in overall revenue but 21st in revenue growth -- saw the greatest leap between 1998 and 1999, driven primarily by a large increase in advertising from Internet companies. The average revenue growth nationally was about 50 percent from 1994 to 1999, said Tony Sanders, a senior research analyst with Duncan's. The New York market's radio revenue increased more than 76 percent, to $708.2 million in 1999, from about $401 million five years earlier. Jayson Blair

Profit before interest, taxes and stock-option costs rose more than 40 percent, to about 600 million euros. Analysts attributed the gains to rising United States sales. She received both her Bachelor's and Master's Degrees from the University of Michigan. In 1979 she received the Ivor Dunsford Memorial Award of the American Association of Blood Banks in recognition of her pioneering work spanning the first forty years of modern blood banking, during which time she established the blood bank supervisor as the mainstay of the hospital transfusion service and as a consultant to the practicing physician in the care of patients. title: Antibiotics on the Farm
description: One of the most striking patterns in modern American agriculture is the increasing use of antibiotics as a regular supplement in the feed and water consumed by cows, pigs and especially poultry. Most of these drugs are administered in small doses to farm animals not to cure sickness but to promote more growth on less feed and to prevent the infections that come with crowding in feedlots and confinement systems. The practice began in the late 1940's and early 1950's and has accelerated rapidly. Nobody knows precisely what volume of antibiotics is used today. But new estimates released by a public interest group this week suggest that the amount of antibiotics used nontherapeutically in American livestock has grown to 24.6 million pounds per year, a number that may be as much as 50 percent higher than it was in 1985.

title: ALCATEL AND MARCONI MAY SELL STAKES
description: Alcatel S.A., Europe's second-biggest phone equipment maker, and Marconi P.L.C., the largest in Britain, said they might sell part of their stakes in Alstom S.A. in the first quarter. Alcatel and Marconi each own 24 percent of Alstom, the world's largest maker of electricity-generation equipment. They expect to sell an unspecified part of their stakes on European and United States markets, Alcatel and Marconi said in a joint statement. No figures were given. Alcatel sold shares in Alstom in an initial public offering in June 1998. It has previously said its Alstom holding is not strategic as it focuses on telecommunications. Alstom shares fell 5.3 percent, to 25 euros. Alcatel shares fell 0.2 euro, to 61.45, and Marconi rose 4 pence, to 676.

title: GENERAL MOTORS AGAIN CUTS PRODUCTION PLANS
description: The General Motors Corporation said yesterday that it would build 100,000 fewer cars and trucks in the first quarter in North America than it had planned last month, to try to reduce dealer inventories as sales slow. General Motors said it would produce 1.2 million vehicles, down 21 percent from last year's first-quarter output of 1.521 million. G.M. plans to produce 562,000 cars and 638,000 trucks, said a spokesman, Tom Wickham. General Motors and other large automakers in the United States have been reducing production because of weaker demand. Last week, the Chrysler unit of DaimlerChrysler said it would build 26 percent fewer vehicles in the first quarter than in the year-earlier period. The Ford Motor Company plans to build 17 percent fewer cars and trucks in the quarter. General Motors shares fell $1.44, to $52.56.

title: POSTAL SERVICE AND FEDEX SEEN CLOSE TO AN AGREEMENT
description: The United States Postal Service and the FedEx Corporation are nearing agreement on a highly anticipated delivery alliance, according to people close to the discussions. Details of the plan are expected to be presented to the post office's board of governors at a meeting today in Washington. It was not clear whether the governors, who would have to approve the alliance, plan to vote on the matter today during a session that is closed to the public. While the agreement still could fall apart, the partnership is likely to include having FedEx, based in Memphis, use its 662 aircraft to haul Priority Mail and Express mail packages for the post office. But the alliance is narrower in scope than the two sides had been discussing last summer, with no apparent plans for the post office to deliver slower-moving ground parcels for FedEx in rural areas that are not reached by FedEx's ground-delivery network.

title: EBAY TO BUY KOREA'S INTERNET AUCTION

The acquisition will probably trim 2 cents a share from eBay's 2001 profit because of interest income it will lose on money used in the purchase. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICE, ARGYLL PRYOR RICE
description: RICE-Argyll Pryor Rice. Scholar of Spanish literature and a former nationally ranked tennis player, died at her home on December 3, 2000. She was the daughter of the late Theodorick P. and Argyll Campbell Ric. Professor Ricewas the author of a book on the Cuban poet Emilio Ballagas and numerous scholarly articles. She undertook research in Cuba during the initial period of the Castro regime. Beginning her career as an amateur tennis player, she was ranked 16th nationally and played at Wimbledon and Roland Garros. Both a Sears Cup player and captain, she led the way for women players in Connecticut. In 1993 she was elected to the New England Tennis Hall of Fame. Professor Rice left a successful career in tennis in favor of academic pursuits. She was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate from Smith College and took her M.A. and Ph.D degree at Yale. She was the first women to have taught undergraduates, in the Spanish Dept. at Yale. Joining the faculty of Connecticut College in 1964, she attained the rank of professor and was for many years chairperson of the Spanish Dept. In her teaching, she integrated music, art, social history and politics into all her courses and presented Spanish literature as a cultural totality. Following her retirement, she contributed to Scribner's series, Latin American Writers, and devoted herself to preparing a critical edition of the prose of Emilio Ballagas. Professor Rice is listed in Who's Who in America. A violinist who in the past had given recitals, she was devotee of music and enjoyed the ambiance of Carnegie Hall and the Metropolitan Opera. Professor Rice is survived by her cousin Henry Gordon Rice of Davis California. Funeral services were held in Blackstone, Virginia.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BERLIN, BESS
description: BERLIN-Bess. Beloved wife of the late Roy, devoted mother of Robert and Mark, cherished grandmother of Daniel, Michael, Robert, Joanna, Brian, and Steven. Services Wednesday, 11:30 AM,at The Reconstructionist Synagogue, 1001 Plandome Road, Manhasset. BERLIN-Bess. The Reconstructionist Synagogue of the North Shore deeply mourns the passing of its founding member, our beloved Bess. Her vision and resolute spirit were dedicated to the establishment of our congregation and the survival of the Jewish people. She avidly and generously supported Jewish education and established an endowment for that purpose in our institution. Those who knew and loved her know the loss we feel. Lee Friedlander, Rabbi Lee Parker Michael Lindner, Presidents

title: Doctor Convicted of Insurance Fraud in Fertility Procedures
description: A Manhattan obstetrician with a celebrity clientele was convicted yesterday of defrauding insurance companies to have them pay for expensive fertility procedures, a case that was closely watched by doctors and their patients in the booming fertility industry.

title: 2 Media Groups Move To Examine Florida Votes
description: After weeks of negotiations, the organized effort by news organizations to examine uncounted Florida ballots has resulted in two independent projects. A consortium of eight news organizations, including The New York Times, The Washington Post, The Wall Street Journal, the Tribune Company and CNN, announced yesterday that they had retained the National Opinion Research Center to examine and report their findings on an estimated 180,000 overvotes and undervotes across the state.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: GREENSTEIN - Joseph. Joseph Yussy, Don Jose Greenstein, age 78 died at home peacefully after a long illness on January 9. Master builder, jungle explorer, founder of Su Casa North and South and World War II veteran. Born in the Bronx, N.Y., son of David and Goldie Greenstein. Survived by his beloved wife of 53 years, Miriam Nates Greenstein; father of daughters Robin Wolfson of Port Chester, N.Y. and Jody Soltanoff of Woodstock, N.Y.; grandfather of granddaughters Kimberly Wolfson Lisack and Kacey Wolfson; grandsons Dr. Gregory Soltanoff and Eric Soltanoff and Joseph Lisack; sons-in-law Larry and Peter; brothers Morris and Irving Greenstein; special friends Carlene and Tyler. Those closest to him know he will soon be back at work, wearing his tool belt, fixing whatever has to be repaired and loving it. You live forever in our hearts-AdiosYour Loving Wife and Daughters Services Thursday, January 11, 1:15PM, Riverside Funeral Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, N.Y.C. Contributions in his memory may be sent to La Cruz Rojo, Isla Mujeres, Quintan A Roo Mexico 77400.

title: WebMD Enters Share Deal
description: The WebMD Corporation, an Internet health information company, gained the right to sell 1.1 million shares of HealthStream Inc. back to HealthStream at a small fraction of the price it paid when HealthStream went public last April. WebMD can return the stock to HealthStream for $1 to $2 a share; it paid $9 a share. HealthStream's stock price declined 19 cents, to $1.31, yesterday.
