title: JAPANESE CONSUMER SPENDING FALLS
description: Consumers in Japan tightened their fists again in November, spending 1.5 percent less than the month before despite healthy increases in outlays for cars and other durable goods. The decline led to a sell-off in shares of retail companies, which contributed to a 1.85 percent decline in the benchmark Nikkei 225 stock index. Consumers' cautious spending habits are often held responsible for Japan's continuing economic doldrums. Stephanie Strom

title: German Hams on Track 49
description: Armin Koglin's timing was perfect. Mr. Koglin, 47, a butcher from Lubeck, Germany, happened to meet an official of the New York State trade development office in Frankfurt about two years ago, when the food market in Grand Central Terminal was being planned. The result of that meeting is evident to anyone who passes through Grand Central Market: Koglin German Hams, where Mr. Koglin, shown below with Franziska Lehmann, his manager, sells 25 enticing varieties of ham made to his specifications by a German butcher in Vancouver, British Columbia. Some are also made in Queens.

title: HYUNDAI MOTOR HOPES TO INCREASE SALES 23% IN THE U.S.
description: The Hyundai Motor Company said it hoped to expand its sales in the United States by 23 percent this year, helped by an improved brand image and a wider range of vehicles. The company, which sold 264,000 vehicles in the United States in 1988 and 244,391 last year, wants to sell 300,000 in 2001, according to Finbarr O'Neill, president of the company's American unit. Hyundai has said that it will consider building an assembly plant in North America when combined sales of Hyundai and its subsidiary Kia reach 500,000 vehicles; Kia hopes to sell 230,000 vehicles in the United States this year.

title: Mayor Presses Port Authority For Control Of Airports
description: Declaring that passengers forced to sit on runways for two to seven hours are victims of a ''form of torture,'' Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced several steps yesterday to pressure the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to give up control of La Guardia and Kennedy Airports.

title: With Eye to D.C., Whitman Gives Rosy Valedictory On Her Tenure
description: Her attention now fixed on Washington, Gov. Christie Whitman offered a rosy recollection of her seven years in office and presented only a few new initiatives today, in what is likely to be her last annual address to the Legislature.

title: NURSING HOME OPERATOR CLOSES ITS FLORIDA BUSINESS
description: Extendicare Inc., an operator of nursing homes in the United States and Canada, said it would pull out of the Florida market because of rising insurance costs. The company said it sold one home in Tampa to a buyer it did not name for $3.7 million, and had leased 15 Florida properties to Tandem Health Care or Senior Health Properties-South. Extendicare, based in Markham, Ontario, got about one-seventh of its revenue of $896 million from its Florida operations in the first nine months of 2000, but the properties lost money.

title: Metro Business Briefing; WEB SITE ACCESS
description: Sweet16.com, a Silicon Alley multimedia company, has agreed to increase enforcement of age-screening and parental-consent procedures on its Web site after complaints from the children's advertising review unit of the Better Business Bureau, according to a statement from the unit. In October, the advertising review unit found ''several infractions'' of the bureau's guidelines on children's privacy on the Sweet16.com Web site. The review agency said the Web site permitted visitors who identified themselves as under 13 to register for chat rooms, newsletters and message boards without parental consent, which is a violation of the guidelines. Sweet16.com officials did not return telephone messages seeking comment. Jayson Blair (NYT)

title: Rock-a-Bye the Vote
description: For the fourth time in five elections, the very young members of Nickelodeon's audience correctly picked the winning presidential candidate. A couple of weeks before Election Day, participants in a Nickelodeon poll voted for Gov. George W. Bush over Vice President Gore by 55 percent to 45 percent. That much would seem simple enough. But if everything that happened between Election Day and Mr. Bush's ultimate victory was enough to make the minds of adults spin, imagine what it did to the children.

title: Judge Rules Funding System Prevents Adequate Education in New York City
description: ANew York State trial judge ruled today that the state's school funding system is so deficient that it does not allow New York City's schools to provide the sound, basic education guaranteed by the state constitution. The ruling is a major victory for an advocacy group that challenged the state's school funding system.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TIGHT OFFICE MARKET
description: Manhattan's office-vacancy rate continued its drop last year, while rents in the borough's top-of-the-line office buildings remained the third highest in the country, according to a survey by an organization of commercial real estate companies. The survey by Oncor International found that the office-vacancy rate in Manhattan was 5.1 percent last year, seventh lowest among the 47 North American markets surveyed. Ottawa had the lowest rate at 1.7 percent. In 1996, the Manhattan rate was 13.5 percent. The average annual rent in top Manhattan buildings last year was $57.51 a square foot, behind $76 in San Francisco and $70 in Silicon Valley. In northern New Jersey, the vacancy rate last year was 10.3 percent; it was 6.72 percent in central New Jersey and 7.43 percent in southern New Jersey. Joseph P. Fried (NYT)

Analysts said the company's net income of 21 million euros ($20 million) and operating income of 103 million euros ($98 million) for the period would have been higher still except for the damping effect of high energy prices on consumer travel spending.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOMMEL, DOROTHY (NEE DIVORIN)
description: KOMMEL-Dorothy (nee Divorin). Died without suffering at age 87 on January 8th, 2001. Devoted to her family and her many friends, admired by all who knew her. She survived with strength the passing of her much loved husband, Sanford Kommel, and her siblings, Helen, Jack, and Cirelle. She lived to take enormous pride in her grandchildren, Janet and David, her daughter, Helene, and son-inlaw, Gord, she is also survived by Sanford's children, Carolyn, and Robert, by Carolyn's daughter, Deborah, and by nieces, Eda, Selda, Cirelle, Eileen, Robin, and Marcia. In May 2000, Dorothy closed her fur buying office, after a sucessful career lasting over 60 years. She was loved and respected by all in the fur market, Dorothy was active for many years in the Golda Meir Group, and New York Chapter of Hadassa, where she will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 12:45 P.M. Thursday, January 11th, 2001. Interment will follow at Riverside Cemetery, in Saddle Brook, New Jersey. Flowers to Riverside Chapel or donations to Hadassah's Sight Savers Program, may be sent. Our enduring recollections of her life well lived and her devotion to all of us will be a blessing.

description: Just off Washington Square Park, in a third-floor classroom at New York University, seven young women with gloves up past their elbows were wiggling their hips and singing ''Take Back Your Mink'' from ''Guys and Dolls.'' Next door, Greg C. Ganakas was telling Erica Piccininni, a redheaded senior playing Adelaide, to be more whiny.

title: 'Survivor' as Star Of CBS Schedule
description: CBS will hitch a large part of its future to its reality-programming hit ''Survivor,'' introducing two more editions of the castaway-survival game and another scheduling move intended to take advantage of the show's popularity.

title: Colombian Rebels May Release 100 Prisoners
description: In what officials see as a conciliatory gesture that may bode well for this country's stagnant peace efforts, the largest rebel organization has announced that it may release more than 100 soldiers and police officers whom it is holding captive, Colombian news media reported today.

title: Yankees and Jeter In Contract Talks
description: Randy Levine, president of the Yankees, spoke yesterday with Casey Close, Derek Jeter's agent, about negotiating a multiyear contract for the Yankee shortstop. They plan to talk again today and hope they can negotiate a contract before the two sides have to exchange salary arbitration figures next Thursday.

title: H & R BLOCK ISSUES A WARNING, AND SOME REASSURANCE
description: H & R Block Inc. said that though a change in the timing of some marketing expenses would cause it to fall short of analysts' expectations for its third fiscal quarter, the fourth quarter would be correspondingly better than expected and the outlook for the full fiscal year ending in April is unchanged. The company, known for its tax preparation services, told analysts at a meeting in New York yesterday that it expected to lose 21 cents to 23 cents a share in the quarter ending Jan. 31 -- analysts had expected 17 cents -- but that net earnings for all of fiscal 2001 would come in around $2.83 a share as expected. The company said it was cautious about the coming tax season because Congress made so few changes in the tax law this year.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LARSON, ALICE
description: LARSON-Alice. The Board of Directors, Administration and entire staff of Isabella Geriatric Center mourn the passing of Alice Larson, wife of Lawrence E. Larson, former President and Chief Executive Officer and currently emeritus Chair of of our Board. We recollect, with love and gratitude, her tireless volunteer efforts over many years which enriched the lives of Isabella's residents. She will be remembered with honor and affection by all who knew her. Richard B. Harding, Jr. Chair, Board of Directors Mark J. Kantor, President and Chief Executive Officer

title: Fox Says It Made Pair in 'Temptation Island' Leave for Lying
description: A couple participating in ''Temptation Island,'' the much-debated new reality television show on the Fox network, were forced to leave the show while it was being filmed in September because they lied to the network and the production company about their being parents of a child, Fox disclosed yesterday.

title: Mayor Falstaff Not Yet Ready For Final Act
description: WHEN you share Rudolph W. Giuliani's love of the Yankees but, sadly, not his passion for opera, you must turn to your betters to fill in the gaps. So opera-savvy colleagues were beseeched for insights into ''Falstaff,'' Giuseppe Verdi's last work, which the mayor invoked on Monday night while giving his final speech on the state of the city.

title: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
description: HEATING OIL DROPS. Heating oil fell on forecasts for milder weather in the Northeast, which accounts for four-fifths of demand. In New York, heating oil for February delivery fell 1.96 cents, or 2.4 percent, to 80.62 cents a gallon.

Hodgman, formerly of Glen Ridge, NJ, also survived by several nieces, nephews, grandnieces & grandnephews. Daughter of the late Clement S. Brainin and the late Helen (nee Stall) Brainin. title: SUPPLIER OF LEASED COMPUTERS LAYS OFF 96 EMPLOYEES
description: Comdisco Inc., a supplier of leased computers and management services, said it would stop providing computer network-management services and would lay off 96 employees. The business is not growing as projected and no longer fits the company's technology-services strategy, Comdisco said yesterday. The unit had just 37 corporate customers, and faced stiff competition.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSON, KENNETH JOSEPH.
description: EDELSON-Kenneth Joseph. On January 8, 2001. Beloved husband of Jill for 45 years. Loving father of Geoffrey, David, Andrew and Joshua. Wonderful grandfather of Charlotte, Annabel, Oliver, Benzi and Mia. Devoted brother to Burt. Cherished father-in-law of Lisa, Cindy and Fiona, and brother-inlaw of Betty and Margot. Ken will be dearly missed. His memory will live on through his family, friends and all those he touched. Services Thursday, 10AM at Barnert Temple, 747 Rte 208 South, Franklin Lakes, NJ. 201-848-1800. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Living Independently Forever, National Down Syndrome Congress and Valley Home Care. We will think of you often, and smile when we do. EDELSON-Kenneth J. The Board of Trustees and Staff of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services note with great sorrow the death of Kenneth J. Edelson. Ken was a devoted and caring volunteer, a member of the Westchester Divisional Committee and its liaison to Developmental Disability programs, and an active member of the Volunteer Services and Scholarship Committees. He was a special man who took on whatever job needed to be done. Ken continued until his death a friendship begun many years ago when he was a Big Brother to a young man. His wife, Jill, is a cherished member of the Divisional Committee for Services to the Developmentally Disabled and his son Andrew was a member of the JBFCS Friends. Our sincere condolences to Jill, their children and grandchildren. Seymour R. Askin, Jr. Chairman of the Board Joseph S. Kaplan President Alan B. Siskind, Ph.D Executive Vice President & CEO Paul Levine Assoc. Executive Vice President EDELSON-Kenneth J. The Divisional Committee and Staff of the Division for Developmental Disabilities of the Jewish Board of Family and Children's Services note with sadness the death of Kenneth Edelson, husband of Jill, our devoted committee member. Ken and Jill have always been good friends to those living with disabilities. Ken will be greatly missed. Susan Tofel Chair, Divisional Committee for Developmental Disabilities Joel S. Rosenshein, Ph.D Director, Division for Developmental Disabilties Esther Lustig Associate Director

But that is what the Pentagon's Ballistic Missile Defense Organization seems to hope the new administration will do. Rushing ahead with this project would be a serious mistake.

title: Commercial Real Estate; Glass Box Will Mark Midtown Home of Photography Center
description: In the middle of Grace Plaza, one of the more notorious public spaces in Midtown during the 1980's, a glass-walled entrance pavilion will be built this year to usher students and faculty members into the new underground school of the International Center of Photography.

title: To Be German and Proud: Patriotism Versus the Past
description: Cornelia Schmalz-Jacobsen, a German politician, has tried, but she just cannot say it. The phrase will not come out of her mouth. ''Not even over my dead body,'' she explains, ''could I say that I am proud to be a German. I even have great difficulty singing the national anthem.''

title: AVAYA GAINS ON PROFIT FORECAST
description: Avaya, a producer of office communications equipment, yesterday raised its estimate for earnings in the year ending in September to $1.27 a share, from $1.23. Shares in Avaya, which is based in Basking Ridge, N.J., climbed $2.56, or 22.3 percent, to $14.06 on word of the disclosure, which the company made in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. Avaya, which was spun off from Lucent Technologies last year, reaffirmed estimates of revenue growth in the midsingle digits and a doubling of net income for the fiscal year. Simon Romero

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOROWITZ, JOSEF,
description: HOROWITZ-Josef, DDS. Died on January 8, 2001 at MemorialSloane Kettering Hospital of cancer. His career as a dentist included service as a Captain in Germany during World War II. He leaves his devoted wife Leatha Lykins; daughter Lynne Van Engel, her husband Daniel and his grandchildren, Emily and Madeleine. He is also survived by his son, Martin Horowitz, his wife Heidi and children, Nathaniel and Ana and a second son Glenn Horowitz, his wife Rebecca; and his sister, Rosalie Lang of Seattle. Dr. Horowitz was a gentle, good and compassionate man who will be sorely missed. Gifts may be sent in his honor to Meals On Wheels.

title: Pinot Grigio Upgrade
description: PINOT GRIGIO, an Italian white wine, does not usually merit a second thought -- at least the mass-market versions don't. You buy it, chill it and drink it, and generally it is crisp, cold and characterless. It is neutral enough to go with just about any light-bodied food. And it is eminently forgettable.

title: SENATOR WANTS BAN ON ALASKAN CRUDE EXPORTS RESTORED
description: After an Oregon newspaper reported on Sunday that BP Amoco had manipulated crude oil prices on the West Coast, Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, wrote to President Clinton asking that a ban on exports of Alaskan crude oil, lifted in 1996, be reinstated. The Oregonian of Portland said that BP Amoco had sold Alaskan crude in Asia at lower prices than it could have received from American refiners to squeeze supply in California, Oregon and Washington, where gasoline prices are as much as 20 percent higher than the national average. The newspaper said it obtained the documents by suing the Federal Trade Commission, which reviewed BP Amoco's takeover of Atlantic Richfield in 1999. A spokeswoman for BP Amoco said the company had done nothing illegal or anticompetitive.

title: Into the Mouths of Babes
description: THERE is a specter haunting American cuisine. It comes in many guises. It bears many names. If it were human, it would have a terrible time getting a date, for it is bland, boring and overweight. Yet, with the ease of a practiced Don Juan, it seduces chefs, restaurateurs and, especially, culinary journalists. I speak of comfort food.

title: Lemon Meringue Scales New Heights
description: LEMON meringue . . . cake? It was not a mistake on the menu at Eli's Manhattan. There it was in the display case of the tapestry-hung space, transformed in the evening from a casual cafe to a softly lighted, more serious restaurant: a golden layer cake that could be a state fair prizewinner, crowned with a bouffant Matterhorn of lightly toasted meringue.

title: Corrections
description: The Public Lives profile on Monday, about the Clinton administration's top drug policy official, Gen. Barry R. McCaffrey, who advocates health insurance coverage for addiction and mental illness on a par with benefits for physical illness, referred incorrectly to the group that has just received such benefits under the federal employee plan. The nine million insured are not all current federal employees; they include dependents and retirees.

title: THERMO CARDIOSYSTEMS BID EMERGES
description: Abiomed, which is developing an artificial heart, said it had been an unannounced rival since last month to Thoratec Laboratories' plan to acquire Thermo Cardiosystems, a heart-pump maker. Thoratec agreed last October to acquire Thermo for shares of its stock that were then worth $572 million but have since declined to less than $360 million. Abiomed confirmed yesterday that discussions with Thermo that began last month had resulted in a formal bid of cash and Abiomed stock worth about $440 million. Thermo and Thoratec shareholders are scheduled to vote on the Thoratec agreement on Feb. 13. Barnaby J. Feder

description: Jim McKay, who hosted the Olympics with warmth and grace at ABC, will join NBC Sports for the 2002 Winter Olympics from Salt Lake City, an industry official said today.

title: Corrections

It was the Bornheim district of Frankfurt am Main; not the town of Bornheim near Bonn.

title: Lyme Disease Drops, Especially in Areas Near New York City
description: Reported cases of the tick-borne Lyme disease dropped last year in Westchester, Suffolk, Nassau and Dutchess Counties but increased in New York City and other parts of the state, according to preliminary statistics released today by state and city health officials.

title: Globe Gets New President
description: Richard J. Daniels has been named president of the Globe Newspaper Company, effective Feb. 16, it was announced yesterday by Richard H. Gilman, publisher of The Boston Globe. Mr. Daniels replaces William B. Huff, 50, who is retiring after 25 years with the company, including serving as president since January 1998.

title: ADVANCED MICRO IS SEEKING PARTNER FOR $4 BILLION PLANT
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc., the Intel Corporation's main rival in the computer microprocessor market, said it planned to find a partner and then build a new factory costing as much as $4 billion by 2004. The plant will make chips on larger wafers about the size of a dinner plate, allowing more than twice as many processors to be built on each wafer and cutting production costs by 30 percent. But the huge cost of tooling up such a plant means ''it is likely that we will enter into some sort of collaborative venture'' rather than going it alone, the company's president, Hector Ruiz, told an industry conference.

Sales at the Oxford Street store rose 1 percent from 1999 levels in the six weeks ended Jan. 6, while sales at its second store, in Manchester, rose 22 percent. Last year, both stores posted strong increases in sales.

title: SOME MIGHT CALL IT HEAVEN
description: Microsoft and LaZ-Boy Inc. said they were teaming to sell the first ''e-cliner,'' a Web-television-enabled reclining armchair. La-Z-Boy's Explorer model comes with a keyboard and a Sony receiver for Microsoft's WebTV, and buyers will get two free months of the interactive television service. The chair's left arm has a fold-out tray table with a keyboard that connects to the receiver using an infrared beam, a 120-volt outlet with a surge protector and ports for high-speed and standard Internet access lines. In the right arm, meanwhile, are a drink holder and storage space. Users must provide their own TV and phone lines. The WebTV chair sells for $1,049 to $1,299, compared with $299 to $1,800 for unwired models. Microsoft's WebTV Plus service costs $24.95 a month.

description: ICG Communications, an embattled provider of communications and Internet services that filed for bankruptcy protection in November, said yesterday that it would lay off 500 employees, or nearly a quarter of its work force. title: NISSAN TO FARM OUT SOME ASSEMBLY
description: The Nissan Motor Company, Japan's third-largest auto maker, plans to cut costs by paying some of its parts suppliers to assemble certain components instead of doing the work itself. Starting in June, the Calsonic Kansei Corporation, in which Nissan holds a 32 percent stake, will send employees to a Nissan plant to set up and operate a factory line that will assemble most of a new- model sedan, leaving Nissan to add only six or seven components to complete the car. A spokesman said Nissan was considering doing the same thing with other new cars. Stephanie Strom

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLER, DR. ALEXANDRA.
description: ADLER-Dr. Alexandra. Died on January 4, 2001 at age 99. She was a brilliant researcher, neurologist & psychiatrist, and the daughter of Alfred Adler, one of the founders of modern psychiatry. description: The German-Italian pianist, composer, editor, essayist and educator Ferruccio Busoni, who died in 1924, was one of music's great visionaries. He anticipated the coming of pan-tonality, microtonal scales and even electronic music. He straddled the north-south European cultural divide, but that experience just fostered his belief that internationalism would increasingly characterize music in the 20th century, which is what happened.

title: Mr. Giuliani's Last Opus
description: In his final address on the state of New York City, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani compared himself to Giuseppe Verdi writing ''Falstaff,'' in which the maestro included every theme he could imagine. It was an apt comparison. In his rambling but entertaining two-hour speech, the mayor covered lots of territory, both emotional and otherwise. He made a pitch to burnish his record in fighting crime and boosting the city's economy. But he also tried to take some of the hard edges off his mayoral legacy before it is too late. In contrast to previous years, Mr. Giuliani praised others, talked about progress being a team effort and worked to defuse some of his more explosive past criticisms.

title: The Pastry Chef Who Came to Dinner
description: This pastry chef makes house calls. Michel Floranc, above, who owns Toute Sweet, a wholesale pastry kitchen in Woodside, Queens, will bake souffles or molten chocolate cakes in your kitchen for a dinner party, or he will be there simply to put his desserts on plates with his own personal touch. In his repertory are excellent thin-crusted apple galettes seasoned with a whiff of cinnamon and decorated with a tangle of dried apple peel (left); sumptuous little chestnut cakes; classics like eclairs; and cakes for special occasions. Desserts prepared and put on plates in your home start at $8 a portion (no minimum number of guests), plus a charge of $25 an hour for the chef. Without Mr. Floranc's participation, the pastries start at $1.50 each for miniature tartlets and eclairs. Apple galettes are $7 each, and most large tarts and cakes, which serve 6 to 12, are $25 to $45. Delivery is available in Manhattan for orders of at least $40; (718) 429-8714.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCOVE, RALPH C., MD.
description: MARCOVE-Ralph C., MD. Died peacefully on January 9 at home following a courageous sixteen month battle of pancreatic cancer. He received his BA and MD degrees from Boston University, Cum Laude and distinguished alumnus. He was affiliated with numerous hospitals in the metropolitan area where he was a pioneer in orthoepedic oncology during his 40-year career. He joined Memorial Sloan-Kettering Center in 1962, he was affiliated with Hospital for Special Surgery and most recently clinical professor of orthoepedic surgery at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was a recipient of numerous awards based on his research and clinical treatments of bone tumors. He has authored and co-authored several books on bone tumors and has published over 300 articles relating to bones tumors. Dr. Marcove was also a recognized authority in the field of Asian Art both in the study and collection. He has donated many pieces of art to Boston University, Palmer Museum, Harvard University Art Museum and Indianapolis Museum. He had an avid interest in the field of music being an accomplished drummer. He is survived by his loving wife, Christina, and daughters, Nancy and Laura. Dr. Marcove was dedicated to the study, treatment and cure of bone tumors and gave a special gift to the people whose lives he touched. Services will be at Riverside Chapel at 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC on January 11 at 11:30AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Robert Fine Cancer Research Lab Foundation, Columbia University, 650 West 168 Street, Room 20-05, New York, New York 10032.

As our only car, it offered space for our two children, the dog and the things we hauled around, like the Christmas tree. We liked being in a big vehicle with a high vantage point in a city full of crazy drivers. Since we take public transportation to work and don't drive much, we could rationalize away the bad gas mileage and the high emissions. And to be honest, an S.U.V. projected a different image than a minivan or a station wagon.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HARVEY, SISTER EDMUND, RSHM.
description: HARVEY-Sister Edmund, RSHM. The trustees, faculty, staff, students and alumnae of Marymount Manhattan College mourn the loss of our beloved and committed trustee Sr. Edmund Harvey. Sister Edmund was not only an active trustee of the College since 1987 and current chairperson of the Student Affairs committee of the Board but also was one of the founders of the college and a driving force in its growth since 1947. Sr. Edmund was faculty member in the department of Psychology at MMC from 1948-1960, Director of Admissions from 1960-61 and Academic Dean from 1961-66. She also taught at Marymount College in Tarrytown and during her life was on the Boards of the Marymount School in NYC, Marymount Tarrytown and Marymount Arlington. Currently she served the Order of the Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary as Director of Ongoing Formation. Sister Edmund was a role model for her students, and articulate scholar, a wise spiritual advisor, and a strong and holy woman who cared deeply for her family, her sisters and her extended family at the College. Her spirit lives in the many lives she touched. William E. Murray Chairman, Board of Trustees Regina S. Peruggi President Marymount Manhattan College HARVEY-Sr. Edmund, RSHM, 76, January 9, Bronx, NY. Religious of the Sacred Heart of Mary for 53 years. Educator at Marymount School, NYC; Marymount Manhattan College, NYC; Marymount College, Tarrytown, NY. Survived by a brother, Edmund Harvey of Delray Beach, FL. Visiting Thursday, 12 Noon-7:30PM, Mass Friday, 10:30AM, both at Marymount Convent, Tarrytown, New York. Mr. Sottsass's stature among designers would be hard to overstate: during a legendary career, he has helped shape the course of furniture, products and lighting by artfully blurring the line between industrial design and craft. He has also designed more than 20 distinctive houses, but the California enclave where his friend wanted to build wasn't accustomed to distinctive architectural statements -- Italian or otherwise. In fact, the town had inflexible rules about what type of design it would permit: its primary objective was to maintain the wooded area's ''rural character.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SALESKY, DAVID
description: SALESKY-David. The Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy extend their sincere condolences to Susan Rudin on the loss of her beloved father. Our thoughts and prayers are with Susan and her family as she mourns his passing and celebrates his long, happy life. May her memories of him sustain her and her family and friends comfort her. The Board of Directors of the Women's Committee

title: Refrain From Spain, Though French, Too, in the Main
description: Spain as seen from a distance occupied much of the Philadelphia Orchestra's evening at Carnegie Hall on Tuesday. Falla's ''Nights in the Garden of Spain'' begins with an indigenous composer, but this was a Spaniard saturated in the elegance and fastidiousness of turn-of-the-century French culture. Here, the wildness and the grit of true Iberian music, a certain lawlessness, if you will, have been neatly arranged and polished. In its music, as in its parks and gardens, France leaves little to chance. The civilizing hand of man is everywhere.

title: Using Unusual Materials For Products and Shelves Alike
description: In the 1960's, the Italian company Mandarina Duck began designing ergonomic handbags and luggage in high-tech materials instead of leather. The company's association with high design continues with the recent opening of its flagship store in Paris. (Barcelona, London and Berlin are next; New York is being considered.) No two Mandarina Duck stores will be the same. The Paris shop is designed by the innovative, somewhat rough-around-the-edges Droog Design of Holland (with NL Architects). A changing-room curtain made of metal rods sways to the touch. Some shelving, above right, resembles a stripped-down school locker. A screen of seesawing nails, like the ones everyone in the 80's seemed to have on the coffee table, makes an original kind of shelving, above left. Mandarina Duck, 219 Rue St. Honore 75001; (011) 33-1-42-60-76-20.

title: The Neediest Cases; A Street-Level Apartment Would Seem Like a Castle
description: A row of 19th-century low-rise tenement-style apartment buildings line the east side of First Avenue between 63rd and 64th Streets. Each weekday morning the ground floors are bustling with the commerce of restaurants and small food shops, a sushi bar and a beauty salon, but on the upper floors, the apartments grow empty as residents leave for jobs throughout the city.

title: A Landmark School Ruling
description: In a strong and welcome decision yesterday, State Supreme Court Justice Leland DeGrasse of Manhattan rightly blamed the state's inequitable allocation of education money for the ''parlous state'' of New York City's schools. The state formulas, which have shortchanged the city for decades, deprive city students of the ''sound, basic education'' guaranteed by New York State's Constitution, Justice DeGrasse ruled in a carefully argued decision. He also decreed that the state's deficient funding system violates the federal Civil Rights Act of 1964 by causing an adverse and disparate impact on minority students, over 70 percent of whom live in New York City.

title: Transcript of Bill Penningtons Visit to the Giants Forum
description: Bill Pennington, who covers the Giants for The Times, visited the forum on Thursday, Jan. 11, to discuss the team and answer questions. Here is a transcript of the event.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: OPEC Faces Balancing Act As It Seeks to Cut Output

title: Marsh & McLennan Fills Executive Post
description: Heidi Miller, who made headlines twice last year by quitting chief financial officer posts, first at Citigroup and then at Priceline.com, will join the Marsh & McLennan Companies, whose roots date back to 1871.

title: Linda Chavez, Victim of Politics?
description: To the Editor:

title: YAMAHA AND FORD IN VENTURE
description: The Yamaha Motor Corporation said it had agreed to set up a joint venture in the Unites States with the Ford Motor Company to develop and manufacture engines for recreational boats. Details like the size and site of the venture had not yet been settled, the company said. Yamaha and Ford said they had invited the Toyota Motor Corporation to join the venture, and that Toyota was considering doing so. Miki Tanikawa

title: ROSS PEROT'S COMPUTER COMPANY TO CUT 200 JOBS
description: The Perot Systems Corporation, the computer company founded by the billionaire Ross Perot, said yesterday that it would cut 200 jobs, or 2.7 percent of its work force, to focus on selling services to finance, health care and manufacturing companies. Perot Systems will take a fourth-quarter charge of $37 million and a first-quarter charge of $11 million for the cuts. Excluding the charges, Perot Systems said it had a profit of 12 cents to 13 cents a share in the fourth quarter and expected a profit of 13 cents to 14 cents a share in the first quarter, in line with analysts' forecasts.

title: Leno Signs For 5 Years Of 'Tonight'
description: Jay Leno said today that he had agreed to a new contract with NBC that will extend his tenure as host of the network's ''Tonight'' show for another five years. The deal will be the third five-year contract Mr. Leno has signed to serve as host of television's oldest late-night show. He had a year remaining on his current deal.

title: Onboard DVD-R Drive Option Another First For Apple
description: Like most computer makers, Apple Computer has been hit hard by the recent decline of the home computer market. But the company is coming off the ropes swinging, using this week's Macworld Expo in San Francisco as an opportunity to unveil not only its new product line, but also its strategy for the future: to serve as the premier hub for the digital gizmos we carry around these days, like MP3 players, digital cameras and camcorders, Palm devices and DVD players.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LASSIN, RAY
description: LASSIN-Ray. Died January 6, 2001. We mourn the loss of Ray Lassin, beloved wife of deceased husband Irving Lassin. Beloved mother of Marsha, Byron and June. Beloved mother-in-law of Michael, beloved grandmother of Patricia, Daniel and David. Beloved sister of Charlotte, Beatrice and Esther. Beloved sister-in-law of Estelle. Beloved aunt of many nieces and nephews. Her death was a deep loss for our closely connected family. We love you and will miss you, Rifky Ray Rosenberg Lassin.

title: Tony Hall Chosen as New Director of Londons Royal Opera House
description: LONDON, Jan. 11  The Royal Opera House announced today that Tony Hall, 49, a career executive with the BBC, will become its new director, installing a newsman in charge of a house that in recent years has become as famous for the conspiracies, betrayals and back-stabbings off stage as on.

title: CHIP MAKER WILL SPIN OFF UNIT
description: The NEC Corporation of Japan said it would convert a division that makes processors for network equipment into a wholly owned subsidiary in preparation for taking the unit public. The unit handles design, development and sales of chips for mobile phone handsets and optical communications equipment, a spokesman said. Two competitors, Nortel Networks and Lucent Technologies, have announced similar plans to offer shares in component units.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARSHALL, VICTOR F., M.D.
description: MARSHALL-Victor F., M.D. The Boards, Faculty, and Staff of Weill Medical College of Cornell University and New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our distinguished colleague Victor F. Marshall, M.D. Dr. Marshall, who was born in Culpeper, Virginia, attended Washington and Lee University and the University of Virginia. After receiving his medical degree from the University of Virginia, he completed a surgery internship and subsequent surgery and urology residencies at The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center. From 1946 to 1976, he was Chief of the Division of Urology at our institution, and was the first James J. Colt Professor of Urology. As a clinician, a researcher, and an educator, Dr. Marshall was a national leader. He made significant contributions in the treatment of stress urinary incontinence, bladder cancer, and pediatric urology, trained many chairmen of urology around the country, and won most of the highest awards in the field. In 1987, he received the Maurice R. Greenberg Distinguished Service Award, New York-Cornell's highest honor. We extend our deepest condolences to his family. Antonio M. Gotto, Jr., M.D., D.Phil. Dean Weill Medical College of Cornell University Herbert Pardes, M.D. President and CEO NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital E. Darracott Vaughan, Jr., M.D. Chairman Department of Urology Weill Medical College

title: Scientists Find Second Pulsar and Link It to Ancient Supernova
description: Astronomers using the Earth-orbiting Chandra X-Ray Observatory have found what they say is evidence that a rapidly spinning object known as a pulsar was created in the spectacular explosion of a massive star that the Chinese recorded in A.D. 386.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MCHENRY, LAURETTE
description: McHENRY-Laurette. On January 5, 2001. Beloved wife of the late William. Survived by her sister, Norma Best, and other family. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street, Friday 2-5 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass at St. Francis DeSales Church, 135 East 96 Street, Saturday 11 AM. Interment Pinelawn Memorial Park.

description: Manhattan

title: Exide Says Indictment Is Likely Over Battery Sales
description: The Exide Corporation, the world's largest maker of car batteries, said today that federal prosecutors, who have been examining its business relationship with Sears, Roebuck & Company, were likely to seek a criminal indictment of the battery company or else demand a plea bargain involving a large fine.

title: Gateway and Hewlett-Packard Hit Hard by Sales Slowdown
description: Investors in computer companies took a double blow to their already diminished hopes for 2001 late today. Gateway announced both disappointing fourth-quarter earnings and layoffs, and Hewlett-Packard warned that it would fall short of Wall Street's projections for its current quarter.

title: SEND.COM FOLDS ITS TENT
description: Citing economic uncertainty and the inability to generate additional financing, Send.com, the online gift-giving service, said it would cease operations and close. The company, which had raised almost $45 million during its four years of operation, said it would honor all orders received before Monday. Ken Cassar, senior retail analyst at Jupiter Communications in New York, said many companies have struggled in the online specialty gift market. ''One reason for Send.com's failure would be its exaggerated sense of potential when the reality was they didn't have the capability to become anything more than a niche business,'' he said. Catherine Greenman

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FINNERAN, WILLIAM C., JR.
description: FINNERAN-William C., Jr. The Society of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick in the City of New York records with profound sorrow the death of William C. Finneran Jr., a Life Member of the Society and extends sincere sympathy to his family. Timothy G. Reynolds, President Henry F. White, Jr., Historian

title: Mother Nature Sends Snow To Test Suburban Manhood
description: SNOW is the only adverse meteorological condition that gives humanity a fighting chance. We must endure floods, tornadoes, cyclones, hurricanes, hailstorms and ice storms as best we can, usually by retreating inside and swearing. But when the first snowstorm arrives each winter, mankind, particularly suburban man, has an opportunity to grab a shovel and show Mother Nature who's boss.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RICHARDSON, DEREK
description: RICHARDSON - Derek. Passed away on January 7, 2001 age 83, after a year's bout with cancer. Formerly of Westport, CT., Derek leaves behind his beloved wife of 60 years, Barbara, and his five children, Derek P., David S., Gay R. Smith, Franklin S. (Tony), and Kate R. Jamison. He is survived by his brother Stanton Richardson of Portland, Ore., thirteen grandchildren, two great-grandchildren and countless friends. He spent 30 years as a dedicated employee of Olin Corporation, rising to the rank of Vice President of Marketing and Sales. Derek will be most remembered for his loyalty, generosity, and devotion to family, friends, church and innumerable charitable organizations. A memorial service will be held at the Trinity Church, Southport, CT. on January 20th, at 2 PM. In lieu of flowers, donations should be made to The Nature Conservancy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEL TORO, MARY ELLIN (NEE KEET)
description: del TORO-Mary Ellin (nee Keet). Died Monday, January 8 at her daughter Diane Garlock's home, Leavenworth, KS. Widow of Walter H. del Toro. She had homes in Winchester, TN and Upper Saranac Lake, NY. Born in Jamaica Estates, NY in 1927. Attended the Mary Louise Academy and married 1947. Lived in East Northport, NY. She taught reading at Christ the King School in Commack, NY and Northport/East Northport School District where she retired in 1993. She is survived by six children, Diane Garlock of KS, Linda Garlock of WN, Kathy Habgood of Rochester, NY, James del Toro of TN, Paul del Toro of CO and Brian del Toro of NY, NY, 14 grandchildren, two great grandchildren. Funeral at St. Francis de Sales Catholic Church in Leavenworth, KS, Friday, January 12.

description: The Stratos Global Corporation said today that two top executives -- Derek Woods, its chief executive, and Robert Benson, its chief financial officer -- had resigned.

title: America's Biggest Airlines Head East
description: United Airlines and American Airlines, the nation's two largest carriers, will aggressively expand their operations in the Northeast, and the legendary but no longer viable Trans World Airlines will be taken over. That will be the net effect of a complex set of agreements among five different airlines, pending the approval of federal regulators and a bankruptcy court. Consumer groups understandably bristle at the prospect of any further consolidation in the airline industry, but these agreements, which were disclosed yesterday, are in the public interest.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: CALIBER LEARNING NETWORK, Baltimore, a provider of communications and training over the Internet, said it would dismiss 40 of its 223 employees, or 17 percent of its work force, to reduce costs as the company tries to become profitable.

description: Drawing up a partition for peace is admittedly a tricky business, but it can work -- provided each party gives the other what it needs: sovereignty, security and a workable arrangement for building a state.

title: SCHWAB TO OFFER AGGREGATION SERVICE
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation said yesterday that it would join the list of banks and brokerage firms that offer to aggregate their customers' financial account information in one place on the World Wide Web. In less than a year, most major financial companies have announced plans to gather account data from competitors on behalf of customers willing to share their passwords. Fidelity Investments, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase already offer account aggregation. Merrill Lynch and E*Trade have said they will offer the service. About 800,000 consumers have signed up for an aggregation service, said Melanie Flanigan, a spokeswoman for Yodlee, the company that provides the service to all of those institutions. Demand for the free service has been so strong at Citigroup that about one-third of the people who signed up for its MyCiti aggregation service do not have an account there, a Citigroup spokesman said. Patrick McGeehan

title: State Officials Are Faulted On Anti-Tobacco Programs
description: Only six states spend even the minimum amount on programs to prevent and stop smoking that is recommended by the Centers for Dsease Control and Prevention, the Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids, an advocacy group in Washington, says in a report to be released today.

title: Low Takes Kamensky To Movies
description: Ron Low passionately believes that the best way for a hockey player to shovel out of the drifts of a slump is for the player to do the spadework alone. Low, the coach of a Rangers team that is burying itself in the standing, has apparently made an exception for Valery Kamensky. Kamensky gets a snow blower.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose on expectations that Japanese exporters and investors will use the currency's recent decline to bring overseas earnings home. In New York, the dollar settled at 116.46 yen, down from 116.69 yen.

description: WASHINGTON  The plan of American Airlines' parent group to acquire the critically ailing Trans World Airlines Inc. and certain US Airways assets, confirmed Wednesday, would give American control of one-fourth of the U.S. air travel market and expand its reach abroad.

title: A History of Dealers in History
description: ''Antiquaires: The Finest Antiques Dealers in Paris'' (Assouline, $70) recounts the history of the centuries-old French antiques industry and explicates the distinctive styles of current Parisian dealers, some of the finest (and most snobbish) in the world. Written by a distinguished French historian of the decorative arts, Jean-Louis Gaillemin, ''Antiquaires'' provides amateurs a glimpse inside this byzantine profession and includes a chapter on ''High Curiosity,'' the cult of unusual items like an ormolu helmet and a papier-mache stag's head.

description: When David Cone and the Yankees parted ways last month, Cone said he wanted to go someplace where he would feel wanted, where he would be needed  someplace like Boston, where Cone will join the Red Sox, whose mission for him will be to defeat the Yankees.

title: A Site Where Writers Can Share Their Pain
description: CATHERINE WALD is a woman on a mission. As the president and chief ''rejecutive'' officer of rejectioncollection.com, Ms. Wald exhorts writers to join their virtual hands together and celebrate -- not their wild successes with publication, but their sad tales of rejection.

title: American Sets Complex Airline Deals in Motion
description: The fate of the audacious plan that would give the nation's two largest airlines control of half the domestic air travel market is now in the hands of government regulators, several labor unions and a Delaware bankruptcy judge.

title: REVLON CREDIT RATINGS CUT, AND BOND PLAN IS ATTACKED
description: Revlon, the cosmetics company controlled by the investor Ronald O. Perelman, had its credit ratings cut yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, which said Revlon's plan to exchange some bonds would be ''tantamount to a default.'' S.& P. lowered the corporate credit and senior secured debt ratings on an affiliated company, Rev Holdings, to CC, the lowest rating for nonbankrupt companies, from CCC-, and said further cuts were possible. The company said in December that it would buy back $630 million of its zero-coupon bonds,, sell new bonds with a later maturity date and swap them for an additional $140 million of the zero-coupon bonds that mature on March 15. Rev Holdings has stated it does not have the money to redeem the maturing bonds, S.& P. said.

title: A Cheaper Flat Panel From Philips Electronics
description: Philips Electronics is giving Apple Computer a run for its money in the flat-panel monitor department -- and the money in question is about $100. The Philips 150X flat-panel monitor has a suggested retail price of $899, compared with $999 for Apple's stylish flat panel of the same screen size.

description: THE reason for the California electricity crisis can be summed up in four words: demand grew, supply didn't.

title: State of the Art: Apple's New Laptop
description: MACINTOSH fans don't always have it easy. They're often found patiently (or vehemently) defending their choice of machine, they must endure occasional pundit predictions that Apple is doomed  and then there's the Laptop Gap. At this very moment, a Mac fan with a pudgy 6.5-pound Apple PowerBook G3 is crammed into an airplane seat somewhere, looking longingly across the aisle as a smug fellow passenger slips open a sleek, superslim Windows laptop.

title: Harnessing a Photon to Bring Quantum Computers Down to Size
description: QUANTUM computers rely on the tiniest objects and smallest interactions in the universe. Scientists measure the atomic spin of molecules and manipulate atoms to make these experimental computers, which one day may perform exceptionally complex calculations.

title: Navigation Alternatives On a Laptop Computer
description: Q. I have a laptop computer but find it incredibly hard to navigate around the screen with just the control knob and buttons below the keyboard. Are there any easier ways to move the cursor?

title: Metro Business Briefing; INSTANT-MESSAGE INVESTMENT
description: Odigo, a Silicon Alley instant-messaging-service company, announced late Tuesday that it had secured $15.35 million in financing from several private investors led by Lazard Technology Partners. Odigo has been a catalyst in a battle with America Online over instant-messaging standards. Odigo is expected to use this new round of financing to expand its instant-messaging services to wireless uses, company officials said. In the battle over standards, America Online has argued that it should not be forced to open up its instant-messaging program to communicate with those provided by other companies because of privacy concerns. But Odigo engineers have repeatedly designed software that has circumvented America Online security measures, allowing Odigo users to communicate with people using AOL's Instant Messenger. Jayson Blair

title: GUATEMALA EASES CURRENCY RULE
description: In an effort to attract foreign investment, remove incentives to use offshore accounts and keep inflation in check, the Guatemalan government said it would lift a ban on the use of foreign currencies for financial transactions inside the country. Beginning on May 1, contracts may be written, salaries paid and bank accounts opened in any currency, not just the Guatemalan quetzal, the economic ministry said.

title: FleetBoston Sells Package Of Bad Loans
description: The FleetBoston Financial Corporation said today that it had sold $1.35 billion of troubled loans to Patriarch Partners, ridding itself of some customers who have had trouble paying back debt.

title: Many Districts Don't Consider City's Gain to Be Their Loss
description: The decision yesterday striking down New York's system of financing education was welcomed in many school districts across the state, though some suburban residents expressed concern about the ruling's long-term implications.

title: Not Really Tempted
description: ''Temptation Island'' -- the ''reality'' program that debuted on Fox Television last night -- is, of course, far less salacious than family watchdog groups suggested it might be. But it is also patently not the effort ''to explore the dynamics of people in serious relationships'' that the Fox Entertainment chairman, Sandy Grushow, said it would be. If lust and envy, two of the seven deadly sins, were to pitch an ''unscripted'' TV show with prime-time restrictions, it might look something like ''Temptation Island,'' in which four couples in long-term relationships find their commitment tested on a tropical island by a harem of well-built, scantily clad members of the opposite sex, all certified by Fox to be free of sexually transmitted diseases.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EDELSON, KENNETH J.

title: Lott and Conservatives Rallying Behind Ashcroft for Justice Post
description: The Republican leader of the Senate today served notice that he had all 50 Republican votes behind President-elect George W. Bush's choice for attorney general, John Ashcroft, and warned that Democratic efforts to derail the nomination could poison the effort to set a new cooperative tone on Capitol Hill.

title: Election Panel Calls for More Money for Equipment and Training
description: An independent commission on election changes, created after problems with presidential balloting in Florida, urged at its first meeting today that more money be dedicated to voting equipment, training and education.

title: A Singing Fish Gets a Personal Touch
description: IN case a plaque-mounted plastic fish that lip-syncs to popular songs isn't weird enough, a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology has come up with a way to allow fans of Boogie Bass and other varieties of the gimmicky singing fish to make their own voices come out of the fish's mouth.

title: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Yahoo Warns Of Sharp Drop In Earnings
description: Facing a slowdown in the overall economy and devastation among Internet companies, Yahoo said yesterday that its profits would fall 10 to 30 percent this year, a sharp reversal from the 34 percent growth that analysts had expected.

title: Legislator Who Endorsed Killing of Police Resigns Under Fire
description: Tom Alciere, a newly elected member of the New Hampshire House who had gained notoriety for saying he supported -- even loved -- the killing of police officers, resigned this afternoon in the face of mounting public outrage.

title: Israeli and Palestinian Officials Meet
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 11  After Israel took limited steps today to ease its blockade of Palestinian territories, senior officials from both sides met late tonight in the latest burst of activity on the deeply troubled peace front.

title: With Plants Sprouting From Walls, It's the Chia Pet of Buildings
description: A new apartment building in Montpellier, in the south of France, is designed to sprout vegetation from its walls. ''I want to see buildings that speak about landscape, sensation and feelings,'' said Edouard Francois, the architect. When he proposed his design for Chateau Le Lez in 1998, he had to overcome objections from authorities who worried that the experimental building would need extra maintenance. The building's exterior walls are crushed volcanic rock that will sustain cacti and figs. Half of the apartments are rentals (from $330 to $1,100), half owner-occupied. Many have open-topped wood cabins on stilts from which to contemplate the nearby river Lez. One-bedroom apartments sold for about $55,000, three bedrooms for about $250,000, all before completion last year. ROBERT SUCH

title: Uruguay's Chief Is Frank (and Frankly Insulting)
description: At 73, President Jorge Batlle likes to say he is in the Carnelli Station of life -- that is the second to last stop on the railroad tracks into Montevideo. So he has nothing to lose by speaking his mind.

title: NO I.P.O. SOON FOR BANK OF CHINA
description: Despite widespread speculation in Asian markets, there is no chance that the Bank of China will conduct an initial pubic offering this year, according to a senior official close to the bank. Meetings the bank held with investment bankers in recent weeks had given rise to rumors that the bank, China's third largest, would go public in a $5 billion offering. The official said the bank would have to go through an extensive restructuring before it could apply for regulatory permission to go public.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, JOSEPH
description: GREENSTEIN - Joseph. Joseph Yussy, Don Jose Greenstein, age 78 died at home peacefully after a long illness on January 9. Master builder, jungle explorer, founder of Su Casa North and South and World War II veteran. Born in the Bronx, New York, son of David and Goldie Greenstein. Survived by his beloved wife of 53 years, Miriam Nates Greenstein; father of daughters Robin Wolfson of Port Chester, New York, and Jody Soltanoff of Woodstock, N.Y.; grandfather of granddaughters Kimberly Wolfson Lisack & Kacey Wolfson; grandsons Dr. Gregory Soltanoff and Eric Soltanoff and Joseph Lisack; sons-in-law Larry and Peter; brothers Morris and Irving Greenstein; special friends Carlene and Tyler. title: Metro Business Briefing; MOVADO TO MOVE HEADQUARTERS
description: The Movado Group Inc., a maker and seller of watches, said yesterday that it was moving its corporate headquarters to Paramus, N.J., from Lyndhurst, N.J., to consolidate management and administrative employees into one location. Movado currently operates offices in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., and Lyndhurst. Employees from Woodcliff will move to the new 58,000-square-foot headquarters in June. Employees from Lyndhurst will move in December. The company also said it would start a line of watches with the Tommy Hilfiger Corporation in the first half of this year.

title: Technology Briefing
description: E-COMMERCE VOTE OF SUPPORT FOR NAPSTER Senator Orrin Hatch called on the recording industry yesterday to catch up with consumer demand for online music, warning that he intended to "do what I can" to see that the major record labels provided for fair, nondiscriminatory licensing of music. Senator Hatch, a Utah Republican who will be chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee on Jan. 20, made his remarks at the opening of a conference sponsored by the Coalition for the Future of Music. About 400 recording artists, technologists, record executives and lawyers gathered at Georgetown University for the two-day event to discuss how the Internet is affecting the creation and dissemination of music. The traditional record industry has been criticized for being slow to offer music online and to provide affordable licenses to Internet companies that are seeking to do so. Senator Hatch, who presided over hearings on the subject last spring, noted that some creative business alliances have since been struck. But he continued to raise the specter of regulation. "It is critical that policy makers be vigilant about keeping the pipes wide open," the senator said, adding that as a songwriter himself he shared the frustrations of artists who find it hard to get adequate distribution and compensation for their music. "If the digital pipes are significantly narrowed by gatekeepers who divert fans to preferred content, a unique opportunity will be lost for creators of music and those fans," he said. Amy Harmon (NYT)

She survived with strength the passing of her much loved husband, Sanford Kommel, and her siblings, Helen, Jack, and Cirelle. She lived to take enormous pride in her grandchildren, Janet and David, her daughter, Helene, and son-inlaw, Gord, she is also survived by Sanford's children, Carolyn, and Robert, by Carolyn's daughter, Deborah, and by nieces, Eda, Selda, Cirelle, Eileen, Robin, and Marcia. In May 2000, Dorothy closed her fur buying office, after a sucessful career lasting over 60 years. She was loved and respected by all in the fur market, Dorothy was active for many years in the Golda Meir Group, and New York Chapter of Hadassa, where she will be greatly missed. Funeral services will be held at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue, at 12:45 P.M. Thursday, January 11th, 2001. Interment will follow at Riverside Cemetery, in Saddle Brook, New Jersey. Flowers to Riverside Chapel or donations to Hadassah's Sight Savers Program, may be sent. Our enduring recollections of her life well lived and her devotion to all of us will be a blessing.

Cisco's second quarter ends Jan. 27. The presentation was Mr. Chambers's first to investors since Dec. 4, when he told analysts the company was not changing its earnings and sales forecasts. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ETHERINGTON, EDWIN D.
description: ETHERINGTON-Edwin D. Of Jupiter Island, Florida, died at his home on Monday, January 8, 2001. He was seventy-six years old. Born in Bayonne, New Jersey, Ted Etherington lived in Old Lyme, Connecticut, and Jupiter Island where he was a resident of twenty-three years. He graduated with distinction from Wesleyan University and Yale Law School. In 1962 he became President and Chief Executive Officer of the American Stock Exchange. From 1966 to 1970 he was President of Wesleyan University in Middletown, Connecticut. He then served as Chairman of both the Center for Voluntary Action in Washington, D.C. and the National Advertising Review Board in New York City. He was a director of several companies including American Express, Automatic Data Processing, Southern New England Telephone, and The United States Trust Company of New York. Throughout his career, Ted Ethertington's altruism found many outlets. He was particularly proud of the Lymes' Youth Service Bureau and the Hobe Sound Child Care Center and the communities they serve. He is survived by his wife of 47 years, Katherine Colean Etherington; his son Deac of Tucson, Arizona; his son Bob and granddaughter Rose Lanier ''Lanie'' of Nashville, Tennessee; and his brother, Donald Etherington of Washington, Connecticut. There will be a private burial in Connecticut. Friends are invited to call at 46-3 Sill Lane, Old Lyme on Saturday, January 13 between 2 and 5PM. A memorial service in Florida will be announced shortly. Memorial contributions should be made to the Lymes' Youth Service Bureau, 59 Lyme Street, Old Lyme, CT 06371, or the Hobe Sound Child Care Center, 11580 SE Gomez Avenue, Hobe Sound, FL 33455. For further information contact the Young and Prill Funeral Home, Stuart, Florida and FultonTheroux Funeral Service, Old Lyme, CT.

description: Arthur Andersen, the giant accounting firm, announced yesterday that Joseph F. Berardino, a managing partner, had been elected chief executive. He will hold that position for four years.

title: Officials Are Forced to Grab the Third Rail of Politics
description: For years, the axiom around the Capitol has been that school aid is the third rail of state politics, capable of powering a political career or killing it quickly. And now a state judge has pushed state officials off the platform and forced them to confront the issue.

title: A Show of Some Very Enduring Solutions
description: ''Most products we use go from cradle to grave,'' said Natascha Drabbe, a Dutch architectural historian, left. But the products in the show she has curated, ''Re(f)use: Solutions for Sustainable Product Design,'' have a life cycle that runs from cradle to cradle. Examples include a ceramic and zirconium wet razor designed by Ross Lovegrove (1989); handbags made from used construction debris; the Wiggle side chair by Frank O. Gehry (1972), seen at center above, made of compressed cardboard and manufactured by Vitra; a freestyle snowboard by Rossignol (1995), made from production waste from skis and snowboards; and disposable cutlery (1996) made from potato starch and designed by Team De Ster of the Netherlands in collaboration with the German firm Biotec.

title: Nuclear Plant Was Restarted Too Fast, Con Ed Says
description: Apparently feeling pressured by supervisors to reopen the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor after 10 months of repairs, control room operators moved too fast to restart the plant last week, making the reactor harder to monitor and control, according to an internal report by Consolidated Edison.

title: Where Hit Men Better Mean It When They 'Yes, Ma'am' the Boss
description: The police in Naples arrested the wife of a jailed mob boss today, a fresh sign that Italian women have broken through the glass ceiling of the organized crime business at least.

title: Taking the Offensive Against Cell Phones
description: JEFF GRIFFIN was sitting in church one Sunday when he witnessed what has become that all-too-common moment of alarm, annoyance and public shame: in the middle of the minister's sermon, someone's cell phone rang -- and rang. A mortified woman in a nearby pew sprang into action, digging desperately through her purse to find the offending device.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SINGER, RABBI YITZCHOK
description: SINGER-Rabbi Yitzchok. EMUNAH of America mourns the loss of Rabbi Yitzchok Singer, brother of our longtime friend and supporter, Jack Singer, and brother-in-law of Shirley Singer, executive vice president. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Marcia Genuth, National President

title: NEW CHIEF FOR REUTERS UNIT
description: Philip Green, 47, was named by the Reuters Group to head its largest business unit, replacing Thomas Glocer, 41, who has been designated to succeed Peter Job as chief executive of the group in July. Mr. Green will be chief executive of Reuters Information, the unit whose financial information terminals are found in many brokerage offices and financial institutions. He will remain chief executive of another unit, Reuters Trading Solutions, which supplies currency trading tools. Reuters has been working to diversify beyond serving news outlets and financial institutions.

title: Escape Prompts Scrutiny Of Texas Prison System
description: The brazen escape of seven inmates from a maximum-security Texas prison last month has quickly become the stuff of a crime thriller whose ending is not yet known. The escapees remain at large, elusive despite a huge manhunt that has intensified since the fugitives were charged with the slaying of a police officer.

title: Poll Watch: Bush Transition Gets High Marks
description: There have been few public polls since the start of the New Year, but a Gallup poll out this week finds the American public generally pleased with George W. Bush's handling of his transition to power, though still not as desirous of a tax cut as they are of repairs to social programs like Social Security, Medicare and health care. In fact, a reduction in federal taxes ranks 13th in a list of 14 priorities put before the public by the Gallup poll.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PIERREPONT, JOHN
description: PIERREPONT-John, 84. On January 10, 2001 after a short illness. Son of the late Ruthurfurd Stuyvesant and Nathalie de Castro Pierrepont, he is survived by his widow, Nancy Weller Pierrepont, a son, John Jay Pierrepont, a daughter, Margaret V.B. Pierrepont, a step-daughter, Nancy Dewey Hoppin, and three grandchildren. His principal interests were in his family and in some of the great charitable institutions of our city: the Wildlife Conservation Society, the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House, and the New York Botanical Garden, and in the growth and well-being of the Knickerbocker Club. A memorial service will be held in New York City at St. James' Episcopal Church, 865 Madison Ave. at 10:30AM on Thursday, January 18. Contributions in his memory may be sent to the attention of Laura James at the Wildlife Conservation Society, 2300 Southern Blvd, Bronx, NY 10460.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARCOVE, RALPH C., MD.
description: MARCOVE-Ralph C., MD. Died peacefully on January 9 at home following a courageous sixteen month battle of pancreatic cancer. He received his BA and MD degrees from Boston University, Cum Laude and distinguished alumnus. He was affiliated with numerous hospitals in the metropolitan area where he was a pioneer in orthoepedic oncology during his 40-year career. He joined Memorial Sloan-Kettering Center in 1962, he was affiliated with Hospital for Special Surgery and most recently clinical professor of orthoepedic surgery at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was a recipient of numerous awards based on his research and clinical treatments of bone tumors. He has authored and co-authored several books on bone tumors and has published over 300 articles relating to bones tumors. Dr. Marcove was also a recognized authority in the field of Asian Art both in the study and collection. He has donated many pieces of art to Boston University, Palmer Museum, Harvard University Art Museum and Indianapolis Museum. He had an avid interest in the field of music being an accomplished drummer. He is survived by his loving wife, Christina, and daughters, Nancy and Laura. Dr. Marcove was dedicated to the study, treatment and cure of bone tumors and gave a special gift to the people whose lives he touched. Services will be at Riverside Chapel at 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue, NYC on January 11 at 11:30AM. Contributions in his memory may be made to The Robert Fine Cancer Research Lab Foundation, Columbia University, 650 West 168 Street, Room 20-05, New York, New York 10032.

title: Game Market Awaits Microsoft's Black Box
description: INTRODUCED to the world with all the fanfare the Defense Department reserves for new multimillion-dollar fighter jets, Microsoft's much-anticipated entry in the video game console market, the Xbox, was unveiled this week by the company's chairman, William H. Gates.

description: It was late September four years ago, and that noted poet laureate, Minnesota Vikings defensive lineman John Randle, was in a four-point stance, bracing for the next Giants play and barking like a dog.

title: Rikers Prisoner Stomps on Cellmate, Killing Him, Officials Say
description: The authorities yesterday were investigating the death of a Rikers Island inmate who they said was found unconscious inside his cell on Tuesday night after being repeatedly stomped on the head by another inmate.

title: MOODY'S CUTS RATING ON SAKS AND SAYS OUTLOOK IS POOR
description: Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating of Saks yesterday to below investment grade and said the outlook for the company was negative, citing ''soft operating performance of the company's department store chains'' and difficult conditions in the retailing industry. Moody's review confirmed the below-investment-grade rating of a proposed spinoff of Saks Fifth Avenue Enterprises. Meanwhile, Bloomberg News reported that a company controlled by Carlos Slim Helu, a Mexican financier, bought 1.95 million shares of Saks stock in the open market last month for $17 million, raising his stake in the company to 14.8 percent from 13.4 percent. Saks, based in Birmingham, Ala., owns a group of regional chains as well as its flagship stores.

title: RETAILER REPORTS STRONG DEMAND
description: The Dixons Group, Britain's largest consumer-electronics retailer, said demand in Western Europe had surged in the first half of its fiscal year, pushing its profits above analysts' forecasts, and that a 6 percent rise in holiday sales meant it could expect a satisfactory second half as well. In the six months ended Nov. 11, net income rose slightly to $:70.6 million ($105.2 million), or 3.4 pence (5 cents) a share, from $:70.4 million ($104.9 million) in the period a year earlier. The figures exclude the company's money-losing Internet service provider, Freeserve, which is being acquired by Wanadoo of France.

title: Lowell Perry, 69, Football Star and Ford Aide
description: Lowell Perry, an all-American receiver at the University of Michigan, the first black assistant coach in the National Football League's modern era and the chairman of the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission in the Ford administration, died Sunday at a hospital in Southfield, Mich. He was 69.

title: COURTTV BUYS 2 WEB SITES
description: CourtTV.com, an online spin-off of the cable TV network, has acquired two crime- oriented Web sites -- thesmokinggun.com and crimelibrary.com -- for an undisclosed sum. Betsy Vorce, a CourtTV.com spokeswoman, said the cost of the two acquisitions would be based on the sites' performance under their new ownership. Thesmokinggun.com publishes legal documents gathered from government and law enforcement agencies, many having to do with well-known people. Crimelibrary.com publishes fiction and nonfiction crime stories. The two sites will continue to operate under their own names, and CourtTV.com will feature links to content from the two sites. Catherine Greenman

title: Russian TV Network Is Said to Be Talking to Turner
description: The American media entrepreneur Ted Turner is in talks to buy part of Russia's biggest independent television network, according to people close to the negotiations. Russia, however, sent signals today that it was not so eager for a deal to take place.

title: Final 'Survivor' May Star in Mean Quiz Show
description: Under increasing pressure to catch up to its rivals in the reality programming genre, NBC has turned to Richard Hatch, the winner of the biggest reality hit so far, CBS's ''Survivor,'' as part of an attempt to create an American version of a British game show.

title: I.B.M. IS NO. 1 ON PATENTS
description: I.B.M. led the parade of companies issued United States patents last year by a wide margin, according to an analysis released yesterday by IFI Claims Patent Services, a patent research firm. I.B.M.'s 2,922 patents included nearly 1,000 in software, a similar total in microelectronics and 400 in data storage. Asian companies, led by NEC of Japan, No. 2 with just over 2,000 patents, made up a majority of the Top 10, although Lucent Technologies moved up from 9th place in 1999 to 5th and Micron Technology jumped to 7th from 14th. Motorola was ninth. Barnaby J. Feder

title: Mogilny Helps Devils Scorch the Coyotes
description: Alexander Mogilny has been the biggest contributor to the Devils' offense for the last month. The Devils have gone 10 games without a loss, and Mogilny has scored 10 goals in that stretch. Mogilny, the gifted wing from Russia, scored two goals tonight to lead the Devils to a 5-1 triumph over the Phoenix Coyotes at Continental Arena.

title: Metro Business Briefing; FIBER-OPTIC RAIL PLAN
description: GPU Inc., the New Jersey utility, said it had reached an agreement with Amtrak to build a fiber-optic network linking six cities along some of the railroad's lines in the Northeast. GPU's Telcom Services subsidiary will build the 375-mile network along Amtrak's Northeast Corridor line, between New York and Washington, and along its Keystone line, between Philadelphia and Harrisburg, Pa. The network will also cover Newark and Baltimore. GPU will string fiber cable using the railroad's existing poles, said David Brauer, the president of Telcom Services. Terms of the 15-year lease were not disclosed.

title: Easy Approval Seen for Education Official
description: President-elect George W. Bush's choice for secretary of education, Roderick R. Paige, told a Senate committee today that he supported using taxpayer money to send children to private schools under some conditions.

title: Motorola Profit Fell in Fourth Quarter
description: Motorola said yesterday that its earnings fell in the fourth quarter as higher sales failed to offset an increase in manufacturing costs, an announcement that underscores the challenges faced by large manufacturers of mobile telephones.

title: Pilot Downed in 1991 Gulf Dogfight Is Now Declared M.I.A.
description: The Navy has decided to change the status of an American fighter pilot shot down over Iraq during the 1991 gulf war from ''killed in action'' to ''missing in action,'' citing new evidence that the pilot survived the crash, defense officials said.

description: TOKYO, Jan. 11 - The president and chief executive of the Bridgestone Corporation, parent of the tire maker that was linked to scores of fatal car accidents in the United States, said today that he would resign in March after eight years in the top post at the Japanese company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FERRARA, JOSEPHINE (SUNNIE)
description: FERRARA-Josephine (Sunnie) Castelluccio, born on the 22nd of August in 1918, in Akron, Ohio. At the age of seven she was sent from relative to relative between Ohio and New York due to the death of her mother. In New York she learned the attributes that took her through life, her independence, self-determination, and, most of all, her strength. As a teenager she lived with her older brother and his wife in Manhattan, moving from apartment to apartment when the rent was due. She met and married her husband, Peter Ferrara, a good-looking young Brooklyn man. After many years of marriage, Peter died, July, 1969. For the past 31 years, Sunnie once again displayed her strength and endurance living life to the fullest in her new home in Pompano Beach, Florida. She reigned over her family with the utmost love and respect. She is survived by her children, Adeline (Addie), Carole, Alex and Jo (Josephine), her grandchildren, Nycole and Jodi and her cherished great grandson, Gavin; her brother, Anthony and Frank Castle; her sister, Rose Mac Sems. She has now joined her sisters Peggy and Lena and her brother Joe. She will always be for her children their strength and the wings beneath their feet. She will be missed and loved always. Mass will be held at Regina Pacis, 65th St & 12th Ave, Brooklyn, 11:00AM Saturday, January 13th. In repose ''Raccuglia & Son'', 321-323 Court St, Brooklyn. 718-855-7737. Visitation Friday, 2-4 & 7-9pm.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GREENSTEIN, JOSEPH

A self made man who truly did things his way. After serving with the armed forces in World War II, he became a very successful builder of private homes throughout Westchester County. In later years, he and his spectacular wife of 53 years, Miriam, owned and operated Su Casa, a unique summer resort hotel in upstate New York. Every winter for 35 years, they spent in the Yucatan on Isla Mujeres, Mexico, where they pioneered a lifestyle and built a beautiful home on the water. Yussy, there was no one like you. You'll be in our hearts and minds forever. Rest in peace. We all hope for happier days to come. Shiva will be observed at 12 Wilkie Avenue, Kingston, New York. title: I.B.M. LAPTOP INCORPORATES TABLET

Folded up, the laptop looks like a thick leather portfolio. Once opened, the left side features a computer with a Pentium III chip and a screen that tilts and flips over for across-the-table presentations. The right side looks like an ordinary paper notepad; when a user takes notes with I.B.M.'s digital pen, though, the notes are displayed seconds later, but as an image file rather than typescript, on the left-side screen. title: UNISYS OFFERS VOTING SYSTEM
