The e-@ction Election Solution could be used to run efficient elections at the city, county or state level, said Unisys, which has already produced electronic voting systems used in Brazil, Costa Rica and the city of Rome. Interest in alternatives to antiquated voting systems has been high since the Florida presidential election debacle, and many companies have claimed to have a part of the solution to the nation's electoral needs. title: DOUBLECLICK CUTS 2001 PROFIT FORECAST
description: Doubleclick, the biggest Internet advertising company, said it broke even in the fourth quarter, on an operating basis, beating analysts' expectations that it would lose 2 cents a share. Including noncash charges and one-time items, the company lost $104 million in the quarter, compared with a loss of $42 million a year earlier. Its revenue increased 41 percent, to $132 million. The company cut its estimate for profits in 2001 by 4 cents, to 7 to 9 cents a share, because it plans to spend $5 million to expand its e-mail business. Last month, Doubleclick called off a plan to buy NetCreations, an e-mail marketing company. Yesterday, Yahoo sharply cut its revenue and profit forecast for 2001 because of soft demand for advertising. Doubleclick said its business would be less affected by this slowdown because an increasing portion of its revenue comes from selling advertising-related software rather than the advertising itself. A real-life Army corporal faces the camera and says: ''And I'll be the first to tell you, the might of the U.S. Army doesn't lie in numbers. It lies in me. I am an army of one.'' By hitting this lone-wolf tone, the ad attempts to address the concerns of young adults who see the Army as a nameless horde, conditioned to follow orders blindly.

Though set in a Taipei whose modern gleam is perpetually cloaked in mist and smog, ''The Personals'' could take place in any city whose residents have purchased material comfort and personal freedom at the cost of loneliness and anomie.

title: G-I SUES THREE LAW FIRMS OVER FILING OF ASBESTOS CLAIMS
description: G-I Holdings sued three law firms for racketeering yesterday, contending that they had ''orchestrated a scheme to inundate the judicial system with hundreds of thousands of asbestos cases without regard to their merit.'' Last week, G-I sought refuge in bankruptcy court from asbestos-liability claims against its GAF subsidiary. G-I's suit yesterday accused one of the firms, Baron & Budd of Dallas, of suborning perjury, and another, Ness, Motley, Loadholt, Richardson & Poole of Mount Pleasant, S.C., of pushing medical experts to give false and misleading testimony. Weitz & Luxenberg of Manhattan is the third firm named in the suit, which was filed in Federal District Court in Manhattan. Defendants in the suit called the allegations frivolous and desperate.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FOX, JOHN L., MD
description: FOX-John L., MD, 83. Died on Saturday, January 6, 2001 at Carolinas Medical Center in Charlotte, NC. The cause of death was due to complications from cardiopulmonary disease. Dr. Fox was born and raised in Brooklyn, NY. He attended Xavier High School in New York City and graduated from St. John's University and New York Medical College. He served as a Captain in the U.S. Army during WW II in the European Theater. During his tour he was attached to the 236-305 General Medical Corps. He was Director of Anesthesia at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York City for many years until his retirement in 1987 and remained on the Honorary Staff. Dr. Fox resided in Garden City, NY for 32 years. Following his retirement he moved to Sag Harbor, NY and recently made his home in Charlotte, NC. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Dolores (nee Klein), and children; John of Garden City, NY, Kevin of Fort Wayne, IN, Michael of Midlothian, VA, Mary Giedraitis of Charlotte, NC, Catherine Bell of West Islip, NY, and Elizabeth Stewart of Cumming, GA, and twelve grandchildren. He was predeceased by his brother Vincent Fox. A Mass of Christian Burial was held at St. Gabriel RC Church in Charlotte, NC on Monday, January 8. Interment followed in Forest Lawn East Cemetery, in Matthews, NC. Services were in the care of Hankins & Whittington Matthews Chapel, 3700 Forest Lawn Drive.

title: Metro Business Briefing; STOCK OFFERING WITHDRAWN
description: Dean & DeLuca Inc., the owner of gourmet food stores, has withdrawn plans for an initial public offering as an economic slump threatens to erode its affluent customer base. The withdrawal yesterday cited ''unfavorable market conditions.'' Dane Neller, the company's vice chairman, blamed a ''choppy market,'' not the recent national slump in retail sales, for the company's decision to pull the stock registration. He said the company would probably refile the I.P.O. when the market improved. ''We have actually had an extremely good year,'' Mr. Neller said. ''We have had increasing revenue, not decreasing.'' Dean & DeLuca filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission in May to raise as much as $69 million through a stock sale. The company had planned to use the cash to help start a national build-out of its stores and Internet site.

title: Much-Sought Speech by Ashcroft Is Found
description: As supporters of John Ashcroft's appointment as attorney general stepped up their campaign, Congressional officials said today that they would soon receive a copy of a May 1999 speech Mr. Ashcroft delivered at Bob Jones University that opponents have hoped would help to damage his chances.

title: INTEREST RATE STEADY IN BRITAIN
description: Resisting pressure from unions and business groups to match the Federal Reserve's recent move, the Bank of England held its benchmark interest rate steady, indicating that inflationary pressures remain a bigger worry than the threat of an economic slowdown. Analysts still expect a half-point reduction in British interest rates by mid-year. Separately, South Korea's central bank also left its benchmark interest rate unchanged, while hinting at future cuts. Alan Cowell (NYT)

title: MOTOROLA WARNS ON OUTLOOK
description: Motorola said yesterday that sales of mobile phones were expected to remain sluggish in the months ahead, with the company's overall sales in the first quarter projected to be little changed at $8.8 billion. Investors, who had been expecting the company to forecast a decline, bid up Motorola's shares by more than 4 percent, to $22.13. The company, based in Schaumburg, Ill., is trying to improve its manufacturing efficiency as rivals like Nokia widen their share of the global mobile phone market. Simon Romero (NYT)

Holmes, you may recall, was the 1970's star of X-rated movies who inspired the central character in P. T. Anderson's film ''Boogie Nights.'' Depending on how you look at it, Holmes, who died of AIDS in 1988 at 43, was either a sexual god or a freak of nature.

description: United Parcel Service said yesterday that it might pursue a deal with the United States Postal Service to place its drop boxes in post offices. The FedEx Corporation, UPS's biggest rival, struck such an arrangement with the Postal Service earlier this week. FedEx said on Tuesday that it expected to place more than 10,000 drop boxes at post offices throughout the country beginning in February, generating about $900 million in revenue over seven years. FedEx also agreed to use spare capacity on its aircraft to carry mail.

title: AMERICAN HOMESTAR SEEKS PROTECTION UNDER CHAPTER 11
description: American Homestar, a maker of prefabricated homes, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy-court protection yesterday, citing a ''severe and prolonged decline'' in sales and its debts from a spate of acquisitions. The company, based in League City, Tex., filed in Houston for itself and for 21 subsidiaries. The company closed plants in the first and third quarters of 2000 and renegotiated some bond debt in October. Separately, a competitor, Clayton Homes of Maryville, Tenn., said it would cut back production at its 20 plants and would fall short of profit forecasts because of weak sales.

title: USG CUTS 500 JOBS AND PLANS MILLIONS IN CHARGES
description: The USG Corporation said yesterday that it had eliminated about 500 jobs and would take fourth-quarter charges of $557 million after taxes. Though some of the charges will cover the costs of closing production lines, most are for settling asbestos-liability claims pending against the company's United States Gypsum subsidiary through 2003. The company said it would add $850 million before taxes to its reserves of $335 million to settle the claims, and that it had no estimate for the amount of liability it would still face after 2003. Fourth-quarter earnings will be reduced by about $12.83 a share, leaving only about 66 cents a share in earnings for the quarter, the company said. Shares of USG were down 6 cents yesterday, closing at $21.69.

title: Corrections

title: Visiting Japan, No Ticket Required
description: I lived in Japan for almost five years, and for much of that time I behaved well. By this I mean that I caused my wife only occasional embarrassment. I was not well suited to Japan. I was too loud, too big, too New York, too much. I crossed at red lights. I ate as I walked. I chatted with strangers at the ballpark. I was an oaf.

description: Robots beware. Life in cyberspace just got harder for you.

title: Containing Mad Cow Disease
description: Since November, Europe has been edging toward a state of agricultural gridlock caused by the threat of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease. The concern is that if cattle contract the disease and are eaten by humans, the humans may get a related disease known as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Since 1986 there have been some 80 human deaths, mostly in Britain, linked with the eating of meat from infected animals. What makes the disease especially insidious is the long delay before onset and the hardiness of the infectious agent, called a prion, that causes it.

title: XSTRATA WILL OFFER $520 MILLION FOR ASTURIANA
description: Xstrata A.G., a Swiss-based metals company, said yesterday that it planned to bid 544 million euros ($520 million) for Asturiana de Zinc S.A., a Spanish zinc mining company. Xstrata said it planned to offer 13.50 euros for each Asturiana share on Monday, a premium of 11 percent over Thursday's closing price. Xstrata disclosed details of the bid Friday morning after Asturiana's stock price began surging on speculation of an offer. The stock rose 8 percent before the plans were disclosed, and gained another 1.15 euros, or 9.5 percent, on Friday to close at 13.30 euros ($12.67).

title: AT&T PAYS COX AND COMCAST FOR AT HOME STAKES
description: Satisfying options that it granted last spring, the AT&T Corporation agreed to buy out two partners in the At Home high-speed Internet service by paying Cox Communications Inc. and the Comcast Corporation about $2.9 billion of AT&T stock, or roughly 59.3 million AT&T shares at current prices, for their 30 million shares of At Home. AT&T agreed last March 29 to give Comcast and Cox the option to sell their At Home stakes to AT&T for at least $48 a share, but not more than $3 billion in all, any time between Jan. 1, 2001, and June 4, 2002; At Home's stock price has declined 77 percent since then and closed yesterday at $8.71. When the deal is completed, AT&T will own about 38 percent of At Home's common shares and control 79 percent of the voting rights.

title: UAL WINS AN APPROVAL FOR US AIRWAYS TAKEOVER

European officials were concerned about overlap among US Airways, United and Lufthansa, with which United has a marketing alliance, on routes between Germany and Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Charlotte, N.C. The proposed combination is being examined by American regulators.

title: Op-Art
REMEC WITHDRAWS ITS BID FOR A RIVAL, ALLGON
description: Remec, an American manufacturer of equipment used in cellular-phone networks, said it was abandoning its offer to buy a Swedish rival, Allgon A.B., after failing to muster enough support from Allgon's shareholders. Remec's stock price has fallen 45 percent since the company made its stock-and-cash offer, then worth $488 million, for Allgon on Sept. 28. Remec sweetened the bid in October, but the continuing decline prompted Allgon's board this week to recommend that stockholders shun the offer. Remec's bid was originally intended to rescue Allgon from a hostile all-stock bid from a Swedish rival, LGP Telecom Holding A.B., which withdrew its offer, then worth $352 million, in October. Based on its closing price yesterday, Allgon's total market value was $272 million.

title: Cynicism Abounds as Californians Lurch Through Energy Shortages

title: Teenage Pickup Gambits, All to the Tunes of the 70's
description: Forget ''Temptation Island.'' The full-evening piece by Mark Dendy that opened the Altogether Different festival at the Joyce Theater on Wednesday night is an uninhibited parade of sexual come-ons as envisioned by a teenage boy growing up in the 1970's. Called ''I'm Going to My Room to Be Cool Now and I Don't Want to Be Disturbed,'' Mr. Dendy's piece is an expertly staged and directed suite of dances set to music of the time, performed by seven good-looking dancers who defy the laws of gravity with supple technical skill and unflagging energy.

The company is seeking large investors to take stakes in Biovitrum, which will be closely held.

title: PRICES RISE FASTER IN BRAZIL
description: Inflation gathered speed for a second month in December in Brazil after the government raised fuel prices. The government index of consumer prices gained 0.59 percent, almost twice the pace of the month before. For the year, the index rose 5.97 percent, in line with the government's 6 percent target. Analysts said there was still room for the Brazilian central bank to reduce interest rates to encourage growth.

title: The Ballad of Cone's Comeback
description: I can see it now. David Cone, who left the Yankees for the Red Sox this week, rides back into the Bronx with the bad guys, breaks up the place and swaggers out, blowing imaginary smoke from the end of his extended index finger. Women weep, and old men scratch their heads in admiration. ''Never should have let that boy go.'' Then they march to the sheriff's office and demand an explanation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GULKER, JACK I.
description: GULKER-Jack I. Beloved husband of the late Bessie. Loving father of Rita and Martin Schiller, and Dr. Ira Caryle Gulker. Dear brother of Samuel and Dorothy Gulker, Abraham and Lillian Gulker, and Pearl Stern. Loving grandfather of Allan Steinmauer, Margery Feld, Jennifer Ephron, Holly Gulker and Matthew Gulker. Adored great-grandfather of six. Services Sunday, 1:30PM, at ''The Riverside'', 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, New York.

title: At American, The Successor Bets Boldly
description: During the nearly three years since he took the reins as chief executive of the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, Donald J. Carty has most often been defined by who he was not.

title: World Business Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLASER, NATHAN
description: BLASER-Nathan. On January 12, 2001. Beloved husband of Maria. Loving father of John, Randy and Sheryl. Dear brother of Sanford and Rose. Adoring grandfather of Alexander, Hunter, Eric and Brittany. Cherished friend. He will be profoundly missed. Visiting Saturday 7-9PM. Service Sunday 12:45PM at ''The Riverside,'' 76th Street and Amsterdam Ave.

title: Roots of the Slowdown
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Middle East, Together and Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HELLER, BRUCE A.
description: HELLER-Bruce A. On January 12th, 2001 of lung cancer. Beloved son of Elaine and Herbert. Dear brother of Lloyd and brother-inlaw of Cathy. Loving uncle of Amy, Maggie and Adam. You were taken too soon. We'll miss your free and youthful spirit. Services Sunday, January 14th, 11:30 AM, at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street. Interment to follow at Westchester Hills Cemetery.

title: Effort on Missile Upkeep Falters, Report Finds
description: A new report by the General Accounting Office says a program to refurbish and extend the life of the nation's aging nuclear warheads is behind its original schedule, 70 percent over budget and plagued by management difficulties.

title: World Briefing
description: EUROPE

title: Judah's Focus Has to Stay In the Ring
description: It would seem to be the last thing a fighter has to worry about, but Zab Judah says his biggest concern in his title defense against Reggie Green on Saturday night is the possibility of boredom.

title: Like Acting and Loving, Honor Suits Jeanne Moreau
description: After an acting career that began in 1948 and has embraced more than 110 movies, Jeanne Moreau has become immortal. For her fans this may not be news. But on Wednesday, dressed in the embroidered uniform mandated by Napoleon, just two weeks from her 73rd birthday, Ms. Moreau became the first woman to be inducted into France's Academy of Fine Arts. Now, according to French tradition, she can really be called une immortelle.

title: Mexican Ruling May Let Spain Try Argentine
description: In a decision that could change international law, a federal judge ruled today that Mexico can extradite a former Argentine navy officer to Spain to face charges of human rights abuses against Spaniards under Argentina's military dictatorship two decades ago.

title: Critics See Little in Ashcroft Speech to Derail Nomination
description: The mystery over what John Ashcroft told an audience at Bob Jones University two years ago ended today when a transcript of his remarks was released showing that he made a series of strongly religious statements.

title: Wall to Wall Baroque, But Who's Complaining?
description: Il Giardino Armonico, the Italian period instrument band that performed at Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday evening, is the kind of ensemble that makes listeners eager to follow its adventures through the repertory. The group, which is directed by Giovanni Antonini, its flute and recorder soloist, plays with the brisk, slightly brash energy that characterized the early recordings of Musica Antiqua Koln, and the adventurous, even audacious interpretive freedom that made Gregorio Paniagua's recordings with his Atrium Musicae de Madrid so irresistible.

title: In His First Days, Bush Plans Review of Clintons Acts
description: CRAWFORD, Tex., Jan. 12  President-elect George W. Bush said today that he planned to review and possibly roll back some of the most ambitious initiatives that President Clinton has taken in recent days, including regulations that put nearly 60 million acres of the nation's forests off limits to development.

title: NBC, Facing a Drop in Ads, Will Cut Up to 600 Positions
description: NBC, accelerating a continuing cost-cutting program in the face of a drop in advertising, will cut 5 to 10 percent of its work force, or anywhere from 300 to 600 jobs. The company expects the reduction, at least some of which it hopes will be achieved through attrition, to be complete by the end of March.

title: 'What Sales Slump?' Foreign Makers Ask
description: For the Nissan Motor Company, it seems like a poor time to be thinking about expanding in the United States. Its troubles at home in Japan are forcing it to close five factories there. Meanwhile, auto sales are slowing sharply here.

title: Fixing Schools Without a Voucher Fight
description: The Bush administration says the first legislative train out of its station will be education reform. That's fitting, because of the high priority Mr. Bush put on education as governor and candidate, and because just about everyone agrees that schooling in the United States needs a thorough overhaul. Nowhere is this clearer than in Washington, where dozens of federal programs dispense billions of dollars with no visible impact on the performance of students or schools. The 106th Congress flirted with reforms but failed to act. Now the 107th faces the challenge.

title: Article 2001011390703696511 -- No Title
description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Measuring Up For Ballet Class
description: Should all children have access to training intended to lead to a career in the highly competitive art of ballet? Should ballet schools be allowed to select the children they believe are most promising? Those questions have been raised, to considerable furor, by Krissy Keefer, a modern dancer, choreographer and teacher whose daughter was not chosen in an audition this summer for a preprofessional beginners' program at the San Francisco Ballet School.

title: Abroad at Home; Perversion Of the Process
description: Linda Chavez was quite right to say, when she withdrew as labor secretary-designate, that the confirmation process in Washington has become ''a game of search and destroy.''

title: Runaway Van Kills 2 Pedestrians in Bronx
description: Two pedestrians in the High Bridge section of the Bronx were struck and killed yesterday by a van that was driven by a drunk man, the police said.

title: VOLVO UNHAPPY WITH ALLIANCE
description: The Swedish motor vehicle manufacturer Volvo A.B. said it was dissatisfied with its alliance with the Mitsubishi Motors Corporation of Japan and was in talks to modify it. Volvo, which owns 5 percent of Mitsubishi Motors and has agreed to buy 19.9 percent of its truck unit, said it was concerned about the growing role of its chief competitor, DaimlerChrysler, which bought 34 percent of Mitsubishi Motors last year and has an option to increase its stake to majority control in 2003. For its part, Mitsubishi Motors has said that it wants to retain its alliance with Volvo, including a medium-size truck they are jointly developing. Volvo won United States regulatory approval last month to acquire the truck division of Renault S.A.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about New York City's settlement of a class action lawsuit over the strip-searching of prisoners misstated the occupation of one plaintiff, Danni Tyson. She is a retail consultant and personal shopper, not a secretary at the United States attorney's office in Brooklyn.

title: HESS WITHDRAWS OFFER TO BUY LASMO, AN OIL PRODUCER
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation said yesterday that it had formally withdrawn its offer to buy Lasmo P.L.C., a British oil exploration and production company, for $3.5 billion in cash and stock. Lasmo said it would accept a bid of $4 billion from Eni S.p.A., Italy's largest oil and gas company. Hess, based in New York, made its offer in November and said last month that it would not try to outbid Eni.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMANN, TRUDY
description: FRIEDMANN - Trudy. Delaire Country Club announces with deep regret the passing of our esteemed member, Trudy Friedmann and extends their sincerest sympathy to her beloved family. Mal Levenson, President

title: City and Municipal Unions Reach Accord on Expanded Benefits
description: The Giuliani administration has reached an agreement with municipal unions on a deal that will expand health care and other benefits for nearly 300,000 city workers and 200,000 municipal retirees.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAHN, NETTIE
description: CAHN-Nettie. Of New York City and Palm Beach, Florida. Formerly of Great Neck, NY on January 9, 2001. Treasured wife of the late Ernest Cahn. Adored mother of Carol Weltz and Mitchel and Lesley Cahn. Loving grandmother of Catherine Weltz, Heather Solomon and Blaire Cahn. Beloved sister of Shirley and Kermit Gordon, the late Miriam Pearlman, and sisterin-law of Eva Kahn. Nettie was a life member of the Women's Division of the American Society for Technion, helping to establish the Nettie Cahn Scholarship as well as the Pearl S. Milch Chair in Biomedical Engineering and Life Sciences. She was also a life member of the National Women's Committee of Brandeis University. She was an active volunteer at the Guild for the Blind and especially enjoyed participating in their annual Posh Sale. In addition to a wonderful sense of humor she was a lover of beauty and style. She was devoted to theater, ballet, opera, travel and her family. She was the quintessential New Yorker and she absolutely adored Central Park. Nettie was very loved and will be deeply missed. Service Sunday, 9:30AM at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. In lieu of flowers donations in her memory may be made to Hospice of Palm Beach County and Technion University.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  JARCHO, LILLIAN
description: JARCHO-Lillian, September 4, 1909-January 12, 2001. Born to immigrant parents and largely selfeducated, she spent 91 years nourishing her mind. Voracious reader, lover of music, ballet and opera. Gardener, historian, traveler and compulsive reader of the New York Times. For 30 years a fighter for socialist causes who believed passionately in a just society. After 1957, a fighter for civil rights, feminism and against the war in Southeast Asia. In later years she worked to help survivors of domestic violence and spent her days growing vegetables at the Queens Botanical Gardens. She could not resist a political debate, picket line or coupon. Beloved wife of the late Ralph Jarcho. Adored mother of Paul, Michael and Alice. Mother-in-law of Judith and Shirley Jarcho, and Tom Gallagher. Grandmother of Michael and Kari, Joshua, Jason and Johanna Jarcho, and Ben Gallagher. Shiva at Alice and Tommy's, Monday, Jan. 15th, 2-7PM.

title: An Embargo in Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BAILEY, JOHN M.
description: BAILEY-John M. On January 11, 2001. Beloved husband of Laura. Adored father of Joshua. Loving son of Morton and Marian Bailey. Devoted son-in-law of Maxwell and Carol Sturtz. Dearest brother of Anne and Stephen Watters, Carol and David Dyer and Ted and Rhonda Sturtz. Cherished uncle of Jesse, Aliza, Justin, Emma, Eva and Satchel. Dear friend and colleague of so many. Service Sunday, 10 AM, Plaza Memorial, 91 Street at Amsterdam Avenue.

title: A Harsh Atmosphere In Spite of a Nude Duet
description: Gardenias have a heady scent. But there was nothing intoxicating about Jose Navas's ''Perfume de Gardenias,'' which received its New York premiere on Thursday night when it was danced by Mr. Navas's Montreal-based Compagnie Flak at the Joyce Theater.

title: In Revamping School Financing, Other States Offer Examples
description: When a State Supreme Court justice ordered the Legislature this week to devise a more equitable school financing system, he sent New York down a path followed by nearly two dozen other states.

title: Oil and War in Sudan
description: Sudan's civil war smolders on at appalling cost, stubbornly resistant to peacemaking. An estimated two million Sudanese have died in 17 years of fighting and famine. Some 4.4 million southern Sudanese have been driven from their homes, the largest displaced population in the world. It is hard to imagine this war getting worse, but now it is -- thanks to the advent of lucrative oil exports.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLS, NINA
description: MILLS-Nina. Born December 2, 1950, died December 28, 2000 in Berkeley, CA. After a long and courageous fight with cancer, she left us too early. Writing, playing music, reading, hiking, traveling, sharing-a life filled with many passions ended too soon. Lovingly and fondly remembering the good years. Michael, Peter, Pumpkin

title: Fire Halts Trains On the West Side
description: A fire in a pile of debris in an electrical equipment room led to the shutdown of nearly all service on the Seventh Avenue subway lines in Manhattan for almost three hours yesterday afternoon, transit officials said.

title: DAIMLERCHRYSLER COMMERCIAL SALES RISE
description: DaimlerChrysler A.G., the big automaker based in Frankfurt, Germany, said that its sales of commercial vehicles climbed 5 percent last year and that it would consolidate into one entity its units that make components like engines and transmissions. The company also said that it was discussing a new joint venture with the Hyundai Motor Company, in which DaimlerChrysler recently acquired a stake, to produce trucks for the Asian market. Ed Andrews (NYT)

title: Crippling the Clean Water Act
description: Ruling in an important environmental case this week, the Supreme Court severely and arbitrarily narrowed the scope of federal clean water protection by overturning a time-honored rule aimed at protecting isolated wetlands. The troubling 5-to-4 decision will make it harder to stem the loss of wetlands that act as natural filters for drinking water, help control floods and provide critical habitat for wildlife.

title: Yankees and Jeter Are Nearing Agreement on Long-Term Deal
description: If Derek Jeter reaches an agreement on the largest sports contract in New York history, it will probably come early next week. Casey Close, the agent for the Yankees shortstop, is engaged in negotiations with the team, and while club executives and Close did not return calls yesterday, one major league executive with knowledge of the talks said there was optimism about a long-term deal.

title: The Memories Linger In the Phills Tragedy
description: Within days after he heard about the accident, Alonzo Mourning drove his souped-up, British-made Aston Martin back to the dealership. He no longer wanted to own a high-performance sports car. Shaquille O'Neal did not want his, either. He asked his mother, Lucille Harrison, to take back his platinum Ferrari M456, which could exceed 200 miles an hour.

title: Faust Learns the Painful Truth: Perfection Is Not for the Having
description: Toward the end of Busoni's opera ''Doktor Faust,'' which is now receiving its premiere performances at the Metropolitan Opera, the famous Wittenberg magus who made a pact with the devil is looking a bit shopworn. Faust has done his share of murders; he has seduced a bride on her wedding day and later abandoned her and their newborn child; he has caroused to his heart's content. But the novelty of novelty has started to wear thin. So Mephistopheles, the consummate puppeteer, pulls another trick out of the flames. He offers Faust the pleasures of Helen of Troy.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a decision by Timothy McVeigh to end appeals of his death sentence for the bombing of the federal building in Oklahoma City referred erroneously to the reaction of Tina Tomlin, whose husband was among those killed. The comment  "By seeming to accept his own death, he may be trying to cheat his victims out of some level of satisfaction they would have had if he had been led down the corridor to his execution still wanting to live"  was a paraphrase of Ms. Tomlin's views and should not have appeared in quotation marks.

title: California Can Tame Its Crisis
description: The lesson to be learned from California's exploding electricity prices and the threat of bankruptcy for its utility companies is not, as some have suggested, that electricity deregulation is inherently a bad idea. California's system blew up when the flaws in the way it implemented reform collided with a run of bad luck.

title: The Bawdy King of Baltimore
description: The Goose's weekly radio show did not start until 7 on Thursday night, but the Barn was already packed by 4 p.m., wall to wall, 300 people, maybe 400, if the truth and the fire marshal be told. A guy in a purple Santa Claus hat was there, drinking straight from a pitcher. So was a woman decked out in a home-made bird costume.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the News Watch column of Circuits on Thursday comparing the price of a new 15-inch flat panel computer monitor from Philips Electronics with one from Apple Computer gave an outdated price for the Apple product. It was reduced on Tuesday to $799, from $999, and is thus $100 less than the Philips monitor, not $100 more.

title: U.S. to Offer Detailed Trail Of bin Laden in Bomb Trial
description: By the late spring of 1996, American intelligence learned that a group of Muslim extremists bent on Holy War against the United States had established a base in Nairobi, Kenya, the government says. The authorities believed that the operatives were tied to Osama bin Laden, the Saudi exile in Afghanistan suspected of terrorism against Americans abroad.

title: Any Means to an End Zone; Meadowlands Mortals Do What It Takes to See Giants
description: In the plain little towns that ring the Meadowlands, where Giants Stadium rises from the swampy flats like a forbidden city, Sunday's N.F.C. championship game will carry with it a familiar, slightly bittersweet taste of exclusion.

title: ADVISERS SET FOR STATOIL OFFER
description: The Norwegian government said it had chosen three investment banks to manage the initial public offering of Statoil, the state-owned oil company. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and UBS Warburg, the investment-banking arm of UBS A.G., will coordinate the offering internationally along with DnB Markets, a unit of Den Norske Bank, a Norwegian bank. Goldman Sachs, which managed the initial offering of Telenor, Norway's dominant telephone company, late last year, was notably omitted from the deal. The Statoil offering is expected to raise 3 billion to 5 billion euros ($2.9 billion to $4.8 billion) for 10 percent to 25 percent of the big oil company.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GRAF, KERMIT. KERMIT W.
description: GRAF-Kermit. Kermit W. Graf noted educator and executive director of Cornell Cooperative Extension of Suffolk County died on January 10 at New York University Medical Center after a long illness. Mr. Graf was 48. He was the valued companion of Victor Cornelius of Germantown, NY, the beloved son of Florence Graf and brother of Gail Matzdorf, Joel Graf and Dennis Graf, all of Wisonsin. His engaging personality and insightful leadership will be greatly missed by his family, his colleagues and his many friends. The burial service will be in School Hill, Wisconsin. A memorial mass is planned for January 27th, at 10:00 AM at St. Lawrence the Martyr Church in Sayville, LI. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Cornell Cooperative Extension of Suffolk County, with memo indicating the Kermit W. Graf 4-H Memorial Fund.

title: Negotiators Work on Plan for California Energy Trouble
description: With the California energy emergency continuing into the early hours of this morning, executives of utilities and power generating plants meeting here today with federal and California officials narrowed their differences over a package intended to rescue the state from its power woes.

title: Fassel Expects a Hobbled Toomer to Be a Starter
description: Amani Toomer is back. Toomer, the Giants' best receiver, went through today's 75-minute practice at full speed, and Coach Jim Fassel said the fifth-year pro would start Sunday in the National Football Conference championship game against the Minnesota Vikings at Giants Stadium.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Public Lives column yesterday about the director Sidney Lumet misspelled the name of a Manhattan restaurant where a party was held after a screening of his new television series. It is Guastavino's, not Gustavino's.

title: An Old Key To Why Countries Get Rich
description: Why has Poland prospered and Russia struggled since the end of the cold war? Why is the economy of South Korea 15 times as large as that of Ghana when they were comparable less than 40 years ago? Why have the Chinese minorities thrived economically in such different places as Malaysia, the Philippines and San Francisco?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROHDE, ROSLYN PERLSTEIN
description: ROHDE-Roslyn Perlstein. Jan. 11, 2001. Cherished wife of Elliot. Dear sister of Mae Liss. Loving mother of David and Dena, Aviva and Brian, Michael and Sophia, Shira, Dana. Devoted step-mother of Laurie and Paul, Steven and Diana. Adored grandmother of Darren, Mollie, Daniel, Aaron, Eliana, Gabriella. Services Sunday 11:30AM, Wien & Wien, Hackensack, New Jersey.

title: Sky Watch: A Celestial Signpost
description: The moon can sometimes be used as a sort of celestial signpost. Take, for instance, the upcoming last quarter moon, which will occur on Tuesday morning; the moons disk will appear exactly 50 percent illuminated at 7:35 a.m. When the moon is in this particular phase it is positioned ahead of the earth as it moves in orbit in space around the sun.

title: In the Middle East, Together and Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: Bradway Gets Down to Business, Beginning Search for Jets' Coach
description: After a tumultuous week in which they lost a legend and hired his replacement, the Jets caught their breath yesterday.

title: Auction Houses Sweeten Deal
description: As they wait for a federal judge to give final approval to a $512 million class-action antitrust settlement, Sotheby's and Christie's have sweetened part of the deal they had agreed to in October.

title: Two Officers Are Shot
description: Two police officers were critically wounded and a suspect was killed last night during a shootout in Orange, N.J., county prosecutors said. The officers underwent surgery late last night.

title: War Chests In Mayor Race Building Up
description: The major candidates in this year's mayoral race continued their aggressive fund-raising during the last half of 2000, according to figures the campaigns intend to file next week. With the Democratic primary eight months away, each of the four main Democratic candidates has raised more than $3.5 million for the September contest.

title: THE BUSH YEARS
description: At his ranch in Texas, the president-elect muses about his inauguration, describes his foreign policy objectives and says he will bring a Westerner's attitude to Washington. An interview with David E. Sanger and Frank Bruni, Section 1, Page 1.

title: Holiday on Monday; Martin Luther King Jr.'s Birthday
description: NEW YORK

title: 2 Officers Critically Injured As Suspect Dies in Shootout
description: Two police officers were critically wounded and a suspect was killed last night during a shootout in Orange, N.J., county prosecutors said.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCH, LORE S. (SUNDERMAN)
description: HIRSCH-Lore S. (Sunderman). 86, of Riverdale, N.Y. She leaves two sons Ronald and Norman Hirsch. Funeral Sunday 12pm at Riverdale Temple, Independence Ave. Burial in Cedar Park Cemetery, N.J.

title: Robert Love, 102, a Developer Of Consumer Credit Insurance
description: Robert A. Love, an economist and businessman who helped develop a type of life insurance that covered the value of home mortgages, died in his sleep on Jan. 5 at his apartment in New York. He was 102 years old.

title: John Pierrepont, 84, Benefactor To New York Nonprofit Groups
description: John Pierrepont, a philanthropist who was prominent in nonprofit organizations based in New York City, died on Wednesday at his home on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Integration, One Sunday At a Time
description: MORE than 40 years have passed since the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. described 11 a.m. on Sunday as the most segregated hour of the week, and in all that time not much has changed. Look around on any given Sunday. Worship remains essentially a tribal act. Whites pray here, blacks pray there, and that, you might say, is that.

title: Yeremeyev Will Start For Rangers
description: The Rangers' equipment managers quickly packed the team's skates in a blue box this afternoon for the trip to Boston. Mike Richter's skates were left at his locker.

title: The Critical Test for John Ashcroft
description: To the Editor:

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VICENTE, ESTEBAN
description: VICENTE-Esteban. The members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters note with sorrow the death of their esteemed colleague whose passing will be deeply mourned by the world of art.

title: Sports of The Times; Clem Daniels, 40 Years A Raider
description: CLEM DANIELS sat in his small office at the Endzone Lounge yesterday afternoon. The phone was ringing off the hook, more now than usual. Everyone wanted access to the hottest ticket in town: the Oakland Raiders playing host to the Baltimore Ravens in the American Football Conference championship game tomorrow.

title: Lemieux Scores Early, and Islanders Fall Short
description: Mario Lemieux scored another goal and the Pittsburgh Penguins won another game, this one by 4-3 over the reeling Islanders before another capacity crowd in Mellon Arena. But it was not the sharpest performance by Lemieux, the 35-year-old superstar and team owner who is making an intriguing comeback after more than three years away from playing in the National Hockey League.

title: Energy and Efficiency
description: To the Editor:

title: A Vision for Books That Exults in Happenstance
description: It is sometimes said of Jason Epstein, the longtime editorial director of Random House now in retirement, that he has had four great ideas in his life. One: At 22 he invented the high-quality paperback in the form of Anchor Books. Two: In 1963, during the New York newspaper strike, he had the idea for The New York Review of Books. Three: In 1982 he created the Library of America with its definitive editions of American classics, conceived earlier with Edmund Wilson at the Princeton Club while Wilson drank a half-dozen martinis. Four: In 1986 Mr. Epstein invented the Reader's Catalog to market books directly to readers, a precursor of Amazon.com.

title: Corrections
description: A map in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about airline consolidation located two cities incorrectly. Baltimore and Washington were reversed.

title: When T.W.A. Was All First Class
description: When I was hired as a flight attendant by Trans World Airlines in 1978, there were women who had worked there so long that they still referred to themselves as ''stews.'' They remembered the days when Howard Hughes, T.W.A.'s founder, used to walk onto a plane, ask the passengers to leave, fill the seats with movie stars and take the crew along for a party. They remembered working around-the-world flights, leaving their home bases for weeks at a time and flying to exotic cities on every continent. They remembered when the dress code required girdles and white gloves.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the boxer Nick Acevedo omitted attribution for a comment from the broadcaster Dave Bontempo, who said: ''Nick's starting to show the promise everyone always thought he had. A lot was expected of Acevedo coming up, so I think his career is just starting.'' Mr. Bontempo spoke to The Ring magazine.

title: Basics Are No Longer Basics And the Message Is Pure Joy
description: Anyone who missed ''Prism,'' the superb ballet that Helgi Tomasson choreographed last spring for the New York City Ballet's Diamond Project, now has a chance to be swept away by its ingenuity and exuberance.

title: State Plans to Raise Fees Paid to Court-Hired Lawyers for the Poor
description: Gov. George E. Pataki and legislative leaders announced yesterday that they planned to increase fees this session for private lawyers appointed by the courts to represent the poor.

title: Amid Pockets of Growth, December Retail Sales Rose a Sliver
description: Retail sales, while clearly weak, defied gloomy expectations and rose slightly in December, the government said yesterday, ending a week in which economic data showed some surprising resilience.

title: A Giant Leaves the Jets
description: Bill Parcells left the Jets in managerial chaos when he resigned as general manager this week -- but his legacy as a coach who turned losing New York football teams into champions will be hard to match. He won two Super Bowls with the New York Giants, took the New England Patriots to a third and electrified the Jets franchise by reaching the American Football Conference championship game in his second season.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SOLOSHATZ, ROSE
description: SOLOSHATZ-Rose. 89, formerly of New York, passed away in Florida January 11, 2001. Beloved mother of Mae and Jerry Lipensky and Jerry and Arlene Sanders. Adored grandmother of five, great-grandmother of nine. Services will be held Sunday, January 14, 2001, 12:30 PM, Gutterman Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York.

title: Article 2001011392702183839 -- No Title
description: January 13, 2001

title: Battle Over Developing a Scenic Mountain Tract
description: A 2,200-ACRE tract in the Appalachian Mountains in western North Carolina that was the location for the movie ''The Last of the Mohicans'' is now the site of another kind of battle, this one between a developer of high-priced residential communities and the state of North Carolina.

title: A Kaleidoscope From Argentina
description: If you like riesling, alberino, muscat, gewurztraminer and viognier, you'll be smitten by torrontes, a white that incorporates their melange of flavors.

title: Measuring Driver Distraction
description: The information highway is rapidly merging with the asphalt variety. But how safe is it for drivers to use cell phones and other electronic gadgets?

title: An Appraisal; Bill Clinton's Mixed Legacy
description: A recent editorial cartoon by Matt Davies of The Journal News showed Bill Clinton trying to make a diving catch of a huge ball. The ball, labeled ''Greatness,'' lands just out of his reach. The drawing provided a haunting visual metaphor for the near-miss quality of a presidency that never quite measured up to the potential that every supporter and most critics knew resided within Mr. Clinton. Yet simply stating the fact that Mr. Clinton is not destined to enter the pantheon of great, universally respected presidents does not capture the richness, complexity and drama of these eight years. No citizen is likely to forget them or, for that matter, to quit debating the man's remarkable gifts and the narcissistic indiscipline that diminished them.

title: INSIDE
description: Reagan Has Hip Surgery

title: MY FIRST JOB; An Early Reward For Honest Effort
description: Ronald D. Sugar, 52, is president and chief operating officer of Litton Industries. Litton, based in Woodland Hills, Calif., supplies military electronics and information systems and is the nation's largest builder of surface combat ships; in December, it agreed to be acquired by Northrop Grumman. Before joining Litton last June, Mr. Sugar was president and chief operating officer of TRW Aerospace Inc.

title: A Foiled Plot by Terrorists Was Aimed at Hundreds of Victims
description: After weeks of advanced training in explosives at one of Osama bin Laden's Afghan camps, Raed Hijazi, a onetime Boston cab driver, was ready for his mission. The chemicals for the explosives were stockpiled. The targets were selected, the homemade detonators wired.

title: Rethink Missile Defense
description: To the Editor:

title: The Way We Live Now: 01-14-01: Expert Opinion: The Kicking Game; Booting It
description: It has been a rough season for N.F.L. place-kickers. According to the league, 25 percent of this year's games were decided by 3 points or less. So there's a decent chance that on Jan. 28, at the end of the Super Bowl, one of these specialists will walk onto the field with the game on his foot. We asked Rolf Benirschke, 10 years in the league and formerly of the Oakland Raiders and San Diego Chargers, and Eddie Murray, in the N.F.L. since 1980 and now with the Washington Redskins, for some insight into their pressurized world.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROSEN, GOLDY MERESMAN
description: ROSEN-Goldy Meresman. Goldy died peacefully in her sleep on January 8, 2001 in her home at Hilton Head Island, SC after a long battle with cancer. She did not give an inch to the disease and was active to the end. The funeral was held in Hilton Head on January 9. She was a superb wife, best friend and cuddle to her husband Richard for 45 years. She was a loving and caring mother to Robert and Jennifer, Susan and Chaim, Stephen and Laurie and a doting grandmother to Levav, Koby, Kinneret, Merav, Gracie and Elizabeth. Goldy was a brilliantly intelligent woman, a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Cornell University and an Honors Graduate of the Cornell Law School at a time when few women were admitted to law school. She practiced tax law while raising her children. Goldy became interested in the Garden City Public School System, particularly in the cause of educating gifted children. She was an elected member of the Garden City School Board for 17 years and distinguished President during five of those years. She had a lasting impact on the Garden City School System. She was a director of the Garden City Jewish Center for 10 years. She was a founding member of the Hilton Head Hadassah, Vice President for Education and a Director. Goldy loved quilting and her quilting friends and she has left us many beautiful examples of her work. She made everything and everyone she touched better. We will all miss her terribly, but she lives on in our shared memories and in the example she set for us of how to live your life as a quintessentially good person. A memorial service will be held for Goldy at 2 PM, Tuesday, January 16 at the Garden City Jewish Center, 168 Nassau Blvd., Garden City, NY.

title: MINORITY TURNPIKE STOPS
description: Black drivers on the New Jersey Turnpike are still twice as likely to be pulled over by the State Police than any other minority or white driver, according to a report on traffic stops between July and December last year compiled as part of a court-ordered measure to combat racial profiling. The report was based on the numbers of stops made by troopers and a census of drivers taking the turnpike, which had not been compiled previously. Black drivers make up 12.5 percent of the drivers on the turnpike but they represent 23 percent of the traffic stops, the report said. Stops for whites, Hispanics and Asians were roughly the same or lower than the percentage of drivers in that category. Karen DeMasters

title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; Founder of Cape May Stage Dies
description: Michael James Laird, 51, the founder and artistic director of Cape May Stage, died on Jan. 6 of complications from liver cancer. ''Michael could do it all -- act, write and produce,'' said Jim Moffatt, president of the Cape May Stage board of directors. ''He was theater in Cape May.'' After he founded Cape May Stage in 1988, Mr. Laird produced and directed more than 70 plays, from the works of Tennessee Williams to ''A Wretch Like Me,'' a 1999 autobiographical drama. He also wrote and acted in the perennial favorite, ''Charles Dickens's A Christmas Carol, Almost.'' A recovering alcoholic, Mr. Laird also was host of a local radio program that focused on alcoholism. ''Michael was a bit of P. T. Barnum and the guy next door,'' Mr. Moffatt said. ''That combination made him a special person, personally and professionally.'' Mr. Laird is survived by his mother, Eileen Laird, and his sister, Karen Laird Rowinski. Alfonso Serrano

There are water-filled, buckwheat, antisnore and magnet therapy pillows, to name a few. Sometimes she recommends a combination of pillows. ''One woman had neck problems,'' Ms. McGill said, ''so she tested four pillows and went with one heated jellyroll pillow for her neck and a Swedish memory pillow, which was designed by NASA. It's a heavy-density foam pillow that conforms to the shape of your head -- and stays that way through the night to support you.''

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: DREAMER, by Charles Johnson. (Scribner, $12.) The story of a poor man whose striking physical (if not spiritual) resemblance to Martin Luther King Jr. lands him a job as a stand-in for the civil rights leader becomes an exploration into the soul of inequality and a probing inquiry into King's life and times. ''Johnson takes bold creative risks,'' Dennis McFarland wrote here in 1998. ''He delivers a lively tale that leaves the reader with enormous concerns to contemplate.'' Scribner has also reissued Johnson's first novel, Faith and the Good Thing ($11), a philosophical ''Pilgrim's Progress'' fable about a black girl's search for the Good Thing in Hatten County, Ga. In 1974 our reviewer, Annie Gottlieb, called this ''a flawed yet still fabulous book, at its best a many-splendored and ennobling weaving-together of thought, suffering, humor and magic.''

title: January 7 - 13; Army Admits Killings Of Korea Civilians
description: After a yearlong study, the Army acknowledged that American soldiers killed unarmed civilians near the village of No Gun Ri in the early days of the Korean War. In 1999 the Associated Press reported that American soldiers had been ordered to kill South Korean refugees in July 1950. But the Army and South Korean investigations found no such order and said the shootings resulted from the confusion of war. There was no agreement on how many Koreans died. Local records list 248 as wounded, dead or missing. Elizabeth Becker

He had been suffering from post-traumatic symptoms ever since he returned from Vietnam in 1969. During the 77-day siege at Khe Sanh, Manny picked up pieces of his fellow G.I.'s. Then he got wounded and medevacked out in a helicopter on a pile of dead bodies.

title: MUSIC; In Search Of a Liszt To Be Loved
description: I HAVE long suffered from Lisztophobia. Though I've occasionally admired a piece by Franz Liszt, I have avoided his music for decades whenever possible. It just doesn't appeal to me, I told myself. I ignored Liszt recordings by Martha Argerich, Claudio Arrau and Jorge Bolet, all of whose work I admired in other repertory. Stubbornly, I held out against Lisztophiliacs (all, inevitably, had-been pianists) who tried to convert me. Meanwhile, I took comfort in the results of highly unscientific surveys (conversations with musical friends and colleagues) that proved I was not alone in my affliction. Why this widespread repugnance? When it comes to Liszt, there are damning common perceptions.

title: Chromatic Notes Of a Winter Melody

On Fifth Avenue they are a welcome sight, suggesting tropical fruit, or a bouquet of delicate spring blossoms. The pink of roses, the blue of hyacinths, the green of cymbidium orchids and the yellow of mimosas are just some of the colors being worn in the city this winter after a decade of minimalist black. Certainly black is practical for every day and great for saving on dry cleaning, while for its upkeep, the bipartisan rainbow coalition cloth coat is a luxury. A surprise was the number of pastel duffel coats, usually cut in neutral beige and brown. This year, they're seen in melting, soft colors. Instead, the board has voted to let individual shareholders replace their own windows if they want to. Is there any way to determine what portion of a reserve fund should be used to improve the quality of life for shareholders rather than provide a benefit to the shareholders who are selling? title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; The Narrow Path
description: For more than a century, the Hutterites have farmed the prairies of the American West and Canada, attracting little notice from the outside world. Hard work, political pacifism and piety based on the Anabaptist movement are among the tenets they have observed over the course of their 472-year history. Alternating waves of prosperity and persecution have borne the Hutterites from Moravia to Russia and, finally, in the 1870's, to North America, where most of them now live in small, communal settlements, surrounded by the raw, expansive landscape they call home. When the photographer Laura Wilson first encountered the Hutterites in 1983, she was struck not only by their disciplined lifestyle but also by her own ignorance of the ''enclosed world'' she had stumbled upon. In HUTTERITES OF MONTANA (Yale University, $39.95), Wilson's vivid photographs and engaging text focus on two Hutterite groups. Penetrating their society was no easy task: it took Wilson months to persuade the Hutterites to let her photograph them; in all, she spent 14 years on the project. Her black-and-white photographs reveal the minimalist settings of Hutterite life -- the neat, sparsely furnished houses; the unornamented sanctuaries where the Hutterites worship at least once a day, not a candle or stained glass window in sight; the well-tended farms and pastures. The Hutterites are physically striking: the men, broad-shouldered, often with trimmed beards, wear tall hats and black pants; the women dress in crisp cotton blouses and skirts, their triple-starched scarves bestowing on them ''the look of alert, still-winged birds.'' While Wilson notes that the Hutterites, now 40,000 strong, are the largest communal group in the Western Hemisphere, she worries that they will not be able to withstand the far reaches of the high-tech, high-anxiety world. Her book inspires appreciation of a culture that, so far, has managed to resist the temptation. Suzanne MacNeille

The prisoner, who had been charged with assault and criminal contempt, was supposed to be under suicide watch. The county, which has since altered procedures for new inmates with mental health problems, will appeal, said Susan Tolchin, a spokeswoman for County Executive Andrew J. Spano. Elsa Brenner

description: JONATHAN BERMAN'S ears perked up quickly back in 1995 when he received an unexpected call from a childhood friend named Paul Schofield. Mr. Berman is a filmmaker, and Mr. Schofield was finishing up a prison term for robbing banks.

She has already helped another struggling newborn to breathe, and reassured several sets of bewildered parents. Now she dreams of sipping a pina colada, or maybe something stronger.

Now, transformed by the stock market boom, it has found a new life as a second or third home for dot-com millionaires. It oozes big, new mon ey, which has overtaken the WASP-iness. Naples is a place where $5 million won't buy much of a house. The choice ones start at $8 million, and in the Strand, a new gated community within an already double-gated community, houses go for $11 to $25 million.

description: To the Editor: I was amused by Wayne Arnold's account of his train ride from China to Vietnam, ''This Train Beats Walking (Sometimes),'' (Dec. 3).

title: The Bush Years; W.'s World
description: Foreign policy has not played a decisive role in electing a president since 1968, the height of the Vietnam War. And since 1992, when Bill Clinton recognized that the end of the cold war made George Bush's victory in the Persian Gulf very nearly irrelevant as a political asset, foreign policy has become an electoral afterthought. In this past campaign, Al Gore and George W. Bush delivered the speeches on diplomacy that are still required in order to scale Mount Gravitas, and in their second debate they engaged in a blurry, amiable 45-minute discussion of foreign affairs. After a brief, failed attempt to get Bush to concede that he would not necessarily intervene abroad even to prevent genocide, Gore essentially gave up trying to draw sharp distinctions with his opponent, apparently reasoning that deploying his immensely superior knowledge of the world might make him seem pedantic rather than seasoned. (Bush was held to have won the debate after successfully reciting the names of four large Middle Eastern countries.) In their closing statements, Gore and Bush hurried back to the home front, focusing on education and tax policy.

title: The Critic in Exile
description: Even before this one, Robert Hughes loved a good fight. For Hughes, the famed Australian critic, there is no such thing as middle ground. There are geniuses and there are fakes. And with a clear mind, we should be able to extol the former and unmask the latter. Hughes's stance, practiced most visibly as the art critic for Time magazine over the past 30 years, is polemical; his prose style, in his editor's words, ''muscular mandarin.'' Many artists have been roughed up by his reviews. Francis Bacon: ''Some art is wallpaper. Bacon's is flypaper.'' Julian Schnabel: ''Schnabel's work is to painting what Stallone's is to acting.'' Even his praise has barbs. In 1987, he described the German painter Anselm Kiefer as ''the best painter of his generation on either side of the Atlantic. If we consider the mediocrity of most of the talent we have,'' he added, ''this may not sound like much of a compliment.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKS, HENDERSON
description: HICKS-Henderson. The Board of Governors, staff, members and friends of Pathways for Youth mourn the passing of our beloved Board President. A committed volunteer for many human services organizations, Mr. Hicks sat on our Board for 15 years, serving as Treasurer and First Vice President before becoming the agency's first African-American President in 1995. We will remember Mr. Hicks as impassioned advocate, consummate diplomat and compassionate gentleman, tirelessly supporting our mission of youth development. Empowered by Mr. Hicks's determined leadership, Pathways more than doubled in size, scope of services and membership during his tenure as President. We extend heartfelt condolences to the Hicks family and immeasurable gratitude for the wisdom, perspective, spirit and energy he shared so gracefully with us and all people in need of meaningful assistance. Hank, you will truly be missed. The Pathways for Youth Family

title: Jamming With Juggling Suns
description: Concentrating on complex instrumentation, the New Jersey-based jam band Juggling Suns performs a danceable set of music that takes its cue from the Grateful Dead, featuring trippy grooves with extended rock, country, jazz and topical jams. Some might find the music, which can be heard on the CD ''Living on the Edge of Change,'' too progressive while others might find it too laid back. But for the countless tie-dyed hippies and jazz aficionados who have followed bands like Phish around for years, this combination is just right. The band achieved a bit of notice in 1998 when its cover of the Dead's ''Sugar Magnolia'' appeared in the 1999 Julia Roberts film ''Runaway Bride.'' And tape recorders are welcome. Juggling Suns encourages taping and trading. The band will appear every Wednesday through at least February at Crossroads at Garwood, 78 North Avenue, Garwood, and this Friday at the Stone Pony, 913 Ocean Avenue, Asbury Park. Robbie Woliver

description: Vice Adm. Harry DeWolf, a destroyer commander who was Canada's most highly decorated naval officer of World War II, died Dec. 18 in his home in Ottawa. He was 97.

title: Cuba, Si and No
description: When Omar Giner left the Russian Tea Room to take over La Isla four years ago, the first thing he did was throw out the old menu. Not literally; under the previous owners, offerings were scrawled on cardboard and propped against the wall. On the surface, La Isla still seems like that kind of place. A faded blue ''Restaurant/Cafeteria'' sign hangs above the doorway. There are twice as many stools at the counter as there are tables. But Mr. Giner, a Cuban-American from Jersey City, isn't interested in appearances. His concern is with putting out copious plates of what he calls ''homespun meets nouveau Cuban'' fare. ''I take what's in the Cuban diet and reinvent it,'' he said. ''But I do it in such a way that the ingredients don't lose their identity.'' This means that old favorites like media noche -- a sandwich of ham, pork, and Swiss cheese on sweet bread ($4) -- and braised pork with fried plantains, black beans and rice ($10.95) share the stage with pan-seared red snapper with a coconut-polenta cake ($17.95). With kicky Cuban music and Spanish-speaking servers, La Isla is full of island soul. By the end of the night, you'll be ready to buy one of the restaurant's black T-shirts with ''Cuba'' on the front and ''No!'' on the back. Mr. Giner said the second word was ''like 'holy cow.' People say it when someone hits a home run.'' When it comes to La Isla, I couldn't have said it better myself. Gretchen Kurtz

title: AMBULANCE CORPS PENSIONS
description: If residents agree in a public vote on March 20, Dobbs Ferry will offer pensions to members of its volunteer ambulance corps. The program would mirror a similar measure, in effect since 1991, that offers benefits to volunteer firefighters 65 and over. The village would pay about $32,000 a year for the first five years to a special retirement fund. Recipients would receive $20 per month per year of service up to 40 years, said Matthew P. title: HUMAN RIGHTS LAW REVISIONS
description: The county Board of Legislators will hold a public hearing on Jan. 22 to consider changes to Westchester's one-year-old Human Rights Law. One amendment would clarify that independent contractors, personal tutors and home and child-care workers are not considered ''employees'' under the law. Thus, someone who did not want to hire a homosexual as a child-care worker would not be charged with discrimination. Another proposal would delete acts of ''verbal intimidation'' from the list of causes for a discrimination claim, to prevent the law from violating free-speech protections. Elsa Brenner

description: Standing at the edge of the swimming pool, Ann Weissman raised her arms and struck an imperious pose. Then she addressed a group of women wearing matching bathing caps in rubber-duckie yellow.

title: Making Sure That Pocket Doors Stay on the Right Track

These doors are good in rooms where space is limited and where there isn't enough clearance to allow for a traditional door swing.

title: Lion Dance for Year of the Snake
description: THE Year of the Snake, year 4699, officially begins on the evening of Jan. 23, but the staff and students of the China Institute are inviting the public to join them in an early celebration on Friday evening. Jiaozi, a dumpling dish that is traditional for this occasion, will be served, and video clips will be screened before a karaoke sing-along of regional folk songs from China. The celebration continues on Saturday with the institute's eighth annual lion dance (a previous event is shown above), a tradition that dates back at least to the 18th century. According to legend, a beast named Nian (which can mean year in Chinese) terrorized a village and ransacked its garden.

title: A World Divided Into Two-Way-Pager Camps
description: STAR JONES was camped out in her usual seat in celebrity row, courtside at a New York Knicks game in Madison Square Garden. Even as the contest between the Knicks and the Milwaukee Bucks went into nail-biting overtime, Ms. Jones, a host of ''The View'' on ABC, was busily multitasking, flipping open the silver Motorola Timeport two-way pager in her lap and tapping away with both thumbs. Cheering boisterously for the home team, she also conducted simultaneous wireless conversations. She read an e-mail message from Puffy Combs, checking to see whether she could make it to his party that night. Then came a message from Derek Jeter, asking for the game's score.

title: 70's Rock: The Bad Vibes Continue
description: SOMETHING happened to rock music in the 1970's that it has never quite recovered from: the sound congealed into a dense, ponderous and soporific mass. In the words of an all-too-popular Jethro Tull album of the period, rock became ''Thick as a Brick.'' Nowhere was this change more apparent than on FM radio. There the playlists narrowed, rock 'n' roll aesthetics became codified into a dull, stiff lockstep and the music business consolidated its clammy grip on the public's imagination. It was as if an Iron -- or rather Led, as in Zeppelin -- Curtain of uniformity had fallen over the freedoms of the 60's. Where playfulness, humor, chaotic weirdness and wayward passion had reigned supreme, now even excess and outrage came to seem stage-managed by some invisible bureaucracy of FM station consultants, management firms, technocrat producers and record company apparatchiks.

title: OPINION; Suburban Bunyan Swings His Ax
description: UNTIL last year I had never split wood, but I had seen the movies: rugged men with beards and muscular arms deftly swinging axes and lobbing uniform chunks of wood onto impressively large, and growing, piles. And I had heard the stories. Everyone I know, it seems, has split wood in the past, and the stories usually spill out with the wide-eyed memory and spirit of that winning touchdown during the homecoming game. I offered an opinion, described as such, that was based on a detailed analysis of evidence. Book reviews in major newspapers have described that opinion in terms like ''persuasive'' (The Philadelphia Inquirer) and ''compelling'' (The Sacramento Bee). The New York Times Book Review said it was ''a plausible case.'' But having said that, I still fear that Bob Woodward has smartly bamboozled the press into generally accepting whatever he says (or declines to say) about Deep Throat as sacred writ.

Lemieux, part-owner and superstar of the Pittsburgh Penguins, scored on the power play Friday night to spark a 4-3 victory over the Islanders in Mellon Arena. The goal was Lemieux's seventh in seven games as the Penguins have gone 5-2 since his return after more than three years out of uniform. title: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; Hispanic Voices in the Theater

''In this country it seems that we always look at England as the main source for plays,'' said Cuban-born Nilo Cruz, resident artist at the McCarter Theater. ''Latino plays come from an emotional center instead of an intellectual -- it is more physical instead of from the shoulder and up.'' Mr. Cruz has created the series ''Other Fires,'' a selection of four play readings representing different traditions within Spanish and Latino theater. The series begins Jan. 26 with ''The Alchemy of Flowers,'' Mr. Cruz's new translation of ''Dona Rosita the Spinster'' by Federico Garcia Lorca, the 20th-century Spanish playwright. ''The Conduct of Life,'' by the Cuban-American playwright Maria Irene Fornes, will be read on Jan. 27 along with ''The Young Lady from Tacna,'' by Mario Vargas Llosa of Peru. ''Cloud Tectonics'' by the Puerto Rican writer Jose Rivera ends the series on Jan. 28. All plays are written in or translated to English. There will be open discussion after each reading. title: The Bush Years; C.E.O., U.S.A.
description: As George W. Bush prepares to be inaugurated as the 43rd president of the United States, those who have not studied him closely tend to divide into two camps: the inspired and the appalled. The first group sees him as Prince Hal, a natural leader seasoned by his rapscallion youth; the second sees him as smug and callow, a Richard II attaining power by accident of birth. But whether they are pulling for Hal or scoffing at Richard, they cite the same biography: that Bush was an incurious student and an unsuccessful young man who just 14 years ago was sitting on top of a collapsing oil firm; that he opted out of the ideological and military conflicts of his generation; that he drank too much for many years; that his experience in public service consists of six years in the bully pulpit of a state with a part-time Legislature -- and that he spent two of those years running for president. It is kind of amazing, these people all say, when you think about it.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; Scent of Jasmine, Taste of Snickers
description: For all its tenderness and warmth, Vineeta Vijayaraghavan's first novel, MOTHERLAND (Soho, $23), has a gutsy air of daring about it. Rather than trying to distinguish itself from the well-worn coming-of-age genre, ''Motherland'' places itself so squarely within the tradition that it winds up being something of a revelation. Like its 15-year-old narrator, ''Motherland'' winningly combines youthful exuberance with the conviction that there is nothing wrong with being a little bit old-fashioned. Maya, a sullen, Americanized teenager, is grimly resigned when her parents pack her off to India to spend the summer with her extended family. But as the hot, lazy days stretch into each other and fate propels the girl and her grandmother to a new closeness, Maya goes from boredom and frustration to self-assured maturity. There's nothing new about the ''summer I grew up'' novel, and here even the family secrets have an air of inevitability about them. (The book's one big twist, a political subplot, seems out of place and disappointingly forgettable.) Despite its lack of originality, however, ''Motherland'' has abundant charm. It teems with sumptuous, loving details of everyday life. Vijayaraghavan shares her protagonist's pleasure in everything from the scent of jasmine in a girl's hair to the sticky sweetness of a Snickers bar in the mouth. And Maya's insights thankfully lack the overreaching fussiness that plagues works written by adults in the voice of adolescents. Her awkward, heartfelt attempts to reconcile her Western and Indian selves feel genuine. The novel may be set in a world of saris and spices, wild boars and arranged marriages, but its rhythms have the familiar, reassuring hum of home. We may have a clear idea of what to expect when we head with Maya off to Grandmother's, but it doesn't make getting there any less of a pleasure. Mary Elizabeth Williams

title: Officer in New Jersey Shootout Is Said to Be Fighting for Life

title: Clearing the Tracks
description: With the big snow that ended 2000, dog sledders in New Jersey are, well, frisky as pups. Snow has been rare on the ground in recent years, and the New Jersey Sled Dog Club has been looking forward to two days of racing on the snow-covered roads in High Point State Park next Saturday and Sunday. This will be only the second time since the early 80's that the races will be held on snow. The problem is, snowmobilers are happy, too, and they've already hit those roads, wearing the snow down nearly to the pavement. Depending on how the roads fare over another week, the races -- open to sleds pulled by three, four, six or eight dogs or to skiers pulled by dogs -- may not go off, according to Kathy Murarik, the club president. Those who want to race ($15) or watch should call her at (973) 663-2164 or the park at (973) 875-4800 Wednesday or later to see if the races have to be rescheduled Feb. 4 and 5.

title: Giving So Little That It Hurts
description: It may sound strange to be publicly humiliated for donating a nearly six-figure sum to charity. But that is what top bankers did last week to executives of Goldman, Sachs and Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, nearly booing them for donating too little at a charity event in London. Goldman, Sachs contributed $75,000 and Morgan Stanley $90,000 to the Save the Children Foundation at the annual International Financial Review Awards, an awards ceremony that aspires to be the Oscars for British banking. Trying to goad Goldman, the host, the British comedian Rory Bremner, joked: ''Quite disappointing that Goldman, Sachs was outbid by the Punjabi dancers,'' referring to the evening's entertainment. The top donor was Citibank, at $390,000. It also happened to win the ''Best Bank of the Year'' award,'' which Sanford I. Weill, chairman of Citigroup, the parent company, accepted in a taped speech. Andrew Ross Sorkin

title: Style; This Is Not a Dresser
description: Our specialized culture frowns on the polymath. You like art? Furniture design? Architecture? Too bad -- choose one. Unless you happen to be Roy McMakin. McMakin, 44, is best known for his furniture designs, which are made by Domestic Furniture, the company he founded in Los Angeles in 1987. His tables, chairs, sofas, beds and sideboards subvert, with varying degrees of audacity, established domestic archetypes -- while remaining both functional and comfortable. You see a wing chair that looks like something out of ''Goodnight, Moon,'' for instance -- but it has a tail. Or there's a table with the earnest simplicity of the Arts and Crafts movement, except for its single drawer pull -- the size of a softball.

description: ONCE upon a time, George W. Bush selected a Democrat to head the Transportation Department, fulfilling his promise of a bipartisan cabinet. The chosen, Norman Y. Mineta, transcended party affiliation because he had wide-ranging experience in Congress and in the private sector. He also had a story. With Mr. Mineta looking on as Mr. Bush announced his choice, the president-elect said, ''I love his story.'' Mr. Bush used the same words when asked why he wept as he announced his pick for secretary of state: ''It was emotional because I so admire Colin Powell. I love his story.''

title: Tsukiji Market in Tokyo: Tuna Sold, Tuna Eaten
description: AS dawn breaks over Tokyo, Tsukiji is already bustling with activity as tens of thousands of people unload and pack, clean and gut, sell and buy tons of fish. Every day more than 3,000 whole tuna arrive from foreign and domestic waters, most frozen rock solid. In preparation for the auction, which begins at 5 every morning, each fish is tagged to identify its origin and species, then assigned a number. Flashlights in hand, nakaoroshi (intermediate wholesalers) inspect the fish prior to bidding. A single tuna can sell for more than $10,000. After buying, the nakaoroshi will dismantle the huge carcasses, some weighing as much as 900 pounds, selling various cuts to buyers from restaurants, supermarkets and other retailers.

title: The Making of an 8-Year-Old Woman
description: In reference to Lisa Belkin's article on the onset of puberty in girls (Dec. 24), I'm glad to see the word is getting out about milk. People are so influenced by the dairy industry's marketing; that's why I believe it's important to get the facts. I started drinking less and less milk (and all dairy products for that matter) years ago when I began studying physiology and biology. The less I drank, the better I felt.

title: Check the Blankets

On the other hand, what does it say about me that I was pleased to discover that I scored 310 points higher than her 1,180? Shakespeare gives a background, a past that is credible, a personal grudge that provides a believable motivation, as well as a general humanity that seems to imply that the villain has a genuine grievance.

She lived to take enormous pride in her grandchildren Janet and David, her daughter Helene and son-in-law Gord. She is also survived by Sanford's children Carolyn and Robert, by Carolyn's daughter Deborah and by nieces Eda, Selda, Cirelle, Eileen, Robin and Marcia. In May 2000 Dorothy closed her fur buying office, after a successful career lasting over 60 years. She was loved and respected by all in the fur market. Dorothy was active for many years in the Golda Meir Group and New York Chapter of Hadassah, where she will be greatly missed. Donations may be made to Hadassah's Sight Savers program. Our enduring recollections of her life well lived and her devotion to all of us will be a blessing.
