title: January 7 - 13; Flight Plans
description: If executives at the nation's two largest airlines, United and American, have their way, air travelers in the Northeast are going to see a lot more of their jets in the years to come. American agreed to buy most of the assets of ailing Trans World Airlines, as well as some of US Airway's operations, including a half interest in the popular Washington-New York-Boston shuttle. The deals were designed to smooth regulatory approval of United's proposed purchase of US Airways. But they have been met with strong criticism from consumer groups who fear higher fares and declining service. Laurence Zuckerman

title: Manolo's 24-Karat Touch
description: The current taste for heedless extravagance and conspicuous exclusivity has finally been bottled -- in the form of gold nail polish, produced by Estee Lauder in conjunction with Manolo Blahnik. Created for the 58th Annual Golden Globe Awards (which will be broadcast on Jan. 21), the limited edition polish is made with -- drum roll, please -- actual 24-karat gold. The bottle, designed by Mr. Blahnik, resembles an inverted stiletto heel. Just 500 bottles will be available free to the public, through a Golden Globes ''sweepstakes'' on the Estee Lauder Web site starting this week and running through Jan. 31. Contestants are instructed to register at www.esteelauder.com; winners will be chosen through a random drawing at the end of the month.

title: When All Roads Lead to a Queens Address
description: Mail sorters at the Community Board office in Corona were confused. Without rhyme or reason, random letters addressed to random people in random states were arriving at the board's office every few days.

title: A Role Model for Urban Revival; Seeking to Turn Around its Downtown, a Neighboring City Looked to Stamford
description: THREE years ago, White Plains was a city in decline. The tax base had been dropping for more than a decade, and the office vacancy rate was more than 30 percent -- the highest in the world for cities of its size. ''You could fire a cannon in the downtown area at night and not hit anybody,'' said Joseph M. Delfino, who became mayor in 1998.

title: 'It's a Man's World': Ahead of Its Time, And Ahead of Ours
description: AT a time when the television landscape, from ''The Real World'' to ''Dawson's Creek'' to ''Malcolm in the Middle,'' is shaped by the networks' quest for young viewers, I can't help thinking of ''It's a Man's World,'' a short-lived series from the early 60's. Although it appeared during the heyday of sugary, idealized family shows, it was more honest, compassionate and accurate in depicting the angst of young adults than any of the glib contrivances that pass for teen realism today.

Our sympathies are extended to his wife, Harriet and the entire family.

title: Attention Shoppers: Vehicle X-ing Ahead
description: AN ''X'' usually stands for experimental, but in the design experiments at the North American International Auto Show this year, it means something more. It is showing up in the names of all kinds of vehicles -- or if not in their names, in their spirit.

title: A Pair of Crystal Gems Right for Their Setting
description: HERE come two more: a pair of New York buildings to which the term architecture can be applied without fear of bearing false witness. By chance, the new arrivals will be one short block from each other, in the southwest corner of SoHo just above Canal Street. Both are residential buildings. Both respond creatively to their surroundings, vividly demonstrating that context is a matter of time as well as space. And both offer further evidence of a trend: the emergence of the crystal as an emblem of new architecture in New York.

description: The perception, however unfair, is that the Giants have ridden their strong defense to today's National Football Conference championship game. Their offense, it seems, has been along for the ride, a sometimes sloppy unit that seems to just get by.

title: January 7 - 13; Expanding Nuclear Service
description: The Pentagon is opening the nation's elite strategic nuclear forces to members of the National Guard and Reserves, reversing a policy that presumed that ''citizen soldiers'' were not up to the standards of full-time service members. The decision, which clears the way for reservists to serve in missile silos and command bunkers or aboard strategic bombers and transport planes, is part of an effort by the Pentagon to rely more heavily on its 870,000 part-time soldiers to carry out the nation's military operations. Steven Lee Myers

Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81 St, Tuesday, January 16, 1:30 PM. Interment, Temple Israel Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society or the Brandeis University National Womens' Committee.

title: Military Bestrides Turkey's Path to the European Union
description: Turkey's powerful military, whose influence and economic reach are unparalleled in other democracies, is facing its toughest fight yet -- not on the battlefield, but in a struggle against those who want to remodel the country to enter the European Union.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLA, ANTHONY L.
description: VILLA-Anthony L. 80, of Peapack, NJ, died on Friday, January 12, 2001. Devoted husband of the late Diana Gambrill Villa and beloved father of Anthony G., Peter L., L. Blair, Nicholas G., Diana Villa Noble and Wendy Villa Robins, and the loving grandfather of nine. Born in NYC, March 3, 1920, the son of Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa. He was a graduate of Groton School and Harvard University. He served during the Seocnd World War with several government agencies and was administrative assistant to the Vice President of the Allied Commission in Italy. Post-war he became the Senior Partner and subsequently Chairman of the brokerage firm Jesup and Lamont & Co; he was then associated with Tucker Anthony & Co. until retirement in 1987. He was at various times a member of the New York and American Stock Exchanges and director of several listed companies. He was a member of the Summerset Hills Country Club, The Raquet and Tennis Club, and a longstanding Governor of The Brook. A memorial service will be held at St. Bridgit's Church, Peapack, NJ, on Thursday, January 25, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Peapack-Gladstone First Aid Squad, 1 St. Luke's St., Gladstone, NJ 07934.

Having moved several times, he knew the difficulties involved in settling in a new location: disconnecting and reconnecting utilities, finding an insurance broker, a mover and other service providers that he hoped would be reputable.

Fond grandmother of the late Matthew Tortorella. Camille graduated from New York University in 1940 and held a Master's Degree in Education from Columbia University. She was a special education teacher for the New York City School System. Viewing at the David J. Hodder & Son Funeral Home, 899 McLean Ave. (near Kimball Ave.), Yonkers, NY, Sunday and Monday, 2-4 and 7-9 PM. Funeral Mass Tuesday, 9:45 AM, St. Barnabas Church. Interment Woodlawn Cemetery.

title: CITYPEOPLE; After 40 Years, on to Retirement's Valhalla
description: ADJUSTING the onyx cufflinks on his dress shirt, Joseph Krenusz stood on the left side of the Grand Staircase of the Metropolitan Opera House last Saturday receiving guests. Perched on the second stair, the petite Mr. Krenusz looked up to his patrons, taking their hands and kissing their cheeks. Occasionally he removed a program from the marble banister, his two gold rings catching the light of the famed Met chandeliers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FORMAN, BLANCHE
description: FORMAN-Blanche. On January 12, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Charles. Devoted mother of Jeffrey and Jean Forman, Ellen and Donald Feldman, Rosanne and Sam Spear. Dear sister of Anna Portman and Edna Thompson. Loving grandmother of Alexis Forman, Victor Forman, Douglas Feldman and Matthew Feldman. Services today, 2 PM at Temple Sinai, 425 Roslyn Road, Roslyn Heights, NY.

title: INVESTING WITH: Bernard F. Myszkowski And Thomas J. Marthaler; Alleghany/Chicago Trust Balanced Fund
description: IN New York, the Subway Series produced loud arguments last fall between fans of the Yankees and the Mets. In Chicago, such disagreements are everyday events for the fund managers Bernard F. Myszkowski and Thomas J. Marthaler, who debate nonstop the relative merits of the Cubs and the White Sox.

title: Playing Musical Chairs With Airlines
description: THROUGH deals of dazzling complexity, the nation's biggest airlines, American and United, are trying to become bigger. American hopes to swallow Trans World Airlines, which filed for bankruptcy protection last week to ease a takeover. United, a unit of UAL, is trying to buy most of US Airways, which has also had financial trouble. To eliminate some anti-trust concerns, American has agreed to buy one-fifth of US Airways, which serves Washington, D.C., and other areas where a merger with United could smother competition.

title: Crime
description: There's a critical vote going on in Florida, and armed troopers ring the Capitol building in Tallahassee to make sure that every precious vote is counted. Meanwhile, inside the State Legislature, a hired gunman is aiming to assassinate the president of the Senate, who is poised to cast a tie-breaking vote. At which point, the Democratic governor steps up and. . . . This chaotic scene, so unlike real life, captures the raucous spirit of S. V. Date's hilarious political satire SMOKEOUT (Putnam, $23.95), which indulges the fantasy of the author, the Tallahassee bureau chief of The Palm Beach Post, about the frenzy of corruption that would be unleashed if someone tried to push through a bill allowing the state to sue powerful tobacco companies like Roper-Joyner Holdings (RJH), the biggest but hardly the only villain of this piece. Of course, the characters are no more than vicious cartoons -- but cartoons that reflect our blackest fears about the politicians we elect.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOHNSTAMM, PAUL L.
description: KOHNSTAMM-Paul L. Died January 10, 2001. Fourth generation President, H. Kohnstamm & Co. and champion of many causes. Husband of Maisie for 56 years. Brother of Elizabeth Ogden and Richard. Beloved father of Kenneth, Peter, Daniel, Joshua, Katherine Piven, Emily Beal and 11 grandchildren. Memorial Service, 3 PM, February 4 at the Hospital for Joint Diseases, 301 E. 17th Street, NY. Contributions welcome at the above.

title: A NIGHT OUT WITH: Julia Stiles; On a Breakaway
description: WHY is it so easy to resent someone so easy to admire? Well, jealousy, of course. Luckily, Laura Rizzo is the kind of perky yet grounded friend who attends Hunter College and aspires to be an elementary school teacher. That's a good thing, because her friend from her soccer league is Julia Stiles, a 19-year-old movie star with an open moon face as expressive as Mary Pickford's.

title: Playing War
description: Michael Finkel's impressive feat of journalism (Dec. 24) about Palestinian teenagers stirred in me the conviction that we are dealing with ordinary people and with layers of politics that make things horrid when they need not be. I do not know what can be done to remedy this but, surely, getting an honest look at the human side of the story can only help.

title: Insiders' Stock Plans Weigh on Krispy Kreme
description: WILL the Krispy Kreme Donut Corporation, the second-hottest initial stock offering of last year, go the way of Starbucks? Or will it fizzle, as have so many other trendy chain concepts? Like Starbucks, Krispy Kreme rocketed after its public debut. From a start of $21 on April 5, it hit a high of $108.50 on Nov. 2.

title: Solo Travelers Get a Break
description: IS another revolution brewing in Boston? Will the single supplement be thrown into the harbor? Three travel companies there are offering trips for which they do not charge the single supplement -- the extra cost travelers pay for occupying a room by themselves.

title: Postage Due: Harwinton Wants Its Hour Back
description: THE United States Postal Service delivers the mail, it is said, deterred by ''neither snow nor rain nor heat nor gloom of night.'' But what happens when this trusty force faces financial hardship? The residents of Harwinton found out, and they are far from happy with the outcome.

title: January 7 - 13; Surprise Inside
description: Scientists have created the first genetically engineered primate, a baby monkey with a gene from jellyfish in his cells. They hope to eventually make colonies of monkeys with genes for human diseases, allowing the diseases and their treatments to be studied. The jellyfish gene was a test -- it directs cells to make a protein that glows under fluorescent light, making it easy to see if the added gene is active. Molecular tests showed the gene was present in the monkey's cells, but they did not make the protein, so they did not glow. Gina Kolata

By the day after Thanksgiving, stores, television studios and bank lobbies are adrift in oceans of poinsettias. Holly and ivy and forced bulbs explode into bloom everywhere. People give and receive everything from monstrous amaryllis to Rex begonias. Every last one of those holiday plants has been cosseted by growers, and pampered by merchandisers so that it will arrive at its destination in peak condition.

Graf noted educator and executive director of Cornell Cooperative Extension of Suffolk County died on January 10 at New York University Medical Center after a long illness. Mr. Graf was 48. title: Kind Hats and Coronets
description: ON Inauguration Day next Saturday, the most important hat in America will be a chocolate-brown creation with an upswept brim by Kokin of West 36th Street. It will be worn by Laura Bush, and if the headwear choices of past incoming first ladies are a guide, it will be intensely scrutinized by millions, lampooned by late-night comics and asked to support, on its fragile velour crown, the hopes and dreams of the millinery industry.

title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: I NEVER saw Kenneth Branagh's HENRY V (1989) when it was in theaters. Like a lot of Amerian moviegoers, I'd never heard of the 28-year-old Belfast-born upstart who had directed, written the screen adaptation and starred in the title role. Then one day I happened upon Mr. Branagh's scene with Emma Thompson, as Katherine, on television, and couldn't take my eyes off it. The whole film is powerful, dark, complex, riveting and every bit as great as Laurence Olivier's 1945 version, right down to the St. Crispin's Day speech. Derek Jacobi plays the Chorus, Ian Holm is Fluellen, Judi Dench is Mistress Quickly, and Paul Scofield is the King of France. Mr. Branagh may have taken a few Shakespearean missteps (''Love's Labour's Lost'' as a 1930's-style Hollywood musical most recently), but his, his directorial debut, is solid proof of his genius - Sunday at 11:15 a.m. and 5:30 p.m., Monday at 8 a.m. on IFC.

title: High Priestess of Down-Home Cooking
description: MY dream in life is having a dinner party for 40 people every night.'' That's what Juanita Cooke, the owner, chief cook and bottle washer of the Cooke's In, told me when I met her socially a few years after reviewing her tiny, one-of-a-kind restaurant on Depot Road in Huntington. When the restaurant opened in 1996, the effervescent former schoolteacher was the cook, comedian and sometime singer (occasionally from the kitchen while working) at the relaxed storefront spot that specialized in down-home Southern and American heartland dishes with a few Caribbean and Italian choices. She developed a cult-like following there that last November stormed her new, larger quarters at 276 New York Avenue (631-424-2181), where the Colonial Diner had been for many years.

title: Reaching for the Stars
description: With dreams of seeing her name in lights, Taina Morales (Christina Vidal, above) traverses the worlds of her traditional Puerto Rican family in Queens and her life as a student at the Manhattan School of the Arts in ''Taina,'' a live action series that has its premiere tonight at 8 on Nickolodeon. Created and produced by Maria Perez-Brown, the show uses music, dance and comedy to explore an ambitious teenager's life as she and her friends work through the insecurities that accompany adolescence -- and their aspirations to become stars. Lisa Lisa of the 1980's pop group Cult Jam and Josh Cruze play Taina's strict but supportive parents.

title: The Name Game
description: At least one hotel is allowing guests to check in under something besides their original names and be proud of it. Through March 31, the former Loews New York Hotel in Manhattan is celebrating its impending name change to the Metropolitan Hotel by offering a free night's stay on a weekend to anyone whose first or last name has been legally changed. Switches made through marriage or divorce don't count , but participants in the federal witness-protection program are eligible. And anyone can take advantage of the discounted $169 nightly rate through March 31 (subject to availability). The hotel, at Lexington Avenue and 51st Street, is still part of the Loews chain. Contact (212) 752-7000 for reservations.

title: Web a Little Friendlier to Frequent Fliers

I figured the airlines' Web sites would make it easy, given that these companies could reap huge savings on customer service costs by giving folks a do-it-yourself option.

title: Brining Pork Chops Makes for Tenderness
description: BRINING works wonders with ham or turkey, producing juicy, firm meat. When I read recently that the method works well for pork, too I was intrigued. Pork has so little fat that it often comes out dry and tough when it's cooked.

title: What Has Tab Turner Got Against Ford?
description: If the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has to be emasculated, I suppose we should be thankful that an advocate like Tab Turner is stepping in to create financial incentives for auto makers to design safer products (Michael Winerip, Dec. 17). But why must Turner devote only an elbow to driving his own S.U.V., while his hands and attention are devoted to drinking coffee and cell-phone conversations? For others' safety, if not his own, I wish he'd call a cab.

Funeral services 11:45 AM, Tuesday, January 16, at ''The Riverside'' 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. Service will also be held on Thursday, January 18, at Danzansky-Goldberg Memorial Chapels, Rockville, MD. title: The Making of an 8-Year-Old Woman
description: About 40 or 50 years ago, I read of a study showing that, in India, the age of menarche was lower in villages that had electric light in the homes. Girls growing up with electric light were maturing earlier than were girls in nearby villages with similar diets and culture but without electricity. The authors of the study postulated that increased exposure to light stimulated earlier menarche. When I read this, I felt it fitted with what I had already learned, that the sexual cycles of many animals are linked to the length of the day and that girls living around the Mediterranean matured earlier than girls in England or Scandinavia.

title: A London Hotel
description: To the Editor: I read Sarah Lyall's account of her pampered stay at the Mandarin Oriental Hyde Park in ''London: Two Tones of Luxury'' (Dec. 3). The experience I had, unfortunately, was very different. Rather than a ''spacious room'' with a view of Hyde Park, my original room was tiny, and overlooked an unsightly air shaft that was under construction. When I asked for new accommodations, I was given Room 301, which had two small windows (one was shattered) and a door that opened onto an outdoor staircase leading to the street. In my mind, that was not a proper room, but rather a corridor that had been walled off. It was, in fact, an emergency exit; and I felt unsafe sleeping in a room with such easy access to the street.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VIER, HENRY J. REVEREND MONSIGNOR
description: VIER-Henry J. Reverend Monsignor. Died from heart failure January 10, 2001 at the Osborn Home in Rye, New York. Msgr. Vier was born in White Plains, NY on September 1, 1913, the son of the late Dr. Henry and Mrs. Henry J. Vier. He graduated from Iona Preparatory School in 1931 and received a BA degree from Georgetown University in 1935. He was ordained on May 18, 1940 at St. Joseph's Seminary. Father Vier then served simultaneously at St. Helena, Bronx and Our Lady of Perpetual Help, Ardsley for a year and a half. In January 1942 he enrolled in the Catholic University School for Social Work and in August 1943 was awarded a Master of Social Work Degree. He, thereupon, was assigned to the Catholic charities of the Archdiocese. In 1943 while at the Church of the Incarnation in Manhattan, he was named Parochial Vicar. On September, 27, 1950 he was assigned to the Lt. Joseph P. Kennedy Home in the Bronx as Assistant Chaplain. On September 7, 1954, he was named Director of the Catholic Guardian Society. In 1958 Pope Pius X11 appointed Father Vier a Papal Chamberlain. On January 31, 1959 he was assigned to Our Lady of Good Counsel in Manhattan and on September 3, 1960 was appointed Spiritual Director of the St. Vincent de Paul Society. On January 21, 1961 Msgr. Vier was named Director of the Mission of the Immaculate Virgin, Mount Loretto, Staten Island. In July, 1961 he was made a Domestic Prelate by Pope John XX111. Msgr. Vier's first pastorate after leaving Catholic Charities in 1969 was at St. Francis of Assisi Church, Mt. Kisco, NY. Four years later he was transferred to the pastorate of St. Raymond's in the Bronx in 1973. While Pastor, he named Chairman of the Inter-Parish Finance Committee of the Archdiocese. In 1976 he was appointed an Archdiocesan Consultor. On September 15, 1976 he was made Episcopal Vicar of the East Bronx. On November 4, 1982 he was reappointed Episcopal Vicar South East Bronx. Msgr. Vier was given special recognition as Benefactor of the Institute of the Brothers of the Christian Schools on October 1985. On April 20, 1986, in a ceremony at St. Patrick's Cathedral Cardinal O'Connor presented Msgr. Vier with the St. George Emblem in recognition of his contributions to Scouting. Msgr. Vier retired as Pastor of St. Raymond's in July 1988 and was named Pastor Emeritus. The Msgr. Henry J. Vier Family Life Center in the Bronx was dedicated by Cardinal O'Connor on September 22, 1997. He is survived by two brothers, John H. of Rye, NY and Thomas H. of Jupiter, FL, eleven nieces and nephews and twenty grandnieces and grandnephews. He was predeceased by a sister, Alice Vier Levins of Greenwich, CT in 1957 and a niece, Marilyn J. Vier of Rye, NY in 1986. Reposing at Graham Funeral Home, 1036 Post Road, Rye, NY on Sunday 7-9pm and Monday 2-4pm. Mass of the Christian Burial at the Church of the Resurrection, Rye, NY, Tuesday 10:00am. Interment Gate of Heaven Cemetery, Hawthorne, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Catholic Charities of NY, 1011 First Avenue, NY, NY 10022. Attention: Naromie Ganesh, 11th Floor.

Hewlett, a visionary leader in industry, science and technology, and international philanthropy. Through his innovative work and generous philanthropical commitments, he made an enormous impact on American society and the entire global community. We are joined by CUNY Chancellor Matthew Goldstein, the Graduate Center's President Frances Degen Horowitz, Vice President Brian Schwartz, and its Officers in extending our deepest sympathies to his wife Rosemary, children and the rest of his entire remarkable family, and to members of the Board and staff of the Hewlett Foundation. title: An Incomprehensible Work? How About Some Footnotes?

For 30 years a fighter for socialist causes who believed passionately in a just society. After 1957, a fighter for civil rights, feminism and against the war in Southeast Asia. In later years she worked to help survivors of domestic violence and spent her days growing vegetables at the Queens Botanical Gardens. She could not resist a political debate, picket line or coupon. title: A World Court That Could Backfire
description: Since last August I have been working at a research institute in Berlin. The institute is located in one of the richest parts of the city, Grunewald, which was home to many Jews before the Second World War. Walther Rathenau, the foreign minister of the Weimar Republic and a leading Jewish industrialist, was assassinated in a place that is two minutes away from my office. I know because there is a small memorial there. The closest rapid transit station to me was the major point of embarkation to the concentration camps for Berlin's Jews. There is a memorial there, too.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CALKINS, SARAH ANNE
description: CALKINS-Sarah Anne, 42. On December 23, 2000 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York; from leukemia. Sarah grew up in Falls Church, VA, and was graduated from J.E.B. Stuart H.S. in 1976. She studied architectural history and was graduated with honors from Smith College in 1980. After earning her degree in 1984 from Columbia University's Graduate School of Architecture and Planning, Sarah opened her own architecture practice in New York City, specializing in residential design. She was a member of the American Institute of Architects (AIA), lectured on architecture at Smith College and Parsons School of Design, and wrote and illustrated travel articles. Sarah leaves her fiance, Dr. Antonio Beltramini, and his son, Roberto. She is survived by her parents, G. Nathan and Susannah Calkins of Falls Church, her sisters, Margaret Calkins Van Auken of Akron and Abigail Calkins Aguirre of Philadelphia, her brother-in-law, Francisco Aguirre and her three nieces. Her oldest sister, Helen Calkins, died in 1978. Sarah's family and her many devoted friends will miss her wit, intellectual curiosity, insight and generosity of spirit. She was like no other. A memorial service will be held at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University, Amsterdam Ave. at 117th St. on Thursday, January 18th, 2PM. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Smith College for a scholarship fund to be established in Sarah's honor.

title: Presidential Preview
description: As President-elect George W. Bush prepares for his inaugural on Saturday, he has been offering the public glimpses of some of the domestic and foreign initiatives that the new administration seems likely to pursue. These snapshots are a bit like getting a look at the trailers for a movie that is still in production. They tell us something about the nature of the next White House, but not enough to form definitive judgments. Mr. Bush's inaugural address should be a better guide to his thinking. Still, some of the plans Mr. Bush has unveiled raise the worrying possibility that he will devote less attention to uniting the nation than he advertised in his campaign.

Sales rose 86 percent to $:1.3 million from $:700,000 in the third quarter, Infobank said in a statement. The company did not provide figures from a year ago. Railtrack's chief executive resigned in November after a derailment led to the fourth fatal wreck on its tracks since 1997. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOGUE, WILLIAM MARSTON
description: HOGUE-William Marston. Longtime headmaster of The Tome School in North East, Maryland, died in Washington, DC, on January 13, 2001. Dr. Hogue was born in Washington, DC, on June 24, 1923, the son of William Henry and Irene Marston Hogue. He attended the George Washington University (B.A. and M.A.) and received the Ph.D. from the Catholic University of America. After several years teaching in Washington, he went to Tampa, Florida, to be assistant headmaster of St. John's School. In 1962 he was appointed headmaster of The Tome School in Port Deposit, Maryland, a post he held for seventeen years. During his tenure, the school, which had never recovered from the effects of the 1930's depression, was revitalized and relocated to a hundredacre campus adjoining the town of North East, Maryland. After relinquishing the headmastership in 1979, Dr. Hogue became executive director of The Jacob Tome Institute, the philanthropic foundation which owns and operates the school. He served as president of the Institute's board of trustees 1992-1994. He was recalled to be interim headmaster of the school 1989-1990. Dr. Hogue wrote a history of The Jacob Tome Institute and its schools, published in 1994 on the hundredth anniversary of the opening of the Institute's first school. His avocation was research in the field of American church history, and he published monographs in a number of scholarly journals. Dr. Hogue is survived by a brother, Walter Everett Hogue of Las Vegas, Nevada. Interment will be private.

title: INTEL AGREES TO ACQUIRE XIRCOM
description: Expanding its reach into wireless computing, the Intel Corporation said yesterday that it would buy Xircom Inc., a maker of networking devices for laptop computers and mobile devices, for about $748 million in cash. Intel will pay $25 a share, 38 percent more than Xircom's share price of $18.06 at the end of trading on Friday. Xircom, based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., will become a subsidiary of Intel. Hurt by the slowdown in personal computer sales, Xircom also announced quarterly earnings of a penny a share for the quarter ended on Dec. 31, compared with 55 cents a share during the period a year earlier. Analysts had forecast earnings of 14 cents a share, according to First Call/Thompson Financial. Revenue was $120.1 million, compared with $124.1 million a year earlier. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: A German Folk Tale, Magic, Demons and All, Courtesy of the Bronx
description: ''Der Freischutz'' is the quintessential German Romantic opera. Its composer, Carl Maria von Weber, took a German folk tale about a huntsman who uses diabolic magic bullets to win a shooting contest, studded it with folk songs and Italianate scenas and crowned it with the well-known Wolf's Glen scene in which the hero, Max, and the evil huntsman, Caspar, cast the bullets at midnight in a cloud of demonic spirits. In the densely orchestrated score, Weber associates specific keys and musical motifs with characters and situations, presaging the Wagnerian leitmotif. Dramatically, however, the piece is more like a hybrid of ''The Waltons'' and ''Frankenstein.''

title: SONY TO DOUBLE PLAYSTATION 2 PRODUCTION
description: The Sony Corporation said yesterday that it would double production of its PlayStation 2 in the next three months after parts shortages left many consumers empty-handed following introduction of the video game console in Europe and the United States. Sony, the world's largest game console maker, aims to make up for the delays, which were caused by lower-than-expected production capacity for the PlayStation 2's advanced graphics chip. The machine was the must-have item this Christmas, though manufacturing delays forced Sony to scale back shipment targets in the United States by as much as half. Sony is stepping up the manufacturing of PlayStation 2's before other companies release competing machines.

title: For Mahler's Ninth, Coddling Is Required
description: Mahler's Ninth Symphony is falling apart. In slow music it will often hover, uncertain, between one step and the next. When the pace is faster, there is a sense of running against the imminent danger of disaster. Climaxes are not assertions but catastrophes caused by overextension or an invasion of foreign material. Always waiting is the dust of despondency, the little falling phrases that form the main subject matter of the first movement, reappear as if from under cover in the second and third, then take over the finale and eventually give the work the close it has been seeking.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HICKS, HENDERSON
description: HICKS-Henderson. The Board of Governors, staff, members and friends of Pathways for Youth mourn the passing of our beloved Board President. A committed volunteer for many human service organizations, Mr. Hicks sat on our Board for 15 years, serving as Treasurer and First Vice President before becoming the agency's first African-American President in 1995. We will remember Mr. Hicks as impassioned advocate, consummate diplomat and compassionate gentleman, tirelessly supporting our mission of youth development. Empowered by Mr. Hicks's determined leadership, Pathways more than doubled in size, scope of services and membership during his tenure as President. We extend heartfelt condolences to the Hicks family and immeasurable gratitude for the wisdom, perspective, spirit and energy he shared so gracefully with us and all people in need of meaningful assistance. Hank, you will truly be missed. The wake and funeral will be held at J. Foster Philips Funeral Home, 179-24 Linden Boulevard, Queens. The wake will be Wednesday January 17 from 4-8PM, program at 6:30PM. The funeral will be Thursday, January 18 at 10AM. The Pathways for Youth Family

description: WEINBERG-Honorable Sanford I. Acting Village Justice of Kings Point died suddenly on January 13, 2001. Beloved husband of Clara. Loving father of Elliot and Eric. Dear brother of Anita Sperber of Boston. He was a partner in the law firm of Batzer & Weinberg, P.C. in Rockville Centre and was of counsel to Mullooly, Jeffrey, Rooney & Flynn in Glen Cove. He served as an Acting Justice in the Village of Kings Point for the past 15 years and was a United States Standing Bankruptcy Trustee. Sandy was the former President of the L.I. Regional Board Anti Defamation League and active in the Republican Party, serving as former Zone Leader of Great Neck. He was also a former Assistant Town Attorney for the Town of North Hempstead. For over 25 years he was an active member of Temple Israel in Great Neck and was a former Trustee of the Mens Club, and former member of the Couples Club. He graduated with Honors from Suffolk University Law School in Boston and was a founding member of its Alumni Association, New York Chapter. Funeral service will be held at Riverside Nassau North Chapels at 10AM Wednesday, January 17 at 55 North Station Plaza in Great Neck, NY. Intermet at Mount Hebron Cemetery in Queens.

title: California's Energy Crunch
description: As politicians in Sacramento struggled to find a stopgap solution to California's energy crisis, other parts of the United States began to wake up to the possibility that what was happening on the West Coast could happen to them. To the extent that California's crisis results from a uniquely disastrous set of miscalculations, it is unlikely to be repeated elsewhere. But it is a cautionary tale nonetheless, especially in big energy-consuming states like New York.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  VILLA, ANTHONY L.
description: VILLA-Anthony L. 80, of Peapack, NJ, died on Friday, January 12, 2001. Devoted husband of the late Diana Gambrill Villa and beloved father of Anthony G., Peter L., L. Blair, Nicholas G., Diana Villa Noble and Wendy Villa Robins, and the loving grandfather of nine. Born in NYC, March 3, 1920, the son of Count and Countess Alfonso P. Villa. He was a graduate of Groton School and Harvard University. He served during the Second World War with several government agencies and was administrative assistant to the Vice President of the Allied Commission in Italy. Post-war he became the Senior Partner and subsequently Chairman of the brokerage firm Jesup and Lamont & Co; he was then associated with Tucker Anthony & Co. until retirement in 1987. He was at various times a member of the New York and American Stock Exchanges and director of several listed companies. He was a member of the Somerset Hills Country Club, The Raquet and Tennis Club, and a longstanding Governor of The Brook. A memorial service will be held at St. Brigid's Church, Peapack, NJ, on Thursday, January 25, at 11 AM. In lieu of flowers donations may be sent to the Peapack-Gladstone First Aid Squad, 1 St. Luke's St., Gladstone, NJ 07934.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BURT, WILLIAM R.
description: BURT-William R. 1914-2001, Hilton Head Island, SC-Col. (USAF ResRet) died January 8 at his home. He was 86. Col. Burt had an illustrious career in the Army Air Corps during World War II and in the Air Force Reserves thereafter. He was a Wall Street attorney, business executive, venture capitalist, rancher and real estate investor. The third child of Chauncey H. and Marion Brennan Burt, he was born in Plainfield, New Jersey and grew up in Manhattan, attended the Bovee School, was a member of the Knickerbocker Grays, a junior training unit of the Seventh Regiment. He studied at Choate and graduated from Philips Exeter Academy in 1932. He attended Yale and received his law degree from Columbia Law School. Mr. Burt interrupted his schooling with four years working for American Airlines in New York City and six years of military service in Washington and London. While at American Airlines, he was among the pioneers of commercial air freight, and he is credited with inventing the model for the modern credit card. His wartime experience is chronicled in his book, ''Adventures with Warlords: Insight into Key Events of World War II,'' published in 1994. Upon his 80th birthday in August 1994, Mr. Burt was honored by Idaho Governor Cecil D. Andrus at the State Capitol in Boise for creating a fellowship and scholarship programlinking the Idaho Fish and Game Department and the Yale School of Forestry and Environmental Studies. The program honored his son, Bobby, who was killed in the Vietnam War in 1969, and two Idaho Fish and Game officers killed in the line of duty. Mr. Burt is survived by his wife, Jean Pfeiffer Burt, his daughter, Cynthia Burt Beebe of Wilton, Connecticut, and two granddaughters, Lauren Ashley Beebe and Gillian von Nieda Beebe. Burial will be in Hailey, Idaho at a later date. Memorial contributions may be made to the Animal Shelter of Wood River Valley, P.O. Box 1496, Hailey, ID 83333

title: Mr. Pataki's Misstep on Schools
description: Gov. George Pataki plunged into the problems of New York City's schools yesterday with an announcement that he would appeal a landmark judicial ruling that called for drastic increases in education aid to the city. That is a serious mistake that will only slow efforts to rectify the glaring deficiencies that led to Justice Leland DeGrasse's historic ruling that the state has failed to guarantee a sound, basic education to city schoolchildren as required by the State Constitution. At the same time, the governor proposed an $83.6 billion budget for the year beginning April 1 that will include a modest step toward ensuring that the city gets more education aid, though nowhere near the scale needed to remedy the defects cited by Justice DeGrasse.

title: LARGEST U.S. SUGAR PRODUCER FILES CHAPTER 11
description: The Imperial Sugar Company, the largest sugar producer in the United States, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors yesterday, listing $1.09 billion in assets and $775 million in debt. The company, based in Sugar Land, Tex., said last month that it missed a payment on a $250 million loan and hoped to avoid bankruptcy by converting debt to equity. Yesterday, the company cited a glut of refined sugar, low prices and high energy costs as the causes of widening losses in the domestic sugar industry.

title: VERIZON REAPPLIES FOR LONG-DISTANCE IN MASSACHUSETTS
description: Verizon Communications said yesterday that it had resubmitted an application to sell long-distance phone service in Massachusetts after compiling new data for federal regulators. The Federal Communications Commission has 90 days to review the application. Verizon withdrew its first application last month after criticism from the Justice Department that Verizon was not providing rivals with speedy access to its network. Competitors like WorldCom have also accused Verizon of overcharging for leased lines and switches. Verizon said it was confident its new application would pass muster.

title: ONLINE SALES FALL SHORT OF HOPES
description: Online sales last holiday season fell 7 percent short of expectations, according to Jupiter Research, which tracks the Internet. Jupiter pegged sales in November and December at $10.8 billion, up 54 percent from the $7 billion a year earlier, but short of its forecast of $12.1 billion. Online sales in the 1999 holiday season increased 125 percent over 1998. Jupiter said the slowdown in 2000 was consistent with studies of Web site traffic last month and with early sales figures released by online retailers. Jupiter said the shortfall resulted largely from a slowdown in advertising and promotion. Saul Hansell

title: DAEWOO CREDITORS SET LAYOFF PLAN
description: Defying strike threats, creditors of the bankrupt South Korean automaker Daewoo Motor released a new plan to lay off nearly 2,800 employees, or 22 percent of the company's remaining work force, by the middle of next month and leave 2,700 more jobs vacant to win better terms for a sale. Saying it had not been consulted, the union representing Daewoo workers voted to strike, but set no date. Separately, the union sued Kim Woo Choong, who ran the Daewoo group before it collapsed in debt in 1999, accusing him of embezzlement. The government said Mr. Kim had been out of the country since 1999, living most recently in the Sudan, and cannot be forced to return to face trial.

title: Not Quite Dry, Not Too Sweet: Be Sure to Eat Your Fruit
description: IN spite of the pretty little box the French peaches were nestled in, I hesitated. After all, the words on the box read only: ''Peach halves, partly dehydrated and sterilized.'' I fully expected something that could be described only as good for you.

title: CASINO COMPANY SUES DEVELOPER OVER LAS VEGAS HILTON
description: The Park Place Entertainment Corporation, the world's largest casino company, said yesterday that Ed Roski, a real estate developer, had violated his agreement to buy the Las Vegas Hilton for $365 million when he failed to appear at the scheduled closing last Saturday. The company said it would stop trying to sell the property and would pursue ''legal remedies.'' Company officials were not immediately available to elaborate. Mr. Roski agreed to buy the hotel and casino in July and won regulatory approval to operate it in October, but he did not arrange to close the purchase by Jan. 3, Park Place said, and he did not make a required payment of $5 million by Jan. 9.

title: Shopping for Antibiotic-Free Meat
description: EVIDENCE has been accumulating since the 1970's that the overuse of antibiotics for animals and humans is creating bacteria that are resistant to the drugs, making it more and more difficult to treat infections. A report released last week by the Union of Concerned Scientists says that the situation is even worse with animals than experts believed, and that antibiotic use may be 40 percent higher than drug industry figures.

description: British Telecommunications said today that it might sell a share of its stake in Airtel, a Spanish mobile phone company, to the public to raise cash and reduce debt.

description: The Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan's largest car manufacturer, said today that it planned to spend as much as $2.1 billion to buy back up to 2 percent of its stock in the biggest share repurchase program ever undertaken by a Japanese company.

description: California narrowly escaped statewide power blackouts today for the second time in a week as the major utilities moved a step closer to bankruptcy and several large electricity generating plants shut down unexpectedly.

title: Nothing Is for Sure, Except All Isms Are Out
description: The color red keeps flaring up like a sputtering pilot light in the otherwise black-and-white visual universe of Richard Foreman's new play. Since Mr. Foreman's latest offering is titled ''Now That Communism Is Dead My Life Feels Empty!,'' it makes sense that red would be the accent du jour. And there are indeed such expected Communism-evoking images as red flags and red stars.

Waxman today urged the justices not to repudiate more than 25 years of legal precedents that have permitted individuals to sue states to prevent violations of federal civil rights regulations.

description: The search remains open for a music director to succeed Kurt Masur at the New York Philharmonic next year, with no decision expected for weeks or even months, orchestra officials said yesterday.

title: SURPRISE RULING IN LAND FEE CASE
description: Swire Pacific Ltd., one of Hong Kong's biggest landlords, said it had lost an arbitration case with the government and might have to pay up to 4.5 billion Hong Kong dollars ($577 million) in back land-use fees and interest on three office towers built in the last decade. The decision was thought to be the first instance of the government's assessing such fees on land covered by 19th-century leases. Swire, which said it could pay the charges out of cash on hand, has not yet decided whether to appeal.

title: RAILWAY TO SELL HEALTH UNIT
description: Deutsche Bahn, Germany's state-owned railway, said it was seeking a buyer for its health care unit, DB GesundheitsService, whose 400 doctors, nurses and technicians treat 240,000 railroad workers at 68 locations. The sale is part of the railway's plan to slim down to its core business, go public and break even by 2005. A deal to sell its security and cleaning service fell through recently because the buyer, a unit of Nomura Securities, said it had too few tangible assets.

title: Metro Business Briefing; SPINOFF IS UNSPUN
description: Vitamin Shoppe Industries, a New Jersey direct-marketing company, has agreed to acquire a Silicon Alley company that it spun off three years ago. Vitamin Shoppe executives agreed to buy the 36 percent of VitaminShoppe.com's shares that it does not own, taking the firm private. VitaminShoppe .com was expected to run out of money in April. The company raised $50 million in the initial public offering of its stock in October 1999.

title: PICKUP TRUCKS FOR CHINA
description: The Shanghai Automotive Industrial Corporation said it would develop a pickup truck for sale in rural China with technical help from the General Motors Corporation. A plant in Jiangsu Province in eastern China will be retooled to build an inexpensive four-seat pickup based on the Opel Combo, sold by G.M. in Europe. Shanghai Automotive already produces sedans in joint ventures with G.M. and Volkswagen in Shanghai. Chinese automakers sold 197,059 light trucks domestically in the first half of 2000, up 7 percent from the corresponding period in 1999, according to government figures.

title: Ankara Journal; Tale of a Banned Poet, a Painting and an Old City
description: As the late-afternoon sun caught the floating dust motes on the third floor of an antique shop here, the light appeared to focus on a portrait painted with care and sympathy by an artist whose understanding of his subject seemed far deeper than the contours of the proud Anatolian peasant's face.

title: When Chefs Chill Out and Cook
description: COOKBOOKS that present top professional chefs supposedly whipping up a family meal at home often seem a bit far-fetched. But just as Emanuel Ax might actually like sitting down at a friend's piano and tossing off a sonata or two, chefs do enjoy cooking just for the fun of it. Frequently, what they say about this type of relaxed cooking, with no restaurant customers to please, can be a treasure for the home cook.

title: A Cellar Master of a Certain Vintage
description: IT'S easy to get tired of New York in midwinter: the crowds, the angry drivers, the dirty snow. Some people head for Miami. Me, I take the A Train to Brooklyn. With the sun on the water, the Brooklyn Bridge soaring overhead and Lower Manhattan a thousand yards away, there is no place like it to see New York. It's a John Sloan painting and an Edna St. Vincent Millay poem and an afternoon spent taking it in will get you through to April better than a weekend in Paris.

title: Traces of Uranium Isotope Found in U.S. Munitions in Kosovo
description: A Swiss laboratory announced today that it had found traces of a uranium isotope that suggest radioactive contamination in American-made munitions that were collected on the battlefields of Kosovo.

title: Metro Business Briefing; CONSULTANTS FOR HARLEM PIERS
description: The city has selected a consulting team to help it develop a master plan for revitalizing the Harlem Piers, officials said yesterday. The plan, to be completed in about six months, will address the feasibility of building a new pier and will include revenue-generating proposals, the city's Economic Development Corporation said. The area to be developed runs from St. Clair Place to 135th Street between Broadway and the Hudson River. The consulting team includes Ten W Architects of Mexico City and Brooklyn, which worked on the redevelopment of the Baltimore waterfront, and Ernst & Young.

title: Editorial Notebook; Hearing the Echo of Earthly Music
description: It seems unlikely that scientists will ever discover another species on earth that practices the scientific method. The fact would be unprovable, of course, for there might always be some undiscovered beetle testing hypotheses experimentally under a rotting log or in a convoluted burrow somewhere. But the practice of science will probably turn out to be the last fundamental divide between humans and the other inhabitants of this planet. Again and again, after starting from an ancient premise of radical difference between humans and other creatures, scientists have discovered profound similarities among us all, profound enough to undermine the initial arrogance and the false self-knowledge of that premise. The more we know about the rest of life, it turns out, the more we know about ourselves and the less we resemble the iconic, self-exalting ideal of biblical or Cartesian man.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, LEONARD
description: DAVIS-Leonard. The American Friends of The Hebrew University and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem deeply mourn the passing of Leonard Davis, AFHU Council of Trustees member and longstanding leader and an Honary Governor of the Hebrew University. Leonard and his late wife Sophie, were longtime supporters and Benefactors of The Hebrew University, as well as many secular and Jewish causes in Florida and New York. In 1972, they established the Leonard Davis Institute for International Relations at Hebrew University to deepen the understanding of international relations by various means, including the promotion of research, the organizing of workshops, conferences and seminars, and the publication of research. Other programs at the University that have benefitted from their generosity include the Sanford F. Kuvin Center for the Study of Infectious and Tropical Diseases and the Bernard Cherrick Center for the Study of Zionism, the Yishuv and the State of Israel. Leonard's wise counsel and dedicated support provided the foundation for AFHU activities in Palm Beach, Florida. In 1977, Hebrew University conferred an Honorary Doctorate of Philosophy on Leonard in recognition of his farsighted concern and his continuing and wholehearted support for scholarship in the service of mankind. We extend our deepest condolences to his sons Alan and Michael, his four grandchildren, and the entire family. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menachem Magidor, President Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, Rector Yigal Arnon, Chairman of the Board of Governors American Friends of The Hebrew University Ira Lee Sorkin, President Keith L. Sachs Chairman of the Board Barbara A. Mandel Honorary President Adam B. Kahan Executive Vice President

title: Modell and Accorsi United by Defeats
description: The Baltimore owner, Art Modell, practically in tears, stood on a podium at midfield this past Sunday, surrounded by Ravens team executives and players, accepting congratulations for the Ravens making it to Super Bowl XXXV. It was the kind of celebration, spurred on by the Ravens' improbable victory over Oakland, that Modell had long dreamed of taking part in. He had done it -- decades of being an owner in the league and he had finally made it to a Super Bowl.

title: Nassau Leader Is Urged Not to Run
description: A year after they lost control of the Nassau County Legislature in a voter revolt set off by the county's fiscal crisis, all nine Republicans who remain in the Legislature called today on Thomas S. Gulotta, the embattled Republican county executive, not to run for a fourth term.

title: ONLINE AD AGENCIES MERGE
description: Two companies that offer advertising media exchanges for the Internet are combining in a deal with undisclosed terms. Mediapassage of Seattle is acquiring OneMediaPlace of San Francisco, formerly known as AdAuction.com. The new company will use the name OneMediaPassage. Gilbert Scherer, chairman and chief executive at OneMediaPlace, will be chairman of the merged company and will share the duties of chief executive with Jerry Machovina, president and chief executive at Mediapassage. OneMediaPlace has specialized in matching buyers and sellers of media like television and radio, while Mediapassage has specialized in helping plan, place, track and pay for newspaper and magazine advertising. Stuart Elliott

title: A Hong Kong Stalwart Resigns
description: The early resignation of Anson Chan as Hong Kong's second-ranking official is an unmistakable warning that the territory's democratic safeguards are being eroded under Beijing's rule. Mrs. Chan, appointed by the last British governor, Chris Patten, as the independent director of Hong Kong's non-political civil service, has made herself a symbol of the autonomy China pledged to respect in Hong Kong when it resumed sovereignty over the territory in 1997. Her decision last week to step down more than a year before the scheduled end of her term signaled that she no longer felt able to guarantee Hong Kong's autonomy in the face of increasing interference from mainland China.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KAWCZYNSKI, THOMAS J.
description: KAWCZYNSKI-Thomas J. 38, January 16th. A Manhattanite for seven years and Controller for the Sulzer USA Company for over 15 years, Tom has influenced the lives of many with his ability to provide calm, direction and clarity. Warm, loving, kind and creative, he offered his friendship freely and shared his talents generously. His bravery in fighting cancer is testament to his strength as an individual, and we can only hope to emulate his fine example of how to live. His untimely death leaves a great and painful void. Tom is survived by his mother, Dorothy, his sisters Donna and Kathy, their husbands Nick and Jim, niece Monica and her husband Tony, nieces Melissa and Jennifer, nephew, Danny, and great-nephew Evan. Tom celebrated life and cherished his extended family of friends. Funeral services will be held in his hometown of Depew, New York on Thursday and Friday at Pacer Funerals, 2275 George Urban Blvd., Depew, N.Y. 14043.

Supervalu said its contract with Kmart was worth $2.3 billion annually; Fleming said it had $1.3 billion in sales attributable to Kmart in 2000. Both said they would bid to become the sole supplier for Kmart's 2,100 stores. Separately, a group including Yucaipa Investment and the billionaire investor Ronald Burkle said in a regulatory filing that it had acquired a 6 percent stake in Kmart.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEUCHTER, BEN ZION
description: LEUCHTER-Ben Zion. It is with great sadness that HIAS, the Hebrew Immigrant Aid Society, notes the passing of our dear friend, longtime colleague and former president (1988-1992). His leadership, dedication and lifelong commitment to assisting Jews worldwide was truly inspiring. During the years of his great leadership, HIAS assisted more than 150,000 Jews from the former Soviet Union to escape persecution and build new lives in the United States. During a crucial turning point in world history, the disintegration of the Soviet Union, Ben Zion Leuchter's tireless advocacy on behalf of refugees was profound. Active in numerous Jewish organizations and co-founder of CLAL, Ben Zion Leuchter was a pillar in the American Jewish community. He was an accomplished journalist, editor and assistant publisher of the Vineland Times-Journal from 1949 to 1977. His devotion, warmth and vision will be sorely missed. Our heartfelt sympathy goes out to his wife, Magda and his entire family. Neil Greenbaum, Board Chair Leonard Glickman, President

Both airlines' Concorde fleets have been grounded since a Concorde exploded on takeoff in Paris in July 2000, probably because debris from a burst tire ruptured its fuel tank.

description: WOLF-Roslyn Zehman. The Officers, Board and Staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of the beloved wife of our distinguished past President Ambassador Milton A. Wolf. She worked with her husband to provide assistance to those in need throughout the world. When her husband represented the United States as U.S. Ambassador to the Federal Republic of Austria, she served with him in Vienna. She was the leader of the spouses of the 105 ambassadors serving in Vienna, where she hosted the SALT II talks, attended by Presidents Carter and Brezhnev. Mrs. Wolf will be remembered for her warmth, generosity, and extraordinary good will. Mrs. Wolf had a lifetime involvement with the Jewish community and truly embodied the quality of a ''Woman of Valor.'' We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, children, grandchildren, family and friends. Eugene Ribakoff, President Jonathan W. Kolker, Bd Chrmn Michael Schneider, Exec V.P.

description: DAVIS-Leonard. The City College of New York and its Sophie Davis School of Biomedical Education/ CUNY Medical School mourn the passing of Leonard Davis, an alumnus who was a major benefactor of his alma mater. A 1944 graduate of CCNY, he and his late wife Sophie are responsible for the creation and funding of City College's performing arts center, Aaron Davis Hall, and the Leonard Davis Center for the Performing Arts, as well as the Sophie Davis School. His vision and generosity benefitted thousands of students and enriched the artistic and cultural life of our city. Leonard Davis' wisdom, friendship and commitment to CCNY will always be remembered and his memory will be forever honored. On behalf of City College's faculty, students and alumni, I wish to extend my deepest condolences to his two sons, Alan and Michael, and their families. Stanford A. title: STRONG JOB PICTURE IN BRITAIN
description: British unemployment in December remained as low as it has been in 25 years, and the tight labor market drove wages up at a 4.2 percent annual rate in the previous three months, the government reported. Rising labor costs led analysts to back away from forecasts of an imminent cut in interest rates and suggested that the British economy was not slowing down the way the American economy appears to be. But with inflation well below the government's 2.5 percent target and the American slowdown considered likely to affect Britain eventually, investors still expect a rate cut later this year. title: Turmoil in Congo
description: Laurent Kabila was welcomed as a conquering hero when his rebel forces marched into Kinshasa in 1997, ousting Congo's longtime despot, Mobutu Sese Seko. But like too many self-proclaimed liberators across post-colonial Africa, Mr. Kabila proved to be a tyrant himself. His removal from power on Tuesday -- there were conflicting accounts yesterday whether he had been killed -- seems unlikely to resolve Congo's myriad problems. Restraint on all sides and throughout Central Africa is required if Congo is to be spared a new round of bloodshed.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEVINSON, EMANUEL
description: LEVINSON-Emanuel, Doctor of Electrical Engineering, leader in the field of inertial navigation and a developer of the ring laser gyroscope, died suddenly January 15 at age 74 in Charlottesville, Va., where he was consultant to Litton/ Sperry Marine. With 53 years in the defense industry, he was a recipient of the Institute of Navigation Berkely Award for contributions to engineering and was the author of numerous papers and patents. His loss is deeply felt by his wife, Shirley, of more than 50 years; his son, Lawrence; his daughter, Linda, and her husband, Manny; his grandsons, Jeremy, David and Jonathan, as well as his professional associates. He was a man who inspired the highest standards of excellence in professional and personal life with modesty, fairness, dedication and loyalty. Funeral services will be held today, 11:30 AM, at Bloomfield Cooper Funeral Home, Manalapan, NJ, (732) 446-4242.

title: EASTMAN KODAK 4TH-QUARTER PROFIT DOWN 50%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profit fell 50 percent because the economic slowdown and the resulting decline in consumer spending hurt film sales. Profit from operations dropped to $200 million, or 68 cents a share, compared with $403 million, or $1.27 a share, in the period a year earlier. Sales fell 6.3 percent, to $3.56 billion, from $3.8 billion. Kodak, which has cut profit estimates three times since September, said an abrupt decline in orders left it with large inventories and increased expenses. But Kodak said its expectations for the second half were unchanged. Its stock rose 56 cents, to $41.88.

title: CHIEF OF TRADER.COM WILL DECLINE PAY FOR 2 YEARS
description: Trader.com, a classified advertising publisher, said its president and chief executive, John MacBain, will forgo all compensation, including certain stock options, in 2001 and 2002 as part of the company's plan to reduce costs and preserve cash. Shares in the company, incorporated in the Netherlands but traded mainly in Paris, rose 29 percent after the announcement, closing at 7.05 euros ($6.61). The company also said it would take a charge of 25 million euros ($23.4 million) for the costs of a restructuring plan, now complete, that eliminated 275 jobs and closed some of the company's World Wide Web sites. The company was founded in 1987 but went public last year.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE CHIP MAKER MISSES FORECASTS Advanced Micro Devices reported fourth-quarter net income yesterday that narrowly trailed forecasts and joined its larger rival Intel in predicting that slack sales of PC's would hurt first-quarter sales. Advanced Micro Devices said its net income for the quarter more than doubled to $177.9 million, or 53 cents a share, from $65.1 million, or 21 cents, a year earlier. Sales rose 21 percent, to $1.18 billion. Analysts had expected the Sunnyvale, Calif.- based company to earn 55 cents a share. In light of weak demand for personal computers and slowing worldwide economies, the chip maker said it expected that normal seasonal weakness in first-quarter demand for PC processors coupled with the effects of excess PC inventories in distribution channels would hurt PC processor sales in the first quarter of 2001. (Reuters)

title: CATHAY JET PURCHASE ON HOLD

title: CURRENTS/MIAMI: ARCHITECTURE; For a Library, Robert Stern Shows His Take on Modernism
description: Robert A. M. Stern Architects is known for saluting the classical past. The new Miami Beach regional library by Mr. Stern, dean of the Yale School of Architecture, and Borrelli & Associates of Miami, draws on what Mr. Stern calls American Modernism. (''I don't like the term Art Deco,'' he says.) Adjoining the new Miami City Ballet building on Collins Park, the library will replace an existing 1950's structure with a sleek, two-story building of tapered, streamlined windows and columns. Mr. Stern's inspiration comes from Miami Beach, and beyond: ''I'm a Brooklyn boy,'' he said, ''so my childhood memories are of the Brooklyn Public Library. It's classical, but in a sleek way.'' Construction is to begin this spring. RAUL A. BARRENECHE

title: ITALY BLOCKS TAKEOVER OF TELEVISION NETWORK
description: Italian authorities have blocked a takeover of the Telemontecarlo television network by Seat Pagine Gialle, the country's largest Internet company. In the ruling yesterday, the authorities said the deal would violate laws blocking telecommunications companies from directly or indirectly controlling commercial broadcasters. Seat, which has been trying to transform itself from a directory publisher into a Europewide Internet and media company, merged last year with the Internet unit of Telecom Italia, the country's dominant telephone company. The chief executive of Seat, Lorenzo Pellicioli, said the deal, to buy a 75 percent stake in the network from the Cecchi Gori Group for 387 million euros ($361 million), was fundamental to its strategy.

At the foot of the bed is a chaise with a computer-TV stand attached in one shiny blob. Raven Hotel Management aimed for a gadget savvy crowd when it turned the 1941 Art Deco original into a 42-room hotel with B-movie chic. The gallery is at 70 NE 40th Street in the Miami Design District; (305) 438-1966.

title: Washington's Guessing Game

title: Metro Business Briefing; SWATCH V. MOVADO

Under the agreement between AMR and the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, which is acquiring US Airways, if AMR were to buy or merge with Northwest, Continental, Delta Air Lines, Southwest or any other domestic carrier of comparable size, it would either have to surrender its share of the shuttle service or sell off other routes and aircraft to avoid becoming larger than United, the filing said. title: Album of the Week
description: GROOVE COLLECTIVE: ''It's All in Your Mind'' (Shanachie). Groove Collective, from Brooklyn, started out with other acid-jazz groups as 1970's revivalists and revisionists, pushing smooth jazz and funk toward the dance floor. But over the years the group has broadened its reach and its ambitions. On ''It's All in Your Mind,'' Groove Collective remains fond of the 1970's but cruises the African diaspora. The album includes pugnacious Nigerian Afro-beat, easygoing tunes with wordless oohs and ahs that suggest Earth Wind and Fire, snappy funk and glimmering electric piano meditations. The opening tune, ''Time Pilot,'' has the stately serenity of something by the French group Air, while an airborne Latin-jazz jam, ''Stargazer,'' has Groove Collective easily keeping pace with the brilliant Cuban pianist Chucho Valdes. Tunes that could get by with a vamp and a melody unfold with multiple themes as arrangements layer on jazzy harmonic convolutions. ''In Your Mind'' free-associates from jazz to funk to Beatles-flavored rock; ''Earth to Earth'' imagines what pygmy funk might sound like. Groove Collective's identity lies not in one fixed style but in its capable hospitality to whatever might keep hips swaying. JON PARELES

title: Metro Business Briefing; JOB GROWTH CONTINUES
description: New York City's economy continued to surge in December, despite the national economic slowdown, according to figures released yesterday by the New York State Department of Labor. Employers created more than 20,000 new jobs in the city in December, bringing the total increase for the year to 90,000, 2.4 percent more than in 1999. That growth rate is far stronger than the national average of 1.5 percent or the statewide average of 1.8 percent. The unemployment rate in the city, when adjusted for seasonal factors, was unchanged in December at 5.6 percent. Statewide, the unemployment rate dipped slightly to 4.5 percent from 4.6 percent; the national average was unchanged at 4 percent. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

title: GAINS FORECAST FOR ONLINE ADS
description: There ''are still plenty of signs of hope'' for online advertising, despite the widespread decline among dot-com marketers, Melissa Gluck, senior analyst at Jupiter Communications, part of Jupiter Media Metrix, said yesterday at an industry conference organized by the American Association of Advertising Agencies and the Association of National Advertisers. She estimated that online advertising would climb to $7.3 billion this year, from $5.3 billion in 2000, and reach $16.5 billion by 2005. Advertising for products like automobiles, health and travel would compensate for reduced spending by dot-coms, Ms. Gluck predicted. Jeffrey Mallett, above, chief operating officer at Yahoo, agreed that ''traditional companies are finally stepping up'' to buy ads online. He noted that more than two-thirds of Yahoo's 15,000 clients a month were traditional companies. The conference, the first event jointly sponsored by the two groups, continues through this afternoon at the Hilton New York. Stuart Elliott (NYT)

description: The New York attorney general's office has filed a federal civil rights complaint yesterday against the small upstate town of Wallkill, charging that it has failed to corral a lawless police department whose officers pull over female drivers to solicit dates, refuse to cooperate with other law enforcement agencies, and systematically harass their many critics, from town officials to the local newspaper.

Ballmer, posed a question. Just how many of these ''new employees,'' Mr. Ballmer wondered, had actually worked at Microsoft before?

title: New Jersey Court Orders Parole for Man Who Killed Two Officers in 1963
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court today ended 21 years of legal wrangling in one of the state's most notorious cases by ordering parole for Thomas Trantino, who killed two Lodi police officers in 1963. But the ruling detonated an explosion of anger from police groups, the families of the victims and politicians who had striven successfully for years to defeat Mr. Trantino's nine previous attempts to win his freedom.

title: Head of J. Walter Thompson quits unexpectedly over health after strong years for the agency.
description: CHRIS JONES, the youngest chief executive in the history of J. Walter Thompson in New York, the world's fourth-largest agency, resigned unexpectedly, effective immediately, for health reasons, executives there said yesterday.

title: G.M. SAYS IT WILL CLOSE THREE MORE FACTORIES FOR A WEEK
description: General Motors said yesterday that it would idle three of its 29 North American factories and furlough 2,450 workers next week to reduce production because of slack demand. Plants in Oklahoma City; Orion Township, Mich.; and Oshawa, Ontario, will be affected. Three other plants were idle this week. The temporary closings are part of G.M.'s plan to reduce first-quarter production by 21 percent from levels of a year earlier, to 1.2 million vehicles. The company said it expected its profits in the first quarter to be marginal.

title: Judge Testifies That Ashcroft Willfully Distorted the Record
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee listened raptly today as Judge Ronnie White of Missouri recounted how he was astonished to learn in 1999 that John Ashcroft had derailed his chance to be a federal judge at the last minute by asserting that he was ''pro-criminal'' and soft on the death penalty.

title: UNION ASKS BOEING TO HALT TALKS WITH JAPANESE COMPANY
description: Union leaders urged the Boeing Company yesterday to stop negotiations with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries over the possibility of hiring Mitsubishi to build wings for jumbo jets in Japan. The company notified its largest union, the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, of the talks two weeks ago. A strike is unlikely, but the union may take legal action or file a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board if the talks proceed, a union official said. Boeing officials were not immediately available for comment.

title: U.S. Twins in Britain Custody Fight
description: LONDON, Jan. 19  A trans-Atlantic struggle for custody of baby twins was headed for the courts today after they were taken from their British adoptive parents in a late night surprise visit by social service workers at a North Wales hotel where the family was staying.

title: No Suspects in a Fatal Shooting Outside a Long Island Health Club
description: Suffolk County police officials said yesterday that they had no suspects in the killing of a co-owner of an Amityville fitness club, who was shot Wednesday night in the club's parking lot.

title: WITH PROFIT DOWN, SEARS MAY REDUCE PRODUCT LINES
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company's chairman and chief executive, Alan Lacy, said yesterday that Sears might reduce or eliminate some product lines to make more room for top-selling categories like appliances, but that the company would continue to be a general merchant. Sears reported that its profit from operations fell 14 percent in the fourth quarter from the period a year earlier, but the figure -- $639 million, or $1.91 a share -- was4 cents a share better than analysts had forecast. Revenue rose 2.4 percent, to $12.4 billion. The company said its credit revenue suffered as customers paid down balances, and it took a charge of $197 million, or 59 cents a share, related to store closings and losses at its pest control business. Shares of Sears fell 26 cents, to $34.49.

title: New York City Pledges $240 Million Toward the Overhaul of Lincoln Center
description: New York City has committed $240 million over the next 10 years for the reconstruction of Lincoln Center, the largest sum it has ever provided to a cultural institution, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Lincoln Center announced yesterday.

title: Donor Asks College To Return AIDS Money
description: In 1997, Dr. Bernard Salick, a medical entrepreneur, pledged $4.5 million to Queens College to help it build an AIDS research center led by a world-class scientist, Dr. Luc Montagnier, the co-discoverer of the AIDS virus. Dr. Salick hoped it would bring the college glory.

title: Another Inaugural Hootenanny
description: If there is one thing America is good at, it is entertainment meatloaf -- a little bit of everything served up all at once. It was true at the Bicentennial and at millennium celebrations coast to coast, and it was true yesterday at the inaugural opening ceremonies at the Lincoln Memorial. Larry King emceed. The Rockettes moved synchronously. There is always a solemn period on Inauguration Day, but that period is preceded and followed by as much hoopla as the party stalwarts, a bipartisan Congressional committee and Washington's society hostesses can round up for, say, $30 or $40 million. For a day or two, it is as though all the state fairs in America, and some of the livestock too, had come to Pennsylvania Avenue.

title: Morris Lapidus, an Architect Who Built Flamboyance Into Hotels, Is Dead at 98
description: Morris Lapidus, an architect long derided and later praised for designing some of South Florida's gaudiest, glitziest and most glamorous hotels in the 1950's and 60's, died yesterday at his home in Miami Beach. He was 98 and lived in a white high-rise he designed that stands near three of his most glittering creations, the Fontainebleau, Americana and Eden Roc hotels.

title: A Windfall For the Modern
description: The name Thomas Walther may not ring any bells with the public, but to people whose passion is photography, he is something of a legend. For more than 20 years, the German-born Mr. Walther has been quietly but obsessively collecting modernist photography, assembling hundreds of works by every leading European and American photographer of the 1920's and 30's. Not only is his collection well known among photography dealers and collectors, but museum curators have also been courting Mr. Walther in the hope that someday their institutions will get at least part of his prized holdings. Last summer the Metropolitan Museum of Art had a show called ''Other Pictures: Vernacular Photographs From the Thomas Walther Collection.''

description: JAMES-Katherine Magner. Died at home on Sunday, December 31st. Daughter of Thomas F. and Isabella C. Magner, she was born on January 23rd, 1901 in Brooklyn, NY. She is the widow of Warner Rutherford James and was also predeceased by a daughter, Cynthia McDonald. She is survived by a daughter, Nancy Magner McDonald of Ponte Vedra Beach, FL and a step-daughter and her husband Clare and Jess Dall of Greenwich, CT; Jonathan Dall of Frankfort, MI; and David and Michelle Dall of Cos Cob, CT. A Memorial Service will be held on her 100th birthday on Tuesday, January 23rd 11:00 AM at the Church of St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th St., New York City. title: Denial for Chiquita Woes
description: A long-running dispute over Europe's banana import quota system is not responsible for forcing Chiquita Brands International toward bankruptcy, a European Commission spokesman said today. Chiquita says quotas have cost it $1.3 billion in lost sales, and it has criticized the Clinton administration for not forcing Europe to open up its banana market. European rules favor former European colonies in Africa and the Caribbean over Latin American nations where most Chiquita bananas are grown.

title: Be Presidential, but Be Brief
description: It's a president's prerogative to change his mind, so maybe tomorrow George W. Bush will forgo his promise of brevity and stupefy us with a speech even longer than the two-hour oration that Edward Everett Hale delivered at Gettysburg in November 1863. (Abraham Lincoln also said a few words.) If, however, Mr. Bush keeps his promise to be brief, he will deserve the thanks of a grateful nation. In between the din of the last election and Wall Street's rumblings, we could use a little peace and quiet.

title: Norton Calls Herself A Passionate Conservationist
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  As opposition to her nomination seemed to dissipate today, Gale A. Norton, the designated interior secretary, began to make the case for policies that would open Alaska's Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil drilling.

title: City Police Are on the Lookout For 7 Escaped Texas Convicts
description: City police officers have been told to be on the lookout for seven convicts who escaped from a Texas prison on Dec. 13, Police Commissioner Bernard B. Kerik said yesterday.

description: Powerful senators from both parties expressed grave doubts today about the plan put forward by President-elect George W. Bush to help low-income elderly people pay for prescription drugs.

title: Film World's Busy Winter
description: Many businesses crank back a notch in mid-January, still sluggish from holiday revels and the chill of winter. But this is an especially busy time in Hollywood, what with the awards season in full swing, the first of the year's big releases being prepared to open and the arrival of another Sundance Film Festival in the snows of the Wasatch Range high above Salt Lake City.

description: Tens of thousands of commuters were stranded at Grand Central Terminal for hours last night after wire trouble shut down the Metro-North Railroad's busiest line for much of the evening rush, the railroad said.
