The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York note with sadness the untimely passing of John Bergreen, a talented photographer and cherished son of Adele and Morris Bergreen. John's kindness reflected the compassionate concern of his parents, exceptional leaders in the Jewish community who expressed a deep commitment to humanitarian causes through their support of UJA-Federation and its affiliated agencies. We extend our deepest regrets to Adele and Morris; to Mr. Bergreen's beloved wife, Natasha; and to his entire family. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair John S. Ruskay, Executive V.P. & CEO

description: Charles Schwab, the discount brokerage firm, said today that its quarterly profit declined for the first time in almost three years, because the stock market plunged and expenses rose.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADAMS, FREDERICK B.
description: ADAMS - Frederick B. The Trustees and staff of The Pierpont Morgan Library mourn the death of Frederick B. Adams, who died in Chisseaux, France, on January 7, 2001. He was 90 years old. He served, with distinction, as the second Director of the Library from 1948 to 1969. Mr. Adams, an internationally renowned bibliophile, had a great and lasting impact on the development of the Library. After his retirement, from his home in Paris, he remained an active proponent of culture and education in America and abroad. We extend deepest sympathies to his widow Marie-Louise de Croy Adams and his entire family. Charles E. Pierce, Jr., Director S. Parker Gilbert, President, Board of Trustees

title: Jeter Seeks Record $18.5 Million in Arbitration
description: When Derek Jeter and the Yankees conclude the negotiations they pursued seriously yesterday, they will have the most lucrative baseball contract and highest average salary ever negotiated by a player who was not a free agent. title: Gomez Assists Devils In Overpowering Flyers
description: Scott Gomez of the Devils demonstrated clearly tonight the significance of winning face-offs in hockey. He won two in the first four minutes, both in the Flyers' zone, and each led to goals that put the Devils on the path to a 7-1 victory over Philadelphia at the First Union Center.

title: Metro Business Briefing; ALGONQUIN FOR SALE
description: After undergoing a $5.5 million renovation in 1998, the storied Algonquin Hotel is going on the market for the third time in 14 years, its owners said yesterday. David B. Deniger, the chief executive of Olympus Real Estate Corporation of Dallas, the principal owner of the Algonquin, said a decision was made to sell the 165-room landmark on 44th Street near Avenue of the Americas after a couple of unsolicited offers were received. When Olympus acquired the hotel in 1997 for $32.6 million, it said that it planned to hold the property for just five to seven years. Hotel Business, an Internet site (www.hotelbusiness.com) for the hotel industry, reported that the asking price was $50 million, but Mr. Deniger said the hotel had not set a price. Terry Pristin (NYT)

title: Mets Add Bullpen Depth
description: Following a strategy that was modestly successful last season, the Mets added another reliever yesterday to a pitching staff that seems to have no available spots.

description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 19  Although many buildings along Pennsylvania Avenue were decorated in red, white and blue bunting, the dominant color for Inauguration Day was apt to be gray.

description: Antitrust regulators in Australia rejected two competing bids to take over Hazelton Airlines, a regional carrier, saying that allowing either Qantas Airways Ltd. or Ansett Holdings Ltd. to take over Hazelton would give the winner too many landing slots at Sydney's main airport, deterring competition. Ansett is owned by Air New Zealand Ltd.

title: DVD Struggles With Success
description: DVD has become such a success that home video doesn't quite know what to do with it. Millions of new players spur fresh activity. Low disc prices boost sales, with DVD's of some titles outselling videocassettes. Not everyone wants to buy every movie, obviously, so DVD rentals are booming. And that introduces video's old split personality -- sales pricing vs. rental pricing -- and raises questions of what might happen at the checkout counter.

title: Turkey Tries to Step Up Sell-Off of State Companies
description: Turkey's privatization officials will hit the road next week in Europe to try to drum up interest among potential buyers for a stake in the state-owned telephone company, a deal many analysts see as a litmus test for the country's economy.

title: California Endures A 2nd Straight Day Of Power Blackouts
description: Northern and Central California endured a second, more extensive day of rotating blackouts today affecting several million people, but officials said that large purchases of power by the state under the governor's emergency decree helped avert additional cutoffs during the afternoon.

title: Selling Point Is a Sore One
description: One of George W. Bush's selling points during the primary campaign last year was inclusiveness. In two campaigns for governor, he and his backers argued, he had done better among blacks and other minorities than most other Republicans, and he would do so in the presidential race.

title: Henman Ponders How to Explain His Loss to Arthurs in Third Set
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 19  The face-painted, flag-waving Brits inside Rod Laver Arena let out a gasp when Tim Henman blew a fuse tonight in the third set after dismantling Australian Wayne Arthurs in the first two sets of his third-round match.

title: Films That Keep Asking, Is It Fact or Fiction?
description: Truth used to be stranger than fiction. But in a media-soaked age, the two are often interchangeable. Reality has become fluid, and no medium has done more to make it so than film, with its wide accessibility, its sense-and-psyche-altering format and its effortless gift for persuasion, all intensified by digital technology. It makes sense that some of our most adventurous artists have adopted it as their preferred medium.

title: Presidents' Words Have Run From Poignant to Prophetic
description: In delivering a farewell speech tonight, Bill Clinton joined a group of presidents who have tried to say more than ''goodbye'' in their last days in office.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WELLS, THOMAS MOORE
description: WELLS-Thomas Moore. Of Scarborough, New York, architect, died after a long illness on January 16, 2001 at his home. He was 59. Mr. Wells was born April 10, 1941 in Boston, Massachusetts. He received his B.A. from Dartmouth College in 1963 and his Masters of Architecture from Columbia University in 1969. Mr. Wells lived in Scarborough, New York for twenty years. Before that he lived in New York City and Boston, Massachusetts. Mr. Wells will be remembered as an architect in the inner city in Newark and East Harlem; for his recent work as a trustee at the Convent of the Sacred Heart, Greenwich, Ct; for the many boats he built and his passion for the sea; and for his warmth, humor and generosity. He is survived by his wife Rosemary of Scarborough, daughter Victoria of New York City, anddaughter Marguerite currently studying in Edinburgh, Scotland, sister Carolyn Wells of West Bend, WI, sister Merritt Wells Stites of Salt Lake City, Utah, brother Theodore of Philadelphia, PA, mother Marianne Monroe Glazier of Salt Lake City, and his two faithful dogs, Snowy and Lucy. A memorial service will be held at the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, Ct, Saturday, January 20, 2001 at 10 A.M. Interment will follow at New Fernwood Cemetery in Kingston, RI at 4 PM. Friends may send memorial donations to the Appalachian Mountain Club, the Sierra Club or the Convent of the Sacred Heart.

title: One Year After a Deadly Fire, Seton Hall Reflects
description: The fire was a year ago, but in her mind, Marissa Southwell can still hear the yells, smell the smoke pouring into her room and feel the intense heat and flames coming from the lounge just outside her door.

title: Free-Speech Advocates Fight Filtering Software in Public Schools
description: One month after Congress passed a law pressuring public schools and libraries to install blocking or filtering software on computer terminals to screen out Internet smut, three free-speech powerhouses are gearing up to slay the measure in federal court.

title: Yoga Gear
description: Yoga is hard enough. Theres no need to drown in the folds of an XXL T-shirt or skid across the room on the wrong mat. As with any other exercise, what you wear and use in yoga determines the quality of your experience. Here are tips for a smooth yogic experience.

title: Stability at the Intelligence Agencies
description: President-elect George W. Bush wisely broke with tradition this week by keeping the nation's spy chief on the job, at least temporarily, as one party prepares to pass control of the White House to the other. The last time that happened was 1969, when Richard Nixon succeeded Lyndon Johnson as president and retained the services of Richard Helms as director of central intelligence. Mr. Bush's decision to extend the tenure of George Tenet can establish a bipartisan principle of the need for continuity in managing the nation's intelligence agencies, especially at a time of formidable challenges.

title: Equity Shrivels as Homeowners Borrow and Buy
description: When Erica Hutchinson and her fiance, Lynn Corbett, bought their brownstone in the Clinton Hill section of Brooklyn for $175,000 three years ago, they persuaded a bank to lend them $230,000. Their argument was that the value of their new home would jump once they used the extra mortgage money to gut the three-story building and fill it with new bathrooms, a new kitchen, new flooring, new windows -- new everything.

title: Metro Business Briefing; STATE SUES DEVELOPERS
description: Charging that they had concealed significant construction defects and failed to provide amenities described in their prospectus, the New York State attorney general's office filed an $8 million lawsuit Wednesday against the developers of a luxury condominium in TriBeCa. If it succeeds, the suit will also bar the developers of the condominium, the Ice House at 27 North Moore Street, from involvement in co-op or condo ventures. The developers of the 13-story building, which once served as a refrigerator for ice from the Hudson River, are Joseph Pell Lombardi, who was also the architect for the conversion, Jack Lefkowitz and Abraham Berkowitz. Mr. Lombardi and Mr. Berkowitz have both severed their ties with the project, which includes 57 residential lofts and five commercial sites. Allegations listed in the suit include defective fireproofing, heating, ventilation, air-conditioning, drainage, roofing and flooring. In addition, the builders used brick veneer instead of brick and failed to install a marble lobby floor and name-brand fixtures described in the prospectus. ''We were the architects and did plans detailing what was to be done top to bottom,'' Mr. Lombardi said yesterday. ''I did not have the authority to enact or direct that work.''

description: David L. Kahn, the associate publisher of The New Yorker, was named publisher of the magazine yesterday, said Steve T. Florio, the chief executive of Conde Nast, a subsidiary of Advance Publications.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  PHILLIPS, CATHERINE
description: PHILLIPS-Catherine. With profound sadness and grief, the Phillip's family deeply mourns the loss of Catherine Phillips, cherished wife and life-long beloved mate of Perry Phillips. Adored, loving, beloved mother and closest friend of daughter Christine Phillips and son Wesley Poriotis. Loyal, loving sister of Clara, and deeply loved full sister of daughter-in-law of Barbara Poriotis. With utmost devotion and intense care she leaves her brother-in-law Chris and his family Guy, Sheila and Brett. Always embracive, warm, kind, generous of spirit, giving, supremely sensitive and supportive of the needs of others, Catherine provided a soothing, safe, open and non-judgemental, healing presence to her family and friends. Regal in bearing, she was democratic in principle, always on the side of those hurt and less fortunate. An aficionado of the Mets and the Cleveland Indians, this rare artist and landscape painter reflected a sensitivity on canvas only matched by the giving spirit with which she nurtured those in need throughout her life. She will be always in our hearts, an active, life-giving force and presence in our memories forever with us. Services will be held at St. Nicholas Greek Orthodox Church, 196-10 Northern Blvd., Flushing, NY, 10:00 AM on Saturday, January 20, 2001.

title: Prizes of Old, From Europe and Asia but Above All America

title: Recalling the Eradication of a 20th-Century Scourge

The story has been told before, most recently in Nina Gilden Seavey's 1998 film ''A Paralyzing Fear,'' but for Americans born after the late 1950's, when vaccines developed by Jonas Salk and Albert Sabin wiped out the illness in the United States, this new film offers a fascinating lesson in medical and social history.

title: Turning New York Yoga on Its Head
description: Yoga is the newest -- and oldest -- trend around. With new yoga centers opening up in New York City faster than you can inhale; a mainstream advertisement featuring a woman in lotus pose, meditating in her high-speed train seat; and publications like The Wall Street Journal and The New Yorker talking about the phenomenon, yoga is, in some ways, the aerobics of the new millennium. But yoga has a lot more staying power than a step bench. In addition to its being a 5,000-year old tradition, yoga is a way of life -- not just an hour set aside for pumping up your heart rate, gaining muscle mass and burning off calories and cellulite. Yoga offers all those benefits, but best of all, it helps you calm your mind, which is more difficult to do than even the most challenging handstand.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINDLER, ELEANOR
description: STEINDLER - Eleanor. Flutist professionally known as Eleanor Lawrence. Died on January 16, 2001, age 64, of brain cancer. Played with American Symphony, New York Philharmonic, Brooklyn Phiharmonic, Metropolitan Opera Orchestra. Founder and Artistic Director of Monomoy Chamber Ensemble in Chatham, MA. Completed two seasons of Monomoy Music in New York City. Also toured as chamber player and soloist. Born Boston, MA., raised Athens, Ohio, B.A. Radcliffe College, M.A. New England Conservatory of Music. Faculty member Manhattan School of Music, participant Marlboro (VT.) Music Festival. Recordings for Musical Heritage label include complete Hindemith Flute Works, Works for Flute by Dohnanyi. Three term President New York Flute Club, longtime Editor Flutist Quarterly. She is mourned by her husband, Frank Steindler, her children, Catherine and Frederick, and her sisters, Elizabeth and Anne Baker. Memorial service Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West 73 Street, NYC Tuesday, January 23rd, 11 A.M.

Even when the movies themselves have been lackluster, Ms. Blanchett's performances have been vivid with submerged feeling. She doesn't so much embody her characters as haunt them, registering unspoken and unconscious hurt in the hollows of her face and her watchful blue eyes.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DEUTSCH, MADELINE MADY
description: DEUTSCH-Madeline Mady, age 70, died Wednesday in Houston after a courageous nine year battle with cancer. She was born April 29, 1930 in Beregszasz, Czechoslovakia. Although she lost her father and brother during the Holocaust, she and her mother survived imprisonment in two concentration camps and endured four years in a Displaced Persons camp before finally being allowed to immigrate to the United States in 1949. Deutsch is survived by her loving husband Tony and adoring sons Mark of New York City and Robert of Germantown, Maryland. She was loved by many and will be sincerely missed.

title: Compelling Landscapes Just a Few Inches Away
description: Landscape is a telescopic word. For centuries it meant a big view: ambitious mountains or lazy hills, sand dunes cleverly arranged by wind, a phalanx of trees marching sturdily into the distance. More recently landscape has also meant little views, snippets and details, at least when applied to images. If you venture into the woods and bend close enough to a rock and its clinging lichen to see nothing else, you do not exclaim, ''What a lovely landscape!'' But what else can you call a picture of a rock, a hummock, a few leaves hung out before a blank sky as if to dry? A photograph that narrows in on such details is a landscape by default.

title: RETRENCHMENT AT CMGI
description: CMGI, the once-highflying Internet investment and holding company, told investors yesterday that it would not be able to meet its revenue and cash-use targets for the balance of its fiscal year ending July 31, as many of its units continue to restructure and lay off employees. Yesterday, its Alta Vista search engine for the World Wide Web eliminated 200 jobs, 25 percent of its staff. It cut 225 jobs in September. CMGI also said it would close ExchangePath, an Internet payments company. On Wednesday, Engage, CMGI's Internet advertising unit, said it no longer expected to break even in its fourth quarter. Engage is cutting 550 jobs, half its work force. CMGI suspended its forecasts of annual revenue of $1.65 billion and a 30 percent profit margin. For the current quarter, which ends Jan. 31, the company expects revenue of $335 million to $345 million. That would be the second consecutive decrease in revenue. The company said it expected to use up $300 million to $400 million of its $1 billion in cash and securities by July 31. Saul Hansell (NYT)

title: Why I Do Yoga
description: Once upon a time, when the weight of yet another personal soap opera was dragging me down, I ventured  on a whim -- to a yoga class at New York Sports Club. I carefully followed the teacher's lead throughout class and suddenly, found myself standing on my head. If someone had told me in advance that my life (not to mention my body) would be turned upside-down by the experience, I wouldnt have believed her. I felt like the bumblebee that flies simply because it doesn't know that, aerodynamically, it shouldn't be able to. Even better, upon leaving the class, I noticed that my emotional drama had not sucked up a single molecule of thought during the hour-long session. Not only did my body feel refreshed, my mind did too. Needless to say, I was hooked. I attended three more classes that same week, have been doing yoga roughly four times a week ever since, and am just about to finish a yoga-teacher training course.

title: The New York Times: Five Years on the Web
description: Five years ago The New York Times announced its arrival on the Internet. "Our site is designed to take full advantage of the evolving capabilities offered by the Internet. At the same time, we see our role on the Web as being similar to our traditional, print role -- to act as a thoughtful, unbiased filter and to provide to our customers information they need and can trust," said Arthur Sulzberger, Jr., publisher of The New York Times. The site looks quite a bit different than it did in five years ago, but its aspirations are largely the same: to be the best news and information site on the Internet. With that in mind, Bernard Gwertzman, editor of The New York Times on the Web, and Martin Nisenholtz, chief executive officer of New York Times Digital, sat down to discuss their five years on the Web, the state of Internet journalism today, and what we can expect in years to come. The discussion was moderated by Bill Goldstein, the Books Editor of NYTimes.com. BILL GOLDSTEIN: Martin, I was hoping that you could tell us a little bit about how you came to be at The New York Times On The Web and what you and Arthur Sulzberger were planning, really, when you came here, what company you were envisioning. MARTIN NISENHOLTZ: Okay. Those are really two separate questions. I had spent my career as a practitioner in this nascent field of interactive media. I was a research scientist at New York University in the late 70s, working on some of the very earliest experiments in consumer online media. They were called teletext and videotext services. And the first wave of this stuff happened in the early 80s. And I moved from NYU to the advertising firm Ogilvy and Mather in 1982 because I felt that one of the very important things that needed to happen for this to become a real business was for the marketing community to embrace it and to somehow make it financially viable, and I thought that if that was going to happen anywhere, it would happen as part of a major advertising agency. So, in 1983, we started the first interactive marketing firm in the United States, called the Interactive Marketing Group at Ogilvy, and I spent 11 years doing that.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STAVE, BERNARD R.
description: STAVE-Bernard R. On January 19, at 96. Attorney for over 72 years in New York City. Graduate of Brooklyn Law School, in private practice for most of his life and on the legal staff of the New York State Banking Department in the 1940's. New York Secretary to Congressman Emanuel Celler, longtime Arbitrator in the Small Claims Court, former president of the Apex Society, Board Member, President and then longtime General Counsel of his beloved Southbridge Towers Housing Cooperative. For over 20 years he devoted himself tirelessly to the 1800 cooperators of Southbridge. The law was his passion and he served his clients with dignity, care and dedication. His pride and affection for his family were known to all with whom he came in contact. He was predeceased by wives Millie and Dinny. He leaves his longtime friend Tessie Wigler, two sons Howard and wife Renee and Bruce and wife Sondra, grandchildren Gregg and Chris, Marjorie and Allahyar, Channing and Sara, and three great grandchildren Elise, Yasmin and Soraya. Graveside services at New Montefiore Cemetery, Pinelawn, NY on Sunday, January 21, at 1:00 P.M. title: Saucy Puppets Serve Up a Renaissance Art Lesson
description: The giant housefly (about the size of a golden retriever) with its red light-bulb eyes is unexpectedly lovable. So is the walking life-size Leonardo da Vinci robotic puppet, which bears a strange resemblance to the hospitable but lethal robot in ''Logan's Run,'' the 70's science-fiction movie. Then there's the eerie, blobby, pinkish, larger-than-human creature that is inflated as the words of the Florentine artist Giorgio Vasari are read. At first it looks a little like the star baby in ''2001: A Space Odyssey,'' but by the time the thing is fully standing, towering over its puppeteers, you half expect it to put on a diaper, head over to Ally McBeal's apartment and dance all night in her bedroom.

title: Concentration Can Have Its Rewards

''It is this experience which generates the music ideas -- and not the other way around.'' This emphasis on the gut over the mind has had a deeply positive effect on his music, which he and a stellar ensemble performed Thursday and yesterday at Tonic.

title: POTASH, A FERTILIZER MAKER, ANNOUNCES SOME CUTBACKS
description: The Potash Corporation, the largest fertilizer maker, said yesterday that it had suspended most production at a plant in White Springs, Fla.; furloughed 300 workers indefinitely; and dismissed about 75 workers to cope with declining prices and demand for products used by corn and wheat farmers. The company said it would also close a factory in Davenport, Iowa, that makes animal-feed supplements, and would shift production to plants in Nebraska and Illinois, resulting in elimination of 27 more jobs. Potash, based in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan, said it would take a pretax charge of $24.3 million related to the two moves.

title: LUCENT TO SEEK BUYERS FOR TWO FACTORIES
description: Lucent Technologies said yesterday that it planned to seek buyers for two of its four remaining factories in the United States in the next six months and to cut costs by contracting out manufacturing. The plants to be sold, in Oklahoma City and Columbus, Ohio, together have 8,400 employees making telephone switches and wireless equipment. Lucent said it could not say if jobs would be eliminated in a sale. Lucent, which since April has spun off one unit, sold another and is preparing to spin off a third, has been slower to shed manufacturing operations than some of its rivals have. The company has said it will discuss a plan to cut $1 billion a year in costs when it reports earnings Wednesday.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOFFMAN, MENDL
description: HOFFMAN-Mendl. The YIVO Institute for Jewish Research mourns the passing of our distinguished emeritus trustee, Mendl Hoffman, visionary businessman, ardent supporter of Yiddish language and culture, who served on the YIVO Board for more than two decades. His connection with YIVO dates to 1945, when as a teenage Holocaust survivor, he helped identify looted YIVO library books (shipped by the Nazis to a warehouse near Frankfurt am Main). In 1947 these books were repatriated to YIVO in New York. He became a volunteer cataloger of these books, and then a Board member. His unique contributions to YIVO will be sorely missed. May his memory be for a blessing. Bruce Slovin, Chairman Dr. Carl J. Rheins, Executive Director

title: RESISTANCE TO SCHNEIDER BID
description: Holders of preferred stock of Legrand S.A. complained that the bid by Schneider Electric S.A. to acquire Legrand valued their shares unfairly, and said they would ask regulators to block the deal. When Schneider agreed to buy Legrand on Monday for about 6 billion euros ($5.61 billion), it offered to pay about 43 percent less for each preferred share than it did for each common share. Legrand preferred shares, which have no voting rights but pay a larger dividend than common shares, usually trade at a 45 percent discount to the common stock, but preferred shareholders said that smaller discounts were used in other recent mergers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEILSHORN, JOHN W. ''JACK.''
description: HEILSHORN-John W. ''Jack.'' Of Litchfield, CT, age 75, died January 18, 2001, from complications of diabetes. He was an Executive Vice Presient with Travelers Corporation of Hartford, CT, from 1985 to 1988, when he retired from a 39 year career in the financial services industry. Prior to that, Mr. Heilshorn was an Executive Vice President at Citibank N.A., NY, NY, from 1960 to 1985. From 1949 to 1960, Mr. Heilshorn served as Chairman of Corporate Strategy and Development as well as Group Head of Investment Management and Domestic Consumer Groups with the New York Trust Company. Among his many charitable pursuits he was Chairman of the Salvation Army's Greater New York Advisory Board from 1981 to 1985, as well as serving on the Executive Committee of the Private Sector Survey on the Cost Control (Grace Commission) from 1982 to 1985. Mr. Heilshorn was also a Chairman of the Forman School Board of Trustees in Litchfield, CT. Born December 28, 1926, in Floral Park, Queens, Heilshorn attended New York University Graduate School of Business Administration from 1950 to 1955. He also attended Rutgers University from 1954 to 1955. Mr. Heilshorn graduated from the United States Merchant Marine Academy with a bachelor of science degree in 1947 and served in the U.S. Navy from 1947 through 1949. He is survived by Helen, his wife of 48 years. Daughters Janet Lynne Cohen of Cherry Hill, NJ, Carol Lee Ebersol of Cornwall, CT, and sons John William Jr., of New York, NY, and the Reverend Mark Lang of Woodbury, CT, ten grandchildren and a sister Muriel Kilbirde of New Canaan, CT. Memorial service will be held at the Litchfield Congregational Church in Litchfield, CT, on January 22, 2001, at 1 PM. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to The Islet Gene Fund, attention: Gordon Weir, Joslin Clinic, Boston, Massachusetts 02215.

title: Ms. Norton Takes the Edge Off
description: It will be interesting to see what kind of interior secretary Gale Norton turns out to be. Given her right-wing political pedigree, Democrats, moderate Republicans and environmentalists had every reason to fear that George W. Bush was handing them another James Watt, Ronald Reagan's disastrous interior secretary and one of Ms. Norton's early mentors. Yet at her confirmation hearings this week Ms. Norton smoothly presented herself as a naturalist and conservationist, redefining some of her earlier positions and softening others. Regrettably, she did not budge from her commitment to help Mr. Bush open up the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge for oil exploration. But her basic message was that she would serve all Americans, and not just the property-rights crowd that has been assiduously promoting her cause.

title: Corrections
description: A report by Agence France-Presse in the World Briefing column in some copies on Wednesday about an investigation in Peru involving Lori Berenson, an American imprisoned there, misidentified the official who acted in the case and misstated its legal disposition. The prosecutor, Maria Peralta, recommended that Ms. Berenson be charged as a collaborator with the Tupac Amaru rebel group rather than as a senior figure in it. The judge, Julian Jeri, did not issue a finding that she was a collaborator and did not close his review of the case. The report also misstated the deadline for setting a date for Ms. Berenson to give oral testimony in a civilian court or for the case to be dismissed. It is 3 days after a senior prosecutor receives the recommendation, not 30 days. The report also referred incorrectly to what the Peruvian government said in 1995 was a planned rebel attack on Congress. The authorities say they thwarted the attack before it occurred; the rebels did not mount an attack that failed.

title: The New York Times: Five Years on the Web
description: Five years ago, The New York Times announced its arrival on the Internet. "Our site is designed to take full advantage of the evolving capabilities offered by the Internet. At the same time, we see our role on the Web as being similar to our traditional, print role -- to act as a thoughtful, unbiased filter and to provide to our customers information they need and can trust," said Arthur Sulzberger, Jr., publisher of The New York Times. The site looks quite a bit different than it did in five years ago, but its aspirations are largely the same: to be the best news and information site on the Internet. With that in mind, Bernard Gwertzman, editor of The New York Times on the Web, and Martin Nisenholtz, chief executive officer of New York Times Digital, sat down to discuss their five years on the Web, the state of Internet journalism today, and what we can expect in years to come. The discussion was moderated by Bill Goldstein, the Books Editor of NYTimes.com.

title: The Rural Life; What the Potatoes Know
description: Last year, it rained all summer. Most of the garden languished, but not the potatoes, which love water. I hilled them twice with compost and by late August each of the potato beds was a tangle of vegetative sprawl, a mass of deeply dissected leaves and contorted stems. No harvest is quite as satisfying as a good potato harvest. The tubers always come as a surprise, patroon-like and globular in their tight jackets. The vines make a satisfying heap, and when harvest is over the ground is suddenly bare and freshly dug, open to almost anything next spring except tomatoes or more potatoes, which might pick up diseases from last year's crop. When I carried the baskets to the house I tried to guess their weight, but the only measure that came to mind was a ton.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction; A Better Orchestra
description: CROOKED RIVER BURNING (Harcourt, $27), Mark Winegardner's bulky yet brilliant new novel, has a familiar plot: West Side guy from union family falls for rich East Side girl whose father is a political boss. The guy, David Zielinsky, dreams of being mayor; the girl, Anne O'Connor, yearns to be a war correspondent. The book follows their sometimes intertwining paths from the late 1940's through the late 60's. What gives the book its edge is its setting: Cleveland. Winegardner weaves the love story through the fabric of a tumultuous era in which Cleveland, one of the birthplaces of rock 'n' roll, slides substantially in population, becomes the butt of many jokes and sees the Cuyahoga River catch fire more than once. The book is peppered with well-known figures, from Eliot Ness to Dr. Sam Sheppard. Winegardner's portraits, for instance, of the legendary disc jockey Alan Freed and of Dorothy Fuldheim, a television commentator who worked into her 90's, are classics. No surprise that Winegardner, who wrote the much-praised baseball novel ''The Veracruz Blues'' (1996), includes a healthy dose of Cleveland Indians action. (Any Indians fan will cringe at his description of Willie Mays's famous catch in the 1954 World Series.) As we follow the adventures of David and Anne, we learn about a gritty, rich and misjudged city. ''What's the difference between Cleveland and the Titanic?'' asked one of the jokes told after the Cuyahoga burned in 1969. ''Cleveland has a better orchestra.'' And, as Winegardner's book shows, so much more. Peter Khoury

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ROZBRUCH, MAX
description: ROZBRUCH-Max. Died on the Sabbath of January 20, 2001, on his 83rd birthday; courageous at death as in life. Beloved and caring husband and best friend of Frieda, his wife of 55 years. Loving, devoted and revered father of Jacob, Alfie and Sandy. Adoring father-in-law to his girls Marsha, Hedy and Yonina. Generous and doting grandfather to Alison, Joshua, Andrew, Jenny, Jason and Libby. Beloved and caring ''big brother'' of the late Martin Rozbruch and Mario Brandt. Born in a small village near Lublin, Poland, the Holocaust separated him by death from his parents and baby sister. He survived the war by evading the Nazis and lived underground in bunkers for four years until the liberation. Throughout this ordeal he saved his three young cousins in the bunkers with him. After the liberation he met his beloved Frieda. They traveled to Italy where they settled and began their beautiful life together. The family came to America in 1953 and began a new life. Max trained himself in his new professiona as a kosher butcher. Through selfless hard work and devotion he supported his wife and three sons. His own education cut short by the war, he nurtured and supported his three sons and saw them all become successful professionals. He delighted in the accomplishments of all of his grandchildren. A sweet, gentle, humble and pious man, a ''prince of a man,'' he brought unlimited love, joy and comfort to all of us who knew and loved him. God's speed on your journey Mordechai Aryeh Ben Shimshon Dovid.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ESPOSITO, MARIO J., HONORABLE
description: ESPOSITO-Mario J., Honorable. The officers, directors and staff of the American Parkinson Disease Association, Inc. (APDA) mourn the passing of the Honorable Mario J. Esposito on January 17, 2001. For much of his adult life, Mr. Esposito worked tirelessly and without recompense to find a cure for Parkinson's disease. Prior to his presidency of the APDA from 1988 to 1994, he was Sr. Vice President of the organization for 23 years. He was responsible, in part, for making the APDA the only grassroots Parkinson organization in the United States, a vision he shared with his entire family. The Hon. Mario J. Esposito served as County Clerk of Richmond, Staten Island, Clerk of the Supreme Court, Commissioner of Jurors and Registrar for Richmond County. A prominent Roman Catholic layman, Mr. Esposito was a member of the Association of Master Knights of the Sovereign Military Order of Malta and the Association of Knights and Ladies of the Equestrian Order of the Holy Sepulchre of Jerusalem. We extend our deepest sympathy to his wife Jean, two sons, Mario J. Jr. and Michael; his sister Sophia Maestrone; his brother Salvatore and the entire Esposito family. John Pillarella, President Joel Gerstel, Exec. Director

title: Provence Legacy
description: To the Editor: Regarding ''A Haunting Legacy in Provence,'' the religious rite used in Avignon, Carpentras, Cavaillon, Aix-en-Provence and a few other Provence communities until the eve of World War II was the last remnant of the old French and Provencal rite practiced by Jews. These once-flourishing French communities produced scholars like the Torah commentator Rashi and others. The particular liturgy was long handed down in manuscript form from father to son, except for two editions printed in Amsterdam about 1740. Such manuscripts are collected by specialists; more general information on the liturgy is found in the Encyclopedia Judaica. Most of the Jewish population today consists of postwar North African immigrants.

title: Lives; The Woman in the Mirror
description: When I was 11, I found out I had a brain tumor. I had surgery to remove it, but the size and location of the tumor caused my optic nerve to atrophy. For three years afterward, I had partial sight, but my ophthalmologist told me that eventually I would go blind. At the end of my 14th year, doctors pronounced me legally blind and said there was nothing that could be done. I had a 5 percent chance of surviving the tumor, and I did, but somehow I could never deal with the fact that I was going blind. I tried to behave as if everything were just fine. When it happened, I was devastated.

title: Reality of Nation's Divisions Quickly Creeps Into the Commentary

Four hundred years after his mysterious, violent death cut short a brilliant career, Christopher Marlowe -- playwright, poet, spy and (some hold) radical atheist and homosexual -- is on the cultural fast track.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  STEINDLER, ELEANOR
description: STEINDLER - Eleanor. Flutist professionally known as Eleanor Lawrence. Died on January 16, 2001, age 64, of brain cancer. Played with American Symphony, New York Philharmonic, Brooklyn Phiharmonic, Metropolitan Opera Orchestra. Founder and Artistic Director of Monomoy Chamber Ensemble in Chatham, MA. Completed two seasons of Monomoy Music in New York City. Also toured as chamber player and soloist. Born Boston, MA., raised Athens, Ohio, B.A. Radcliffe College, M.A. New England Conservatory of Music. Faculty member Manhattan School of Music, participant Marlboro (VT.) Music Festival. Recordings for Musical Heritage label include complete Hindemith Flute Works, Works for Flute by Dohnanyi. Three term President New York Flute Club, longtime Editor Flutist Quarterly. She is mourned by her husband, Frank Steindler, her children, Catherine and Frederick, and her sisters, Elizabeth and Anne Baker. Memorial service Rutgers Presbyterian Church, 236 West 73 Street, NYC Tuesday, January 23rd, 11 A.M.

description: MY first encounter with the Corbin Sparrow, a half-pint electric car as rare as a Cape May warbler and just as hard to spot, came while visiting friends in Menlo Park, Calif., last summer.

title: NEW USERS FOR OLD COMPUTERS
description: Westchester has about 400 unneeded computers that it wants to give to nonprofit agencies, as allowed for under a new county law. The equipment includes IBM-compatible computers, low-end Pentium processors and assorted peripherals. The giveaway is an extension of the Westchester Access Program, which helps match businesses looking to get rid of old computer equipment with nonprofit organizations. To learn more, go to http://www.westchestergov.com/westchesteraccess on the Web. Elsa Brenner

title: An Independent Woman
description: I first see Liv Ullmann standing in the door of her New York apartment, and for a moment I am struck by a quality of almost tangible luminescence, an aura that transcends her iconic status as the muse of a great and melancholy director -- the village genius from Sweden,'' as Ingmar Bergman once described himself. Days later, I find myself trying to figure out her singular physical effect, the way it caught me off guard, as though flesh-and-blood reality had, just this once, outdone the mythologized screen image. Perhaps it had something to do with simple atmospherics, the stage setting of a gray December afternoon against which Ullmann stood out with a particular vividness. Or perhaps it was that she was taller and slimmer than I had expected, more regal -- still recognizably the figure of mesmerizing allure who graced ''The Passion of Anna'' and ''Cries and Whispers.''

title: Buddy for Life
description: As an expatriate Rhode Islander and former Providence resident, I found your article entertaining but short on context. To understand Buddy Cianci, you must know what came before him. Providence was once the great sinkhole of New England. Entrenched party hacks lined their cronies' pockets while accelerating the city's swift slide into urban decay and suburban flight. Then Buddy stepped off the bus (literally, in a TV ad from his first campaign) and stopped the madness.

title: The Last Stand Against the Taliban
description: The counterattack is carried out under cover of darkness, two groups of turbaned mujaheddin crawling up a steep slope to retake a mountain post lost the previous day to their Taliban foes. A confused melee of automatic-rifle and rocket fire ensues, lasting until the early hours of the morning, when the dawn reveals a small victory: seven dead Talibs sprawled on the barren soil, bodies twisted in the graceless posture of battlefield death. Mules ascend the narrow tracks to bring fresh ammunition to the fighters, while a pony carries down the mujaheddin's only casualty -- a fighter who stepped on a mine in the firefight.

description: OSTROW-Alice. Of Newton, MA, January 4, (Scardino). Beloved wife of the late Pierson Ostrow. Loving mother of Dani Danzig of Newton. Sister of Marge Dauber of Elkins Park, PA., and grandmother of Jake Carpenter and Jessie Danzig. Memorial Services will be held on Saturday January 27th at 3 PM at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th St. Donations to continue to Mrs. Ostrow's social action work may be made to the Alice Ostrow Memorial Fund C/O Dani Danzig, 37 Mountfort Rd., Newton, MA 02461. Late longtime union supporter and fair housing activist.

description: READ-David Haxton Carswell, D.D. Read is mourned by the members, friends, officers and staff of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, who extend their deepest sympathies to David's wife Pat Gilbert-Read and their son Rory. A memorial service of Witness to the Resurrection and Thanksgiving for His Life and Ministry will be held Tuesday afternoon, January 23, at 5:00 PM in the Church Sanctuary located at Madison Avenue and 73rd Street, New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the David H.C. Read Preacher/Scholar Fund or the David H.C. Read Memorial Chapel Fund, both of Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, 921 Madison Avenue, NYC 10021.

title: Food; You Elegant Fowl
description: The style was one of gracefulness and ease. Our Greatest Generation had won the war and after checking out Europe decided that we Americans needed to be more European. Grown-ups admired the effortlessness of Joe DiMaggio and Fred Astaire, which disguised their immense effort, and the unruffled smoothness of James Bond (at least until Sean Connery stopped playing him). At the Oscars, actors often wore white tie and tails and went on to witty parties where they dined on pheasant under glass. The era of braggadocio, self-promotion and urgent confessionalism from sports heroes, rock stars, presidential candidates and the Oprah hadn't yet smothered us. Modesty and privacy were virtues, class distinction flourished and not being seen to sweat was the social ideal.

title: The Dogs Are Out
description: To the Editor: I was amused by reponses to ''Who Let the Dogs Out? Europeans!'' (Nov. 26). My encounter with this phenomenon occurred some years ago in Nice while looking for a hotel. On entering one, a large dog pounced and knocked me down, knocking my glasses off and badly spraining my elbow. When the owner emerged, I was visibly upset, explaining (in French) that I was just looking for the entrance. Her reply? ''Ca suffit!'' (''That's enough!'') as she turned to comfort the dog! I stayed elsewhere.

The list included two Nassau County companies: OSI Pharmaceuticals Inc. and Aeroflex Inc. OSI's stock had soared ninefold, Aeroflex's nearly sixfold.

title: Stairways to Heaven
description: WHAT is the most frequently used form of public transportation in New York City? If you're thinking subway, bus or taxi, think again. It's the elevator. Every day, several times a day, millions of New Yorkers step into elevator cabs for quick vertical rides in buildings which, it should be pointed out, owe their very existence to elevators. (No elevator, no high-rise.)

title: The World; Russia's Latest Dictator Goes By the Name of Law
description: OF the torrent of words unleashed in the last decade to describe Russia's experiment in self-government, maybe none are more revealing than the ones President Vladimir V. Putin uttered last year as he assured Russians that their democratic future was secure. The days of strongman rule are over, he said; in the new Russia, there will be only one dictatorship: a ''dictatorship of the law.''

title: S. F. Yolles, 81, Nation's Top Mental Health Official in 60's
description: Dr. Stanley F. Yolles, who as the nation's top official on mental health in the 1960's denounced what he saw as ''stupid, punitive laws'' on drug use and was eventually forced out by the Nixon administration, died on Jan. 12 at University Hospital in Stony Brook, N.Y. He was 81 and lived in Stony Brook.

No longer will this be a mostly dot-com world, and many companies, not wanting anyone else to use their names online, want to make sure they control their identities, no matter what three letters come after the dot.

Surely, such accessible jazz enlarges the entire audience rather than takes sales away from the more avant-garde singers that your writer seems to favor.

title: Ragtime: No Longer A Novelty In Sepia
description: RAGTIME is a whole world of music that has grown strange to us. Sure, everyone knows Scott Joplin and the cheerful strains of ''The Entertainer'' from the movie ''The Sting'' -- at least, everyone who remembers the 1970's, when the music enjoyed its strongest revival (there was another around 1950). But the popular image of ragtime today is largely that of a jaunty, sweetly tinkling piano soundtrack to a sepia-tinted world of shirtwaists and bowler hats.

title: The Pop Singer
description: A backless floor-length gown of copper Swarovski crystals, handmade beaded earrings and streams of feathers in the hair made up the outfit chosen by Jana, a Native American singer, for her inaugural ball performance last night. The ensemble illustrates her fashion m.o. of ''blending my 200-year-old Lumbee culture with the modern world,'' said Jana, 23. A week earlier, at the Pantene Pro Voice music competition party at the Supper Club, left, Jana, whose single ''More Than Life'' is in heavy rotation on pop and dance radio stations across the country, described her look as ''natural and earthy but over the top.'' She was decidedly earthy in caramel-color ostrich boots from Steve Madden, faded jeans, a clingy snakeskin-pattern top by Andasimo, who designs for Manhattan's Intermix boutiques, and a belted bronze sweater by Guess? Onstage, she said, ''I wear feathers, suedes and beads, mostly in red, blue and yellow, the traditional colors worn by tribal dancers.'' Jana's dancers reinforce her sartorial messages with red war paint and platinum blond wigs. JENNIFER TUNG

title: Hot Actor of the Moment Can Also Play It Cool
description: WITH my character in 'Traffic,' I knew where I was coming from, what I wanted and where I was going,'' says Benicio Del Toro, describing the role that has earned him a New York Film Critics Circle award and a Golden Globe nomination and has made him a strong Oscar contender for best supporting actor. ''When you know that, man, it's not easier to play, but it's clear. All you got to do is just be.'' He cracks a smile and nods toward the pizza that's been cooling on our table for the past few minutes. ''Now let's try this guy,'' he says with glee as he reaches for a slice.

title: For Burns's Birthday, Paying the Piper and Renting a Kilt
description: The birthday of Scotland's national hero and poet Robert Burns is on Thursday. It is traditionally celebrated at dinners where his poetry is read and where bagpipers pipe in the haggis, the Scottish pudding made of organ meats. The Pipers Cove is a store in Kearny that rents out bagpipers and kilts. John (Jock) Nisbet, a bagpiper himself, and his wife, Joan, own the Pipers Cove and, in the same building, the Argyle Restaurant, where Burns's Birthday is being celebrated nightly through next Saturday. Mr. Nisbet recently talked about the bagpipe business.

title: Malcolm Watkins, 89, Collector of Artifacts From Early America
description: C. Malcolm Watkins, a museum curator and collector of everyday objects who believed that American culture could be distilled in an earthenware teacup, died on Jan. 12 in Leesburg, Va. He was 89 and lived in Reston, Va.

title: A Vision of Unity
description: On a cold, drizzly Saturday in Washington, the nation's most reassuring public ritual played out once again, as George W. Bush embraced the presidency with an alliterative promise to lead the nation with ''civility, courage, compassion and character.'' Like many new chief executives before him, Mr. Bush carefully chose language that summed up his campaign message, forecast his future direction and drew a contrast with the previous administration.

description: FOR Americans who wonder about their responsibilities in Africa now that Laurent Kabila has met his end in Congo, the most instructive lesson may be how Americans acted when he first emerged on the scene in the mid-1990's.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, REV. JOHN H. III.
description: MILLER-Rev. John H. III. On January 18, 2001. Of Little Compton, RI. Son of the late John H. Miller, II and Harriet (Crane) Miller of Rumson, NJ. Devoted husband of Lora Elkinton Miller, loving father of Hope, Rhoads, and Edward Miller, brother of Talbott and David Miller. He served his country in the U.S. Army, ranger qualified 1966-1969. Avid sailor and skier, John was a humble man, who always put his family, friends and ministry first. He was the Protestant Chaplain for the State of Rhode Island Department of Corrections. Graduate of Marvelwood School, Defiance College and The School for Deacons of the Episcopal Diocese of R.I. Ordained Deacon on March 28, 1992, John was at the time of his death completing his studies for a Masters Degree in Spirituality at The General Theological Seminary. John's memory will live on through the many people he helped during his life. He will be greatly missed. Memorial Service Tuesday, January 23rd, 12 noon at Cathedral of St. John, 271 North Main Street, Providence, RI 02903. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the John H. Miller Foundation-General Delivery, Little Compton, RI 02837.

description: I read Hajdu's article with a familiar sadness. The music industry has long asked new artists ''who'' they sound like, instead of the more interesting ''what'' they sound like. The industry is in the business of selling recordings and in almost every instance can be counted on to avoid risks and to shun the new. It is a sad twist of fate that many of the jazz icons who will be properly celebrated in Ken Burns's film were unable to make a living playing their music in the United States and had to travel to Europe and Asia to find audiences receptive to their search for free musical expression.

description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson said he would drop out of the public spotlight for a while after acknowledging that he had fathered a child out of wedlock with an employee in his civil rights organization, the Rainbow/PUSH Coalition. He apologized in a statement after he learned that The National Enquirer was about to publish an article about his extramarital affair. Pam Belluck

title: January 14-20; Boy Guerrillas Surrender
description: It was an image both disturbing and slightly absurd: the front-page photograph, early last year, of a cigar-puffing 12-year-old Burmese rebel leader sitting on an adult follower's lap. And the tale was stranger still. The boy, Luther Htoo, and his twin brother, Johnny, pint-sized commanders of a guerrilla army linked to a suicidal raid on a hospital on the Thai border, were said to be reincarnations of past warriors and to possess supernatural powers -- like making bullets bounce off them. But the miracles seem to have worn thin, for after months on the run, the boys, along with 14 followers, surrendered to Thai authorities. Hubert B. Herring

title: Airbus Flying Biggest, Boeing Flying Farthest
description: AVIATION is full of superlatives, like the fastest, highest or most luxurious, and last month Airbus went for biggest, with its 656-seat A-380. But the company that has dominated big planes for 40 years, Boeing, is now pushing the envelope in a different direction, and approaching a truly epic milestone with the newest versions of the 777, which will be able to fly nonstop almost halfway round the world.

title: The Way We Live Now: 1-21-01; Abstinence Minded
description: It must amaze teenagers that sex education can generate such political firestorms, given how dull it usually is. At my public high school, we took it somewhat less seriously than shop and typing; in shop, at least I learned how to use a C-clamp, but despite the relative candor of our sex-ed curriculum, I can't remember anything useful, much less sexually inspiring, that came out of it. Mostly I remember a film depicting Michelangelo's David, first in his normal state of grace, then suddenly, as the camera zoomed in, very much aroused. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOOMER, DR. WILLIAM ERNEST
description: BLOOMER-Dr. William Ernest, (1916-2001), 84, of Pasadena, California, died Sunday January 14, at Long Beach Memorial Medical Center. His ten-year battle with cancer ended with his wife and children by his side. Dr. Bloomer was born in Denver Colorado, December 20, 1916, son of the late Charles and Winifred Bloomer. After moving to California, he graduated from Beverly Hills High School in 1934, and received his Bachelor of Science degree from Stanford University in 1938. He received his M.D. from Yale University School of Medicine in 1942, and completed his internship in surgical service at Stanford University Hospital in San Francisco in June of 1943. Serving in the United States Army Medical Corps from 1944 to 1946, he was stationed in Texas, England, and finally at Letterman Hospital in San Francisco, California. After the war, he returned to Yale University School of Medicine as a Fellow in Thoracic Surgery, and completed his residency in general and thoracic surgery at Yale New Haven Hospital. He was certified by the American Board of Surgery in 1952, and the Board of Thoracic Surgery in 1956. Following a fiveyear period as Assistant Professor in Surgery at Yale, Dr. Bloomer moved to California in 1959, enthusiastically embarking upon his lifelong career in thoracic and cardiovascular surgery. He joined Drs. Jerome H. Kay and Robert M. Anderson in private practice at St. Vincent's Hospital in Los Angeles. He was a Clinical Assistant Professor in Surgery at University of Southern California from 1959 to 1961. It was at this time that he published his most important work, ''Surgical Anatomy of the Bronchovascular Segment,'' coauthored by Drs. Averill A. Liebow and Milton R. Hales, which demonstrated his innovative techniques for using injection-molded plastics to study the anatomy of the lung. In 1960, Dr. Bloomer joined Dr. Robert M. Anderson in thoracic and cardiovascular surgery at the Hospital of the Good Samaritan in Los Angeles. From 1961 through 1967, he was the Chief of Thoracic and Cardiovascular Surgery at Los Angeles County Harbor General Hospital. He became an Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery at UCLA School of Medicine in 1961, holding that position until his death. In 1966, he joined Drs. Jerome A. Cope and Arthur J. Beland in Long Beach. He began his solo practice in 1969, based primarily out of Long Beach Memorial Medical Center. Dr. Bloomer was a member of numerous medical and surgical societies, to include locally, the Los Angeles and Long Beach Surgical Societies, regionally, the New England Surgical Society and Western Thoracic Surgical Association, and nationally, the American College of Surgeons, the Society of University Surgeons, the American Association for Thoracic Surgery, the Society of Thoracic Surgeons, the Society for Vascular Surgery, the International Society for Cardiovascular Surgery, and Sigma Xi. He is survived by his wife, Cornelia (Lee), his daughter Lianne Nall, his three sons Will, Robert and Charlie, and five grandchildren. A memorial service will be held in Long Beach California, at a time to be announced.

Levels can also be used to indicate whether a vertical surface is perpendicular, or plumb, with the horizontal plane. These measurements are important because any structure needs to be level and plumb if it is to stand and resist the forces of gravity.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DAVIS, LEONARD
description: DAVIS-Leonard. The staff and Senior Fellows of the Leonard Davis Institute of Health Economics at the University of Pennsylvania mourn the loss of Leonard Davis. Along with his beloved wife, Sophie, Leonard Davis had the vision to recognize the coming changes in the nation's health care system. Together, they created one of the country's first academic institutes devoted to improving the health of the public through careful study of the economic and social forces that shape health care. Under the Davis' guidance, and with their support, the Leonard Davis Institute of Health Economics became a model that many other universities have hoped to emulate. We extend our sincerest condolences to Mr. Davis' sons, Alan and Michael; to his four grandchildren; to his entire family; and to the Davis' close friend & colleague, Marilyn Hoadley. David A. Asch, Executive Director

title: Indoor Start-Ups
description: Seeds of many cool weather vegetables and flowers can be started through February, but hold off on the heat lovers unless you have a cold frame to protect tender plants. If you have a cool windowsill with lots of sun, start containers of lettuces like dark red Devils Tongue or Bijou, and you will harvest at about the time you plant your first crops outdoors. Keep catalogs: they can be indispensable references on germination and plant culture. PATRICIA JONAS

description: An agency specializing in cruises is offering two guarantees, mainly intended to attract new cruise-takers. The agency, Travel Services International of Delray Beach, Fla., says it will match any advertised cruise fare, and will give a refund for the unused part of the cruise and pay for transportation back to the original port for any client who is dissatisfied after 24 hours aboard a cruise. The double guarantee applies to new bookings made before March 31 and cruises completed before Dec. 20 that have been sold by the agency's branches: Cruises Only in Orlando; the Cruise Line of North Miami Beach and Syosset, N.Y.; CruiseOne and Cruises Inc. of Pompano Beach, Fla., and www.mytravelco.com.

Until the age of 6, he lived on a grassy patch called Kelly Field in San Antonio. While Lieut. Carlisle Ferris (who would eventually become an Air Force colonel) was off teaching soldiers to fly, Keith was drawing pictures of the planes that landed to show his father when he got back.

title: Buddy for Life

On her kitchen counter was a bottle of Mayor's Own marinara sauce, complete with Cianci's face on the label. Having tried the sauce, I was curious to learn more about the mayor, and thanks to your article I did. The sauce, by the way, is delicious.

title: AT THE GALLERY WITH/Randal Davis; A Show of Works by Women That Expand Language in Art
description: THE written word has often played a crucial role in the creation of modern and contemporary art. One early 20th-century example of the use of language in art is the Dada movement, which demonstrated that the printed word can enhance, even rival, the pictorial image in importance.

description: FOLK art signs for taverns and inns once commonly spiced the landscape, a form of art accessible to the gaze of all.

title: Reckonings; Jerking The Other Knee
description: Remember the knee-jerk liberals? Washington used to be full of people who viewed greedy businessmen as the root of all evil, who thought that a new government program was the answer to every problem. Some of them wielded influence in the early Clinton administration. But after the defeat of the health care plan, they were sent into exile. Bill Clinton became a pragmatist, someone who appreciated the virtues of the market without deifying it and understood the limits of government without demonizing it.

title: A Kashmiri Mystery

I expected a new insight but instead got the same rehash about the ''most dangerous place for possible nuclear confrontation.'' The more likely place for this, in my opinion, is the Middle East.

The state's utilities have been struggling with power shortages, which grew more severe because of some generator shutdowns and a financial crisis caused by soaring prices on the overheated wholesale market.

She was ''Mom'' to many, regardless of their age, and support to all. Her spirit endures and lives through us. We have been fortunate to have had her help us ''Discover the Spirit''. title: MOVIES: CRITIC'S CHOICE
description: IF ''O, Brother, Where Art Thou?'' doesn't convince you that George Clooney is the new Clark Gable, maybe a look back at RED DUST (1932) will. Gable was 31 in this, his first film with Jean Harlow, and, like Mr. Clooney these days, he's the picture of movie-starrish easy charm. Gable is also much more convincing in the role than when he reprised it for ''Mogambo,'' the 1953 remake. He's a rubber-plantation worker in Indochina who has a fling with a stranded steamship passenger of easy virtue (Harlow, barely 21 at the time and adorably comic) but quickly throws her over for a ''real lady'' (Mary Astor), who turns out to be equally seducible. But she has a husband (Gene Raymond), one so sincere he may force Gable's character to do something noble. Victor Fleming directed, and John Lee Mahin wrote the smart, snappy script - Saturday at 7:30 a.m. on TCM.

title: Bared: the Heartbreaking Geometry of the Triangle
description: FOR those of us who felt it was the better part of common sense to treat the presidential indiscretion not as a major crime but as a boorish misdemeanor, there were nevertheless moments during the Monica Lewinsky scandal when the stomach turned and bile rose in the gorge. For some, it may have been the semantic sophistries of President Clinton during the hearings; for others, rumors that in private the president was bragging about his escapade and laughing at all of us. For me, the moment of maximum distaste came with the shot of the president striding to the helicopter, post impeachment, one arm around his wife, the other around his daughter. The wife, I thought, however humiliated, can fend for herself. But what about the daughter?

title: Six Places in Seville Where Tapas Are Just a Start
description: SEVILLE, the capital of Andalusia, may also be the noshing capital of the world. Tapas were born in Andalusia, and the wealth of tapas bars in this city -- from literal holes in the wall to tony cafes -- bespeaks a unique style of eating, one well suited to a climate that is warm and sunny much of the year, to late traditional meal times, to an irrepressible joie de vivre and, concomitantly, to conversations in decibel levels too high for conventional restaurants.

title: Wintry Tale With a Warm, Fuzzy Ending
description: I AM a cold person. Of body, not heart. I don't know if it's low blood pressure, bad circulation or genetics. But getting around in a typical winter, I am a runny-nosed, red-cheeked streak of flying fluff and the layered look, like the Pillsbury dough person. My life revolves around the temperature outside, and I leave home only when I absolutely must. Thank goodness for cable and Jane Austen. Bedtime, I put my flannel nightgown on over my clothes, then get undressed. The friends I have left make house calls.

title: Word for Word/W. and J.Q.A.; Dueling Resumes: President No. 43, Meet No. 6
description: IN taking the oath of office yesterday, George W. Bush became only the second son of a former president, after John Quincy Adams in 1825, to become the nation's chief executive. In most ways, Mr. Bush could not be more different from Adams. Where Mr. Bush is known as upbeat, outgoing and an indifferent student, Adams was intense, moody, a skilled diplomat and a driven scholar who was ill at ease in politics.

But as the offers and counteroffers fly, an ethical question arises: Once you accept a job offer, is it ethical to go back on your word because someone else makes you a better deal?

On her next visit, she should talk with Victoria Herberta, the owner of Pigdom, 4208 Crawford Street, to understand the history and inspiration of pig art, and to learn about her extensive gardening. title: A Primer On Jazz (in 1,638 Pages)
description: I'M not a gatekeeper, an early adopter, much less an arbiter of taste. When it comes to music, I set up pretty far down river, wait until any one of several friends gives me the nod, and only then do I start to proselytize. I've gotten away with this as an adult; but I wince when I think back on how, as tender young men, we used to menace one another with our tastes. ''So, what are you listening to?'' we would ask, the way any bully harvests fear. ''Never Mind the Bollocks,'' ''Trout Mask Replica,'' ''Metal Machine Music'': each answer was more arcane, more demanding, more unmelodic, a more finely calibrated totem in the quest for peer status than the last. The problem governing adolescence, it turned out, wasn't that you didn't get to choose your parents. It was that you had to choose your music. And this, of course, was a ceaseless tournament to determine where in the pecking order you might be.

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Fairest of Fowls
description: The world of chickens is a world of wonders. Consider the 179 photographs by Stephen Green-Armytage beautifully reproduced and collected in EXTRAORDINARY CHICKENS (Abrams, $24.95). The flamboyant, unlikely, extravagant birds depicted in studio portraits come in all sizes (bantam to colossal) and shapes (Botero-plump to pitiful) and colors and textures; I am particularly taken with the frizzles, although the silkies give them a run for their money. Many wear headdresses that would make a Las Vegas showgirl blush; others sport absurd beards, muffs and whiskers. The Faverolles salmon hen, for example, looks like an outraged society matron wearing a boa, while the bald head and lavish muttonchop whiskers of the Araucana white rumpless hen would become any Victorian elder statesman. The detailed sections on feet and spurs and, especially, combs make one ponder about the adaptive and evolutionary purposes that lead to peculiarities like, say, the comb of the Minorca black hen, something like a many-fingered red rubber glove abandoned on her head. Green-Armytage, whose book grew out of an assignment for Life magazine, has also provided a useful text, including a brief history of chicken fancying (Queen Victoria was an early poultry fan) and short descriptions of the breeds pictured, from the Appenzeller Spitzhauben, new on the show circuit, to the showily long-tailed Yokohama. Sarah Ferrell

Trying to find it on my first visit, I was sure I was the victim of a cruel prank, one that would end badly for me. ''Ah, signor, you went to 14th and Grand? Under the viaduct? title: The Way We Live Now: 1-21-01: Intimations; Mixed Blessings
description: With the arrival of 2001, I find I can't help thinking about Nietzsche, celibacy and George W. Bush. Actually, I started thinking about the first two back in 1968, when I saw ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' (George W. Bush was not yet on my mind.) At the aerospace research laboratory where I was working, a new employee had just started. She was into science fiction, so I thought that tickets for opening night would impress her favorably. They did, but when the film was over, I was struck not by its space-age flourishes but by its view about human evolution -- so similar, I thought, to Nietzsche's view about the emergence of the ''superman.'' My date, however, was not into such philosophical speculations. So, ruining all chances for further developments in our relationship, I rushed her home and spent the rest of the night rereading my Nietzsche. I should have foreseen right then and there my path to celibacy, but it was to be four more years before I heard the call.

By holding up the vices and foibles of his contemporaries to ridicule, Brant's book helped prepare the ground for the Reformation. In SHIP OF FOOLS (Ace, paper, $12.95), by Richard Paul Russo, a starship named Argonos wanders the galaxy, its thousands of inhabitants unsure of their mission. Although most were born on the ship and have never known any other existence, they are divided into rancorous factions, unable to agree on anything except that something in their lives has gone terribly wrong.

title: Necessity for Every Do-It-Yourselfer: A Level
description: THE level is a simple but important tool that should be a part of every do-it-yourselfer's tool kit. It works on the simple principal that a liquid always finds its own level. The word level explains its function. Levels are used to describe a perfect horizontal plane that is balanced with the forces of gravity. Levels can also be used to indicate whether a vertical surface is perpendicular, or plumb, with the horizontal plane. These measurements are important because any structure needs to be level and plumb if it is to stand and resist the forces of gravity.

title: Overhauling New York's Drug Laws
description: Gov. George Pataki made a good start last week toward a much-needed reform of New York's unjust and unworkable drug laws. The governor's package, though far short of what is needed, is an important political step toward revamping an anti-drug experiment that has overloaded the state's prisons with more than 10,000 nonviolent drug users who needed treatment more than punishment for their addictions.

title: In the Heart Of Moorish Granada
description: JUST as it is a geographical fact that the Alhambra overlooks Granada, so it is a sad truth that most visitors to the monumental palace-fortress overlook -- in both senses of the word -- the rest of the city. It is easy to understand why this 13th-century Arabic stronghold attracts tourists by the tens of thousands. An exquisite ensemble of Islamic architecture and art, celebrated for centuries in poetry and song, popularized by Washington Irving's ''Tales of the Alhambra,'' its image endlessly replicated on postcards, the Alhambra represents the essence of Andalusia, a historic landmark encrusted with romantic associations. In spring, summer and fall, crowds flood through the Court of the Lions and the Patio of the Myrtles lugging cameras and video equipment, firing off shots of the backs of each other's heads. All the while, guards urge them to put out their cigarettes and deposit gum wrappers and orange peels in the proper receptacles. To prevent the grounds from being overrun and to protect the heritage of the last Muslim rulers of Spain from ruination, the Alhambra has had to impose a limit of 8,800 daily admissions, and it requires tickets booked in advance with designated time slots.

title: A Mission Fulfilled: Bringing Flamenco To the New World
description: THE sounds of stamping feet and lustily strummed guitars burst from every corner of this radiant city last September during the Bienal de Flamenco. Day and night, in 16th-century plazas and Art Deco theaters, top-flight dancers and musicians celebrated the art over a four-week period packed with performances, workshops and classes. Since its founding in 1980, the Bienal has become the most popular and sophisticated festival of its kind, drawing fans to southern Spain from all over the world. Flamenco festivals are as integral to Andalusian life as sunshine and red wine, with almost every village known for its own individual style. It is where youngsters learn to perform, artists hone their skills and legends assert their supremacy.

The brand has taken off in the last 18 months ($2,350 to $25,000 at Tourneau Time Machine, 12 East 57th Street). Panarei makes 15,000 watches a year, as opposed to 300 three years ago. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, REV. JOHN H. III
description: MILLER-Rev. John H. III. On January 18, 2001. Of Little Compton, RI. Son of the late John H. Miller, II and Harriet (Crane) Miller of Rumson, NJ. Devoted husband of Lora Elkinton Miller, loving father of Hope, Rhoads, and Edward Miller, brother of Talbott and David Miller. He served his country in the U.S. Army, ranger qualified 1966-1969. Avid sailor and skier, John was a humble man, who always put his family, friends and ministry first. He was the Protestant Chaplain for the State of Rhode Island Department of Corrections. Graduate of Marvelwood School, Defiance College and The School for Deacons of the Episcopal Diocese of R.I. Ordained Deacon on March 28, 1992, John was at the time of his death completing his studies for a Masters Degree in Spirituality at The General Theological Seminary. John's memory will live on through the many people he helped during his life. He will be greatly missed. Memorial Service Tuesday, January 23rd, 12 noon at Cathedral of St. John, 271 North Main Street, Providence, RI 02903. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the John H. Miller Foundation-General Delivery, Little Compton, RI 02837.

title: The Bush All-Stars
description: As Republicans see it, President George W. Bush has assembled a national security dream team, featuring Dick Cheney as vice president, Colin Powell as secretary of state, Donald Rumsfeld as secretary of defense and Condoleezza Rice as national security adviser. But as Phil Jackson, the coach of the Los Angeles Lakers, could tell Mr. Bush this season, putting superstar players on the court does not always guarantee harmony or success. Indeed, as former presidents like Ronald Reagan and Jimmy Carter can attest, high-powered advisers often end up battling over everything from policy to access to the Oval Office. Given the mix of strong personalities and potentially competing policies in the new administration, Mr. Bush may have to deal with more friction than he expects.

title: Defying the Norms in Midtown
description: You probably don't envy the apartment John Bonafede and his four roommates share. Yes, they've got 2,800 square feet in midtown with a wrap-around balcony and somewhat affordable rent. But all five share one bathroom and suffer both the fear of rent hikes and the side effects of 20-somethings cohabitating outside the set of "Friends." Abandoned sofas border the living room, dirty dishes fill the sink and the refrigerator holds five half-full jars of mayonnaise. The sight would send Monica, the "Friends" character, screaming. But Bonafede, co-founding member of this unofficial artists' collective and a 27-year-old decorative and fine-art painter says, "I'm more concerned with what can be done in here instead of to here."

title: Patents; Some of I.B.M.'s 2,886 patents last year turned it away from circuit boards and semiconductors.

title: The Painted Bird, Caged: What Is the Truth About Art?
description: One of the more interesting things about ''More Lies About Jerzy,'' an earnest and plodding new play by Davey Holmes drawn from the enigmatic life of the novelist Jerzy Kosinski, is that it raises the same questions about itself that it asks about its subject. The play, which opened on Sunday at the Vineyard Theater, is about authenticity and fabrication as they pertain to both writing and living, and it presents its central figure with the same mixture of fact and fiction with which Kosinski himself evidently wrote and lived.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 7 about an alliance between the Episcopal Church and the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America misstated the process for installing new Lutheran bishops. It requires at least three bishops who are considered part of the historic episcopate -- the succession that reaches back to St. Peter. The three could include bishops from the Episcopal Church, or from Lutheran churches in other countries that recognize the historic episcopate. It is not necessary for the three to be Episcopalians.

title: Mr. Bush's First Opportunity

Yesterday Mr. McCain reintroduced the campaign finance reform bill he has sponsored with Senator Russell Feingold and reiterated his demand that it be taken up right away. Some Republicans are urging Mr. McCain to let the new president come forward with his own agenda first. But as Mr. McCain said yesterday, every request for delay is really a request for time to kill the bill.

title: Technology Briefings
description: E-COMMERCE DRUGSTORE.COM'S LOSSES NARROW An online retailer, Drugstore.com , reported a loss yesterday that was narrower than expected for its fiscal fourth quarter, but projected continued shortfalls for this year. The company, which sells health and beauty products and prescription drugs, reported a net loss of $28.6 million, or 45 cents a share, for the quarter, excluding amortization of intangible assets and stock-based compensation. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had, on average, expected a loss of 55 cents a share. Drugstore.com, based in Bellevue, Wash., is projecting a loss of $83 million to $88 million for this fiscal year. The company also said that it would eliminate 125 jobs and that its chief financial officer, David Rostov, would resign.
