title: Metro Business Briefing; INVESTIGATION OF WAGES
description: The Gristede's supermarket chain announced yesterday that it would begin investigating allegations that its delivery company, Great American Delivery, was paying the stores' deliverymen less than the minimum wage. Gristede's said that it renegotiated its contract with Great American, which is based in New York, last August to ensure that the delivery company was complying with wage laws. Many deliverymen say they work more than 60 hours a week, yet are paid less than $200 a week, including wages and tips, well below the federal minimum wage of $5.15 an hour. Gristede's said that if it determined that Great American was violating wage laws, it would suspend the company's contract or rescind it. Charles Baur, owner of Great American, did not return several calls to his office yesterday. Supermarket officials said the deliverymen were employed by Great American and not Gristede's. But Catherine Ruckelshaus, a lawyer for the deliverymen, said Gristede's was effectively their employer, noting that Gristede's often tells them when and where to make deliveries and often uses them to bag groceries. Steven Greenhouse (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing; AUCTION OVER PROPERTY SALES
description: Stop and Shop Supermarket was the sole bidder yesterday at an auction for the right to sell properties owned by Bradlees, the discount retailer that sought bankruptcy protection last month. No one else matched the $150 million minimum offer to Bradlees by Stop and Shop, a Royal Ahold unit that guaranteed at least 90 of the leases, said Deborah J. Piazza, a lawyer for Bradlees. Stop and Shop owned Bradlees from 1961 to 1992. Under the agreement, Stop and Shop would join Bradlees in selling 105 stores, the Bradlees corporate headquarters in Braintree, Mass., and three distribution centers. United States Bankruptcy Court Judge Burton R. Lifland will review the proposal in a hearing on Thursday in Manhattan. If it is approved, Stop and Shop and Bradlees will hold auctions to sell the leases. Stop and Shop and the Bradlees creditors will split the proceeds if the properties bring in more than $150 million. Stop and Shop agreed to pay the carrying costs on the leases until they are sold, which could help Bradlees avoid as much as $50 million in costs, Ms. Piazza said. Bradlees operates stores in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Maine and Pennsylvania.

Since October, Ansett and Qantas have been outbidding each other in the battle for Hazelton. The Qantas withdrawal clears the way for Ansett, which is a unit of Air New Zealand, to get the 50.1 percent of shareholder approval it needs to proceed with a takeover. Its chief executive, Gary Toomey, said Ansett would consider steps it can take to obtain the regulatory approval.

Shares in EM.TV have fallen sharply the last six months. Mr. Haffa is a brother of EM.TV's chief executive, Thomas Haffa, who has acknowledged that he sold shares last year. The brothers face an insider-trading investigation by the German securities regulator and at least eight shareholder suits accusing Thomas Haffa of not telling investors early enough about EM.TV's declining profit outlook.

title: Defying Types to Undermine Assumptions
description: On Wednesday night at Fez, Amy Correia risked a platitude and ended up with an elucidation. Accompanied by Gerri Sutyak on cello, she tackled ''La Vie en Rose,'' the world's classiest saloon song and the legendary Edith Piaf's signature. It takes audacity for a young American to claim such a weighty text, but Ms. Correia succeeded, using the song to help define her own talent.

title: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
description: YEN GAINS. The yen rose after a report on Japan's services industry suggested the economy may not be as weak as previously thought. In New York, the dollar settled at 116.39 yen, down from 117.42 yen on Friday.

title: Norton Made Calls Warning of 'Smear Mail'
description: Gale A. Norton, the interior secretary-designate, made a series of recorded telephone calls in competitive legislative races in Colorado just before last November's election asserting that Democrats were engaged in a ''smear campaign'' against their Republican opponents, a tape of one of her calls shows.

title: GERMAN EXCHANGE TO SELL STOCK
description: Deutsche Borse said it planned to raise as much as 984 million euros ($915 million) in an initial public offering, giving it greater means to make acquisitions as stock exchanges explore cost-cutting combinations. The stock offering values Deutsche Borse at as much as 3.4 billion euros ($3.18 billion). Investors can subscribe to the shares at a price of 285 euros ($266.48) to 335 euros ($313.23). About a third of the exchange's shares will be available for trading. Deutsche Borse has learned from its failure to merge with the London Stock Exchange, Rolf Breuer, chairman of Deutsche Borse, said last week. Now, its priorities are alliances in the area of clearing and settlement rather than trading platforms, he said.

title: PRO FOOTBALL; Carruth Sentenced To Nearly 19 Years
description: Rae Carruth, the former Carolina Panthers wide receiver, was sentenced today to more than 18 years in prison for masterminding the death of the woman pregnant with his child.

title: Nurturing Nature
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: The Neediest Cases; Pounded by Illness, Lifted by Kindness
description: Yvonne Reed-Bennett, 33, has had it with hospitals. ''Waking up in straitjackets, with I.V.'s hanging from my arm,'' she said, ''I don't do that no more.''

title: The Big City; A Town Made For Gossip In Any Era
description: FROM a historical perspective, Midtown Manhattan may seem the perfect place for Bill Clinton to set up shop. But will he regret it?

title: A New Enterprise Joins Growing Community of Online Schools
description: There are two stories about how the 104-year-old Calvert School in Baltimore wound up in the home schooling business. One centers on bugs, the other on bucks.

title: Claude Palisca, 79, Musicologist Specializing in the Renaissance
description: Claude Victor Palisca, a musicologist who specialized in the Renaissance, died on Jan. 10 in New Haven. He was 79 and lived in New Haven.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KOEPPEL, ALFRED J.
description: KOEPPEL-Alfred J. The Officers, Board of Directors, and staff of UJA-Federation of New York mourn the passing of Alfred Koeppel, a friend and supporter of this organization, whose life and good deeds are continued by his family. To his wife, Ruth; to his children, Lynne and Caleb, Lesley and David, and Sarah and Robert Cohn; and to the entire family we extend our sincere condolences. James S. Tisch, President Larry Zicklin, Board Chair & President-Elect John S. Ruskay, Exec VP & CEO

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COSENTINO, JOSEPHINE BATCHELDER
description: COSENTINO-Josephine Batchelder. 75, of New York City, entered into eternal rest on Saturday, January 20. Born in Lynn, MA, she was a 1946 graduate of Wellesley College in MA. She is survived by her husband John A. Cosentino of New York City, and her two sons John A. Jr. of Simsbury, CT, and Paul B. of Richmond VA. Also surviving is a brother, Harry C. Batchelder of New York City, and four grandchildren, Jessica, Joshua and Matthew of Simsbury, CT, and Trent of Richmond, VA. She was predeceased by a grandson, Willy. All services were private. For information, contact C.C. Van Emburgh Funeral Home, Ridgewood.

title: Ousted Manila Leader Says He Yielded Just Temporarily
description: Joseph Estrada, forced from the Philippine presidency last week, indicated today that he had yielded power only as a temporary measure and appeared to be creating a basis for legal challenge to his ouster.

title: China, With an Eye on Critics, Says It Will Ratify Rights Pact
description: China will probably ratify a major international rights convention by the end of March, officials said today. The nation is apparently seeking to head off an early confrontation with the Bush administration over human rights and to enhance its chances to be host to the 2008 Olympics.

title: U.S. Men To Add Brazil To Schedule
description: The United States men's team will be well prepared for the 10 qualifying games it will play in trying to earn one of three berths from the North and Central America and Caribbean region in the 2002 World Cup. Along with games against China in Oakland, Calif., on Saturday and against Colombia in Miami on Feb. 3, the Americans will announce today that they will play Brazil on March 3 at the Rose Bowl in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians referred incorrectly to United Nations resolutions on the conflict. While Security Council Resolution 242, passed after the 1967 Middle East war, calls for Israel to withdraw its armed forces "from territories occupied in the recent conflict," no resolution calls for Israel to withdraw "to its pre-1967 borders."

title: Review/Fashion; Ah, for a Little Inner Lewdness. Or Maybe Lots of Inner Lewdness.
description: Only hours before the spring 2001 couture show today for Dior, seamstresses were poring over pieces of John Galliano's childishly indolent skirts like country ladies gathered at a quilting bee. Bits of fabric and thread lay scattered on the floor of Dior's main salon, while in the ateliers the atmosphere was almost surreal as middle-aged workers in lab coats bent over dresses of savagely cut black neoprene and rocker coats emblazoned with skulls and embroidered graffiti.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LEWIN, GORDON
description: LEWIN-Gordon, 61, of Pompton Plains, NJ, died on January 20. He was born in NYC and raised in Tucson, Arizona. He moved to Pompton Plains 29 years ago. He was a loving, dedicated father and is survived by 2 sons, Joseph of Hamilton, NJ and Steven of Pompton Plains, NJ. Mr. Lewin worked for The New York Times for 32 years as a financial analyst in the Financial Department and was a member of the Newspaper Guild. He served on the Board of Trustees of Newbridge in Pompton Plains. Funeral Services were held yesterday at the Jewish Memorial Chapel in Clifton, NJ.

title: Florida Urged to Adopt Uniform Voting System
description: The officials who run Florida's elections called on the state Legislature today to end the tangle of punch-card, lever and optical scanner systems used in the state and to adopt a uniform method for Floridians to cast votes.

title: Tunnel Vision; Going to Extremes on the Long-Haul Subway Line
description: At work last Friday, Wayne McLamore drove 62 miles. This was not so bad, considering that he used to drive 124 miles. And especially considering that his co-workers can sometimes cover 155, which is like driving from Midtown to the Maryland border.

title: Knoblauch Practices Basics
description: Spring training is a month away, but Yankees second baseman Chuck Knoblauch has been at the club's minor league facility in Tampa, Fla., for more than a week now, working on the fundamentals of fielding, in an effort to conquer the throwing jitters that have plagued him for the last three seasons.

title: DURA PARES ITS EARNINGS FORECAST AND WILL REDUCE STAFF
description: Dura Automotive Systems Inc., a maker of brake pedals and other auto parts, lowered its fourth-quarter earnings forecast by more than half on slower auto and recreational-vehicle parts sales and said it would cut jobs. Dura said it expected to earn 15 cents to 20 cents a share, less than the 75-cent average estimate in a First Call/Thomson Financial poll. Dura earned $1.10 a share a year earlier. The company said it would reduce its work force of about 21,000 people and close plants in Elkhart, Ind.; East Jordan, Mich.; and Chard, England. Dura would not say how many jobs it would cut. The company also said it would take unspecified charges to realign in Europe.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BEY, SAMUEL E.
description: BEY-Samuel E. The Rabbis, staff and students of The Les Turchin Chabad House at Rutgers University mourn the passing of our esteemed friend Samuel E. Bey. We extend our deepest condolences to his wife, Mollie, and his children Stanley Bey, Arne Bey, and Sharyn Turchin, wife of our Honorary Chairman, Les Turchin. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Yosef Z. Carlebach

title: French Corruption Trial Begins
description: The corruption trial of a former French foreign minister, Roland Dumas, began today with his former mistress, also on trial, describing how he helped her receive millions of dollars from a state-owned oil company while she was associated with him.

title: Swinging Away at Handicaps
description: To the Editor:

title: When Teenagers Smoke: A Closer Look
description: For many students, something happens in the short time between their arrival in middle school in the fall and the following spring -- and it is not good.

title: Millrose Tradition Is on Carroll's Side
description: In the past 23 years, Irish milers have won the Wanamaker Mile 15 times. Mark Carroll knows the tradition and knows that the burden is on his shoulders. To him, it is no big deal.

title: Carruth Sentenced to 18 Years
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C., Jan. 22  Rae Carruth, the former Carolina Panthers wide receiver, was sentenced today to more than 18 years in prison for masterminding the death of the woman pregnant with his child.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  METTAM, CHARLES T.
description: METTAM-Charles T. Age 76. Of Durham, N.H. on January 21, 2001. Husband of Jean Lawrence Mettam. Funeral Saturday, 2PM, Saint George's Church, Durham, N.H.

title: Tommie Agee, of Miracle Mets, Dies at 58
description: Tommie Agee, the center fielder who made two of the most spectacular catches in World Series history in propelling the Mets to their stunning 1969 championship, died yesterday at Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan. He was 58.

title: Learning Channel Sues Over a Web Site
description: The Learning Channel, a unit of Discovery Communications Inc., has sued Pearson P.L.C., the world's largest educational publisher, contending infringement of its trademark by an Internet site operated by Pearson.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about the Alfred I. duPont-Columbia University Awards for broadcast journalism misstated the ownership of the top award winner, American Radio Works, which won the gold baton for a documentary on Serbian atrocities in Kosovo. It is the documentary unit of Minnesota Public Radio and NPR News, not an independent radio company.

description: By CARL S. KAPLAN

title: Foreign Affairs; Not Happening
description: There's something strange going on here. If you look around the Balkans today you'll see that democracy movements are tentatively sprouting in the two ethnically pure Balkan states that caused the most trouble during the Bosnian war: Serbia and Croatia. And democracy is least alive and well in the place where NATO and U.S. troops are present, namely multi-ethnic Bosnia (and Kosovo).

title: In a 'Twist of Fate,' Lieberman's School Bill Could Help Bush
description: As President Bush prepares to introduce his education proposal on Tuesday, his best shot at success may come from the unlikeliest of allies: his campaign adversary, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman.

title: Managing Pain After Surgery
description: To the Editor:

title: Putin Scaling Down Chechen War Despite New Fighting
description: President Vladimir V. Putin effectively downgraded Russia's war in Chechnya today from a military to a counterterrorist operation, saying he planned to cut Russia's 80,000-member force in the rebellious province by nearly three-quarters in coming months.

title: UNEXPECTEDLY HIGH PROFIT FOR OPENWAVE
description: Openwave Systems, a fast-growing communications company that focuses largely on mobile Internet access, said it had an operating profit in the fiscal second quarter of $15.8 million, or 9 cents a diluted share, far exceeding the expectations of analysts polled by First Call/Thomson Financial of a loss of 3 cents a share. Revenue at the company, which was formed by the merger of Phone.com and Software.com, climbed to $109.7 million in the quarter, from $29.1 million in the period a year earlier. Openwave, however, had a net loss for the quarter, including acquisition costs, of $228.6 million, wider than its loss of $168 million last year. Simon Romero (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SHAPIRO, IRVING
description: SHAPIRO-Irving. The Anti-Defamation League mourns the passing of our dear friend, Irving Shapiro, a member of our National Commission. A longtime Chair of ADL's Middle East Committee, Irving was dedicated to peace and security for the Jewish State. A committed and steadfast leader for thirty years, he worked tirelessly to further ADL's agenda. We will miss his wise counsel and good humor. We extend our condolences to his wife, Dorothy, his daughters, his brother, Sidney, and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Glen A. Tobias National Chairman Abraham H. Foxman National Director

title: Byron De La Beckwith Dies; Killer of Medgar Evers Was 80
description: Byron De La Beckwith, whose 1994 conviction in the murder of a civil rights leader three decades earlier symbolized a transformation in Mississippi, died on Sunday night in Jackson, Miss. He was 80.

title: Gillette Chooses a New Chief, A Veteran of the Cookie Wars
description: The Gillette Company turned yesterday to a man who had invigorated the sale of lunch meats and cookies at Nabisco and Kraft in hopes that he might find a better way to sell razors and batteries.

title: Bucks Will Challenge Knicks' Defensive Run
description: The Knicks have all but forgotten about their National Basketball Association record of holding 33 straight opponents under 100 points. Jeff Van Gundy belittled the mark two weeks ago, saying that a solid defensive club holds opponents below 90 points, and even the players realize that stopping teams from reaching 100 is nothing special in this low-scoring era of basketball.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  RYAN, WILLIAM J.
description: RYAN-William J. 103. On January 20, 2001. Dartmouth 1918. WWI Veteran. Engaged in investment banking, resident of Wilton, Ct. since 1932. Survived by sister Rita Corcoran of Winchester, Ma.; sons Chilton, Geoffrey Cobb, Christopher Capen and Peter Sanford; grand-daughters Catherine Ryan Maeglin of NYC, Nina and Susanna Ryan of Gloucester, Ma.; great grandchildren Ryan Richard Maeglin and Chelsea Victoria Maeglin of NYC. Pre-deceased by wife Margaret Cobb Ryan and daughters Margot and Lisa. Reposing Collins Funeral Home 4-7pm Tuesday, 92 East Avenue, Norwalk, Ct. Funeral Mass Wednesday 11am, Our Lady of Fatima Church, 228 Danbury Road, Wilton, Ct

title: Ex-President Barred From Leaving Philippines
description: MANILA, Jan. 23  The Philippines' new government today barred the ousted president, Joseph Estrada, from leaving the country and froze his bank accounts as it opened a new investigation into charges of widespread corruption in his administration.

title: Sports of The Times; Amazing Mets Lose Their Leadoff Man
description: Nearly 33 years ago, Tommie Agee was preparing to lead off his first exhibition game with his new team, the Mets. But first, his new teammate Ed Charles had a word of advice regarding the Cardinals' ace pitcher, one Bob Gibson.

title: AMGEN SHARES RISE ON RULINGS
description: Shares of Amgen, the world's largest biotechnology company, surged yesterday after a federal judge ruled that its rival, Transkaryotic Therapies, had infringed on three Amgen patents on its anemia drug, Epogen. Amgen sold about $4 billion of the drug worldwide in 1999. The company's stock rose $7.63, to $67.63. Transkaryotic Therapies shares tumbled $10.88, to $23.13, making it the day's worst performer.

title: Billick Goes On Offensive In Defense Of Ray Lewis
description: Perhaps when a Ravens team bus sideswiped a police escort cruiser and dragged it for several feet along a road divider on the way to the airport today, the tone was set for how the Ravens would present themselves when they arrived here for the Super Bowl. Like the harsh sound of metal scraping against concrete, Ravens Coach Brian Billick dismissed most of the niceties that are the norm at a team's first news conferences at a Super Bowl and went into an extended castigation of reporters for their ongoing interest in the saga of Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices to Weigh Issue of Child Pornography and Computer-Generated Images
description: While it has long been beyond debate that the government can make it a crime to possess or to distribute child pornography, a case the Supreme Court accepted today poses a new constitutional question for the computer age: whether the First Amendment permits criminalizing child pornography that depicts not actual children but computer-generated images that look like actual children.

title: With Seattle a Vivid Memory, W.T.O. Seeks a New Host City
description: The World Trade Organization's last top-level meeting, which left Seattle reeling after violent protests, scores of arrests and property damage, was not the greatest advertisement to lure countries to be the host of its next big gathering later this year.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the politics of the war on drugs referred incorrectly in some copies to Gov. Christie Whitman's position on racial profiling by the New Jersey State Police. She has acknowledged the practice and moved to stop it; she has not apologized for it.

title: Show Children Love, With a Carrot Stick
description: My parents certainly meant well when they wheedled and cajoled and bribed their then-scrawny preschooler to eat the nutritious foods they served. So did my grandmother when she fed me sticks of butter, bars of cheese and cans of evaporated milk to fatten me up.

title: Enron Earnings Up 34% in 4th Quarter
description: The Enron Corporation, the world's biggest energy trader, said today that its fourth-quarter profit rose 34 percent as natural gas and electricity sales surged and the company remained unscathed by the California energy crisis.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRANK, ANN MARQUSEE
description: FRANK-Ann Marqusee. Passed away January 21, 2001 peacefully in her home in FL. She is survived by her devoted and beloved husband Charles, adoring children Patricia (Neil) Koslowe and Pamela (David) Garry. Cherished grand children Jamin (Shana), Shana (Bini), Oren, Jenna, Tavi, Sarah and Talia, five adored great grandchildren and a loving brother Charles Marqusee.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DI RAFFAELE, IDA
description: Di RAFFAELE-Ida. Our beautiful special Ida. Your radiance, care and love was our gift. We will miss you forever. You were such a large part of our lives. Our hearts are with Bob, Carrie, Jeff and the rest of your beautiful family. Love, Barbara and Philip

title: Administration Leaves Power Crisis in California's Hands
description: President Bush's top economic officials gathered today to deal with the threat of electricity blackouts and utility bankruptcies in California. But they decided that the federal government should let California solve its own power problem.

title: Despite Strong Sales, Dell Warns of Lower-Than-Expected Earnings
description: Despite sales growth that quadrupled the average for the personal computer industry, Dell Computer warned yesterday that earnings would miss its estimates by as much as 8 cents a share for the current quarter.

description: To the Editor:

title: A New North American Chief for Phillips Auction House
description: Moving quickly to put his own team in place, Simon de Pury, the chairman of Phillips, de Pury & Luxembourg, appointed John Block yesterday as chief executive of the newly rebuilt auction house in North America.

title: Sports of The Times; Newsome Still Has All the Right Moves
description: A FEW minutes before the American Football Conference championship game between Oakland and Baltimore nine days ago, Ozzie Newsome, the Ravens' vice president for pro personnel, was sitting in the press box. We exchanged pleasantries, and then I asked the inevitable question: What do you think? Without taking his eyes off the field, Newsome said, almost offhanded, that he liked the Ravens' matchup at tight end.

title: AIRLINE IN BANKRUPTCY SAYS NEW MONEY HAS NOT ARRIVED
description: Legend Airlines Inc., a start-up carrier that filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy last month, said a group that pledged $20 million to help it restart operations did not provide the funds as promised yesterday. The lender, the Legend Funding Group, said it was still working to provide funds for the carrier but it would not give any assurances on when a loan would be made, said T. Allan McArtor, chief executive and president of Legend Airlines. The airline began flights in April from Dallas Love Field and was flying to Washington, Las Vegas, Los Angeles and New York before it suspended operations.

title: Revisiting A Homage To American Composers
description: In the years between the two world wars, American composers were at once fascinated and intimidated by contemporary music in Europe. Many of them went to Europe to study and to hear all the latest works, even the young Copland, who was intensely curious about what was going on, though he couldn't wait to get back home.

title: In a blow to Young & Rubicam, United Airlines consolidates and hands its accounts to Fallon.
description: ANOTHER closely watched review by a giant advertiser to consolidate worldwide account duties has ended, in this instance with the smaller of the two competing agencies victorious.

title: Bush Administration Warns Iraq on Weapons Programs
description: The Bush administration warned Iraq today to honor its agreements to destroy its nuclear, chemical and biological weapons programs, but the White House said it was too soon to say what steps the new administration would take to ensure Baghdad's compliance.

description: Home Plate, Multiplied

description: To the Editor:

title: Justice Dept. Finds Success Chasing Health Care Fraud
description: While drug lords and organized-crime bosses may have been the more high-profile targets of the Department of Justice in recent years, among the most hotly pursued culprits have been those who commit health care fraud.

title: Tamil Rebels Extend Cease-fire Offer for Another Month
description: NEW DELHI, Jan. 23  Ethnic Tamil rebels who have been fighting for a separate homeland in Sri Lanka since 1983 extended their one-sided cease-fire for another month today. They also called on other nations to try to persuade Sri Lanka to halt its military offensive and restart peace talks that broke off more than 5 years ago.

title: Bush Appoints Powell's Son To Lead F.C.C.
description: President Bush today appointed Michael K. Powell, the oldest son of Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, to be the next chairman of the Federal Communications Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ZOLA, FRANCES WAKSHULL
description: ZOLA-Frances Wakshull, on January 18th, 2001. Beloved wife of Herbert. Loving mother of Marilyn. Dear sister of Rose Wakshull, Lillian Siegel, Sara Slutsky and Samuel Wakshull. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, January 28th, 2 PM, at West Side Institutional Synagogue, 120 W. 76th St.

title: Independent Plants a Factor In the Latest Energy Crisis
description: N.R.G. Energy Inc. was not even a stand-alone company a year ago, but it has big plans for the next few years: building enough power-generation plants to supply the equivalent of 35 million homes.

description: Following are excerpts from a memorandum issued today by the Palestinian Media Center assessing the role of the Clinton administration in Middle East peace talks:

title: Front Row; More French Fabulousness Is on the Way
description: On the long list of cultural products the American marketplace probably doesn't need more of at the moment -- a list that might include boy bands, memoirs of malfunctioning lives and movies made with hand-held cameras -- is the fashion magazine that purports to be groovy. Urbane newsstands are already filled with European titles like Purple, Self Service, I.D., and Dazed & Confused, and in recent years similarly themed American publications like Flaunt have squeezed their way onto the racks.

title: 4 of 7 Texas Fugitives Captured In Colorado as 5th Kills Himself
description: For nearly six frantic weeks until today, the search for seven heavily armed escapees from a maximum-security prison in Texas had gone nowhere, an endless trail of useless tips and fruitless leads that led investigators from Mexico to Mississippi to New York City.

title: Broadway Remembers Peter Gennaro
description: With dance steps, Broadway show tunes and black-and-white video clips, New York's dance world bade farewell to the choreographer Peter Gennaro yesterday afternoon in a two-hour tribute at the Broadhurst Theater.

title: SCHERING AND ENZON WIN APPROVAL FOR HEPATITIS DRUG
description: The Schering-Plough Corporation and Enzon Inc. have won approval from the Food and Drug Administration to sell Peg-Intron, a hepatitis C drug that analysts say could have more than $2 billion in sales. The injectable drug is a once-weekly version of Schering-Plough's Intron A, the world's top-selling hepatitis medication, and is considered by analysts to be a key to increased sales for Schering-Plough over the next five years. The move clears Schering-Plough to market Peg-Intron in the United States, giving the company an edge on Roche Holding A.G., whose own next-generation hepatitis drug, called Pegasys, is still being reviewed by the F.D.A.

title: Spared Threat of Death Sentence, Man Admits Killings at Wendy's
description: One of the men accused of killing five people and wounding two others in a grisly robbery at a Wendy's in Queens last spring pleaded guilty yesterday, then detailed how the fast-food workers were methodically bound, gagged and shot in a basement freezer.

title: DRUGSTORE.COM'S LOSSES NARROW
description: An online retailer, Drugstore.com, reported a loss yesterday that was narrower than expected for its fiscal fourth quarter, but projected continued shortfalls for this year. The company, which sells health and beauty products and prescription drugs, reported a net loss of $28.6 million, or 45 cents a share, for the quarter, excluding amortization of intangible assets and stock-based compensation. Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had, on average, expected a loss of 55 cents a share. Drugstore.com, based in Bellevue, Wash., is projecting a loss of $83 million to $88 million for this fiscal year. The company also said that it would eliminate 125 jobs and that its chief financial officer, David Rostov, would resign.

title: Article 2001012392723526100 -- No Title
description: By SUSAN STELLIN

title: Those Icy Fingers
description: Q. When my fingers feel cold as ice indoors, how cold are they?

title: SBC CLEARED FOR LONG DISTANCE IN KANSAS AND OKLAHOMA
description: SBC Communications Inc., the No. 2 local telephone carrier, won approval from the Federal Communications Commission yesterday to sell long-distance communications services to its customers in Kansas and Oklahoma. Yesterday's approval, which takes effect on March 3, brings to four the number of states where the Bell local phone giants that emerged from the old American Telephone and Telegraph Company in 1984 have won entry into the long-distance arena. In late 1999, Bell Atlantic, now Verizon Communications Inc., won the right to sell long-distance service in New York. Last year, SBC entered the long-distance market in Texas. Seth Schiesel (NYT)

title: Music Connects With a Patient
description: To the Editor:

title: The Gavel Gap
description: George W. Bush will have a harder time picking federal judges than any of his predecessors -- and not just because the evenly divided Senate and the objections of interest groups may make confirmation difficult. The greater problem is the powerful financial incentive for some of the best lawyers to stay in private practice -- and off the bench.

title: With V.A., a Healthy Turn for Blacks
description: It has been well established that when it comes to receiving medical care, blacks often do not receive the same quality of treatment as whites.

title: HUB, A TORONTO INSURANCE COMPANY, BUYS KAYE GROUP
description: Hub International Ltd., an insurance company based in Toronto, agreed yesterday to buy the Kaye Group of New York for $120.5 million in cash and convertible debentures. Hub International will pay $9.33 in cash and $4.67 principal amount of debentures convertible into shares of Hub shares at $11.27 a share. The $14-a-share value is a 78 percent premium to Kaye's closing price Friday. Kaye has $98 million of debt. The purchase will expand Hub's United States operations. Kaye Group had $57 million in sales in the first nine months of 2000, and has offices offering underwriting and brokerage services in New York, Connecticut, Rhode Island and California.

title: New Trial Is Sought for Inmate Whose Lawyer Slept in Court
description: A death row inmate in Texas whose lawyer slept through parts of his 1984 murder trial should be a granted a new trial and be represented by a defense counsel who is not unconscious for as long as 10 minutes at a time, his new lawyer told a federal appeals court here today.

title: Former Slave Havens in Brazil Gaining Rights
description: The nearest telephone is 19 miles away, and television arrived only in 1998. For generations, communities of poor blacks like this one, people descended from slaves who had run away from their masters during Portuguese colonial times, have existed in wary seclusion deep in Brazil's trackless backlands.

title: Outlook for Changes at Sega Pushes Shares 19% Higher
description: TOKYO, Jan. 23  The shares of Sega , the struggling video game company, bucked the downward trend in Japan's stock market and rose sharply today on speculation that it would soon focus on developing game software for rival manufacturers' hardware.

title: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS MISSES FORECASTS
description: A drop in consumer sales that led to weaker demand from electronic equipment makers pushed Texas Instruments' fourth-quarter earnings below analysts' expectations, the company said yesterday. The company, which makes 60 percent of the chips used in cell phones, also said it expected a 10 percent decline in first-quarter revenue, compared with the previous quarter, because of a worldwide slump affecting consumer electronics. Texas Instruments, based in Dallas, said fourth-quarter earnings were $549 million, or 31 cents a share. Although this was 25 percent higher than earnings a year earlier, it was 2 cents lower than earnings in the third quarter and it missed the 33 cents average estimate of analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. Revenues for the quarter were $3.03 billion, an increase of 15 percent from $2.64 billion a year earlier. Total revenue for 2000 were $11.86 billion, 22 percent higher than in 1999. Jennifer 8. Lee (NYT)

title: Lightning Rods in Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Correction: In a column on Jan. 9, I wrote that John Quincy Adams was the only ex-president to run successfully for public office after leaving the White House. Many, many keen-eyed readers have written to point out that Andrew Johnson was elected to the Senate in 1875. However, Johnson, who was actually picked by his state legislature, did not have a career that we'd want his successors to emulate, since he died of a stroke shortly after being sworn in.

title: Maps Point to 'Hot Spots' In Southern California
description: Geologists have developed maps showing which parts of Southern California are most vulnerable to shaking during earthquakes. Structures built on soft sediments in valleys and basins surrounded by mountains would, under certain conditions, shake more than twice as much as would structures built on harder rocks. Shaking is also more likely in areas where these soft sediments are deepest, including a four-mile-deep basin south of downtown Los Angeles, a six-mile-deep basin on the northern edge of the San Fernando Valley and a 10-mile-deep basin in Ventura County. The map above is of the Los Angeles area. But because each earthquake is unique, actual patterns of shaking and structural damage will vary greatly.

title: MASCOTECH CHANGES ITS NAME AND MERGES WITH 2 OTHERS
description: The metal products maker MascoTech Inc. has changed its name to the Metaldyne Corporation and said it would merge with Simpson Industries and Global Metal Technologies Inc. to form an auto-parts maker with about $2 billion in annual sales. The merger will be completed by about midyear, Metaldyne said. A group led by Heartland Industrial Partners bought MascoTech in November for $2 billion in stock and assumed debt. The purchase was the first by the investment firm, which later bought Simpson and Global Metal. The merger reflected the push by automakers for parts suppliers to reduce costs and make larger sections of vehicles rather than individual components. Metaldyne will make metal parts for transmissions, as well as drive gears and engine parts, and will have more than 9,500 workers at 50 plants in 11 countries.

But including 9.1 billion euros of one-time gains, net income for 2000 rose to 7.4 billion euros. Sales rose 15 percent, to 40.9 billion euros, or $38.5 billion, last year from 35.5 billion euros in 1999.

title: Vegetable Soup

Generally, it is prepared with trimmings you would normally throw away: the inedible deep green parts of the leeks' leaves, the tough ends of carrots, turnips, cabbage and celery. These are the very same vegetables that, along with some others, are going be sliced neatly to become the stars of the finished soup. When you're making the stock, there's no need to get delicate about it, just throw the scraps into the pot in chunks or big pieces; it doesn't matter much. And the proportion of one to the other is rarely critical.

description: Richard Bergeron, president of a computer consulting company, has Lou Gehrig's disease. He uses a number of devices that help him do his job, like a motion detector on his computer that lets him type by raising his eyebrows. The clothier Hugo Boss will lease a three-level, 14,300-square-foot store at the base of the building, which is to open in 2003. Although Hugo Boss is building a new store not far away, at Fifth Avenue and 56th Street, Kenneth A. Himmel, president and chief executive of the Palladium Company, one of the partners in the center, said the West Side was a distinct submarket.

title: Menus That Don't Tell the Whole Story
description: THERE is something unexpected on the menu at Pico, a new Portuguese restaurant in TriBeCa: brook trout wrapped in caul, with spinach, thyme, chanterelle mushrooms and green olives. What's unusual is not that the chef, John Villa, enfolds his fish in caul fat, the membrane that encases the internal organs of barnyard animals. What's surprising is that he mentions it at all.

title: 5 Linked to Banned Sect in China Set Themselves on Fire in Protest
description: Five people believed to be members of the banned Falun Gong spiritual group doused themselves with gasoline and set themselves on fire in the middle of Tiananmen Square this afternoon, a dramatic act of protest on the eve of China's most joyous holiday, Spring Festival, or Chinese New Year.

title: To Crumb A Cutlet

Yet in many ways it is the meat most suited to that simple treatment. Like veal and chicken, lamb is lean enough to handle the added richness; like good beef, it is flavorful enough not to get lost. It can also be cooked rare so that it doesn't dry out, and is neither mushy nor tough.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HOENER, DIETHELM BERND
description: HOENER-Diethelm Bernd, age 60, died unexpectedly on January 17 at his vacation home, ''La Fleuriere'' in Cannes. Mr. Hoener was a financier, a philanthropist, and a noted collector of German expressionist art. Born in Allenstein, Germany, he graduated from the University of Koeln with a Masters Degree in Business Administration. Mr. Hoener then studied law in Goettingen, Germany before coming to the United States, where he earned an LL.M. degree from the University of California at Berkeley. Early in his career, Mr. Hoener served as a Vice President in the Corporate Finance and Merger and Acquisition Departments of Morgan Stanley & Co. Incorporated and Morgan Stanley International in New York, Paris, and London. Mr. Hoener left Morgan Stanley to serve as the asset manager of a major private European investment pool and, in 1981 established a private investment company in New York to facilitate the re-allocation of his clients' assets into high-growth small capitalization equities in the United States, principally through a venture capital investment program. Having retired from active management, in recent years Mr. Hoener sought to promote venture capital investment in Europe and was honored by the ETH Zurich for initiating and sponsoring a highly successful lecture series on venture capital held in Zurich and St. Gallen. Mr. Hoener received awards from both Germany and the United States of America in recognition of his contributions to the promotion of German-American relations. For many years, he was a member of the board of directors of the American Institute for Contemporary German Studies. In addition to funding many other charitable causes, he was a principal supporter of the Fulbright Scholarship Program. His philanthropic efforts brought Mr. Hoener many commendations from governments and from private organizations. Most recently, he was cited by President Clinton for his work in connection with the Fulbright Program. Mr. Hoener is survived by his wife, Stephanie and his son, Philip. There will be a funeral mass at 10;30 am on Thursday, the 25th of January, at the Sacre Coeur du Prado church, Avenue du Prado, Cannes. In lieu of flowers, and in accordance with Mr. Hoener's wishes, memorial donations may be sent to: The Honeypot Charity, Barclay's Bank, Bracknell Branch, Bank Sort Code 20 - 11 - 74, Account Number 40762563, Codeword: Hoener

Ownership is theft, they tell their victims, quoting the 19th-century French socialist Pierre Prudhon. Their goal, a retrospective voice-over explains, is to abolish injustice and the state.

title: New Jersey Officials to Try to Recover Badges That Sheriff Illegally Sold
description: As a close aide to the ousted Bergen County sheriff pleaded guilty today to illegal fund-raising in the office, law enforcement officials said they would try to retrieve special badges improperly doled out to contributors last year.

title: INSURER SOLD TO BRITISH COMPANY
description: The Orient Corporation, a leading Japanese consumer credit company, said it would sell its Orico Life Insurance unit to Prudential P.L.C., a major British insurer, for 23 billion yen ($197 million). Officials of Prudential, which is not related to the Prudential Life Insurance Company of the United States, said that Orico is financially and operationally sound. Through Orico, Prudential, which has made acquisitions and alliances in 11 Asian nations, gains a foothold in Japan, the world's largest life insurance market. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: THE BOSS; I Hope What I Do Matters
description: I don't want to wake up and be 70 and have wasted it. There's a Kris Kristofferson song that has the lyrics ''Lord help me, Jesus, I've wasted it.'' It's a great tragedy -- people who reach a point and realize that it wasn't enough.

title: A 'Ballo' Returns, Drama Unmasked, Under Domingo
description: ''Un Ballo in Maschera'' is an elegant opera. By the time he wrote it, Verdi was able with ease to turn a rather ordinary libretto -- with your standard Gypsy fortune teller, doomed passion and conspiracy to murder -- into an opera filled with melody and sparkling ensembles. ''Ballo'' exudes the light-hearted urbanity of its protagonist, King Gustav, a counterpart of the Duke of Mantua in ''Rigoletto'' without the amorality.

title: Park Avenue Hotel
description: The Doral Park Avenue, at 38th Street and Park in Manhattan, is offering rooms on Friday, Saturday and Sunday nights through March for $169, subject to availability. The 188 rooms and 3 suites have neoclassical-style furnishings, Italian marble baths, Frette bathrobes and a daily copy of The New York Times. Tax is extra. Also, American Express card holders get a rate of $179 a night, subject to availability, any night of the week through April 29. Contact the Doral at (877) 993-6725; www.doralparkavenue.com .

title: Killing of 2 Israelis Shuts Down the Mideast Talks, but Hope Is Still in the Air
description: The killing of two Israeli civilians by Palestinian militants today interrupted a new round of peace negotiations here, with Prime Minister Ehud Barak condemning the slayings as ''horrendous'' and ordering the three cabinet ministers in the talks to return to Jerusalem.

title: M.T.A. Head Expected to Announce Resignation
description: E. Virgil Conway, a trusted lieutenant to Gov. George E. Pataki who has presided over the Metropolitan Transportation Authority during almost six years of rebuilding and steadily rising ridership, is expected to announce today that he is stepping down as chairman of the agency.

Beloved husband of Janet (Wardle). Devoted father of Michael and Timothy. Fond brother of Anne, Mary, Buddy and Eileen. Alumnus All Hallows School, Fordham U., veteran US Army, retired VP of Norland Industries. He will be greatly missed by his family and friends. Funeral service 2PM, Saturday, January 27, Summit Presbyterian Church, 6757 Greene St. and Westview Ave., Phila., PA 19119. Family would appreciate donations in Tom's memory to Fox Chase Cancer Center, Dept. Medical Oncology-Dr. Naomi Haas, 7701 Burlholme Ave., Phila. PA 19111.

A Salvador Dali sketch hung on the wall across from him, a gift from Freddy Mercury of Queen, who, after headlining the first Rock in Rio festival in 1985, was impressed enough to ask Dali to create something for Mr. Medina, a Brazilian impresario.

title: Where Food and Talk Coexist
description: NEW YORK restaurant fatigue can strike without warning. It can happen 30 minutes into an hourlong wait for a table at the newest downtown hot spot. It can descend when the waiter brings over an amuse-bouche, calls it an ''amusay'' and proceeds to tick off an incomprehensible list of ingredients that probably include the words ''cilantro'' and ''foam'' too close together. Suddenly, a profound sense of ennui envelopes the table. Existential questions pop up and expand like a giant souffle: Why am I here? What is the point? When can I leave?

title: Ruling Could Hurt Efforts to Ban Masked Rallies
description: A Manhattan Criminal Court judge ruled yesterday that a New York State law prohibiting masked gatherings does not apply to peaceful political rallies, a decision that could undermine efforts to ban masked rallies by groups like the Ku Klux Klan.

title: J. C. PENNEY PLANS TO CLOSE UP TO 50 STORES
description: The J. C. Penney Company, the retail chain based in Plano, Tex., said yesterday that it planned to close as many as 50 department stores around the country as part of its new chairman's strategy to cut costs and revive profits. Company and shopping mall executives said the stores at the Galleria mall in White Plains; the Harrisburg East Mall in Harrisburg, Pa.; and the Sierra Shopping Center in Susanville, Calif., were among those that would be closed. Penney's chairman, Allen L. Questrom, was hired in September to turn around J. C. Penney, which has had falling profit or a loss for five quarters.

title: Sports of The Times; This Player Saved A Life, Not a Game
description: MARK SMITH could easily have ducked for cover when he saw the flames racing through the car, but he could not ignore the pair of hands flailing through the back window.

Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 St, Wednesday, January 24, 7 to 9 PM. Memorial service to be announced at a later date. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him.

title: Bush Calls for School Vouchers but Includes Some of Democrats' Ideas
description: WASHINGTON  President George W. Bush unveiled a program designed to shore up education at the country's weaker public schools  his top priority, he said  and did so in a way that might hint at his governing style: by insisting on more than he is expected to get but adding aspects of a Democratic plan to broaden the appeal.

title: Last 2 Texas Fugitives Are Captured
description: DENVER, Jan. 24  The last two of seven fugitives from Texas were apprehended early this morning in Colorado Springs, ending an exhaustive 42-day search for men whom the authorities believe killed a police officer 11 days after they escaped from a maximum security prison.

title: Poll Watch: Mixed Views on Bush
description: Americans hold a number of ambivalent or seemingly contradictory views about George W. Bush, according to a recent CBS News Poll taken shortly before Mr. Bush was sworn in as the 43rd president.

title: So You Think Your Kitchen Is Small?
description: YOU may have been to Caviar Russe on Madison Avenue. You may have sat on its plush banquettes and lingered over the tasting menu, beginning with a selection of caviars on abalone spoons and sampling your way through 10 courses, including scallops and foie gras, halibut with smoked pheasant, sweetbreads with cranberries and porcini jus.

title: MARCHFIRST TO CUT 550 MORE JOBS
description: MarchFirst, the new-economy consulting company, said yesterday that it would cut an additional 550 jobs and close offices just two months after cutting 1,000 workers. The moves are meant to stem losses as part of a larger revamping. The company, which is based in Chicago, hopes to bolster its business and its sagging stock price. The job cuts will drop the company's employee total to 7,600; the office closings will be in Pittsburgh and Montreal.

title: And the Serpent Said, Have a Bite of Chocolate
description: The little storefront, rimmed in Christmas lights and carrying a mysterious name, El Eden, suggests that a fortuneteller waits inside. On the contrary, this boutique at 46-20 30th Avenue in Astoria, Queens, is a den of indulgence, selling handmade chocolate truffles in more than a dozen flavors.

title: Putin Writes to Bush, Urging Warmer Russia-U.S. Relations
description: MOSCOW, Jan. 24  President Valdimir V. Putin sent a letter to President Bush this week proposing broader Russian-American cooperation and setting out the major issues on which he believes the two countries can cooperate, the Kremlin's press service said today.

title: Mexicans Seen Waiting Some More for a Phone
description: In the days when Mexico's government ran the telephone company, people said the only way to get a phone line was to wait for a relative to die. All that was supposed to change in 1990, when the state sold the monopoly to Telefonos de Mexico, or Telmex, with a promise to promote efficiency and a competitive spirit in the industry.

title: A Downturn?In Asia, Few Are Very Worried
description: SINGAPORE  After two consecutive years of stronger-than-expected expansion, Asia's developing and newly industrialized economies are set to slow significantly in 2001, while Japan, the region's dominant economy, is likely to limp along at a sluggish rate, as it has for nearly a decade.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  KARCHMER, HARRIET
description: KARCHMER-Harriet. On December 24, 2000. Born Springfield, MO February 19, 1925. A Tulane Univ. graduate, she translated Russian documents for U.S. government. In NY, she organized trade shows and promoted the work of an antiZionist Orthodox Jewish group. A tireless champion of Palestinian rights, she contributed her writing skills, brilliant historicism and extensive archives to many writers and researchers advancing a humanitarian agenda. Her wise counsel and loving kindness are missed by countless friends.

description: Presidential food tasters, whose main responsibility is to see that the president is not poisoned at home or abroad, had an added responsibility at last week's inauguration that may have struck those who read about it as baffling.

description: BALLARD POWER SYSTEMS, Burnaby, British Columbia, a fuel cell maker, said it had received a $1.3 million order from Honda Motor Co.'s research unit, which is competing to put an environmentally friendly car on the road.

description: UNDER a roofed podium inside Raymond James Stadium yesterday, Ray Lewis had several microphones in his face.

title: Supremacist Who Killed Postal Worker Avoids Death Sentence
description: The self-proclaimed white supremacist who sprayed automatic gunfire in a Jewish community center filled with children here 18 months ago, then confessed to murdering a letter carrier he later chanced upon because he was Filipino, will plead guilty Wednesday morning to 16 felony counts in return for a sentence that will allow him to avoid the death penalty, officials with knowledge of the case said.

title: BUSH ADDS 2 WEEKS TO ORDERS ENSURING CALIFORNIA POWER
description: President Bush agreed today to extend for two weeks federal orders that require power producers to sell surplus electricity and natural gas to California. But his administration warned the state that it would have to resolve the crisis on its own after that.

title: The Way to End Term Limits
description: Almost eight years ago, New York City residents voted to limit the number of consecutive terms that elected officials could serve. It was a fundamentally unsound decision, infringing on the basic right of future voters to choose whether to retain a particularly effective politician or throw a particular rascal out. The policy needs to be overturned -- but only by another referendum, not by members of the City Council trying to get around what they see as a punitive and inconvenient law.

title: EXCITE@HOME TO LAY OFF 250 EMPLOYEES
description: Blaming in large part a slowdown in Internet advertising, Excite@Home yesterday announced layoffs of 250 employees, or 8 percent of its work force. The company, which provides high-speed Internet access and operates several Web sites, including the Excite.com Web portal and bluemountain.com, also said it planned to close its offices in Seattle and Austin, Tex. Alison Bowman, a company spokeswoman, said the layoffs were concentrated among employees who work on content at Excite Studios, the unit that operates the company's Web sites. The company is based in Redwood City, Calif. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: E*TRADE LEAVING NASDAQ FOR NEW YORK STOCK EXCHANGE
description: The E*Trade Group, the online broker that helped fuel trading on the Nasdaq market, said yesterday that it planned to move its listing to the New York Stock Exchange. The surge in the Nasdaq's composite index led to a gain of more than 900 percent in E*Trade's stock price from 1996, when it was first sold, until the end of 1999. E*Trade's shares, which fell 72 percent in 2000 as the Nasdaq plunged, are 19 percent higher than their initial price of $10.50 a share. It is the latest technology-related company to switch exchanges; Global Crossing moved to the New York Exchange in November.

description: With one-third of the world's work force unemployed or underemployed, at least 500 million new jobs will be needed over the next decade to accommodate new arrivals in the job market and help reduce global unemployment by half, the International Labor Office says in a new report.

title: Metro Business Briefing; MADISON SQUARE CAMPUS ADVANCES
description: Credit Suisse First Boston took another step toward creating a corporate campus in the Madison Square neighborhood yesterday, when the investment bank agreed to lease 1 Madison Avenue from MetLife. First Boston's headquarters is next door, at 11 Madison Avenue, and the company recently rented 12 floors nearby, at 315 Park Avenue South. The company said the three buildings would house most of First Boston's 8,500 employees in New York City. First Boston will occupy a 1.4 million-square-foot structure at 1 Madison, which is connected to the bank's headquarters by an underground passageway and an enclosed walkway at the 10th floor. The bank will sublease the adjoining 41-story tower, also at 1 Madison Avenue back to MetLife, which will keep its headquarters and 500 employees there. But MetLife will be moving about 1,700 other employees, according to real estate executives.

title: Metro Business Briefing; GENERATOR SITE PROPOSED
description: Senator Charles E. Schumer suggested yesterday that the New York Power Authority place a new generator on property owned by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority in Long Island City, rather than on vacant land next to the Silvercup Studios, which is concerned about its noise. Officials at the state agency previously said they had ruled out the suggested location because of several problems, including the lack of a gas connection. Mr. Schumer said he had worked out a deal with Con Edison for a connection at a cost of $2 million, and officials at the power agency said they would study the proposal. Dean Murphy (NYT)

title: Corrections

He meant that in golf Mr. Clinton would lose the privilege of skipping the putt when the ball was close to the hole.

Its two characters are unimaginative suburban Americans -- Emma, a woman in her 60's, and her 30-ish daughter Terri -- and their relationship belongs on a talk segment moderated by Ricki Lake or, to invoke Terri's own heroine, Oprah Winfrey, with a title like ''How Do I Cope with My Daughter's Self-Esteem Problems?''

title: Practicing at Carnegie For a Program in Spain
description: Jesus Lopez-Cobos is about to turn over the reins of the Cincinnati Symphony to the promising young conductor Paavo Jarvi, but he still has some touring on his agenda: on Monday evening he led the orchestra at Carnegie Hall, and after a stop in Cincinnati to change luggage, he is to take the ensemble and the evening's program to Spain. That probably explains the evident care the orchestra took in preparing its account of Falla's ''Three-Cornered Hat,'' Suites 1 and 2, the closing work on the program and by far the most rhythmically vital and finely polished performance of the evening.

title: RECORD LABEL SETTLES WITH NAPSTER
description: TVT Records, a New York-based independent record label, has withdrawn its lawsuit against Napster, the first time a label has settled with the embattled Internet music start-up. Under the agreement, users of the Napster service will be allowed to exchange songs to which TVT owns the copyrights. Steve Gottlieb, president and founder of TVT, will act as an adviser to Napster, the companies said. Napster and TVT did not, however, disclose the other terms of the settlement, such as whether and how TVT will be compensated. Napster, an explosively popular service with 56 million registrants that has engendered the ire of the record industry because it permits free exchange of copyrighted music, remains in litigation against the five major record labels. TVT filed its lawsuit last June in Federal District Court in New York. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: Extending the Life And Lore of Graffiti

title: PUBLISHER TO LAY OFF 130 AND CLOSE OFFICES IN 3 CITIES
description: Hungry Minds, the publisher of the ''For Dummies'' instructional books and Cliffs Notes, said yesterday that it would lay off about 130 workers, or 19 percent of its employees, to cut costs. The company said it would save $10 million in 2001 as a result of the layoffs and $16 million annually after that. Hungry Minds, based in New York, said demand had fallen in its computer book business and sales had slumped on its Internet sites and in retail bookstores. The company also said it was lowering fiscal 2001 earnings estimates to 10 cents a share from 50 cents and it would close offices in Chicago, San Francisco and Foster City, Calif.

title: Well-Known Skyscraper Sold to Little-Known Family

title: Metro Business Briefing; MILLSTONE SALE APPROVED
description: The Connecticut Department of Public Utility Control yesterday approved the $1.3 billion purchase of two of the three Millstone nuclear power plants in Waterford by Dominion Resources of Virginia. The Connecticut Light and Power Company, a subsidiary of Northeast Utilities, and the United Illuminating Company are selling all of Millstone 2 and more than 90 percent of Millstone 3, in which some minority owners are retaining stakes. The purchase remains subject to approval by the federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission. Millstone 1, shut in 1995 because of operating problems, is being decommissioned. Joseph P. Fried

title: Colombia Adds Troops at Rebel Zone as Deadline Nears

title: Ex-Giant Ingram Faces Counterfeiting Charge
description: Mark Ingram, who played with the Giants' winning Super Bowl XXV team, remained in jail tonight after being charged on Tuesday by Miami-Dade County police with two counts of automobile theft. The Secret Service is also expected to take Ingram into custody on a federal charge of possession of counterfeit money after a bond hearing Thursday, The Associated Press is reporting.

title: DELL AND UNISYS EXPAND ALLIANCE
description: Dell Computer and Unisys said yesterday that they had completed plans announced last month to expand their marketing alliance and that the new arrangements were expected to generate $1 billion in added sales. Unisys will resell a number of Dell midrange servers under its own brand and market Dell personal computers to Unisys customers. Unisys's high-end CMP computers, which cluster up to 32 Intel processors, will become Dell's main product for the large-computer market.

title: Greenspan Hints Tax Cuts Might Help Weak Economy
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 25  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said today what many Americans have been feeling the last few months: that the economy has slowed sharply. Using the extra-cautious language that is his trademark, Mr. Greenspan indicated that some tax cuts might be a good idea.

title: BB&T TO ACQUIRE 2 MORE BANKS IN SOUTHEAST
description: The BB&T Corporation, the fifth-largest bank in the Southeast, said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the F&M National Corporation and Virginia Capital Bancshares for $1.35 billion in stock to increase its market share in northern Virginia and metropolitan Washington. BB&T, which acquired five banks in 2000, will pay $1.17 billion for F&M National, exchanging 1.09 shares of BB&T for each F&M National share. That values the acquisition at $40.67 a share of F&M, a 47 percent premium above Tuesday's closing price. Separately, BB&T said it would exchange 0.4958 to 0.606 of a share for each Virginia Capital share, depending on BB&T's average price over a 10-day period before Virginia Capital's shareholders vote on the acquisition. The transaction is now valued at $180.5 million, or $18.50 a share, a 9.8 percent discount to Tuesday's closing price.

title: Is Cindy Crawford A Bad Neighbor?
description: THE model Cindy Crawford and the nightclub entrepreneur Rande Gerber spend most of their time in Los Angeles. But they keep a co-op apartment in Manhattan at 33 East 70th Street, where they now find themselves squaring off with their neighbors. Last week, when the couple arrived in New York to open Mr. Gerber's new nightspot, the Underbar on Union Square, they said they were surprised to find themselves defendants in a lawsuit filed Jan. 10 by Marina and John French, their downstairs neighbors. The suit asserted that the Frenches' lives had been disrupted since 1998 by ''intolerable noises'' from upstairs, in particular ''the intimate sounds of daily life.''

The new venture, to be called Detergentes Bombril, will assume control of three of Bombril's plants to manufacture detergents and other household products under the Bom Bril brand. Bombril, which is controlled by the Italian company Cirio, leads the market in household cleaning products. Last year, Clorox bought Bombril's cleaning utensils businesses in Colombia, Venezuela and Peru. Jennifer L. Rich (NYT)

title: Pardons on the Sly
description: Anger over Bill Clinton's abuse of the pardoning process mounted yesterday, as well it should. This page has criticized Mr. Clinton for his last-minute pardon of the fugitive commodities trader Marc Rich. But a broader look at Mr. Clinton's final pardon list makes clear that the outrage extends well beyond the undeserved leniency for Mr. Rich. We are particularly troubled by the numerous instances in which Mr. Clinton granted pardons or commutations without proper consultation with federal prosecutors, often to reward friends or political allies or gain future political advantage.

title: KIMBERLY-CLARK TO BUY ITALIAN DIAPER MANUFACTURER
description: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation has agreed to buy Italy's No. 2 diaper manufacturer, Linostar, from the Bolton Group to help expand its Huggies sales internationally. Terms were not disclosed. Kimberly-Clark will sell diapers under the Lines name in Italy for a few months, then market the diapers with the Huggies name, its president, Thomas Falk, said yesterday in a conference call for analysts. Linostar has almost $100 million a year in sales, he said. Costs of the purchase, introduction of a moistened toilet tissue in the United States and higher energy costs will slow Kimberly-Clark's earnings growth in the next two quarters, but the company will still increase earnings at least 10 percent a share for 2001, Mr. Falk said in the call.

title: JAPANESE CHEMICAL COMPANY ADMITS HELPING FIX PRICES
description: Ueno Fine Chemicals Industry, based in Japan, has agreed to plead guilty and pay an $11 million fine for its role in a 17-year conspiracy to fix the price of a food preservative, the Justice Department said yesterday. Three top Ueno executives were indicted yesterday in San Francisco by a federal grand jury, the Justice Department said. They are: Yuji Komatsu, a Ueno board member; Yoshihiko Katsuyama, a general manager of sales; and Wakao Shinoda, a sales manager. The conspiracy involved preservatives called sorbates.

The property code must be provided when reserving. The Comfort Inn and Suites in Carbondale, Colo. (code CO116), between Vail and Aspen, has rates from $89. The rates start at $79 at two other Colorado Comfort Inns: in Avon (CO052) and Dillon (CO001). In New Hampshire, the Comfort Inns in Ashland (NH022) and Lincoln (NH009) start at $79, too. And the Comfort Inn in Killington (VT401) has rates starting from $75. To reserve, call (800) 228-5150 or (800) 517-4000.

title: Saarinen's Classic Vassar Dorm Is 50's New Again
description: Frances Fergusson, the president of Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., is part academic, part patron of architecture (she commissioned Cesar Pelli to design the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center, finished in 1993) and part preservationist. In 1998, she started restoring the Emma Hartman Noyes House, a 1958 dormitory by Eero Saarinen. The house had grown sadly shabby. Tables were scratched, and most of the Saarinen Tulip and Womb chairs had disappeared. The lounge's sunken conversation pit, above (known as the passion pit), was originally upholstered in mauve, orange and green, but was redone in the 70's in drab brown. Dr. Fergusson was partly inspired by the students. ''They had a prescient appreciation of the 1950's before the 50's became so popular and had always referred to the lounge as the Jetson Lounge,'' she said. ''It was a fun project to do, because the bones were all there.''

title: Broad Cuts at Lucent Include 10,000 Jobs
description: Lucent Technologies, one of the world's biggest makers of communications equipment, announced a broad reorganization that includes eliminating 10,000 jobs, about 9.4 percent of its workers. Fifteen hundred of those are to be in New Jersey, where the company employs 17,000 people. Throughout Lucent, many cuts will come in overlapping sales and marketing groups.

title: GLOBAL JOBLESS REPORT
description: A United Nations employment survey found that 160 million people are jobless, 20 million more than before Asia's 1997 financial crisis. Growth in labor supply and loss of jobs from restructuring are the causes, said authors of the study, the World Employment Report 2001. The technology revolution has not reached many parts of the world, leaving an estimated 1 billion, or one-third of the world's work force, unemployed or underemployed, the International Labor Organization said in the report, which is published every two years.

There on screen are its still-tatty rooms ($14 a night), its heavy brick facade, the cracked sidewalks outside and, nearby, the other sad, fallen buildings in Los Angeles's impoverished, abandoned core.

title: At the South Pole, Acting as Her Own Diagnostician, Physician and Savior

While working in Antarctica, she diagnosed her own breast cancer but could not be flown out until the worst of winter had passed. It sounded like a painful twist on a cliche: we can send a man to the moon but we can't get someone out of the South Pole? Yet the extreme cold made landing a plane impossible, and Dr. Nielsen was forced to treat herself medically until the Air Force rescued her several months later.

Minority shareholders have been trying to block the auctions over concern that their interests would be compromised by mergers that are expected to take place after the licenses are sold. title: Keeping a World Pairs Title Despite an Early Disaster
description: The best players in the world regularly gather in the Netherlands in January for the Cap Gemini World Top Pair tournament. But the 16-pair field in The Hague last week was not as strong as usual: the Italian stars who have dominated world play in recent years were missing because of a tournament in Australia, as were some of the top American partnerships. Even so, nearly half the players were former world champions.

title: Capriati Reaches Her First Slam Final
description: The stifling humidity had left Lindsay Davenport with molasses in her blood and lead in her shoes, while an energized Jennifer Capriati kept bouncing on the court like a boxer on canvas.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: INTEL CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., said Craig Barrett, its chief executive, planned to sell 400,000 common shares of company stock valued at $13.2 million, according to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The document, dated Jan 22., was filed one week after Intel forecast that its first-quarter sales would fall 15 percent from the fourth-quarter level.

title: Bush Team Tiptoeing Around Mideast
description: In contrast to the frenetic dealings between the Clinton administration and Israeli-Palestinian negotiators in the last several months, senior Bush officials are taking a more subdued approach with the latest round of talks.

title: Rosebrook Canyon's Snowy Abyss Beckons
description: The sign at the head of Rosebrook Canyon, a narrow, twisting downhill trail in this White Mountain resort, does not exactly warm the heart. ''Do not ski alone,'' it cautions.

title: Tale of the Jumbuck and the Billabong, Interpreted
description: TO many people around the globe, the biggest surprise at the Sydney Olympics last year wasn't the winners but the music. It turns out there are three Australian anthems. There is the Australian Australian anthem, ''Advance Australia Fair,'' which was so unpopular in some quarters that it was actually rescinded as the national anthem from 1977 to 1984. There is the royal Australian anthem, ''God Save the Queen,'' sung whenever the queen is present.

title: Rats May Dream, It Seems, Of Their Days at the Mazes
description: Elephants dream of munching sweet grass under a starry savannah sky. Dogs, paws aquiver, tails thumping faintly in slumber, chase squirrels in the park. And cats, of course, dream of mice.

title: Chase Ends With Driver Dead And Passenger Facing Charges
description: A police chase early this morning in which Newark officers exchanged shots with two men in a sport utility vehicle ended in East Orange with the driver dead and his passenger charged with killing him, the Essex County prosecutor said.

title: Making Waves Is Nothing New for Met's Maverick
description: Count on Joseph Volpe to stir things up, to use his powerful position as general manager of the Metropolitan Opera to jolt the $1.5 billion renovation plan for Lincoln Center by pulling out the Met and announcing plans to proceed with its refurbishment independently. It is frustrating, no doubt, to the other Lincoln Center arts organizations involved in the program, but knowing Mr. Volpe as they do, probably not all that surprising.

title: ERROR DOWNS SEVERAL MICROSOFT SITES
description: Microsoft took most of the day yesterday to fix ''an operational error'' that shut out millions of users from its group of Web sites starting Tuesday night. Sites including Microsoft.com, MSN.com, MSNBC.com, WindowsMedia.com, Expedia.com and Carpoint.com were unavailable nearly 24 hours. The problem also crippled some of the company's European Web sites. Adam Sohn, a Microsoft spokesman, attributed the problem to an incorrect configuration change by a Microsoft technician. The problem limited access to the domain name system, or D.N.S., server, which translates a domain name into a numerical Internet address. ''This was an operational error,'' the company said in a statement, ''and not the result of any issue with Microsoft or third-party products nor the security of our networks.'' Earlier, a spokesman ruled out a denial-of-service attack, in which a malicious computer program sends thousands of requests for information to a site, swamping the servers. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Even Without Hampton, Hough Still Likes Mets' Staff
description: The most fun you can have in coaching, Charlie Hough said yesterday, is at Class A. Some pitchers do not know how to throw a pitchout; others have never thrown a changeup. A coach's job is to teach.

title: ALCAN PROFIT FALLS
description: One-time charges mainly related to its takeover of Alusuisse Group Ltd. resulted in a 43 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit for Alcan Aluminium of Canada to $110 million, or 34 cents a share. That was below the 42 cents a share forecast by analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial. The interim president and chief executive, William Blundell, who replaced Jacques Bougie earlier this month, said ''weakening economic conditions will affect aluminum demand during the next couple of quarters.'' Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

title: HOMEBUILDER BID RAISED
description: The British homebuilder Persimmon raised its offer for Beazer Group to $:538 million ($791 million) to try to bring to a close weeks of takeover skirmishes between four of the industry's leading players. Under the terms of the new offer, each Beazer share would be exchanged for 109 pence in cash and 0.3086 new Persimmon share. Persimmon said its bid was $:47 million higher than its previous bid and represented a premium of 43 percent to the closing price of Beazer shares on Dec. 13, the day before Beazer announced a merger-of-equals with the Bryant Group. That deal collapsed when Taylor Woodrow agreed to buy Bryant on Monday for $:535 million. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Petitgout Hurt in Practice
description: The Giants' starting right tackle, Luke Petitgout, injured his left ankle during today's practice when a teammate rolled backward over Petitgout's lower leg. According to an account by a pool reporter watching the Giants' practice, Petitgout was injured during a full-squad running play. Afterward, Petitgout's ankle was heavily taped and iced. The report said Petitgout threw down his helmet leaving the practice field after the injury.

title: Nostalgia for the News Scoop And the Old Tin-Pot Despot
description: Forget the beat, beat, beat of the tom-tom. Nobody ever really filed stories that way anyhow. The real music in the Jean Cocteau Repertory's revival of Tom Stoppard's ''Night and Day'' is heard just before the lights come up, when the metallic clickety-clack of an old typewriter -- a vintage Underwood or possibly a Remington to these ears -- permeates the darkness. For veteran hacks who spent their youth chasing headlines there is no sweeter sound.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  DILLOF, CAROLYN
description: DILLOF-Carolyn. On January 22, 2001, age 52, after a brief battle with pancreatic cancer. She was born in Philadelphia, where she received her R.N. from Philadelphia General Hospital School of Nursing. She had been a resident of Great Neck, NY for 28 years and an Assistant Librarian at the Lakeville Elementary School for the past 12 years. She is survived by her daughter and son, Emily and Thomas Dillof, her mother Jacqueline Frank, and her siblings Jim Bell, Sheila Hutnick, Dan Bell, Christine Ockenlander and Jeanne DiLeonardo. A memorial servicwill be held on Saturday, January 27, 2001 at 1:00 p.m. at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation at 48 Shelter Rock Rd., Manhasset, NY. In lieu of flowers please send donations in Carolyn's name to either Planned Parenthood of Nassau County, 540 Fulton Ave., Hempstead, NY 11550 or GMHC, 119 West 24 St., NY, NY 10011.

title: Metro Business Briefing; UNFREE VERSE
description: It seems that 10 months in jail have inspired Dana C. Giacchetto, the former ''investment adviser to the stars'' who pleaded guilty to stealing millions from his clients, to get in touch with his Homeric side. During a sentencing hearing on Jan. 17, Mr. Giacchetto submitted a plea for leniency to Judge Robert P. Patterson Jr. of Federal District Court in Manhattan in the form of a handwritten 10-page poem titled ''Pontifex Vivam.'' Among its lines: ''On approaching that revered bench, one resounding note contains a pantheon of centrifugal light,'' and ''Does Apollo breathe the same as you and I, upon the approach beyond reproach?'' Edward Wong

title: A Playground for Feld at Balanchine Tribute
description: Bach's organ music is heard loud and clear via an amazing high-tech system in the New York State Theater. A cast of 63 fills the stage, which is extended by a 14-foot apron over the orchestra pit. Maria Kowroski, one of the New York City Ballet's golden girls, is literally stretched to the utmost as a high-class contortionist. Damian Woetzel, the company's great virtuoso, is just as literally wound up in a white cloth like a mummy. And yet, earlier, he has one of the longest and most difficult male solos in the repertory.
