During the campaign, the Bush team asserted that extended peacekeeping in the region is Europe's responsibility, not ours, and that long-term ''nation building'' missions only degrade our troops' combat readiness over time.

title: T-ONLINE POSTS LOSS
description: T-Online, the Internet subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom, said it ran a big loss last year even though its sales climbed sharply. On a cash-flow basis, before accounting for taxes, interest and depreciation, the company lost 125 million euros, or about $116 million. Though analysts had expected a big loss, several said the results raised new questions about the quality of T-Online's sales. Profits from access fees evaporated as the company offered customers low monthly flat rates. And although revenue from advertising and e-commerce climbed 75 percent, analysts said more than half that growth came from sales to the parent company, Deutsche Telekom. Edmund L. Andrews (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, DR. BENJAMIN
description: MARGOLIS-Dr. Benjamin. It is with profound sadness that the Board of Directors, students and faculty of the Mid-Manhattan Institute for Psychoanalysis mourn the death of a pioneer of Modern Psychoanalysis, Dr. Benjamin David Margolis. He was a brilliant communicator of modern psychoanalytic theory and technique, an elegant thinker, a stimulating and supportive teacher, and a man of great wisdom and kindness. His papers on modern psychoanalysis have taught generations of clinicians how to apply Dr. Spotnitz's techniques with narcissistic patients. He welcomed MMI into the community and championed its directors, always encouraging them to step forward with their ideas. A man of capacious mind and heart, he was unique and is completely unforgettable. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Deborah Margolis, his wife; to his daughter, Helen Michael, and her husband, Mel, and to their family. In Dr. Margolis' honor we are establishing a new scholarship fund to help candidates complete the training program. Donations to the Benjamin Margolis Scholarship Fund may be made in care of MMI, 239 Central Park West, Suite 1AS, New York, NY 10024.

title: I.B.M. TO SELL SERVICES FOR BLACKBERRY PAGER
description: I.B.M. said yesterday that it would bolster its wireless consulting business by helping companies link workers remotely to corporate data using the BlackBerry pager made by Research in Motion Ltd. I.B.M., the No. 1 provider of computers and related services, will train specialists and offer services specially designed for the BlackBerry, an enhanced pager that includes electronic mail and network access, said Val Rahmani, who heads I.B.M.'s global wireless programs. Terms were not disclosed. BlackBerry is a wireless two-way pager with a small keyboard that lets users send and receive information, including e-mail messages, via radio waves.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 9 about a visit to Africa by Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori of Japan misstated the amount and ranking of his country's budgeted overseas development aid. For the 1999-2000 fiscal year the aid was about $15 billion, not $10 billion. Thus Japan ranked ahead of the United States and Germany, not equal to them, and was not surpassed by France.

title: New York Area Has a Cushion, Economists Say
description: Last week, Jupiter Media Metrix joined the list of Internet companies in Manhattan's Silicon Alley planning to cut jobs. On Tuesday, AOL Time Warner said it would eliminate some positions at its magazine division. That same day, J. C. Penney announced that it would close a store in Westchester County.

title: LONDON EXCHANGE CONFIRMS LEADER

The 200-year-old institution named Oscar Fanjul, chairman of Hydroelectrica del Cantabrico; Nigel Stapleton, chairman of Veronis Suhler; Robert Webb, a legal executive at British Airways; and Janet Cohen, advisory director at HSBC, to replace board members from financial institutions including Goldman, Sachs and Credit Suisse First Boston. title: Can You Hum a Few Bars of the Atrium?
description: Design, music and fashion are cross-pollinating as never before. Allen Clapp, the lead singer and a songwriter for the Orange Peels, a band in Sunnyvale, Calif., is doing his bit. Mr. Clapp, in the foreground of the band, below, is an unabashed fan of Joseph Eichler, the 1950's builder who sold Modernist homes with flat roofs and atriums, floor-to-ceiling glass walls surrounding indoor gardens. Mr. Clapp grew up in an Eichler house in Foster City, Calif. As an adult, he and his wife, Jill Pries, saved for 10 years to buy an Eichler house, which they did last year, in Sunnyvale. So when Mr. Clapp designed the album art for the Orange Peel's newest CD, ''So Far'' (Spinart, $16), he chose pictures of his Eichler house. ''I suppose there's some sort of subliminal connection between our sound and the architecture,'' he said. ''Sort of a spacious kind of sound.''

description: In announcing that his first foreign trip as president will be to Mexico, George W. Bush is living up to his campaign pledge to forge a ''special relationship'' with that nation. Though that phrase is usually reserved for America's traditional friendship with Britain, Mr. Bush is right to set ambitious goals for strengthening relations with Mexico. Thanks to President Vicente Fox's electoral defeat of the long-ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party last year, a more democratic Mexico can be an important American ally in this hemisphere.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LONG, HARRY
description: LONG-Harry. Born April 15, 1912, died January 24, 2001. Beloved husband, father, grandfather and great-grandfather, passed yesterday after a valiant struggle with heart disease and its attendant difficulties. Harry leaves behind a legacy of commitment, wisdom and knowledge, business acumen and, most of all, love for his wife Irma, children Bob and Madeleine, grandchidren Amy and Terri, and great-grandchild Rebecca. Harry was born close to the Depression and struggled through it to found Long's Bedding in 1936, now in its seventh decade. With his wonderful wife he worked all his life to ensure that his children were enabled to succeed in whatever they choose to do. He leaves all of us richer and wiser and more able to face a future of challenge and unpredictability. Funeral today 12:00 noon, Riverside Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY.

title: NEW NETWORKING PRODUCTS FROM CISCO
description: Cisco Systems announced a new line of wireless networking products, designed to provide high-speed Internet access to laptop computers and hand-held devices, and said two major customers were already using the products. Microsoft and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill recently began using the newest version of the devices, called the Aironet 350 series, Cisco said. At the university, strong radio signals carry the Internet and e-mail access to the laptops of 3,400 freshmen, even through walls. North Carolina said it expected the network to connect 15,000 undergraduates by 2003. About 5,000 Microsoft employees have access to the network at their campus in Redmond, Wash., with plans to expand the access to 20,000 soon, Cisco said. Information sent across the wireless network is encrypted for security. 3Com unveiled a competing product for businesses, called AirConnect, earlier this week. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, DVORA (NEE WOLINSKY)
description: COOPER-Dvora (nee Wolinsky). On Saturday, Jan. 20, in York, PA. Born March 4, 1910, in Gomel, Russia. A graduate of the Workmen's Circle School, Wadleigh High School and the City College of New York, she was a trained classical pianist with her own weekly radio show on WEVD-FM and she danced with the companies of Katherine Dunham & Martha Graham. She was instrumental in the organization of numerous locals affiliated with the International Ladies Garment Workers Union. As the wife of the late Rabbi Eli Louis Cooper of Temple Beth Israel in York, PA., she served as rebitzen of the congregation, treasurer of its sisterhood, and editor of its bulletin for more than 20 years. She is survived by her daughter, Stephanie R. Cooper; son-in-law, Howard Weinberg, and her grandson, Joshua Cooper Olesker, all of New York City. Memorial contributions may be made to the Jacob T. Zukerman Fund of the Workmen's Circle, 45 East 33 Street, New York, New York 10016.

title: Senate Panel Gives Warm Reception to New Labor Nominee

title: The Perfect Score? How Does 3-0 Sound?

On the sideline during games, after an offense does all its shifts and motions and presnap tricks, he will yell the play, call it before it is run, and his defensive players will shake their heads in amazement, wondering who gave him the number to the football psychic hot line.

Maybe the young Vanessa Redgrave, Meryl Streep, Jason Robards and Al Pacino could have turned Lucy Thurber's ''Killers and Other Family'' into gripping, intelligent theater. But then again, maybe not.

title: PARTHUS POSTS 68% GAIN IN REVENUE
description: The Irish microchip designer Parthus Technologies announced a 68 percent increase in annual revenue, to $31.9 million, but a net loss of $16.1 million including compensation expenses and amortization for the year ended Dec. 31. Revenue from license sales rose threefold, as 32 customers bought the rights to use Parthus-designed microchips in their wireless devices. The company also announced that 3Com had purchased a license for all four of its chips, which include a mobile computing platform, a chip for wireless streaming of video and music, and a chip that lets cell phones use the global positioning system. Brian Long, above, the chief executive of Parthus, said that the company's wide range of intellectual property placed it in a strong position to ride out a possible slowdown in the cellular phone market. Brian Lavery (NYT)

title: ADOBE TO SPEND $50 MILLION TO EXPAND CENTER IN INDIA

Nearly all Adobe products now have some Indian-developed components, Mr. Chizen said. P.J. Anthony (NYT)

title: Ladyville Journal; Listen! In Belize's Jungles, It's the Voice of Britain

title: A Place to Put the Laptop When It's Time to Cross Your Legs
description: The problem with laptop computers is their name: the lap is actually the least comfortable place to put them. But as these powerful, versatile machines increasingly replace deskbound PC's, they have to go somewhere. Now, a new breed of laptop desk has emerged, allowing students, road warriors and stay-at-homes to type in comfort -- in ergonomically correct chairs, on sofas, even lying in bed. And for those who peruse their spreadsheets at Starbucks, there is a portable stand that folds compactly into a small bag.

title: Metro Business Briefing; QUEENS WEST DEVELOPER
description: City and state officials announced yesterday that they had designated LCOR, a national real estate company, to develop a $500 million commercial complex at the Queens West site on the waterfront at Hunters Point. LCOR is expected to break ground within three years to build five buildings, including a hotel, retail space and offices. The announcement came only months after AvalonBay Communities began work on the first of three apartment houses at the 74-acre Queens West site, across the East River from the United Nations. Those buildings will join Citylights, a 522-unit cooperative apartment house and the only new building on the site. The city, the state and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey have sought to develop the Queens waterfront since the early 1980's. Charles V. Bagli

title: 7 Charter Schools Approved, 4 of Them in New York City
description: The trustees of the State University of New York have approved seven new charter schools: four in New York City, two in Buffalo and one in Troy.

title: Luminously Appointed in Choicest Plastic
description: Bot, below, a restaurant that opened downtown in NoLIta this month, resembles an 1,800-square-foot plastic jewel box. White chairs and counter and the magenta and orange tables are plastic. The white curtains in front and the retractable ceiling in the rear are polyurethane. And everything, lighted from beneath, behind or above, glows. An undulating chartreuse wall hides pipes and makes the transition from inside to outside seamless. In summer, the rear will open onto a bamboo garden, and the white ceiling will retract, exposing the sky, and probably laundry on fire escapes. ''I wanted something 21st century and luminous -- although some people say it's so 60's,'' said Danny Emerman, a partner in Bot, a spinoff of his other restaurant, Bottino, in Chelsea. Mr. Emerman asked Thomas Leeser, a Manhattan architect, who designed Bottino, to do Bot, which is at 231 Mott Street (near Prince Street). Mr. Leeser chose plastic for two reasons: it's cheap and it's colorful.

title: To Record, Perhaps to Save, China's Endangered Old Houses
description: Can photographs save China's traditional architecture? ''Living Heritage: Vernacular Environment in China,'' an exhibition of more than 75 photographs, 40 of them by Li Yuxiang, documents ancestral halls, pagodas and courtyards. Since 1990, Mr. Li, who lives in Beijing, has been photographing China's disappearing traditional buildings. Entire tile-roofed villages (think ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon'') are threatened. In 1991, Mr. Li's photographs, like one of rammed-earth family dwellings in Fujian province, right, began appearing in books published in China. A local government in Wenzhou, a city in Zhejiang province, set aside funds to preserve old houses after his first book came out, he said. A catalog with more than 200 photographs is available for $49 at the China Institute, 125 East 65th Street. The show opens today and runs through June 10. Admission, $3; information, (212) 744-8181.

title: Money and the Mayoral Race
description: The nation looks to New York City's campaign financing system as the best and fairest way for candidates to run for public office. Untainted by big contributions, freed to campaign instead of groveling constantly for funds, candidates who participate in the city's program receive public matching funds as long as they follow the rules and reveal the details about how they get and spend their money. Now come troubling hints from Michael Bloomberg, the media billionaire, that he is thinking about running for mayor without participating in the city's voluntary campaign finance system. For a man new to campaigning, this decision could be a major political error. If Mr. Bloomberg runs, he should join in the system like everyone else.

title: Endangered Isles
description: The Galpagos Islands have belonged to Ecuador since 1832, just before Charles Darwin arrived on board the Beagle in 1835. Remote and biologically unspoiled as they were even then, the Galpagos were nonetheless already part of the larger world, a regular port of call. While it was true that on those reptilian islands ''the chief sound of life is a hiss,'' as Melville wrote, it was also true, according to Darwin's biographer, Janet Browne, that you could buy pigs and goats there or mail a letter. But the isolation that made the islands a perfect laboratory in which to study the variation of species as they occur in nature remained largely unviolated.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARTIN, EDWARD JOHN
description: MARTIN-Edward John. Of Florida and New York, 90, suddenly on January 22, 2001. Beloved husband of the late Katherine (nee Bennett). Survivors include his wife, Grace B. Schwefel Martin. Devoted father of Edward, Katherine, Elizabeth and Patricia, Karen S. Butler and Charles Schwefel, 7 grandchildren and 2 great grandchildren. Retired president of John P. Maguire & Co., New York City, who served his country honorably as a Lieutenant, U.S. Navy, during W.W. II. Dedicated treasurer of the Southside Hospital, director of the Friendly Sons of St. Patrick and member, Cardinal's Committee of the Laity. Memorials to Southside Hospital.

title: Chiquita Sues Europeans, Citing Banana-Quota Losses
description: In the latest move in an escalating trade dispute, Chiquita Brands International sued the executive body of the European Union yesterday for $525 million in damages related to banana quotas that the company contends have pushed it to the brink of bankruptcy.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MARGOLIS, DR. BENJAMIN D.
description: MARGOLIS-Dr. Benjamin D. Trusted, beloved, lifelong companion, friend and teacher of many years, brilliant pioneer of Modern Psychoanalysis, Mensch. Thank you and good-by. Dr. Ion Collas

title: Byrum's Putter Gives Magee Help On Double Eagle
description: Scores dropped faster than the desert temperature today in the first round of the Phoenix Open, which featured a tournament-record number of sub-par rounds and the rarest of double eagles, by Andrew Magee.

title: HARTFORD IS BUYING FORTIS UNIT FOR $1.1 BILLION
description: Hartford Financial Services said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire the variable life and annuity business of Fortis, Belgium's biggest financial services company, for $1.12 billion in cash. Hartford, the sixth-largest United States insurer by market value, said the purchase of the unit, Fortis Financial Group, would solidify its position in the variable annuities market and increase its mutual fund assets by more than 30 percent. As part of the transaction, Hartford will acquire Fortis Advisers, a subsidiary that acts as the investment adviser for the 38 Fortis mutual funds in the United States.

title: Fassel Turns to 2 Veterans
description: Giants Coach Jim Fassel has pushed all the right buttons with his team in the past two months. Now he'll try it one more time by asking the veterans Keith Hamilton and Lomas Brown to speak to the team before Super Bowl XXXV.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  EISENBERG, DR. WILLIAM
description: EISENBERG-Dr. William. The medical staff of NYU Downtown Hospital is deeply saddened by the loss of Dr. William Eisenberg, Director of Ophthalmology and member of the medical staff since 1983. We mourn his passing and extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife and family. Steven Brandeis, President Medical Staff NYU downtown Hospital

title: California's Lawmakers Submit an Energy Relief Proposal
description: Encouraged by signs that the state could persuade generating companies to sell power to California at sharply reduced prices, Gov. Gray Davis and legislative leaders have drafted a comprehensive financial package for resolving the simmering energy crisis.

title: Times Vice President For Labor Relations
description: The New York Times has promoted Jay I. Sabin, executive director for labor relations for the newspaper since 1999, to vice president for labor relations. Mr. Sabin, 35, will supervise dealings with 15 unions. He reports to Marc Z. Kramer, vice president for production and labor relations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Monday about the tradition of Saturday night bluegrass shows at a barn in Suwanee, Ga., misstated the age at which a picker, Jeff Deaton, first visited the barn. He was 6 days old, not 6 years.

title: Israeli Campaign Is Tepid Despite High Stakes
description: JERUSALEM, Jan. 26  When Israel and the Palestinians are simultaneously engaged in a violent conflict and peace negotiations, with the potential for their precarious relationship to disintegrate quickly, Israelis' choice of a leader could have far-reaching consequences.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: The city founded by the Dutch finally has a Dutch restaurant. It's NL, for the Netherlands, and it starts with a tremendous advantage: virtually no one has the slightest idea what Dutch cuisine is. In a bleak essay on the food of the Netherlands, the Oxford Companion to Food singles out stamppot (mashed potatoes and vegetables) and pap as the country's two crowning glories. Cheese, pancakes and beer are probably the only culinary contributions that have made any international impression.

title: Weekend Tips
description: Realistic Expectations

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MASLOW, ELEANOR
description: MASLOW-Eleanor. Wife of the late Louis, beloved mother of Richard and mother-in-law of Barbara, much loved grandmother of David and Cari; Jillian; Louis II (Chip) and Victoria (Tori), great grandmother of Emeline Eleanor.

title: On a Shoestring, Searching for a Vision
description: In the Hollywood version, Paul Gauguin (1848-1903) was the last 19th-century swashbuckler-artist and the first 20th century hippie.

title: The Driveway? In Another State; A Blunder in 1642 Creates Headaches Today For Homeowners Who Straddle a Border
description: Up here in the Notch, a tidy pocket of land where Connecticut borders Massachusetts on three sides, strange things happen to ordinary people.

title: A Museum Wins an Original Howdy
description: ''The Howdy Doody Show'' went off the air in 1960, but the adventures of Howdy hardly stopped then.

title: Journalist's Odyssey Leads to Philanthropy
description: THERE have been many things said about C. Shelby Coffey III. He is the courtly Southerner with oodles of charm who has occupied some of the biggest media jobs around.

title: WITH DEMAND STRONG, COMPANIES INCREASE BOND SALES
description: With demand strong, the American Tower Corporation, the nation's largest independent owner of broadcast-transmission towers, tripled its offering of high-yield bonds this week, to $1 billion from $350 million. Other companies also reported strong demand. Alamosa PCS Holdings increased its bond issue 25 percent, to $250 million; and Allied Waste Industries increased its bond sale 20 percent, to $500 million. Companies have raised more than $12 billion this year, a sum that is more than a quarter of all the bonds sold in 2000. Corporate treasurers are taking advantage of declining borrowing costs and a resurgence in investor appetite for bonds of lower-rated companies.

title: New Spending And Tax Cuts In '02 Budget
description: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, in his final budget plan, offered city residents a crowd-pleasing smorgasbord yesterday, with funds for new museums, low-cost housing and an extended school week and a sprinkling of new tax cuts on top.

title: ATI SELLS BROADCOM STAKE
description: ATI Technologies said it had sold its 494,000-share stake in Broadcom, the telecommunications chip maker, for a gain of about $54 million. ATI received the stake last month, when Broadcom bought SiByte Inc. ATI owned an 11 percent SiByte stake and exchanged shares in the company for Broadcom stock. ATI, which is based in Markham, Ontario, and is the world's biggest maker of graphics parts for PC's, has said it will use proceeds from the sale to finance operations. The company had a loss of $16.2 million in its latest quarter, in contrast to a year-earlier profit of $53.6 million.

title: Argentina Off to Fast Start This Year
description: After years of desultory results, the Buenos Aires stock market has begun the year by soaring 26 percent, easily beating every other stock exchange in the world.

title: 4 Who Got Leniency Defrauded U.S. for Religion
description: The school at the Toldos Yakov Yosef seminary in Brooklyn sounded noble and worthy. It offered needy students federal financial aid known as Pell Grants for close-in, independent study of Judaica under the guiding hands of mentors.

title: A Week in Prague
description: Afive-night stay in Prague starts at $499 a person, based on double occupancy, with Nordique Tours. The rates are valid through March ($599 in April) and include round-trip air fare from New York to Prague through Helsinki on Finnair, five nights in the Hotel Victor, daily breakfast and hotel transfers in Prague. There are six-night plans that combine Prague and Warsaw ($699), Prague and Budapest ($719) and Prague and Vienna ($725). Rates are valid through March and go up by $100 in April. A train ticket between cities is included in the price; weekend departures are $20 extra. Contact Nordique Tours at (800) 995-7997; fax (310) 645-1071.

title: WorldCom Expected to Cut Its Work Force by 10,000
description: WorldCom Inc. is expected to announce plans to lay off more than 10,000 employees, or 13 percent of its worldwide work force of 77,000, as the company seeks to cut costs at some of its slow-growing businesses, people close to the company said today.

title: Metro Business Briefing; LAND AVAILABLE
description: New York City has announced that it will accept proposals for the development of city-owned property at 16 locations for industrial, retail and residential use. The largest sites are a 107,000-square-foot plot in the Bathgate Industrial Park in the Bronx and two lots totaling 306,000 square feet in the College Point Corporate Park in Queens. Other sites include industrial properties and city-owned parking lots in Brooklyn and Queens. The city's Economic Development Corporation selects plans for city-owned land based on the offering price, an assessment of a project's economic viability, its impact on the surrounding community and the developer's experience. Proposals are due by March 29. Tara Bahrampour

title: Cairo Journal; Egyptians Tighten a Seat-Belt Law Till It Hurts
description: In a city where driving often seems more akin to performing interpretive dance than following mere traffic rules, drivers are trying to cope with the latest road shocker: the sudden, strict enforcement of mandatory seat-belt laws.

title: In Premier's Job, Where Quebec Lost an Orator, It Prepares to Gain an Accountant
description: Bernard Landry, the heir apparent to Quebec's premier, was all over the newspapers this week. Dressed in the uniform of finance ministers the world over -- white shirt, graying hair and wire-rimmed spectacles -- he lectured readers about the wonders of a new Norwegian factory here that will produce automobile suspension control arms made of an aluminum alloy.

title: Article 2001012691239312963 -- No Title
description: The New York Times: Technology-Text Version

title: Odds and Ends
description: The families of Giants players arrived in Tampa on Thursday, but they are not staying with the team. Giants Coach Jim Fassel has wanted to keep his players involved in their meetings, practices and film-study sessions. The players will be together with their families during their free time on Friday, but after that there will be little interaction until after Sunday's game.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDIN, EDYTHE (EDIE)
description: GOLDIN-Edythe (Edie). Passed away January 24, 2001, beloved wife of the late Louis, wonderful mother of Arlene & Helen, Roger and Jay, loving grandmother of Paul, Karen, Larry, and Andy, great grandmother of Alexandra, Matthew, Sarah, Stephanie, and Teddy. Funeral service at 9:45 A.M., Friday at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

title: Article 2001012693413555341 -- No Title
description: January 26, 2001

title: In the Whirl of Court Tennis, Where the Elite Meet to Swat
description: Idon't often rub shoulders with royalty. As Rodney Dangerfield might say, the closest I ever got was a pair of kings in a poker game.

title: Interpreting Mr. Greenspan
description: Alan Greenspan's endorsement of tax cuts in his Congressional testimony yesterday all but puts to rest the question of whether Congress will enact such cuts in the coming months. But President Bush ought to avoid the temptation to misread the Federal Reserve chairman's testimony to be an endorsement of his extreme 10-year, $1.6 trillion tax cut proposal. Tax cuts may be inevitable, but their scope remains very much a subject for debate. Indeed, on this score Mr. Greenspan offered some cautionary words that need to be heeded. He also countered the administration's specious argument that fiscal policy is the best means of jump-starting a slowing economy.

title: Economic Groups Call for New Power Supplies
description: Some of New York City's most powerful economic interest groups, including the Building and Construction Trades Council and the Real Estate Board, said yesterday that they feared that the city would face an energy crisis as early as this summer, and urged that new electricity supplies be installed as quickly as possible.

title: Dealers Triumph With Americana
description: The Americana sales last week at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York were successful, but two Manhattan dealers proved they could still hold their own against the auction houses.

title: RUSSIAN TELEVISION DISPUTE
description: Russia may force a management reshuffle at the country's biggest independent television station, NTV. NTV's biggest creditor, the state-controlled gas company, said it had become the largest shareholder in the network after it won a court order freezing a portion of NTV's shares and would seek to elect a new board . The media company, however, said legal precautions it had taken would block a reshuffle. Sabrina Tavernise (NYT)

title: Ashcroft Faces New Criticism Over Stand on Ambassador
description: A prominent gay philanthropist who is the former American ambassador to Luxembourg, James C. Hormel, said today that Attorney General-designate John Ashcroft misled the Senate Judiciary Committee last week about his involvement in an effort to block Mr. Hormel's ambassadorial appointment.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHAINHOLTZ, HENRY, CLU
description: SCHAINHOLTZ-Henry, CLU. Beloved husband of the late Pauline. Devoted father of Dr. Bernard and Joan Schainholtz and Rita and Michael Resnick. Cherished grandfather of Dana Schainholtz, Mara Schainholtz and her fiance, Tim, and Jennifer and Marc Devins. Adoring great grandfather of Samuel. Graduate of New York Law School. Service Friday January 26, 11 A.M. at ''Sinai Chapels'', 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

title: The Heat Gets to Rafter, but Agassi Stays Cool
description: All night long, Patrick Rafter looked as if he had just walked in from a downpour with the way his shirt stuck to his skin and his sneakers squished when he darted to the net.

title: Two Museums Celebrate Mies
description: Museums, even those perceived as competitors, have begun sharing in new ways. They have started buying artworks together, teaming up on Internet ventures and jointly hiring experts. Now, for the first time in memory, the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art will coordinate complementary exhibitions examining the work of Ludwig Mies van der Rohe.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about efforts by the Monsanto Company to influence government regulation of genetically engineered foods misstated the publication date of an essay by the company's former chief executive, Robert Shapiro, that acknowledged strategic errors by the company. The essay was published last year by Washington University in St. Louis, not this year.

title: Jerusalem, the Dream and Reality
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about a pickup in consumer spending reversed last year's and this year's statistics on the effectiveness of discounts in drawing customers to full-price merchandise. About one of every two consumers who buys a discounted item this January is also buying a product that is not on sale; last year the ratio was one in three.

title: Transcript of Thomas Georges Visit to the N.F.L. Forum
description: Thomas George, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, visited the forum on Jan. 26, to discuss the league and answer questions. Here is a transcript of the event.

title: White House Staff Detailing Damage by Its Predecessor
description: The White House is compiling a list of acts of vandalism by departing Clinton administration officials but has declined to open a formal investigation, Ari Fleischer, the press secretary, said today.

title: A Tough Act to Follow
description: Note: This lesson was originally published on an older version of The Learning Network; the link to the related Times article will take you to a page on the old site.

title: Invisible Lines Made For Raucous Disputes
description: In 1642, when Nathaniel Woodward and Solomon Saffery concluded their survey that mistakenly created the Notch in Connecticut's boundary with Massachusetts, they inadvertently provoked a century and a half of antipathy among residents whose towns had suddenly changed states.

title: Fewer Borders For Global Accounting
description: A new International Accounting Standards Board was appointed yesterday, with a mission of producing coordinated accounting standards within a few years.

title: Public Interests; Rudy's Next Stand
description: It's hard to know exactly when Rudy Giuliani became a full-feathered lame duck, but it might have been the day he decided that both his girlfriend and his wife required police protection. Granted, our mayor tends to regard armed, taxpayer-supported guards as something that no serious person would leave the house without, like shoes. But you want to believe that if there were a re-election on the horizon, he would have respected the public's desire to limit its investment in security details to one significant other per administration.

title: Foreign Affairs; Bosnia, Sort Of
description: What is the best way to sum up the situation in Bosnia today, five years after NATO came to its rescue? Very simple: Bosnia today is sort of a country -- it's sort of united, sort of divided, sort of peaceful, sort of corrupt, sort of coming back, sort of not coming back -- a place where NATO armies feel sort of good about what they've done to stabilize the country, but where NATO diplomats feel sort of bad that Bosnia's Serbs, Muslims and Croats still have not come together enough for the state to function on its own.

title: A Career of Musical Peaks
description: After Giuseppe Verdis death on January 27, 1901, the outpouring of grief in his native Italy was unprecedented. When his funeral procession passed through the streets of Milan, nearly a quarter of a million people turned out to mourn the man whose music had stirred the emotions of a passionate people. Toscanini conducted the "Va, pensiero" chorus from "Nabucco," which had become a quasi-Italian national anthem. Italian and European dignitaries attended, as did Puccini, Mascagni and other composers of the younger generation.

title: Seton Hall Reaches Settlements With Families of Two Victims Killed in Dormitory Fire
description: Although it has legal immunity from negligence lawsuits, Seton Hall University has reached financial settlements with the families of 2 of the 3 freshmen killed in a dormitory fire a year ago and 10 of the 58 students injured in the blaze, university officials said yesterday.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FELDMAN, SAM
description: FELDMAN-Sam. January 26, 1998. In our hearts always remembered and sorely missed. Rita, Rob and Rick

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  ELMAN, NAOMI GEIST
description: ELMAN-Naomi Geist. Age 86. Of New York City. On January 22, 2001. She leaves her daughter, Peggy Gillespie, granddaughter Jay, nieces Harriet Moulton and Susan Geist, nephews Jack Hayflick and Harry Geist. Memorial March 18, 2001 in New York City.

title: Investment Banks Playing Key Roles in California Power Crisis
description: Wall Street investment banks with big financial stakes in the success of energy deregulation are playing important behind-the-scenes roles as officials in California struggle to fix the state's troubled electric power system.

title: Album of the Week
description: CRISTIAN VOGEL: ''Rescate 137'' (NovaMute). Cristian Vogel, a hugely prolific techno disc jockey and producer, likes unpretty sounds: brittle, chopped-up, filtered, distorted timbres that have been nearly detached from any organic source. He loves scrapes, gurgles and static; he is also fond of cold, bleeping tones that are unmistakably synthetic.

title: MOVIE GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. The ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on

title: Scenes From A Collaboration
description: ''She's here a very short time,'' Liv Ullmann said, introducing Lena Endre, the young Swedish actress who stars in ''Faithless,'' a film that Ms. Ullmann has directed from a new script by Ingmar Bergman. Ms. Endre was in the United States to talk about her collaboration with Ms. Ullmann on the movie, which opens in New York today (review, Page 16). A quick return was mandated because Ms. Endre is at work in a new Bergman production at the Royal Theater of Stockholm, an adaptation of Schiller's ''Maria Stuart.''

title: Robert W. Morse, 79, Educator And a Designer of Submarines
description: Robert Warren Morse, scientist emeritus at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, who helped build the Polaris missile submarine as well as Case Western Reserve University, died on Friday at a nursing home in Falmouth, Mass. He was 79 and lived in North Falmouth.

title: Wariness and Optimism Vie As Gays View New President
description: It was a first for gay Republicans. Last week's inaugural events included a breakfast honoring the Republican Unity Coalition, a new political group that includes gay members of the party. The master of ceremonies at Friday's celebration was a respected Republican elder, former Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, a close friend of both the Bush and Cheney families.

title: IN POLICY CHANGE, GREENSPAN BACKS A BROAD TAX CUT
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, gave his blessing today to a substantial tax cut, but warned that it should not be so big that it would plunge the government back into deficit if the federal budget surplus fails to materialize as projected.

title: Livin' Off the Grid, in California and . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: A Collector Who Knew How to Beat the Drum and Sound the Trumpet
description: When Harry Lunn discovered for himself the work of Ansel Adams in 1970, photographs were not widely viewed as fine art, and there was almost no market for them in the United States. There was only one photography gallery in Manhattan, opened the year before by Lee Witkin. Neither Sotheby's nor Christie's offered regular sales of photographs in New York.

title: SPARE TIMES: FOR CHILDREN
description: Theater

title: Beijing in Battle With Sect: 'A Giant Fighting a Ghost'
description: As he ambles down the street with a newspaper under his arm, the clean-shaven engineer, dressed in a neat down jacket and blue slacks, could be an advertisement for the new urban China. He has a Ph.D., speaks a bit of English, likes to surf the Net and has moved steadily up in his profession.

title: Choosing Hunter College President Puts CUNY Trustees in Tug-of-War
description: The selection of the next president of Hunter College on Manhattan's East Side is the subject of a fierce power struggle, with Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani lobbying trustees of the City University of New York to choose Jennifer J. Raab, chairwoman of the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, and the university's chancellor, Matthew Goldstein, jockeying for a proven manager of a large complex organization.

title: One Is Not Just a Girlfriend, But the Other Has Merit Too
description: The New York singles scene has rarely looked drearier than it does in Neil Turitz's sour romantic comedy ''Two Ninas.'' In this elongated, formula-ridden sitcom posing as a movie, the date-weary Manhattan singles exchanging acerbic banter suggest the tougher, far less intellectual offspring of Woody Allen characters drenched in a whiny Seinfeldian dyspepsia.

title: Ericsson Plans to Stop Manufacturing Mobile Phones
description: LONDON, Jan. 26 - L.M. Ericsson, the giant Swedish electronics company, said today that it would stop manufacturing mobile phones, as it tries to shore up a division that is hemorrhaging cash.

title: Reformer Finally Confirmed As Serbia's Prime Minister
description: The leader of the Democratic Party, Zoran Djindjic, was finally confirmed today as Serbia's new prime minister, and his government was sworn in a month after his 18-party alliance won a sweeping election victory.

title: Putting On the Ritz Just by Parking the Car
description: IN a city where apartment rents can top $10,000 a month and dinner for two can cost $400 or more, should it be a surprise that garage spaces have crossed the four-digit barrier? At least two Manhattan garages are charging more than $750 a month for cars and over $1,000 for some sport utility vehicles.

title: Ex-President of Teamsters Is Charged With Lying
description: Ron Carey, the former Teamsters' president who won election on an anticorruption platform, was indicted yesterday on federal charges that he lied repeatedly in an investigation into fund-raising in his 1996 re-election campaign.

title: National News Briefs; Alabama's Chief Justice Posts Commandments
description: With no fanfare, Alabama's new chief justice has hung a copy of the Ten Commandments in his chambers.

title: A Comeback by Devils Is Wiped Out by Blues
description: Martin Brodeur took a peek behind him, into his goal, then looked down at his sweater and his feet, hoping to see a puck still in play. But a foghorn was blowing loudly, Pierre Turgeon was being mobbed by his teammates and, just like that, Brodeur knew that his long unbeaten streak was over.

title: GAME MAKER LOWERS OUTLOOK
description: Eidos P.L.C., creator of the Tomb Raider video game and its heroine Lara Croft, lowered financial expectations for the current year, citing delays in the introduction of new games. Its shares fell 7.9 percent, to $:2.56. Eidos said Commandos, Sartopia and Gangsters would be released starting in April rather than the fourth quarter of the current fiscal year, which ends March 31. The company also said it would postpone the rollout of games designed for PlayStation 2, including Herdy Gerdy and Eden, until demand improved. Eidos will report results for the third quarter on Feb. 28. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Corrections
description: A Man in the News article on Jan. 5 about Joe Allbaugh, President Bush's choice to head the Federal Emergency Management Agency, misidentified the Democratic governor of Oklahoma under whom he served as deputy secretary of transportation in the early 1990's. It was David Walters; Delmas Ford was the state's secretary of transportation.

title: American Home Posts a Loss As Two Rivals Report Gains
description: The American Home Products Corporation posted a loss of $3.82 billion in the fourth quarter after a charge that was higher than expected for diet pill litigation. Its rivals Eli Lilly & Company and the Schering-Plough Corporation said profits rose as they sold more drugs that are meant to have fewer side effects.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TRAIN CAR CONTRACTS
description: A Canadian company has won a $412.8 million contract to build 350 subway cars for New York City and a $179.3 million contract to supply 100 commuter rail cars to the Long Island Rail Road. The company, Bombardier Inc., said delivery of the subway cars was scheduled for 2002 and 2003. The contract is subject to financing approval by the Federal Transit Administration, the company said. It will start delivering the cars to the railroad in the second quarter of 2003. The Long Island order represents the conversion of an existing option included in a 192-car contract that Bombardier won in May 1999. The conversion brings the value of the entire Long Island order to $694.4 million, Bombardier said. The subway order brings to 1,855 the number of cars that Bombardier will have built for the New York subway since 1982, or about one-third of the city's 6,000-car fleet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUDGE, SHAW
description: MUDGE-Shaw. Founder and Chairman of Shaw Mudge & Company in Shelton, CT. Died suddenly Tuesday evening, January 23, 2001. He was at home with his wife, Patricia Grant Mudge. In addition to his wife, Shaw Mudge, 77, is survived by two sons, The Reverend Shaw Mudge, Jr. of Walton, NY and Grant Mudge, President of Shaw Mudge & Company, and five grandchildren. Mudge graduated from The Choate Rosemary School in 1941 and was a member of The Chi Psi Fraternity at Yale University graduating class of 1945W. During World War II, Mudge served as Lt. j.g. in the ''Small Boat'' Navy performing convoy escort duty in the Atlantic and Pacific. Before co-founding Shaw Mudge & Company in 1969, Mudge co-founded P. Robertet Inc., manufacturers of aromatic compounds in 1947. Mr. Mudge held leadership positions many industry, civic, environmental, and political organizations. Mudge was Chairman of the National Advisory Council to the U.S. Senate Committee on Small Business. He also served as Connecticut's Co-Chairman to the White House Conference II on Small Business. Mr. Mudge was founding director of National Small Business United as well as a current board member of The Fragrance Materials Association. The Society of Cosmetic Chemists recognized Mudge with The Merit Award, and in 1985, he became the SACIA's (Southwestern Area Commerce & Industry Association of Connecticut) first Small Business Advocate of the Year. Also in 1985, he received a Certificate of Appreciation from the Animal Protection Institute in Sacramento for his efforts to save the wolf and grizzly bear by including them on the Endangered Species list. Funeral services will take place at the Second Congregational Church on 139 Putnam Avenue in Greenwich, Connecticut beginning at 2 PM on Saturday, January 27. Instead of flowers, donations would be welcome at The Camp Pasquaney Trust, 5 South State Street, Concord, NH 03301.

title: The Conflict in Congo
description: The expected swearing in today of Joseph Kabila as the new president of Congo hardly represents a bright new era for that war-battered nation. His unelected regime is dominated by the same military clique of family and ethnic kinsmen that surrounded his mercurial father, Laurent Kabila, before his assassination last week. But the advent of new leadership in Kinshasa, combined with a new administration in Washington, presents an opportunity for fresh thinking on Congo's ruinous war. Talks this week between rival nations that are plundering Congo suggest there may be a chance to revive a peace accord signed by all sides in 1999.

title: Bearing Witness to the Past in an Oddly Banal Present
description: ''Voyages'' was shown as part of last year's New Directors/New Films series. Following are excerpts from A. O. Scott's review, which appeared in The New York Times on March 27. The film -- in French, Hebrew and Russian, with English subtitles -- opens today at the Walter Reade Theater at Lincoln Center.

title: Capriati Upsets No. 1 Hingis
description: MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Jan. 27  Eleven years after she turned pro and six years after she vanished from the tennis scene, Jennifer Capriati won the first Grand Slam title of her career with a 6-4, 6-3 victory against the No. 1 player in the world, Martina Hingis, to win the Australian Open today.

title: Karen Kilimnik
description: 303 Gallery

title: ART GUIDE
description: A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

title: Man Is Told He Will Lose 'W' License Plate to Politics
description: Call it double U or dubya. These days, it's shorthand for power and a symbol for victory. It comes at the beginning of winner, White House and world leader.

title: Corrections
description: An article in World Business on Wednesday about telephone service in Mexico referred incorrectly to Banamex, part owner of Avantel, a company that has begun offering local phone service in Mexico City. Banamex, Mexico's largest financial institution, operates the country's second-largest bank; the largest is BBVA Bancomer.

title: Adding a Financial Threat to Familiar Promises on Education
description: The proposal President Bush introduced this week to ''transform the federal role in education'' is, in fact, mostly a collection of measures from current or previous federal law, with one exception: the threat to deprive failing public schools of federal aid and convert that money into vouchers given to students' families.

title: Town Hopes to Reclaim Its Indian Ancestors
description: Thirty-five years after 600 American Indian graves were opened and the bodies packed off to a university in the name of science, this small riverfront town is trying to reclaim and rebury the bodies in the name of sacred obligation.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  TAI, YUAN SHING
description: TAI-Yuan Shing. The American Heart Association in New York City mourns the passing of Mr. Yuan Tai. Mr. Tai and his family have been longtime friends of our mission. Over the years, their generosity has supported our heart disease and stroke programs to save lives from heart disease and stroke and sponsored the research of young medical scientists. title: Super Bowl Matchup; Why the Giants Will Win
description: It is difficult to ignore the Ravens' defense in any way. This defense, as the Giants have smartly acknowledged all week, has earned everything it has accomplished. It has produced an effort in style and in numbers that is unmatched in pro football history. It all starts with middle linebacker Ray Lewis, but the other components are more varied and more layered. Combine the coaching, the scheme and the personnel of this defense, and the Giants, like all other teams this season, will find the search for yards and points brutally tough. But the Giants are the pick here because as good as the Ravens' defense is, the Giants' defense is more than capable, especially against the Ravens' offense. The Giants' defense against the Ravens' offense is the game's biggest mismatch. Expect the Giants' offense to do just enough and the Giants' defense, in a surreal twist, to dominate.

title: VISTEON SAYS IT WILL CLOSE ELECTRONICS PLANT IN CANADA
description: The Visteon Corporation, a leading maker of auto parts, said yesterday that it would close an electronics plant in Ontario within two years because it was selling its business that makes air-bag sensors. The company employs about 1,200 workers at the plant in Markham, Ontario. The plant makes air-bag systems, electronics for heaters and air-conditioners and engine and interior parts, a spokeswoman said. Visteon would not say how many jobs would be eliminated. The company plans to relocate the making of heating, air-conditioning and engine-control sensors to other unspecified locations.

title: MICROSOFT PLANS JAVA OFFENSIVE
description: Microsoft unveiled technology yesterday intended to translate programs written in the Java computer language so they can be used on Microsoft's .Net platform. .Net, an online extension of the Windows operating system, is intended to allow people to work over networks. Microsoft has created software to translate programs written in more than 20 computer languages for use on .Net. Earlier this week, Microsoft said it had agreed to pay $20 million to settle a lawsuit filed by Sun Microsystems four years ago. Sun had accused Microsoft of making modifications to the Java platform. The move announced yesterday by Microsoft involves translating the Java programming language, which is only a part of the Java platform, Sun officials said. David Harrah, a Sun spokesman, said the technology did not appear to violate terms of the settlement. Matt Richtel (NYT)

title: CISCO ADDS TO ASIAN COMMITMENT
description: Seeking to fuel development of Asia's Internet infrastructure, Cisco Systems, the network equipment company, will pay $1.05 billion to the Softbank Corporation's venture capital division over the next several years. Softbank, based in Tokyo, has stakes in more 600 Internet companies. ''It's creating the substrate for Internet access and usage to grow in Asia the way it has in the U.S.,'' said Gary Reischel, president of Softbank Venture Capital. Cisco also announced a separate $200 million investment in Softbank, as well as a repurchase of Softbank's stake in Cisco Systems KK, Cisco's Japanese sales and marketing unit, for $275 million. Catherine Greenman (NYT)

title: SONY'S PROFIT SLIPS
description: The Sony Corporation said that its third-quarter profit declined 22.8 percent, to 72.2 billion yen ($611 million), hurt by problems with its electronic game division, despite a 10 percent increase in sales. ''All in all, the result was so-so,'' Teruhisa Tokunaka, the chief financial officer of Sony, said. The games division, struggling with the PlayStation 2 game console, lost 13.9 billion yen. Miki Tanikawa (NYT)

title: Metro Business Briefing; GALLERY REFUNDS
description: A gallery that sold fake paintings over the Internet will refund $111,000 to 18 bilked customers under a settlement with New York State, Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer said Wednesday. His office had charged the gallery, the Antique and Design Center of New Windsor, N.Y., with offering works with forged signatures of artists like Oscar Bluemner, Milton Avery and Oskar Kokoschka for prices from less than $1,000 to more than $13,000. The gallery owners, Jerry and Jill Schuster, are also to post a $70,000 bond before they can continue to do business in the state and will pay triple damages for any future violations. They did not admit any wrongdoing in agreeing to the settlement. Joseph P. Fried

title: Senate to Take Up Campaign Finance Issue

title: NISSAN PLANS BRITISH PLANT

The decision comes on the heels of a $:40 million (pounds) aid package the British government promised Nissan if it would build the Micra in Britain. It also is in contrast to moves by other carmakers, like Ford and General Motors, which are closing British plants because of the strength of the pound against the euro. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: A Semi-Feminist Potpourri Ending in a Battle Hymn
description: The centerpiece of Sally Kellerman's new cabaret show at Feinstein's at the Regency is a potpourri of song fragments billed as ''The Women's Medley,'' in which the original ''Hot Lips'' Houlihan from ''M*A*S*H'' strings together bits and pieces of nearly two dozen of her favorite songs, most of them written by women. Introduced by Helen Reddy's singsongy jingle ''I Am Woman,'' this feminist tribute brings in everything from ''The Way We Were'' to ''We Shall Overcome,'' to ''America, the Beautiful'' (revised to include the line, ''And crown thy good with sisterhood''). It culminates with an excerpt from ''The Battle Hymn of the Republic,'' whose fiercely militant lyrics were also written by a woman (Julia Ward Howe).

John Viener stars as John, who decides that he wants to give up his job and shoot a film (which he hasn't gotten around to writing yet) that he is determined to get into the Sundance Film Festival. (The movie comes from Mr. Stern's 1999 book, ''How to Shoot a Feature Film Under $10,000 and Not Go to Jail.'')

title: Pages That Glow With a Forgotten Master's Forgotten Art
description: The illumination of manuscripts is not a robust profession today, but in the time of the French artist Jean Poyet (circa 1445-1503), a good hand could earn his bread at it and eat cake, too. Hand-lettered and illustrated prayer books -- particularly those called Books of Hours, containing appropriate devotions for seasonal, monthly and daily as well as hourly recital -- were runaway best sellers in the Christian world, surpassing even the Bible, from the mid-13th to the mid-15th centuries.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  IMPELLIZERI, MARIO E.
description: IMPELLIZERI-Mario E. Pension consultant Mario E. Impellizeri died January 18 in Fort Lauderdale FL. He was 84. He resided in Westhampton Beach NY and Fort Lauderdale FL. Mr. Impellizeri, cofounder of the Pension Research Studies Group at Manhattan College, co-wrote ''The Mirage of Private Pensions'' with Brother Cornelius Justin. He testified extensively before the House Labor Sub Committee in the 1970s on pension legislation. He also appeared before the McClellan Committee. Congressman Alfred Santangelo called Mr. Impellizeri the ''Father of Pension Reform.'' He was often quoted in the Congressional Record and was interviwed on the subject of pension reform on numerous radio and TV programs including the Today Show where he was interviewed by Hugh Downs. He bacame a nationally recognized authority on private pensions and founded a business Impellizeri Associates, Actuaries and Consultants after his retirement from a career with the US Department of Labor. He had served earlier as Deputy Commissioner of Equal Opportunity in New York. He was a past President of the Westhampton NY Rotary and was a Paul Harris Fellow. Mr. Impellizeri is survived by his wife Monica, his sister Frances Tosi and her husband Lou Tosi, his daughters Marylou Impellizeri and Lila Titone, his grandchildren Jacqueline, J.J., Alexandra and Christopher Titone and by his sisters-inlaw, Anne Impellizeri and Anne Nicastri. His brother Julius Impellizeri was counsel to the Knapp Commission.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, LINDA T., M.D.
description: SCHNEIDER-Linda T., M.D., age 95, died on January 23, 2001, at her home in New York City. Dr. Schneider was born in Tallinn, Estonia, on April 15, 1905. She came to New York City in 1923 supported by a YMCA scholarship to Vassar College, became a U.S. citizen, received her undergraduate degree from Northwestern University and the M.D. degree from the University of Rochester. After internship and residency at the Babies & Children's Hospital, she became an attending pediatrician and a faculty member of the then Western Reserve University Medical School in Cleveland, Ohio. Following a period of private practice, she was appointed Director of School Health by the East Cleveland Board of Education, which position she held until her retirement in 1975. Thereafter, she lived with her daughter and son-in-law in Chicago and New York City. Her husband, Dr. Wilmot F. Schneider, predeceased her in 1964. She is survived by her daughter, Mrs. David B. Skinner; four grand-daughters: Dr. Linda S. Callans of Philadelphia, Dr. Kristin A. Skinner of Los Angeles, Ms. Carise B. Skinner-Rowley of Rochester, N.Y., and Ms. Margaret L. Skinner of New York City; and four great grandchildren. Services and burial will be conducted privately.

Those mines accounted for a quarter of the company's copper output last year. Its fourth-quarter energy costs rose 65 percent.

title: ONLINE GROCER'S LOSS NARROWS
description: The Webvan Group, one of the last remaining online grocers, reported a narrower-than-expected loss and announced a restructuring that decreases the cash it needs to raise this year as it seeks profitability. The company, based in Foster City, Calif., said that excluding acquisition-related expenses, it lost 23 cents a share, 8 cents more than a year earlier but a penny better than Wall Street's estimates. Revenues were $84.2 million, compared with $19.8 million a year earlier. Webvan had said it would need to raise at least $80 million during the third quarter of 2001. But the company said yesterday that it would reduce operating expenses, lay off 150 employees and cancel planned expansions into the Baltimore-Washington area and northern New Jersey. Company executives still expect to need a cash infusion of at least $40 million by early 2002.

title: Metro Business Briefing; TEXACO TO LEAVE WESTCHESTER
description: Since October, when Texaco, the oil company headquartered in Harrison, N.Y., announced that it had agreed to be acquired by Chevron Corporation and that the new headquarters would be in San Francisco, it had been assumed that the corporate presence in Westchester County would shrink, but it was not clear by how much. This week, Texaco, one of the county's largest employers and a philanthropic powerhouse, confirmed people's worst fears: no one will stay behind if the takeover goes through. In a presentation on Tuesday at Texaco's corporate center, managers said the 1,000 people working there could apply for positions in the newly merged company, to be called ChevronTexaco Corporation, at a number of places in the United States, or could seek severance packages. Over all, the combined work force will be reduced by 7 percent, or about 4,000 employees, said Paul Weeditz, a Texaco spokesman. Lisa W. Foderaro

Egghead said it expected to report a fourth-quarter loss of 23 cents to 25 cents a share on revenue of $91 million to $93 million.

title: The Energy Calamity in California
description: It is astonishing -- and alarming -- how little it took to cripple California, the incubator of high technology and a driving force in the nation's economic growth. Just a few years ago, the state's economy was booming and there was a modest surplus in electricity. Today California is scrambling to buy power at exorbitant rates, consumers have been hit with rolling blackouts, the utilities are nearly bankrupt and businesses are curbing production or threatening to move out of state. The only solace is that the crisis thus far is primarily financial. There appears to be enough power available physically if some way can be found to obtain it and pay for it.

title: Campaign Finance Reform; Mayor Giuliani's Damaging Lawsuit
description: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani filed suit yesterday to halt improvements in New York City's exemplary campaign financing program. The mayor's legal team argued that a 1998 charter revision banning corporate campaign contributions also had the effect of nullifying a law that encourages candidates to rely on smaller contributions in return for receiving more city money for their campaigns. The City Council speaker, Peter Vallone, has vowed to fight the mayor in court or ''to use any means necessary to protect the integrity of the law.'' That is a wise move. The mayor's lawsuit should not be allowed to stall the nation's best campaign financing program.

Putin -- is near endgame, and that Mr. Putin's allies smell victory.

title: Rage and Taunts Fill Courtroom as a Killer Gets Life in Prison
description: Arohn Kee, convicted in a seven-year spree of murder and rape that left three teenagers dead, almost certainly would have received the sentence he got yesterday -- life in prison without possibility of parole -- even if the families of his seven victims had not said a word at his sentencing.

title: California's Leader in Singing the Praises of Public Power
description: S. DAVID FREEMAN is only 5 feet 8 inches tall, but he stands out in any crowd, if only because a tall, cream-colored cowboy hat is almost never off his head. It began as a dermatological defense against the Texas sun when Mr. Freeman worked as a public power czar there more than a decade ago, but has assumed an indoor-outdoor status as iconic as the man himself.

title: Woods's Streak Ends And Calcavecchia Leads
description: Tiger Woods stood in the 18th fairway today with 87 yards remaining in his PGA Tour-record streak of never shooting worse than par. He turned to his caddie, Steve Williams, grinned and said, ''Be nice to hole this out, wouldn't it?''

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Jets, Citing Benefits to City, Detail a Stadium Plan
description: In releasing their most detailed plans yet for a billion-dollar complex on the West Side of Manhattan, the New York Jets said the economic benefits to New York City would come not from the football games in a new stadium but from an expanded convention center on the site.

title: Sports of The Times; A Matter Of What Is And Isn't
description: A YEAR ago we sat around in ice-swept Atlanta wondering how the Tennessee Titans could slow down the St. Louis Rams and their high-octane offense.

title: Bushs First Week in Office Garners Respectful Reviews
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 27  As President Bush completes his first week in office, prominent Republicans and even many Democrats agree that he has presided over one of the most orderly and politically nimble White House transitions in at least 20 years.

title: Need Money? Rob a Bank. Need Advice? Study 'Heat.'
description: If your cultural memory stretches back to the early 1980's -- in which case you are not part of the target audience of ''Sugar and Spice'' -- you may remember John Cougar Mellencamp's little ditty about Jack and Diane. These happen to be the names of the ''two American kids'' whose careless love sets in motion the plot of this contrived, funny exercise in B-movie teensploitation.

title: Rights Group Scores Success With Nike
description: Ayear-old labor rights group formed by students and universities has registered its biggest success thus far by getting Nike Inc. to press managers at a Mexican apparel factory to rehire hundreds of workers after a three-day strike.

title: Friends And Family Bid Agee Farewell
description: It was a sight that the former pitcher Jim (Mudcat) Grant would never forget. It was the spring of 1962 when the 19-year-old bonus baby walked into the Cleveland Indians' clubhouse. ''He wore a red tie, a red belt, red socks and a white seersucker suit that was two sizes too big for him,'' Grant said this morning in the Grace Baptist Church in Mount Vernon. ''His parents had obviously bought it for him and figured he'd grow into it.''

title: Commissioner Defends the Off-Field Behavior of Players
description: When Commissioner Paul Tagliabue delivers his state of the National Football League address shortly before the Super Bowl each year, it is usually a calm, scripted affair. Tagliabue is often prepared for every question, and answers each one professionally.

title: Campaign Finance Reform; Senator McCain's Reasonable Deal
description: Senator John McCain's hard-line insistence on an early debate and vote for campaign finance reform paid off yesterday when Trent Lott agreed to a quick timetable for consideration of the McCain-Feingold bill. A surprise accord between Mr. McCain and Mr. Lott, the majority leader, calls for the legislation to be considered in late March. Mr. Lott also repeated that, at least for now, he did not expect that he would try to block the bill with a filibuster, which would require 60 votes to overcome. The agreement now clears the way for a tough debate in which reformers have the major challenge of defeating an expected barrage of crippling or weakening amendments.

title: Ericsson to Farm Out Production and Cut Losses on Handsets
description: LONDON, Jan. 26  L. M. Ericsson, the giant Swedish electronics company, said today that it would stop manufacturing mobile phones, as it tries to shore up a division that is hemorrhaging cash.

title: Ravens' Lust for Spotlight Puts Giants on the Spot
description: Jim Fassel grabbed the Lombardi Trophy and posed for a group of photographers early this morning, a trial run of sorts roughly 60 hours before the kickoff of Super Bowl XXXV. On a stage awash in klieg lights, Fassel was beaming in his last news conference of Super Bowl week. If six days of interviews, functions, practices and meetings had worn him out, he hid it well.

title: An Anxious Wait
description: For the thousands of Gujarati immigrants in New York, it was a day when telephone calls did not get through and hopes hung on scraps of information about relatives and friends in the devastated area. For one merchant in Jackson Heights, Queens, hours of dialing finally brought good news about his father.

title: More Layoffs at Delphi
description: TROY, Mich., Jan. 26  Delphi Automotive Systems , the auto-parts maker, said today that it would lay off about 5,000 workers for a week starting Monday because of production shutdowns by General Motors , its biggest customer and former parent. Most of the Delphi layoffs will be in plants in Ohio and Michigan, with smaller numbers in Alabama, New York and Indiana, a spokeswoman, Claudia Piccinin, said. Delphi had to furlough about 4,300 workers this week after G.M. shut down three assembly plants.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MUDGE, SHAW
description: MUDGE-Shaw. National Small Business United mourns the loss of Shaw Mudge. Shaw was an extraordinary small business activist who deployed his amazing network of friends and contacts to the benefit of the entire small business community. A founding board member, Shaw was designated as Trustee Emeritus. He was one of the great small business leaders. With condolences to his family.

title: World Business Briefing
description: AMERICAS JOB GROWTH IN CHILE Chilean unemployment fell to a nine-month low in December as the country's $68 billion economy generated new jobs after a yearlong recovery. Unemployment fell more than expected, to 8.3 percent from 9.4 percent in November, the government said. Unemployment was 8.9 percent in December 1999. The December jobless rate was the lowest since March. (Bloomberg News)

title: India, in Grief and Anger, Tallies Huge Quake Toll
description: AHMEDABAD, India, Jan. 27  The floors of the collapsed school are stacked on top of each other like four thick slices of bread and crushed between them are dozens of the sons and daughters of India's striving middle class, trapped when a powerful earthquake struck this thriving city in western India on Friday.

title: Ashcroft Gives Judiciary Panel His Written Replies to Hundreds of Questions
description: John Ashcroft submitted to the Senate Judiciary Committee today hundreds of written responses to questions as the battle over his nomination for attorney general was swiftly moving to a conclusion, and possibly a vote next week.

title: XXXV AND ALL THAT
description: A special preview section lays out the Giants' blueprint for beating the Baltimore Ravens tomorrow. Dave Anderson writes about the two quarterbacks; William C. Rhoden looks at Baltimore's Ray Lewis and other great middle linebackers. And charts offer a portrait of the two teams.

title: A Personal Gift to the Philharmonic
description: In his first major donation to the New York Philharmonic, Alberto W. Vilar, a high-tech stock investor and a free-spending patron of the arts, has pledged $250,000 to subsidize three performances of the Verdi Requiem in 2002.

title: From Underwater Sounds, Perhaps the Sirens' Call
description: ''Words Will Be Spoken/Echo'' began magically, on Sunday night at P.S. 122. The new piece, created and performed by Hetty King and Lin Snelling, emerged gradually from darkness. First there were soft underwater sounds; then very slowly one became aware of a figure at the back of the stage. As slowly, another grew more visible across the stage.

title: Execution Is Stayed for Man Convicted of Killing Officer
description: Five months after splitting 7 to 7 on whether to grant a new hearing to a man condemned to death for killing a police officer, an appeals court today stayed his execution to provide more time for the United States Supreme Court to consider his claim that he has new evidence.

title: California Lawmakers Debate Bill to Compensate Utilities
description: Amid skepticism about the success of an auction intended to purchase long-term energy supplies, California legislators debated a bill yesterday that would help the state's biggest utilities recover billions they have lost buying electricity at prices far higher than they can charge customers.

description: JANUARY is almost over, and those seed catalogs are piling up. Have you pruned the grapevines yet? Ordered those fruit trees and asparagus roots? Built the new fence for the vegetable garden?

title: U.S. Legal Obligations to Suspects Are Questioned in Bombing Case
description: Within weeks of the bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa in August 1998, American investigators and prosecutors flew from New York to Kenya and Tanzania to search for the bombers and their handlers. On Aug. 12, five days after the attacks, the American agents accompanied the Kenyan police as they entered a dingy hotel in a village outside Nairobi known by the nickname Little Somalia.

title: California Adopts Plan for Electric Cars
description: Ignoring last-minute objections by the automobile companies, the California Air Resources Board has approved a scaled-down plan requiring that 2 percent of the cars offered for sale in the state by major manufacturers be battery-powered starting in 2003.

title: Still Robert Shaw's Spirit
description: Robert Shaw is no longer with us, but the valuable choral workshops he ran so well at Carnegie Hall live on through surrogates and survivors. Using choir directors, singers and church musicians from around the world and shepherding them through an inventive and efficient rehearsal process, these annual events have showed that sophisticated singing groups can be created in a matter of a few days.

title: Man Pleads Guilty to Sex Attack On Girl at High School in Queens

And what were their results?

title: Bookend; Medieval Superheroes
description: Imagine a reader confronted seven or eight hundred years from now with a collection of modern short stories. Beyond the solvable puzzles posed by terminology and machinery and usages long obsolete, there would loom the larger difficulty of appropriate readerly reaction. In our unmediated evocations of 20th-century happenstance, dealing with sexual relations and career disappointments and social embarrassments, heavy with dialogue and the revelations of childhood and ending with epiphanic moments of self-knowledge or of terse spoken farewell, all lightly larded with descriptions of nature the characters pass through or furniture they sit on or television shows they halfheartedly watch -- in all this, what was meant, the future reader must ask himself, to be surprising, to be in its small surprise amusing, to deviate interestingly from normal expectation, to be, in brief, news, telling the vanished inhabitant of today's long-settled dust what he did not quite know before, broadening and enlightening his sensibility with the delicate shocks of art?

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  CARLSON, CAROLE J.
description: CARLSON-Carole J., 60, of New York City, died Monday, January 8, 2001 at her home. She was born January 2, 1941 in Connecticut, daughter of the late George E. Carlson & Edith V. Carlson. Carole worked as a medical secretary & was an avid painter and knitter and enjoyed fine cuisine. She is survived by two daughters, Samantha and Pamela Schwartz and son-in-law Stephen Cassidy, all of New York City.

title: CHARTER SCHOOL TURNED DOWN
description: State officials have rejected the Renaissance Academy charter school proposal in Mount Vernon, citing problems with the its financing and its proposed site at 32 South Fifth Avenue. The school, which would have been the only charter school in Westchester, had drawn opposition from local officials and school board members, who said it would have created social and racial divisions by drawing public funds from the district's long-troubled schools. ''We are disappointed, but we still believe a charter school is needed in the district,'' said Georgina Sussewell, a member of the proposed school's board. The board has not decided whether to apply again next year, she added. State officials approved 7 of 12 charter proposals that had reached the final round of the application process. Robert Worth

title: Let Them Eat Sandwiches
description: The new Cosi Sandwich Bar in downtown Mount Kisco brings a touch of Paris to town. The original Cosi, in Paris, was discovered by Jay and Shep Wainwright, two brothers who were determined to bring the concept of the restaurant -- and the recipe for its signature bread -- back to the States. They opened the first Cosi in 1996 in Manhattan.

title: WHITE PLAINS INITIATIVE
description: Mayor Joseph M. Delfino of White Plains has announced a plan to protect the city's environment and open spaces. Called the White Plains Environmental Protection Initiative, it is the largest local municipal proposal to preserve open space in Westchester. The city's plan calls for the creation of an Open Space Acquisition Fund that has a financing commitment of $5 million; an increase in property taxes is not expected. The mayor will also be the chairman of an Open Space Acquisition Advisory Committee, which will include two members of the Common Council and eight White Plains residents, including members of the Planning, Conservation and Recreation Advisory Boards. Elsa Brenner

title: Sanctions Are a Weapon We Need
description: Testifying at his confirmation hearing this month, Secretary of State Colin Powell made clear he has trouble with one nettlesome foreign policy issue: sanctions against foreign nations. He thinks there are too many and seems inclined to want to get rid of a lot of them. ''Stop, look and listen before you impose a sanction,'' he said. ''Count to 10, call me.'' The only exception conceded by Mr. Powell is Iraq. There, he wants to tighten the screws to force compliance with United Nations demands to eliminate weapons of mass destruction.

title: Five Blind Boys in Pomona
description: Not to be confused with another classic gospel group, the Five Blind Boys of Mississippi, these five men, who hail from the Alabama School for the Blind in Talledaga, have a distinctive sound of their own. From intricate gospel harmony to quasi doo-wop, the Five Blind Boys glide effortlessly through an exhilarating evening of spiritual gospel and secular pop. Sometimes it's like a music history class, where you get to see the deep gospel roots of such artists like James Brown and the Isley Brothers. They defined the term hard gospel in the 1950's and there's some mighty larynx-ripping occurring in the course of their set. For the performance at 8 p.m. Saturday, Clarence Fountain, one of the top gospel shouters, returns to lead the group through a raise-the-roof revival at the Stockton Performing Arts Center in Pomona. Robbie Woliver

(And in someone else's obit, no less!) It is enough to make us feel truly insignificant. Of course, it was Trudeau who said that living next to the United States was like sleeping with an elephant. Well, the elephant just rolled over again.

description: When incoming presidential aides arrived at their White House offices after the inauguration, they found desks upended, headsets glued to telephones and bumper stickers poking fun at their newly elected boss.

Despite an 18-month crackdown on the sect, China has been unable to suppress or even identify its followers, and on Jan. 1, its leader, Li Hongzhi, announced on his Web site that followers should not practice forbearance in the face of unreasonable attacks.

Mr Greenspan said that improvements in the economy's long-term potential and swelling surplus projections had ''reshaped the choices and opportunities before us'' to permit a combination of debt reduction and tax cuts. His guarded endorsement gave new impetus to the Republican effort to push through the biggest tax reduction since the Reagan administration.
