title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HEGYI, MILTON T.
description: HEGYI-Milton T. 84, of Hallandale, FL, formerly of Mount Vernon, NY, died on January 17, 2001. Beloved husband of Ruth (Levinson). Adored father of Pamela Hoffman, Carolyn Kaller and Joyce Pines. Cherished grandfather of Jeremy, Benjamin, Zachary, Samuel and Jed. Dear brother of Robert Hegyi and the late Betty Moskowitz and the late William Hegyi. Father-in-law of Warren Hoffman and Lawrence Pines. title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHNEIDER, LINDA T., M.D.
description: SCHNEIDER-Linda T., M.D., age 95, died on January 23, 2001, at her home in New York City. Dr. Schneider was born in Tallinn, Estonia, on April 15, 1905. She came to New York City in 1923 supported by a YMCA scholarship to Vassar College, became a U.S. citizen, received her undergraduate degree from Northwestern University and the M.D. degree from the University of Rochester. After internship and residency at the Babies & Children's Hospital, she became an attending pediatrician and a faculty member of the then Western Reserve University Medical School in Cleveland, Ohio. Following a period of private practice, she was appointed Director of School Health by the East Cleveland Board of Education, which position she held until her retirement in 1975. Thereafter, she lived with her daughter and son-in-law in Chicago and New York City. Her husband, Dr. Wilmot F. Schneider, predeceased her in 1964. She is survived by her daughter, Mrs. David B. Skinner; four grand-daughters: Dr. Linda S. Callans of Philadelphia, Dr. Kristin A. Skinner of Los Angeles, Ms. Carise B. Skinner-Rowley of Rochester, N.Y., and Ms. Margaret L. Skinner of New York City; and four great grandchildren. Services and burial will be conducted privately.

description: California continues to struggle with a crisis that seems surreal at its core: the state that is the epicenter of the nation's high tech economy has been repeatedly struck by the failure of a vital piece of its electrical service. State leaders edged toward a first-step solution, negotiating to buy power on long-term contracts at reasonable prices, then pass it on to the state's near-bankrupt utilities. The state would float bonds to finance the deal, perhaps in exchange for receiving utility stock that could be sold to repay the cost once the market rebounded. Consumers would also pay through an extension of recent rate increases. But officials warned that a crash program to conserve energy and finish construction of new power plants would still be needed to avoid blackouts at times of peak demand this summer. Todd S. Purdum

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FEIGENBAUM, GEORGE
description: FEIGENBAUM-George. Former member of the Baltimore Bullets and Milwaukee Hawks of the National Basketball Association (NBA), and member of the NBA Retired Basketball Association, died on December 26, 2000. In 1946 George graduated from New Utrecht High School in New York City and was selected to the first team All-PSAL. That year he led New York City PSAL in scoring. As a result of George's basketball skills, ability and finesse on the court his talent became evident to many fans across the country. He went on to a basketball career that started at the University of Kentucky after the legendary Coach Adolph Rupp recruited him as the only schoolboy from New York. He finished his college career at Long Island University (LIU). He took his hardnosed approach to the hard court all the way to the National Basketball Association. He played in the NBA for two years and excelled in the game that he loved. He continued playing professionally in the Eastern League and the American Basketball League (ABL). George left professional basketball and in 1961 formed his own successful plumbing company located in NYC, called St. Marks Plumbing & Heating Co., Inc. He was born in Binghamton, NY, moved to Brooklyn, NY and has lived in North Woodmere, NY for the past twenty-five years. He married in 1957 and is survived by his wife Francine, daughter Allison, sons Michael and Jonathan, son-in-law Mark Rosenbloom, and his grandsons Jake, Zack, and Maxx, his mother Lillian, and his brother David. George was a contributor to various religious organizations as well as to the underprivileged. George was a loving, compassionate and giving person to all those who knew him.

title: 'The Biographer's Tale'

"Here sprang up many faces without necks, arms wandered without shoulders, unattached, and eyes strayed alone, in need of foreheads." He frequently quoted Empedocles, usually this passage. We were discussing, not for the first time, Lacan's theory of morcellement, the dismemberment of the imagined body. There were twelve postgraduates, including myself, and Professor Ormerod Goode. It was a sunny day and the windows were very dirty. I was looking at the windows, and I thought, I'm not going to go on with this anymore. Just like that. It was May 8th 1994. I know that, because my mother had been buried the week before, and I'd missed the seminar on Frankenstein.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MALTONI, CESARE
description: MALTONI-Cesare. The Executive and Fellows of the Collegium Ramazzini mark with great sadness the passing of the General Secretary of our organization, Professor Cesare Maltoni age 70, at his home in Bologna, Italy on January 21, 2001. Professor Maltoni was a distinguished pathologist and oncologist who made fundamental contributions to the literature of carcinogenesis. His passionate dedication to the health and safety of workers around the world led him to translate these laboratory findings into practical steps for worker protection against carcinogen exposure and cancer. Vigorous and outspoken, Professor Maltoni's discoveries on the cancer causing properties of benzene and vinyl chloride and many other industrial substances, have made the workplace safer for millions of workers around the world. With the late Professor Irving Selikoff, Professor Maltoni founded the Collegium Ramazzini, an organization based in the City of Carpi, Italy, the birthplace of Bernardino Ramazzini, the father of occupational medicine, which is dedicated to the scientific bases of occupational medicine and its social consequences. Professor Maltoni's work will be continued by the Fellows of the Collegium.

title: January 21-27; Texas Fugitives Captured

The notion of bringing disparate images and information together in a single composition has affected all of the arts. It reflects the pace of the century; anything could be accessed immediately. That collage often creates complex, even confused, compositions is also in step with real events.

Five guides, passing around a microphone, started pointing out historic landmarks, putting names on mountain ranges and desert plants, explaining the lay of the land and the chronology of its inhabitants. An hour later, at our border crossing in Nogales, we boarded another bus and were off on a three-day fact-packed immersion into the world of O'odham Indians, the Sonoran Desert, and the indefatigable 17th-century Jesuit missionary Eusebio Francisco Kino.

title: Jan Karski
description: I am distressed that you did not choose to print a photograph of the heroic humanitarian Jan Karski (''What He Saw''). The picture you selected of the small boy was a moving but much reproduced image and could not convey the unique authority of Karski's own visage. Even in his 80's, this short, slight man had the erect stature of his breeding and military training. But the gaunt cast of his face was not wholly owing to his age and Slavic heritage. When he was sought by the Nazis, he had several teeth removed to change his appearance and thus forever bore evidence of some of what he had endured, bearing witness to the Holocaust. Scholar, patriot, war hero, he endured much else with stoic gallantry and wit. In a radio interview a few years before his death, he could be brought only to say quietly, ''I saw terrible things.''

title: Look at Brazil
description: Someday, we may look back on the year 2001 with nostalgia for a time when AIDS was merely a health catastrophe. Soon, AIDS in Africa will be doing more than killing millions every year. It will destroy what there is of Africa's economy and cause further instability and, perhaps, war. In the year 2010, the country of South Africa will be almost one-fifth poorer than it would have been had AIDS never existed. Throughout Africa, the disease has ravaged the young, urban and mobile. It has robbed schools of their teachers and hospitals of their doctors and nurses. Businesses are depleted by the need to cope with sick and dying employees. AIDS takes the breadwinner, leaving millions of destitute elderly and orphans who will grow up without going to school, many on the streets. As they lose their productive citizens, the nations themselves face collapse.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry; Poet and Concubine
description: One of Vietnam's greatest poets, Ho Xuan Huong -- whose dates, as far as we know them, roughly correspond to those of Jane Austen -- lived through a time of national upheaval and personal frustration. She was a concubine (''like the maid, / but without pay,'' she writes in one poem) and, according to legend, she ran a tea shop in what is now known as Hanoi, from which vantage point she railed against her fate, being a talented, intelligent woman in a world dominated by the male Confucian establishment. Ho's stature rests on her mastery of classical technique, her mordant humor and on what John Balaban, in his excellent introduction to SPRING ESSENCE: The Poetry of Ho Xuan Huoung (Copper Canyon, paper, $15), the first substantial anthology of Ho's poetry in a Western language, calls ''her exquisite cleverness.'' Ho delighted in puns and double entendres, tonal play, anagram-like subtexts and elaborate rhyme schemes that were even more intricate than the established formal patterns warranted. Many of her poems conceal an alternate meaning, usually sexual, sometimes obscene. In the simple landscape of daily objects -- jackfruit, river snails, a loom, a chess set, and perhaps most famously a paper fan -- Ho found metaphors for sex, which she turned into trenchant indictments of the plight of women and the arrogance, hypocrisy and corruption of men. She could vent her disapproval on members of her own sex, too, as in one poem where she scolds a young widow for overindulging her grief. In still other poems, she paints miniature portraits -- a village schoolmaster, a retired doctor, a Buddhist nun, a lustful monk -- that are by turns funny, chiding, picturesque or sarcastic. Though not a definitive gathering of Ho's work, Balaban's deft translations are a beautiful and significant contribution to the West's growing awareness of Vietnam's splendid literary heritage. Philip Gambone

Investigators have confirmed the group's existence, although they believe it is loosely organized and includes just a handful of troopers. Andrew Jacobs

description: The black-and-white cookie, that frumpy and oversize mainstay of New York City bakeries and delis, has not endured by dint of its taste. Unlike other edible icons, like New York cheesecake or bagels, there is no such thing as a delicious black-and-white cookie. They are either edible or inedible. Fresh-baked and home-baked are the best.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  FRIEDLANDER, SAM
description: FRIEDLANDER-Sam. July 2, 1911-January 28, 1995. Remembered always. Ruth

title: Better Drug Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks
description: WONDERS OF THE AFRICAN WORLD, by Henry Louis Gates Jr. Photographs by Lynn Davis. (Knopf, $24.95.) The Harvard professor and noted essayist draws on 30 years of experience visiting and studying Africa in this lively introduction to the continent's history and archaeology, which highlights the achievements of African societies from Timbuktu to Zanzibar. Originally a ''companion'' to a PBS series, the book is somewhat limited in scope, but ''Gates writes with concentration and clarity,'' William Langewiesche wrote in the Book Review in 1999.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  FLYNN, MARY E.
description: FLYNN-Mary E. Died January 26, 2001, age 93. A native and real New Yorker. Beloved sister of the late John, James and Daniel. Beloved aunt of Patricia, John and James. Mass of the Resurrection at the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, 415 W. 59 St., NYC, on Tuesday, January 30 at 10 AM. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent in her name to St. Paul's Church.

title: Article 2001012890821380318 -- No Title
description: CYBER LAW JOURNAL

title: Basement Fire in the Bronx Leaves a Mother of 3 Dead
description: As a father's desperate screams awoke neighbors, a fire swept through a basement apartment in the Bronx early yesterday, killing a woman and leaving her three young children in critical condition, police and fire officials said.

title: Frozen in Amber of the City
description: IN Lisbeth Firmin's paintings of New York, human figures are suspended in time. They are often in motion, crossing intersections, meandering down avenues or cycling down narrow streets. (The image above is titled ''Biker on Broadway.'') In other works, tall buildings are juxtaposed against small residential walk-ups. The perspective is never straightforward but always leans toward the unusual.

title: Did Memory Serve?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ideas & Trends; When Is a Fake Too Real? It's Virtually Uncertain
description: IN the science-fiction thriller ''The Matrix,'' Keanu Reeves confronts a future in which computer-generated virtual reality is not only indistinguishable from ordinary experience but also has powerful real-world consequences. Last Monday, the Supreme Court announced that it would follow Mr. Reeves into the virtual realm by agreeing to hear a case concerning whether uncannily realistic digital simulations of children involved in sexual activity should have real-world consequences of up to 30 years in prison.

title: Trials in a Family's Own Court
description: PARENT and child conflicts are as old as the Old Testament. But when Debbie Mathers-Briggs, the mother of the foul-mouthed rapper Eminem, took her son to court for defamation in 1999, she seemed to be breaking new ground. He had described her as a drug addict in magazine interviews, so she sued. Even in this blame-crazy culture, it was a little much.

title: Coping Without Electricity in California's E-World
description: Thousands of people in Silicon Valley are seriously addicted to speed -- the pace at which information flows, that is. But when the electricity dried up, those hooked on computers, handheld devices and the like faced a dose of cold, cruel reality.

title: Baby, It's Warm Inside
description: A visitor from Minneapolis, where the ice lies thick on the lakes, expressed amazement at the number of fur coats being worn in New York and the opulence of the sable, chinchilla and Chinese ermine. With their flat pelts, the silhouette is pencil slim. The three below are, from left, a summer ermine, a Manchurian ermine and a sheared mink; right, a 1930's heirloom, a Siberian white ermine trimmed in sable. Men are wearing furs as well: far left, a mink coat and hat; bottom, second from right, a hamster ensemble.

title: Screamin' Jay Hawkins
description: I was saddened to learn of Jay's passing. From mid-1976 on and off through about 1980, I was Screamin' Jay Hawkins's occasional recording producer, as well as his contracted, full-time, exclusive (so our contract said, anyway) personal manager. Jay could drive you nuts. He could frustrate the hell out of you with his paranoia (sometimes aimed at the very people who were actually helping him). And now, having learned he had 57 children, I shouldn't be surprised that he had a habit of breaking his contractual agreements -- or of having more than one manager at a time.

title: Sunnyside Journal; The Memories of Home Leave a Poet Inspired
description: Down on 44th Street in Queens, Osherowitz the ornery tailor mended clothes and spat silver pins as he spoke into the telephone. Over on 43rd Street was Big Freddy's pot-bellied dad, Ed, who sold chocolate on the black market and made a killing on Hershey bars during the Second World War. On Queens Boulevard, rock-hard gefilte fish was on sale in the back room of an auto supply store that smelled of rubber, oil, pike and carp.

title: A Natural Comes of Age (All of 18)
description: HER father, at the time the first violinist of the Cleveland Quartet, was on tour in Europe. Her mother, a pianist, had her own concert dates on the road. So it was most inconvenient of Alisa Weilerstein, at 2, to develop chickenpox. Thank heaven for the grandmother who hastened from Albany to Rochester, bearing a handmade set of toy string instruments: two violins, viola and cello.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HANNA, ROBERT J.
description: HANNA-Robert J. On January 24, 2001 at age 49. Senior V.P. of Prudential Securities. Beloved son of Mary and the late Joseph Hanna. Beloved brother of Maryellen Linen, Kathleen Norman and Joseph Hanna. Cherished partner of 16 years to Kevin Lonergan. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St., Saturday and Sunday 25PM and 7-9PM. Funeral Mass at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, Park Avenue at 84th St., Monday 10AM. Interment private. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Robert J. Hanna Memorial Trust, 1 New York Plaza, New York, NY 10292, C/O Bella Loykhter.

title: Oyster Beds And Electricity
description: THE most lucrative oyster beds in Connecticut are in New Haven Harbor. That is the exact place where the Long Island Power Authority hopes an electrical cable can be buried next year to carry up to 600 megawatts of power for 26 miles underneath Long Island Sound to the island, where the demand for electricity appears to be creeping close to the limits of the supply.

title: January 21-27; Congo Leader Buried
description: President Laurent D. Kabila, who was assassinated by a bodyguard in the capital's presidential palace, was buried in a state funeral that raised grave doubts about who will control the Congo's government.

title: POSSIBLE END TO BASS BAN
description: A 25-year ban on commercial fishing of striped bass in the Hudson River may be ending, Jennifer K. Post, a spokeswoman for the state Department of Environmental Conservation, said. The commercial harvest and sale of striped bass from the Hudson was prohibited by the conservation department in 1976 because of health concerns related to PCB levels in fish. Only recreational fishing for striped bass is allowed. In recent years, however, PCB contamination in fish in the lower Hudson has been found to be within allowable limits. Elsa Brenner

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  DONSKY, MARILYN
description: DONSKY-Marilyn. The stars shine so brightly on your special birthday. We feel your love. Your Adoring Family

title: IMPROBABLE STORY NEEDS AN ENDING
description: It is customary, almost obligatory, for National Football League players to end practices with hands held aloft and clasped, concluding with a shout: ''Super Bowl!''

title: Start Seeds Wisely
description: Who isn't intoxicated by whiffs of spring in seed catalogs? Sober up by measuring the square feet you can devote to starting seed indoors, evaluating the conditions you can provide until it is time to plant outside and remembering that you are not supplying plants to the neighborhood.

title: Try Thinking of Teachers as Managers
description: To the Editor:

title: California Still Stands, Despite One More Punch
description: BASED on all the hoo-ha, one may think that the shocks from California's power crisis will soon loose the state from the North American land mass. The stock market is telling a different story.

title: After Ignoring Warning, St. John's Loses to Tech
description: It was St. John's first trip to the hills of southwest Virginia and Coach Mike Jarvis worried that his young, urban team might become complacent in this quiet country. Virginia Tech is new to Big East basketball; St. John's is one of the conference's most celebrated members. The Red Storm was finding its legs at the right time of the season; Virginia Tech was stumbling toward a disastrous end to its inaugural Big East season.

title: A Fight for Survival in the Broadband Wreckage
description: UP to its knees in uncollected bills from customers that resell its high-speed Internet connections, suffering from a battered stock price, relying on competitors to deliver its product and caught in a severe market downturn, Covad Communications may be facing a technology-sector version of the perfect storm.

title: Cowboys of the Sky
description: ON a recent winter afternoon, as the temperature dipped below freezing and a brisk wind blew along the cross streets of Midtown Manhattan, an ironworker named John Collins stepped out onto a six-inch-wide steel beam 24 stories above Seventh Avenue and started to walk across it. Mr. Collins carried 45 pounds of equipment on his belt, including two spud wrenches; an eight-pound sledgehammer known to ironworkers as a beater; a crowbarlike tool used to pry steel beams; and a few dozen inch-thick bolts in a hip pouch. Walking quickly but steadily, he traversed the 10-foot beam.

title: Quick Passes to Start Against a Run-Stuffing Defense
description: MATCHUPS WORTH NOTING

title: The Way We Live Now: 01-28-01: ShopTalk: Six-Day School Week; Weekend Worriers
description: For American schoolchildren, the five-day week is as much of a given as the 30-minute sitcom and the summer vacation. But lately educators have begun advocating a sixth day of classes. And earlier this month, Mayor Giuliani introduced a proposal to create weekend classes for close to 100,000 public-school students. Would more classes on more days yield more benefits? Or do two days of down time play a structural role in children's development? We called on Levin (principal of KIPP Academy Charter School in the South Bronx, which requires attendance for nine and a half hours Monday through Friday, plus two or three Saturdays a month and several weeks in summer) and Elkind (a professor of child development at Tufts University and author of ''The Hurried Child: Growing Up Too Fast Too Soon'') to discuss these questions.

title: A Garland of Mission Gardens
description: WHEN it's winter in Seattle, the words ''California garden'' hold an almost mystical appeal, and ''mission garden'' adds the allure of history, spirituality and antique Spanish grace. With my own surroundings sorely lacking all of these, I hatched a scheme that any sun-starved northern-tier gardener could relate to: in five days I'd hit as many mission gardens as time and daylight would permit between Santa Barbara and San Diego. Though I wasn't certain how many missions that entailed or where exactly they were, I did have a detailed mental image of what a mission garden should look like -- arches and oleander, fuzzy gray herbs and succulents spilling out of chipped terra-cotta pots, tiled roofs and bougainvillea -- a fantasy concocted of old picture books, climate envy and unbridled botanical imagination.

title: Hunting Clubs Fret as 'Fore' Replaces 'Tally Ho'
description: With the cry of a copper horn and a symphony of yelping dogs, two dozen members of the Essex Fox Hounds will bolt off into the snowy hills Sunday morning, hoping the pack catches a whiff of their elusive, russet-furred quarry.

title: Coltrane Was Ignored
description: To the Editor:

title: Mind and Body
description: To the Editor: I read the article on CuisinArt Resort in Anguilla, ''Rejuvenating, Any Way You Slice It'' by Caroline Seebohm (Dec. 31) the morning before my arrival there, and was somewhat disheartened by her comments about the ''rather makeshift'' Hydroponic Cafe.

title: Paid Notice: Memorials  HOCHBERG, SAMUEL DAVID
description: HOCHBERG-Samuel David. Dad, it's been 15 years. We will always miss you. Love always, Sylvia, Neil and Children Marsha, Marty and Children Alan and Children Bobbi

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEISZ, EDITH B.
description: WEISZ-Edith B. On January 25, 2001 at age 89. Beloved wife of the late Dr. Arthur Weisz, loving mother of the late George Weisz, and adoring grandmother of Jessica Weisz. Services are at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81 Street, Tuesday, January 30, 11:30 AM. Interment private.

description: Clearview

title: West Takes Calm View Of Laker Tiff
description: If he were still a full-time employee, Jerry West's stomach would be churning today. One of many people who suffer from atrial fibrillation, West would face an irregular heartbeat as he tried to sleep and forget about whatever perils faced the franchise.

title: No Change Of Plans For Knicks Vs. Lakers
description: The task seemed so formidable that it nearly forced Jeff Van Gundy to resort to trickery. With his top two centers sidelined and several other players nursing nagging injuries, Van Gundy, the Knicks' coach, considered abandoning his beloved style of smash-mouth basketball in Sunday's matchup against the Los Angeles Lakers.

title: FOLLOWING UP
description: Award in Needle Case Delayed Pending Retrial

title: From Oregon, Un-Californian Chardonnays
description: A liability of far too many muscular, pendulously fruity, heavily alcoholic California chardonnays is their built-in conflict with food. Leaner chardonnays from the Willamette Valley of Oregon, now increasingly ascendant, are friendlier, as inquisitive consumers are learning and as the Burgundy Wine Company recently showed itself.

title: Albee, Directing Albee, Is Impish About the Baby
description: FOR Edward Albee, the creator of so many children of ambiguous provenance and dark destinies, to call his new piece ''The Play About the Baby'' is an act of mischievous provocation. Naturally, there has been much speculation among critics and theatergoers about just who this baby is and whether the imaginary son in ''Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?'' has come to life as the new baby's young father. Is it mere coincidence that the ''Virginia Woolf'' son and current father share the same early trauma -- a broken arm?

title: And Bear In Mind
description: (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)

title: Oh, That's Her
description: Although everyone is asking ''Who is Jill Scott?'' -- it is the name of her debut album -- all that should soon change after the Grammy Awards on Feb. 21, where she is nominated for three awards. A former member of the Philadelphia hip-hop group the Roots, Ms. Scott is an inventive poet and R&B singer-songwriter who offers a very personal and unsentimental look at urban life. Using a jazzy looking glass, her mix of hip-hop and traditional soul, is vivid, yet simple. She soars through a series of vignettes that are easy on the ear and thrilling for their subtle grace. A nice change from the standard overproduced, generic R&B that floods radio. She will appear Saturday at the Tropicana Casino in Atlantic City. Robbie Woliver

title: Buzz, Incorporated; When Businesses in the County Want to Make News, They Turn to a Pair of Ex-Journalists
description: BACK in the 1980's, when Geoff Thompson and Dean Bender were the top business editors of the Gannett Suburban Newspapers, they developed a morning ritual involving the press releases they received.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  LOEW, DR. GILDA B.
description: LOEW-Dr. Gilda B. On January 5, 2001, at age 70, in Atherton, CA, after a valiant struggle with breast cancer. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, Gilda attended Erasmus Hall High School, graduated from NYU (B.S.) and Columbia (M.S.), and earned a Ph.D. in chemistry from UC Berkeley. After several university and other jobs and during a distinguished scientific career, she founded her own successful Molecular Research Institute in 1979. The Institute, located in Mountain View, CA, applies computational methods in chemistry to biological and pharmaceutical problems. Gilda also had a passion for literature, the arts, dancing, politics and travel, as well as for heartfelt, outspoken and intense conversations with her friends and family. She is survived by her husband Gregory Loew, her five children Paul, Linda, Neil, Florence and George, her grandchildren Nathan, Aaron and Avalon, and her brother and sister-inlaw Harold and Debra Thaw.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COPELAND, PAMELA CUNNING HAM
description: COPELAND - Pamela Cunning ham, 94, of Wilmington, Delaware, died at her home on Jan. 25, 2001. She was the widow of Lammot du Pont Copeland. Mrs. Copeland's survivors include 2 sons, Lammot duP. Copeland, Jr., and Gerret vanS. Copeland, both of Wilimington, DE and a daughter Louisa C. Duemling of Washington, DC; ten grandchildren and eighteen great grandchildren. A service will be held on Tuesday, January 30th at 11:00 AM at Christ Church, Buck Road, Wilmington, DE. Burial will be private. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests contributions to Delaware Nature Society, P.O. Box 700, Hockessin, Delaware 19707; Winterthur Gardens, Attn: Donor Information Services, Rt., 52, Winterthur, DE. 19735; or Gunston Hall, 10709 Gunston Road, Mason Neck, VA. 22079-3901.

title: Books in Brief: Fiction & Poetry
description: RESIDENT ALIENS

title: No Parking, No Parishioners, an Orthodox Church Fears
description: Last year, when a task force made up of Brooklyn community representatives considered what should be done with 18,000 square feet of state-owned parking lots in Boerum Hill, its members recommended low-rise, mixed-use buildings that would enhance and preserve the character of the landmarked residential neighborhood. But parishioners of the adjacent St. Nicholas Antiochian Orthodox Cathedral are worried that development of the property could threaten the character, even the survival, of their congregation.

title: POSTINGS: Crossroads on the Lower East Side; Retail Stores And Rentals
description: Already a magnet for young people flocking to the neighborhood their grandparents strove to leave behind, the Lower East Side has had another infusion of youth with the opening of the Crossroads, a market-rate rental building at East Broadway and Rutgers Street. Half the apartments, or 42 of the 83 units, have been taken by the New York University School of Medicine, to be rerented to postdoctoral fellows and faculty members.

title: For Hungry Shoppers In Paris
description: IT'S noon on a gray December day in Paris and I've just completed a gratifying morning of shopping at La Samaritaine, one of the quartet of great old city department stores, the others being Le Bon March, Le Printemps and the Galeries Lafayette. Besides finding a set of drapery hardware in La Samaritaine's enormous basement housewares department at a fraction of the eye-popping price back home in New York, I've learned that the French word for finial is embout.

title: Postcards From the Edge of Good Taste
description: WHEREVER I travel, running concurrently with my restaurant reconnaissance and my exploration of boutiques and art galleries is a constant quest for a native art form of an altogether different variety. The way some people seek out bazaars, my own peculiar radar is sweeping for the bizarre -- specifically in the form of postcards.

title: Montana Republicans Seek to Ease Environmental Laws
description: Citing steadily declining jobs in traditional industries like mining, logging and energy development, Montana is preparing to change its environmental regulations to make them more favorable to business.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WEINBERG, SONNENBLUM AMY
description: WEINBERG - SONNENBLUM Amy. It is with great sorrow that we announce that our mother, Amy Weinberg-Sonnenblum, died of natural causes on January 23, 2001. Beloved wife of the late Irving J. Weinberg. Loving mother of Janice Berger of West Palm Beach, FL, Alice M. Chafetz of Rockville Centre, NY, and Paul D. Weinberg of Long Beach, NY. Also survived by her most devoted six grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. We deeply mourn her passing.

title: LIPA Offers Incentives To Cut Summer Surge
description: In anticipation of tight energy supplies this summer, the Long Island Power Authority will offer yearlong lower rates to businesses, schools and government offices that generate at least half of the power they use during late spring and summer hours when electric demand peaks.

title: Edward Dimock, 71, Scholar of Indian Studies
description: Edward Dimock, an influential scholar of Indian studies and an emeritus professor at the University of Chicago, died Jan. 11 at his home in Centerville, Mass. He was 71.

title: Williams Proves He's Ready On a Night of Fists and Firsts
description: Ricardo Williams Jr. scintillated the crowd in his professional debut, and then stopped his opponent with an impressive show.

title: Anesthesiology
description: Heroin

title: In a Virtual Sculpture Park, the Art Talks Back
description: IT used to be that viewing works of art was an experience marked by a certain decorum. A hushed setting encouraged the serenity and detachment necessary to absorb truths revealed in works of timeless beauty. Whether or not you could rely on your fellow cultural pilgrims to behave in a civilized manner, one thing was certain: the art, at least, would mind its own business.

title: L.I. @ WORK
description: Procter & Gamble Ends Suit Against Distributor

title: A Plastic Surgeon Who Lifts Spirits, Not Faces
description: MENTION plastic surgery in New York, and the mind automatically travels to the indulgences of the rich and famous: tummy tucks for celebrity mothers, brow lifts for television anchors, face lifts for Upper East Side doyennes. But far from the hushed dcor of Park Avenue waiting rooms, there is a grittier edge to plastic surgery in this city, where doctors struggle to repair the ravages of urban life.

title: A Friendly Ear For Any and All New York Writers
description: IRWIN GONSHAK has welcomed best-selling writers like Evan Hunter (a k a Ed McBain) and Lawrence Block on ''Anything Goes!'' But what makes his stubbornly quirky radio show special is that he champions writers who are unpublished, and often unpublishable. A tax assessor spouting haikus. A retired legal secretary reciting poems about love and death. An office temp tripping over her words.

title: Catching a Dognap
description: For dogs that really hate to leave the house, Paradise Ranch, northeast of Los Angeles, offers home-style lodgings while the master is away. Besides wading pools and shady cabanas for naps, the 1.5-acre property features sleeping accommodations in full-size furnished bedrooms in two houses. The basic rate is $45 a day. Dogs are not kept on leashes or in cages (the property is fenced in), but male dogs more than a year old must be neutered. And for an extra $5 a night, a caretaker will sleep with a dog. Hotel pickup is available in a Mercedes. Paradise Ranch is at 10268 La Tuna Canyon Road in Sun Valley, about 45 minutes from Los Angeles International Airport, near Burbank. Call (818) 768-8708; on the Web www.paradiseranch.net

title: Taking a Holiday From the Internet
description: Investors may not be the only people losing interest in the Internet.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLOCK, HARRIS
description: BLOCK-Harris. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Company, PC, deeply mourn the passing on January 24, 2001 of Harris Block. A valued & respected client for many years, he was admired, honored and held in high esteem by every member of our firm. A man of integrity, highly intelligent, generous, charitable, possessing all the qualities of just being good, he will be missed but always remembered. Our deep condolences to his family.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  MILLER, JULIAN
description: MILLER-Julian, 80. Died January 25, 2001, after a lengthy illness. Beloved husband of Marion (Peters) for 59 years. Devoted father of Barry and Diane, Kenneth and Ronnie, Cathy (Catie) Miller of Hawthorne, FL, and Charles. Loving grandfather of Jill, Jeffrey, Jessica and Rebecca Miller. Devoted brother of Gloria Blick of Stamford, CT. Memorial services at Gutterman's, 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, at 2 PM, Monday, January 29. Shiva at 25 Hampshire Road, RVC, through Wednesday, January 31.

title: More Noise Than Art
description: To the Editor:

title: Whose Sidewalk? Whose Tree? A Knotty Diplomatic Conundrum
description: The last person you want to trip on the sidewalk in front of your house is a karma expert like Shelley Ackerman. But despite the bruises and sprained ankle Ms. Ackerman received when she stumbled over a crack in the pavement outside the Nigerian Embassy, she wishes no one harm. She just wants someone to fix what she calls ''that death trap.''

title: A Frugal Kramnik Recycles Moves That Beat Kasparov
description: Frugality has never been included among the attributes of a world champion, at least not until now. But Vladimir Kramnik trotted out the same openings that he used to win his Braingames Network world title in November against Garry Kasparov in his next contest, an exhibition match with the Hungarian grandmaster Peter Leko in Budapest, Jan. 2 to Jan. 8.

title: Crime
description: A seam runs down the spine of Michael Connelly's new police procedural, A DARKNESS MORE THAN NIGHT (Little, Brown, $25.95), dividing the narrative between two detectives working two Los Angeles homicide cases and setting us up for the moment of truth when one of these investigators accuses the other of committing the crimes. The plot device may be clever, but it doesn't generate real tension because the cop accused of being a serial murderer is none other than Connelly's longtime series hero, Harry Bosch, and unless an author is feeling suicidal, he's not about to sacrifice his hero for some cheap plot thrills.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Still a Need For Environmental Rescue
description: Re '' 'Eco-Terrorism,' and Nary a Redwood In Sight'' [Jan. 14]: It is true that our island does not contain the most flashy of natural wonders -- there are no magnificent geysers, grand stone arches or forests of gargantuan trees -- but that does not mean that we should allow what is left of our open spaces to be devoured by developers.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page credit in Arts & Leisure today for the cover of a 1934 music magazine, with the article about Bing Crosby, misspells the owner's surname in some copies. He is the writer of the article, Gary Giddins, not Giddons.

title: In Rearview Mirror, a Wistful Gaze at the Olds
description: A man might leer at a Lincoln or covet a Cadillac, people used to say, but he married an Oldsmobile.

title: Mortgage Company Opens Storefront in White Plains
description: First Alternative Mortgage, based in New Rochelle, has opened a branch in White Plains. Unlike the company's other offices, in New Rochelle and Kingston, the branch is a storefront, catering more to walk-in customers.

title: Residential Sales
description: In the following reports, the ''listed at'' price is the asking price when negotiations began that ended in the sale. Time on market is from most recent listing to contract.

title: For Springsteen, Bar Mitzvahs and Conan, This Drummer Sets the Beat
description: IT would be too much of a clich to say Max Weinberg was born to drum, despite the fact that it is apparently the truth.

title: With Bonnet Up but Chin Held High
description: THERE IS something akin to poetic justice in running out of fuel in a Rolls-Royce Corniche, being watched by an assortment of doormen, policemen and passers-by as one pours in a gallon of foul 11th Avenue no-name gas out of a battered can. The Corniche, after all, is one of the world's most exclusive and expensive convertibles, a conveyance intended for leisurely cruising along the Riviera by the deserving rich, not for joyrides by cynical hacks.

title: Now That Pluto's Gone
description: To the Editor:

title: Back Talk; McMahon's Power Signals A New Era
description: ''When the Super Bowl's over, that's it for me until next season; I'm done,'' said Bruno Sammartino, who will watch the game today in the Pittsburgh house he has lived in these past 40 years. ''Well, I might just take a look at that first game, see what he's up to now.''

title: Merrymaking With the Fezziwigs
description: ON a raw, gray, mid-December afternoon, the French Parlor at Manhattanville College was aglow with much merrymaking and toasting of the season. A woman, dressed head to toe in white with a long lace veil, greeted guests who seemed to take her appearance in stride as they entered the mahogany-paneled parlor.

title: One-Man Muse
description: ''Back in the 50's, the ability to be a fashion model was innate, something a woman either had or didn't.'' The designer Azzedine Alaa was discussing Stella Tenbrook, once a star mannequin for the legendary couturier Jacques Fath and Mr. Alaa's ideal.

title: Call It the Slowpoke in Hoboken
description: Next to Frank Sinatra and big-hair bars, this riverfront town may be best known for its lack of parking.

title: Yozo Hamaguchi; Mezzotint Engraver, 91
description: Yozo Hamaguchi, a Japanese-born artist known for his work in mezzotint engraving, a technique he was introduced to by the poet E. E. Cummings, died in Tokyo on Dec. 25. He was 91.

title: Diane Forley and Michael Otsuka
description: SOME people form first impressions by watching the way others treat waiters, handle bugs, fold clothes in a suitcase or behave during the chanting period in a yoga class. For Michael Otsuka, a chef, the herbs a person uses say a lot.

title: A Showcase Of Architectural Gems
description: Most everyone knows that the Empire State Building is a city landmark and that Trump Tower is not. But how about the Starrett-Lehigh Building at 601 West 26th Street or the quaint town house en route to the subway?

title: More Help for the Ethically Challenged
description: TAKE heart, morally adrift fellow residents. It's time for another visit from the Jersey Ethicist.

title: Parcells Fails to Join Levy, Swann and Five Others in Hall
description: Lynn Swann cried. Marv Levy joked. Bill Parcells was absent.

title: Ravens Have Been Planning for This Moment Since Before Season Began

title: Books in Brief: Nonfiction; Projecting With Mekas
description: Jonas Mekas's collection of film snippets is loaded with images of the famous -- like Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis and Caroline Kennedy, and John Lennon and Yoko Ono at their Montreal ''bed-in'' -- but these are not conventional portraits. In JUST LIKE A SHADOW (Steidl/ Scalo, $29.95), sequences of three or four film frames, often sliced randomly midframe, are presented with sprocket holes and scratchy optical soundtracks intact. Mekas's images are jerky with movement, either washed out or underexposed, and seemingly shot from the hip, but all have a feeling of spontaneity and the immediacy of life. Norman Mailer's quizzical, pained expression is juxtaposed against the American flag; the ailing but indomitable George Maciunas, the founder of the Fluxus art movement that links many of the subjects in the book, is shown smiling in his hospital bed. There is a marvelous sense of intimacy to Mekas's art of simply filming experience: a sequence of his young son vying with a large ginger cat is an ephemeral yet timeless moment. ''My film work is one long film which is still continuing,'' Mekas says in an interview with Jerome Sans. ''I don't really make films: I only keep filming. I am a filmer, not a filmmaker.'' Eric P. Nash

title: Visiting Mexico

Not knowing the Spanish phrase for ''helicopter rescue,'' I swallowed my pride and slowly crab-walked all the way down, to the delight of the many other visitors who now possess a priceless photo of the terrified would-be adventurer.

title: Bing Crosby, The Unsung King of Song
description: FOR the last decade, whenever I mentioned to anyone that I was working on a life of Bing Crosby, the usual response was, ''Why?'' I can't say I was surprised. For 30 years, between 1927 and 1956, Crosby was a looming presence in America's cultural landscape. At the peak of his career, in the 1930's and 1940's, he was thought by many to be the most famous American alive. For much of that period, he was undoubtedly the most admired. The cycle of ''Road'' pictures with Bob Hope established Crosby as a great comic actor. Yet by the 1960's, the ocean began to roll over Der Bingle, and though he continued to sell millions of records -- chiefly holiday songs -- he had morphed into a grand old man while retaining little of the bite of his contemporary, Louis Armstrong, or his aging offspring, Frank Sinatra. Crosby's reputation faltered along with his music after his death, in 1977. When his eldest son, Gary Crosby, published a bitter memoir describing the unflappable Bing administering vigorous corporal punishment, his halo tilted and crashed. Soon the afterlife of his career imploded. Jazz lovers kept his memory alive, mainly because of his early records and the later collaborations with Armstrong, Louis Jordan, Les Paul and others. But jazz lovers are by nature classicists, and Crosby had spent most of his life on the other side of the divide: the pop world, where success is measured in numbers -- a world remade by rock, in which even the oldest of oldies postdate ''Heartbreak Hotel.''

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  SICHROVSKY, KAREL
description: SICHROVSKY-Karel. On December 11, 2000, age 76, of Forest Hills, NY. Beloved husband of Marie (nee Sarafianos) for 42 years. Dear brother-in-law of James and Viginia McCrory. Loving uncle of Thomas (Marlene), Gail (Willard), Nancy (Anthony) and Amy (Vincent). Fond great-uncle of Kelly, Corey, Stephen, Scott, Demetri and Louise. Born in Vlasim, Czechoslovakia, on September 16, 1924, the son of the late Karel and Vlasta (nee Smahova) Sichrovsky, he attended Charles University in Prague from May 1945 to February 1949, and passed his first state exam. As a refugee in Ludwigsburg, Germany, Karel received a scholarship to the University of Geneva, Switzerland, graduating in November 1950 with a degree (licensie) in political science. In April 1951 he joined Radio Free Europe in Munich as a writer serving on the Czech desk until August 1956, when he came to live in the United States. There he was a senior writer at RFE's New York office until September 1959, reporting chiefly on labor. He continued his studies of political science and history at Columbia Univeristy, receiving an M.A. in 1958 and the Certificate of the Program on East Central Europe in 1959. He became a US citizen December 27, 1960. Until he retired in 1987, his scholarship, language and editorial skills gained him the respect of those with whom he worked in the world of publishing. He ran his last race with courage and grace. A celebration of the life of this remarkable man will be announced at a later date.

Courtesy of the Microsoft Corporation, every attendee was given a $600 Compaq iPaq hand-held computer, complete with a wireless networking card. title: Assisting the Homeless
description: There are as many ways into the homeless shelters of this city as there are occupants. Some people are almost overcome with surprise at finding themselves lost in ''the system,'' while others have felt its gravity tugging at them their whole lives. For most of us, who are assured of a bed and a roof at night, it seems easy enough to imagine the choices one might have made to stave off homelessness, except that choice is usually the last thing those facing the streets actually have. One by one the attributes of their humanity are taken away by circumstance -- their sense of family, vocation, even identity -- and they are left with the raw emptiness of being unhoused in a world that is no longer recognizable. It is life, but only just.

title: QUICK BITE/Hoboken; Bread, Plain but Not So Simple
description: The ingredients of great bread are deceptively simple. ''All it takes is flour, water, salt and a little bit of yeast,'' said Ivan Rodriguez, who has managed Hoboken's 63-year-old Antique Bakery since 1987. He speaks so matter-of-factly -- just a few ingredients, right? -- that you find yourself vowing to head home and dig out a mixing bowl. But after one bite of Antique's crusty white peasant round, you realize that the idea of baking such an extraordinary loaf is akin to standing in front of a Jackson Pollock painting and saying, ''I could do that.'' With its crackled crust and chewy texture, the pagnotta, as the round loaf is known, is the perfect complement to fresh mozzarella, tomato and basil. The pagnotta comes in three sizes, small ($1), medium ($1.70) and large ($2.35), and keeps for two or three days. The semolina and whole-wheat rounds, which spend about 10 minutes less in the coal-fired brick ovens than their white-flour counterparts are less crusty. Antique is the opposite of a yuppie hangout: no tables to linger at, no organic whole-wheat loaves with currants and hazelnuts, no cappuccino. It's a working man's bakery, turning out some 3,000 loaves and rolls a day, 75 percent of them destined for restaurants and delis in New York City, Jersey City and Hoboken. Focaccia (plain, $2; with tomatoes, $2.50) or bread stuffed with sausage, peppers and onions ($3.75) is about as fancy as it gets. Unless you count the green and red neon ''Antique Bakery'' winking in the window. Gretchen Kurtz

title: Historic House Hunting
description: George Washington Foster Jr. slept here -- here being Park Ridge, in Bergen County, where he lived from 1902 until his death in 1923. Foster was one of this country's first black architects, and he is profiled in ''The Architecture of Bergen County, New Jersey,'' by T. Robins Brown and Schuler Warmflash, just published by Rutgers University Press ($35). Mr. Foster's work is mainly in New York City, but many notable buildings in Bergen County are described in the book. The book is really a history of the county, told through architecture. More than 150 photographs plus maps and figures trace the days from from the stone houses of Dutch settlers 300 years ago, to (real) Colonials to the extravagant early-20th-century Crocker-McMillin mansion, known as Darlington in Mahwah (the county's first national historic landmark) and on to modern homes and buildings, including diners; this is New Jersey, after all.

When I ask the red-haired, bespectacled curator about his furniture, he gives me an art history lesson of the post-war and contemporary period, replete with the visual aid of a coffee-table design book. Then I get the tour, a recounting of the who, when, where and for-how-much of every object in the 780-square-foot apartment. The foyer houses a large photograph by Dutch photographer Rineke Dijkstra similar to ones I had just seen at the new Tate Modern in London; Levin's is of twin boys standing at the beach, and, like the Tate's, is part of Dijkstra's famous "Beaches" series. Levin, who curates a large private collection, tells me that even the walls are painted with the same white paint used by the Museum of Modern Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. title: Editorial Observer; The Pursuit of Innocence in the Golden State
description: I remember her vividly, a woman standing in the liquor aisle of a grocery store in a Sacramento suburb. She had a cigarette in one hand and with the other she placed a fifth of store-brand vodka in the grocery cart. I was 14, and it was a summer morning, 1966. My family had moved to California from Iowa only a week before, fresh as a load of turnips just lifted from the soil. I knew the woman was divorced by the way she held her cigarette, by the way she did not look around to see if anyone was watching when she took the vodka off the shelf. In Iowa, liquor was segregated in a state-owned store with all the sensory appeal of an auto-body shop. No one divorced, and smoking was, if nothing worse, a waste of matches.

title: Unarmed Threats

Familiar issues like terrorism and nuclear proliferation now must share the foreign policy agenda with threats that carry no weapons. Environmental damage, water shortages, mass movements of refugees, overpopulation, infectious diseases and even third-world poverty all affect American security. Some of these problems can intrude on our soil. But all can lead to the kind of instability and conflict that has frequently warranted American intervention.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  WOLF, ROSLYN ZEHMAN
description: WOLF-Roslyn Zehman. The Officers, Board and Staff of the American Jewish Joint Distribution Committee (JDC) mourn the passing of the beloved wife of our distinguished past President Ambassador Milton A. Wolf. She worked with her husband to provide assistance to those in need throughout the world. When her husband represented the United States as U.S. Ambassador to the Federal Republic of Austria, she served with him in Vienna. She was the leader of the spouses of the 105 ambassadors serving in Vienna, where she hosted the SALT II talks, attended by Presidents Carter and Brezhnev. Mrs. Wolf will be remembered for her warmth, generosity, and extraordinary good will. Mrs. Wolf had a lifetime involvement with the Jewish community and truly embodied the quality of a ''Woman of Valor.'' We extend our heartfelt condolences to her husband, children, grandchildren, family and friends. Eugene Ribakoff, President Jonathan W. Kolker, Bd Chrmn Michael Schneider, Exec V.P.

title: Technology Briefings
description: DEALS ARIBA TO BUY AGILE SOFTWARE Ariba Inc., a busi- ness-to-business network service provider, is acquiring Agile Software , a leading provider of Internet-based business-to- business communication technology. Ariba, of Mountain View, Calif., was one of the first network service providers to help companies move their business service relationships to the Internet. The acquisition will allow the company to add collaboration capability to its services, allowing its customers to communicate and coordinate product supply, design and other electronic-commerce functions. Each share of Agile common stock will be converted into 1.35 shares of Ariba common stock, resulting in an aggregate purchase price of roughly $2.55 billion, the companies said.

title: POLYONE TO CLOSE FOUR PLANTS AND LAY OFF 65 WORKERS
description: The PolyOne Corporation, a chemical maker created last year by the merger of the M. A. Hanna Company and the Geon Company, will close four plants and lay off 65 workers to save about $6 million a year. PolyOne, which is based in Cleveland, will take a pretax first-quarter charge of about $7 million and add $1.7 million in restructuring costs to the $393 million transaction value of the merger. Savings this year will amount to about $4 million, the company said. Plants in Conroe, Texas; Denver; Glen Rock, Pa.; and San Fernando, Calif., will be closed by midyear. The plants make plastics, vinyl and color additives.

title: There Are Questions You Shouldn't Answer
description: Some interview questions are tough, like the perennial favorite about that two-year gap in your rsum. Other questions -- concerning age, race, marital status and other personal characteristics that are protected under antidiscrimination statutes -- are illegal. Experience has helped employment agencies and career advisers distill the difference. This guide, available on job Web sites and from headhunters and career advisers, can act as a guide for interviews. If you are asked an illegal question, experts suggest that you try to figure out what the real issue is -- your ability to travel, for example -- and answer that question instead. DAVID KIRBY

description: UNITED NATIONS, Jan. 30  Declaring that no task was more urgent than rescuing 1 billion people in the world from "abject and dehumanizing poverty," the United Nations today proposed dozens of ways to finance the economic development of poorer countries.

description: The Transportation Department has given Austrian Airlines an immunity from antitrust laws that frees it to coordinate schedules and fares with United Airlines, Lufthansa and S.A.S.

title: MAXIM TO BUY DALLAS SEMICONDUCTOR
description: Maxim Integrated Products, which makes semiconductors that convert sound and temperature into computer signals, has agreed to buy Dallas Semiconductor for about $2.5 billion in stock. Maxim will pay 0.6163 share, valued at $39.14 based on Friday's close, for each Dallas Semiconductor share, which is 46 percent more than the company's Friday closing price of $26.81. Maxim, based in Sunnyvale, Calif., expects to complete the purchase in the second quarter, and has no plans to cut jobs. The move will allow Maxim to sell power-management and communications chips. Dallas Semiconductor had sought a buyer after it had trouble replacing its founder, chairman and chief executive, Vin Prothro, who died of a heart attack in November, company officials said.

title: Some Brands To Be Sold By Unilever
description: Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch consumer goods giant that bought Bestfoods in the United States last year, said today that it had agreed to sell some of its European sauces and packet-soup businesses to Campbell Soup for about $920 million to satisfy conditions imposed by regulators when they approved the Bestfoods deal.

He wrote for 1970's and 80's television programs like ''Good Times,'' ''Hart to Hart,'' ''Eight Is Enough,'' ''Magnum P.I.'' and ''Murder, She Wrote.'' He had no trouble finding agents to secure work for him. His annual salary was $150,000 to $200,000.

description: Giants quarterback Kerry Collins slightly separated his throwing shoulder in the third quarter of the Giants' 34-7 loss to the Baltimore Ravens in Sunday's Super Bowl XXXV. But Collins, evoking some gallows humor, joked that the injury did not affect his performance.

title: WESTPOINT STEVENS TO CLOSE PLANT AND CUT 468 JOBS
description: WestPoint Stevens Inc., a leading maker of bedding and towels, said it would close a plant in Seneca, S.C., and cut 468 jobs as it consolidates manufacturing to reduce costs. The plant is expected to be shut at the end of March, the company said. Some employees will be offered jobs at nearby WestPoint plants, the company said. The cuts affect about 2.9 percent of the more than 16,000 people WestPoint employs. The company, which makes Martex, Utica and Lady Pepperell brand linens, said in October that it would close two plants, one in Roanoke Rapids, N.C., and the other in Union, S.C., and lay off about 565 people, or 3.4 percent of its work force then, as part of a restructuring announced in June.

description: TAMPA, Fla., Jan. 29  Ravens Coach Brian Billick had not yet slept on his accomplishment, had not yet woken up as the Super Bowl champion, when he was thinking about what next season would be like.

title: Faith-Based Services
description: Few would dispute the proposition by President Bush yesterday that religious groups can effectively provide social services for the poor. But Mr. Bush's ambitious proposal to channel federal funds to ''faith-based'' groups to serve social needs is a potentially dangerous erosion of the constitutionally shielded boundary between church and state. As the Supreme Court has observed, that boundary not only protects Americans from improper government support for religion. It guards religion itself from government encroachment and regulation.

description: Among the myriad museums here, the Muse Guimet is one that people either love with a deep, almost secret passion, or have probably never set foot in. Lately, however, its lovers have been pining, separated from the museum's remarkable collection of Asian art for five long years while its 19th-century home on the Place d'Ina near the Seine has undergone a $48 million overhaul.

description: BEIJING, Jan. 30  One week after five people described as Falun Gong members set themselves on fire in Tiananmen Square, China finally informed its own people tonight. It broadcast grisly police videos of the burning believers as part of a newly intensified campaign to discredit the outlawed spiritual group.

description: Sendups of the culture of Hollywood, its superficialities and self-importance, constitute a minigenre by now, a particularly wearying one. The amusement factor in the kind of paranoia, insecurity and materialism that pervades the celebrity culture and its aspiring constituency has grown familiar and wan, enough so that you'd think -- and wish -- writers would be less eager to exploit it than they are.

But at the same time, far fewer such cases are being brought, and many lawyers are turning away clients because their injuries are not debilitating enough to bring in big awards.

But this variety and availability, along with changes in food production, eating habits, people's age and overall health, and the food-borne organisms themselves, have resulted in a number of serious and sometimes fatal episodes of food poisoning in recent years.

Jacobson, which makes a market in shares of about 90 companies, will be combined with Spear, Leeds & Kellogg L.L.C., the trading firm that Goldman bought last year.

description: The Dow Jones industrial average posted a strong gain today, but most of the stock market remained stagnant as investors awaited the Federal Reserve's next move to cut in interest rates in an effort to revive the slowing economy.

title: So They're Snarky, Whiny and Loud. They Look Fabulous.
description: ''Outwit, Outplay, Outlast'' are still the words on the ''Survivor'' logo, but ''Survivor II'' really should add ''Outhype, Outsnipe.'' The sequel reached ridiculous heights of publicity even before it arrived on Sunday, shrewdly positioned by CBS in the plum spot right after the Super Bowl. And when it arrived, the new episode displayed a bitter tone. Already loaded with connivance and suspicion, the new ''Survivor'' fits neatly into the season's latest crop of reality shows, which are all about betrayal.

description: The New Jersey attorney general's office has subpoenaed records relating to a lucrative land deal central to New York City's plan to export its trash, an agreement that would benefit a trash hauler barred from doing business in New York City and the family of the mayor of Linden.

description: Researchers reporting on the effectiveness of new drugs tend to skimp on providing information on their safety and side effects, according to a study published last Wednesday in The Journal of the American Medical Association.

description: Sovereign Bancorp, which operates bank branches throughout the northeastern United States, agreed to sell 18 offices in Delaware, southern New Jersey and Pennsylvania to the Fulton Financial Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. The transaction includes $319 million in deposits and $53 million in loans, the companies said. Fulton, based in Lancaster, Pa., operates 160 banking offices in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Delaware and New Jersey, and has assets of $6.6 billion.

title: Work Has Just Begun for Pained Giants
description: As Giants Coach Jim Fassel has done all season, he pushed all the right buttons with his team, this time in the emotional and draining moments after the Giants' crushing 34-7 loss to Baltimore in Super Bowl XXXV. With the team gathered around him Sunday night, Fassel told the players how proud he was of them. He implored them to remember this moment and to use it as motivation to get back.

title: The Bids Too Low, Cablevision Is Said to End Rainbow Auction
description: The Cablevision Systems Corporation has taken its programming unit, Rainbow Media, off the auction block after it failed to receive bids beyond $4 billion, executives close to the sale said yesterday. Instead, Cablevision is reconsidering creating a separate tracking stock for Rainbow Media, the executives said.

title: The Stakes Will Be High In St. John's-UConn Game
description: One has lost four games in a row for the first time in four years, the other is coming off a comatose performance that resulted in a disheartening loss to one of the Big East's weakest teams. When Connecticut meets St. John's tonight at Madison Square Garden, the stakes will transcend the annual city-versus-suburban rivalry and the game will not be a showcase for two of the conference's perennial powers.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  HIRSCHBERG, ELIZABETH GAREY
description: HIRSCHBERG-Elizabeth Garey, 87. January 18 at home in Charlotte, NC. Her elegance and charm were surpassed only by her courage and spirit. Survived by her daughters Brenda Miles, Charlotte, NC; Suzanne Miles, Sante Fe, New Mexico; and her son Robert Miles, Sacramento, CA; seven grandchildren; five great-grandchildren; four devoted sisters; 42 nieces and nephews; 17 greatnieces and nephews. Memorial service February 18, at Harbor Lawn-Mount Olive Memorial Park, Costa Mesa, CA. In lieu of flowers the family suggests donations to Hospice at Charlotte, 1420 E. 7th St., Charlotte, NC 28204.

title: People
description: * Michael Garcia was named to the new post of president and general manager for the Latin American operations of Tribal DDB Worldwide, Miami. He had been vice president for strategic consulting at Eon Strategics, New York. Tribal DDB is part of the DDB Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group.

title: ARIBA TO BUY AGILE SOFTWARE
description: Ariba Inc., a business-to-business network service provider, is acquiring Agile Software, a leading provider of Internet-based business-to-business communication technology. Ariba, of Mountain View, Calif., was one of the first network service providers to help companies move their business service relationships to the Internet. The acquisition will allow the company to add collaboration capability to its services, allowing its customers to communicate and coordinate product supply, design and other electronic-commerce functions. Each share of Agile common stock will be converted into 1.35 shares of Ariba common stock, resulting in an aggregate purchase price of roughly $2.55 billion, the companies said.

title: Loss at California Utility Is Placed at $4.5 Billion
description: A state-ordered audit of the financial records of Southern California Edison shows that the utility lost roughly $4.5 billion through the end of last year because of the soaring wholesale price of electricity, but Gov. Gray Davis said the report still did not justify a rate increase for the utility.

title: Teachers to Have Training Web Site
description: The Board of Education has awarded a $500,000 contract for the development of a Web site to train teachers. The contract was awarded last week to Classroom Connect Inc., a Silicon Valley company that specializes in Internet-based curriculum and professional development for elementary and secondary school teachers.

title: Grim Task Now In India Quake: Excavate Dead
description: Three days after an earthquake devastated swaths of western Gujarat, the search for survivors has largely given way to the grim task of excavating the dead from the rubble.

title: Metro Business Briefing; FULTON STREET UPGRADE
description: Bedford-Stuyvesant's main commercial thoroughfare, Fulton Street, has an abundance of street vendors, 99-cent stores, beauty and nail salons, and jewelry and liquor stores. But it lacks many of the businesses that residents of other neighborhoods take for granted, like dry cleaners, sit-down restaurants and book and record stores. Last week, city officials awarded a $3 million grant to the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce to be used to strengthen existing businesses and attract new retailers to Fulton Street. The grant will be used to improve facades, street lighting and window displays and for other services like marketing, planning and business assistance, said Kenneth Adams, the chamber's president. Terry Pristin

title: Metro Business Briefing; EARTHWEB FOUNDERS RESIGN
description: A week before EarthWeb, one of the first content companies in Manhattan's Silicon Alley to make a splash with an initial public offering, is scheduled to report its earnings, the two brothers who founded the troubled Internet company announced yesterday that they had resigned from their management positions. EarthWeb officials said Jack D. Hidary resigned as president and chief executive of the company and became the chairman instead. His brother Murray Hidary resigned as executive vice president but will continue to serve on the company's board. Peter A. Derow, the former president of Institutional Investor Inc., a subsidiary of the Walt Disney Company, was named president and chief executive of the company. EarthWeb lost $33.5 million on revenues of $51.1 million in the first nine months of last year, compared with a loss of $24.9 million on revenues of $19.5 million in the first nine months of 1999. Jayson Blair

title: OFFICEMAX TO CLOSE 50 STORES AND CUT 1,200 JOBS
description: OfficeMax Inc. said it would close 50 stores and cut 1,200 jobs and warned investors that it would post a loss for its fourth quarter. After reviewing its nearly 1,000 stores, OfficeMax has identified 50 poorly performing ones that it will close within three months. As a result, the company said, it will take an after-tax charge of $75 million in its fourth quarter, which ended on Saturday. OfficeMax also warned that it would post a loss of 5 cents a share or more for the quarter. The retailer blamed lower consumer spending in the United States for the loss.

title: Why Fight the Surplus?
description: Contrary to conventional wisdom, Alan Greenspan is not an oracle; he is a brilliant economist with certain political views. And that means when he speaks we should listen critically, sorting out the economics from the ideology. We would have done well to remember that last week, when Mr. Greenspan, in a meeting before the Senate Budget Committee, endorsed tax cuts.

title: INTEL'S LOW-VOLTAGE CHIPS READY
description: The Intel Corporation has unveiled two new microprocessors for the subnotebook category of laptop computers and said that an International Business Machines computer, scheduled for release tomorrow in Japan, would be the first to use the chips. Frank Spindler, vice president and general manager of mobile platforms for Intel, said the low-voltage Pentium III and Celeron processors, which both run at 500 megahertz, were the world's first to operate under one volt while consuming less than a half watt of power. Intel, however, has lagged behind Transmeta, an upstart chip maker that last year began making low-voltage chips for subnotebooks made by Sony, NEC, Fujitsu, Casio and Hitachi. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: The Neediest Cases; Longing to Look Just Like Her Twin
description: When visitors come to her home for the first time, little Marie Estevez is reluctant to come out of her room. When she finally emerges, she hides behind her mother's sweater and peeks around her mother's side with her good eye.

title: INDUSTRIAL PRODUCTION IN JAPAN
description: Industrial production in Japan rose 1.5 percent in December, beating economists' projections. But the figure fell short of corporate forecasts, and it did little to redeem what otherwise was a dismal fourth quarter, with output rising a scant 0.3 percent, a sharp decline from the 1.6 percent to 1.7 percent pace of the previous two quarters. The Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, which compiles the statistics, lowered its assessment of the health of Japan's industrial production on the back of the December figures for the first time since September 1998. Stephanie Strom (NYT)

title: From a Musical Prodigy to a Master Conductor
description: Lorin Maazel, the New York Philharmonic's choice to succeed Kurt Masur as its music director, will be the 24th conductor to hold that position or an equivalent. (The titles have changed over the years.) He is also only the third American to lead the orchestra, after Urelli Corelli Hill, its first director, and Leonard Bernstein, its 19th.

description: AT&T reported a huge fourth-quarter loss yesterday, burdened by write-offs from its high-speed Internet holdings and the erosion of revenue from long-distance operations.

title: CANADIAN AIRLINE ACQUISITION
description: Two small Canadian airlines have agreed to combine operations, forming the country's No. 2 carrier -- although with annual revenue of about 1 billion Canadian dollars a year ($664 million), it will be only one-tenth the size of Air Canada, the leading airline. Toronto-based Canada 3000 Inc., which is primarily an international airline, is offering one share for 2.5 shares of Royal Aviation Inc. of Montreal, which operates short domestic routes. The transaction, valued at 84 million Canadian dollars, is conditional on acceptance by Royal shareholders. Timothy Pritchard (NYT)

description: Douglas Howcroft Mazonowicz, a graphic artist who helped preserve some of the world's most famous prehistoric cave paintings by recreating them on silk, died on Sunday in Riverdale, the Bronx. He was 80.

title: Luring the Best in an Unsettled Time
description: FOR much of the last century, employment in America rested on an exchange that contemplated far more than a day's wages for a day's work: it was all about a bundle of unspoken long-term commitments. Employees gave companies their loyalty -- however grudgingly -- in return for training, promotions, steady raises, job security and identity.

title: Re-entry Means Resetting Their Sights
description: WHETHER they left the workplace for four months or 14 years -- or are considering a leave -- women will find that re-entry takes planning, ingenuity and flexibility regarding salaries, schedules and even the work itself. Resilience doesn't hurt, either, when it comes to the emotional burden of working in a society in which 64 percent of respondents, as measured by a 1996 national Gallup poll, said they believed children were better off if their mothers stayed home.

title: Metro Business Briefing; GAS PIPELINE PROPOSED
description: KeySpan Corporation, the energy company based in Brooklyn, proposed yesterday to build a new natural gas pipeline that would bring gas into the New York metropolitan region from the recently developed fields off Nova Scotia. The pipeline, which would be owned by a partnership formed by KeySpan and the Duke Energy Corporation, would extend 40 miles from existing pipelines in southern Connecticut, cross Long Island Sound, and end at KeySpan's property near the site of the old Shoreham nuclear power plant, about 60 miles east of New York City. Numerous hurdles exist: the plan requires approval by federal energy officials as well as state regulators in Connecticut and New York. Kirk Johnson

title: Transcript of Mike Freemans Visit to the N.F.L. Forum
description: Mike Freeman, who covers the N.F.L. for The Times, visited the N.F.L. forum on Jan. 29, to discuss the Super Bowl. Here is a transcript of the event.

title: CONVERGENT FIRES 160 WORKERS
description: Convergent Communications, a provider of Internet and network services, said it had dismissed 160 people, or 22 percent of its workers, and closed five offices after selling its telephone unit. Convergent Communications said it sold the unit on Friday to Phoenix-based Inter-Tel for an undisclosed amount and planned to focus on data networking and Internet services rather than telephone systems and equipment, the company spokeswoman, Jil Hicks, said. Convergent Communications closed offices in Boston; Omaha; Portland, Ore.; Seattle; and Tampa, Fla., as part of the cuts. The company said it would hire about 70 new employees to sell data-networking services.

title: President Offers Plan to Promote Oil Exploration
description: President Bush said today that he was ''deeply concerned'' that the power crisis was ''spreading beyond the California borders'' and vowed to make it easier for companies to explore, exploit and transport oil and gas for the production of more electricity.

title: Anvil Chorus? Nope, Think Of a Clangor Of Busy Riffs
description: Opera companies around the world are celebrating the centenary of Verdi's death, which was Saturday night, with new productions of his operas. But Joel Sachs, who conducts the New Juilliard Ensemble, the school's adventurous group for contemporary music, had the interesting idea to pay homage to Verdi by exploring the music that came in his aftermath.

description: ''I've had plenty of defective products, clearly defective, where I won't even talk to the people because their injuries aren't severe enough. If they're not a quadriplegic, a paraplegic or losing some part of their body, there's no way I'm going to take that case.''

His announcement sets up what is expected to be a hugely competitive Democratic primary between the son of a former governor and the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, who is seeking to become the state's first black governor.

title: Helping New Workers Look the Part
description: YOU might not think that Dress for Success, the four-year-old nonprofit organization that provides free clothing to low-income women entering or re-entering the work force, could afford to be selective. But when it has its annual clothing drive, or when it receives donations from companies like Jones New York, Liz Claiborne and Talbots, not everything makes it to the fitting-room floor.

title: A Countertenor Sets Out on an Expedition
description: Equipped with a costume and a role to portray and animated by the guidance of a stage director, the countertenor David Walker may well have something to communicate as an artist, as his flourishing opera career since he won the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions in 1998 would seem to indicate. But in a song recital a singer is far more exposed. Furthermore, Mr. Walker, in his New York recital debut at Weill Hall on Friday night, was probably not at the top of his game; that he didn't give an encore indicated that he himself didn't feel he'd done his best.

title: Investors' Advocate at the S.E.C.; Departing Chief Leaves Legacy Of Activism
description: Within the confines of a two-century-old Quaker meetinghouse here, Arthur Levitt, the departing chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, was in his element. In his 43rd, and final, investors' town hall meeting earlier in January, Mr. Levitt sounded the battle cry against financial miscreants -- and the crowd loved it.

title: India's Boundless Grief
description: The casualty count in India keeps rising after the violent earthquake that convulsed the western state of Gujarat last Friday. Like the quake that devastated western Turkey two years ago, indeed like nearly every major earthquake, the estimates of the numbers of dead and injured rose slowly at first and then shot up abruptly as more and more aid arrived and the scale of the devastation became apparent. Estimates of the numbers of dead now reach as high as 20,000.
