title: EDSTROM, BAUSCH & LOMB EXECUTIVE, RESIGNS
description: Bausch & Lomb said that Hakan Edstrom, who oversaw the company's contact lens, lens-care products, surgical and other businesses in North and South America, had resigned to pursue other opportunities. Bausch & Lomb, a leading maker of contact lenses, said earlier this month that fourth-quarter profit would fall short of Wall Street's expectations because of slowing demand for a vision-correction laser surgery procedure known as Lasik. The company said Mr. Edstrom, who was president of the Americas division, would pursue other career opportunities and declined to comment further. Shares of Bausch & Lomb, which is based in Rochester, fell 80 cents, to $45.08. Last week, Bausch & Lomb said profit from operations in the fourth quarter fell to $37.4 million, or 70 cents a share, from $51.4 million, or 88 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier as demand slowed for lens-care products and laser-surgery equipment.

He graduated from Harvard University in 1929. Mr. Glynn was a lifelong horseman and polo enthusiast. He is survived by his daughter, Sanford Glynn, of Boykin, SC, his son, Michael Glynn, of NYC, and granddaughter, Shannon Woolfe, of Hillsborough, NC. He was predeceased by his wife of 55 years, the former Mabel Jennings. Services will be held Friday, February 2, at 11 AM, St. Thomas Aquinas Church, 1719 Post Road, Fairfield, Conn. In lieu of flowers, donations in Mr. Glynn's memory may be made to the Thoroughbred Retirement Foundation, 450 Shrewsbury Plaza, Suite 351, Shrewsbury, New Jersey 07702.

The site, www.consumer.gov/sentinel, contains a database of more than 300,000 consumer complaints lodged with the commission over the last several years. Online since 1997, the site had been restricted by passwords to law-enforcement officials worldwide to allow them to share tools and ideas for investigating and prosecuting cases. Part of the site remains accessible only to law enforcement officials.

title: Disney, in Retreat From Internet, to Abandon Go.com Portal Site

title: Amazon Announces 15% Cut in Workforce

title: BT MAY UNLOAD ALL OF YELL
description: In the first sign that the British Telecommunications restructuring plan may be developing some cracks, the company said it was rethinking its plan, announced in November, to sell a 25 percent stake in Yell, its directory and e-commerce unit, to investors in an initial public offering. Instead, it said, it may spin off the unit as an independent company or, analysts said, it may sell Yell to a competitor. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

title: Officer, Sobbing, Recalls Secret Life of Crime
description: The fear of getting caught had passed, as had the shame of pleading guilty before a federal judge to charges of armed robbery and murder conspiracy. So the only thing that remained for Anthony Trotman yesterday was to tell the tale of his startling transformation from a New York City police officer to a member of a brazen Brooklyn robbery gang.

title: BP AMOCO PLANS TO SHED ITS STAKE IN LUKOIL

BP Amoco, which also owns a chain of gas stations and an interest in a natural gas field, said the stake was not big enough to give it influence over Lukoil's management. The company, which acquired the stake in its takeover of the Atlantic Richfield Company last year, said it would use the $650 million in proceeds to invest in projects elsewhere. title: NESTL AND COKE EXPAND PARTNERSHIP
description: Nestl S.A. plans to expand its joint venture for ready-to-drink beverages with the Coca-Cola Company to enter new markets and segments. Nestl and Coca-Cola plan to rename their partnership, which has existed since 1991, Beverage Partners Worldwide. The equally owned venture, whose products include tea and coffee, currently operates in 24 countries, including Canada, Germany and Hong Kong. The partnership allows Nestl to sell some of its products through Coca-Cola's distribution network. Beverage Partners Worldwide will focus on marketing and sales of ready-to-drink beverages that are sold in places ranging from grocery stores and vending machines to gas stations and cinemas.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  UNTERMYER, SAMUEL II
description: UNTERMYER-Samuel II. Born in New York City, November 25, 1912 died of natural causes at the age of 88. He graduated from Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1934. Served in the Navy as an Engineering Officer in WWII. Married Joan Silvia Gray who preceded him in death. Mr. Untermyer invented the ''Steam Forming Neutronic Reactor, And Method Of Operating It.'' While working for General Electric in 1954, he developed the Boiling Water Reactor, which provided electricity for PG & E Company through 1963. He was a founder of the American Nuclear Society, a Fellow of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers. He received the Franklin Institute Newcomen Medal in 1981, wrote many technical papers, and co-authored a book. His Vallecitos Power Plant held the Atomic Energy Commission's ''Power Reactor License No. 1.'' After his retirement, he continued his work towards peaceful development of nuclear power, starting his company National Nuclear Corporation. He assisted his brother Frank on a book about his grandfather, Samuel Untermyer I. He was also an avid equestrian, a founding member of The Shack Writers, and enjoyed fishing, gardening, traveling and the arts. He is survived by four children and three grandchildren. For further information, please contact the Roller Hapgood Funeral Home, 650-328-1360.

title: Technology Briefing
description: HARDWARE INTEL CUTS CHIP PRICES Intel slashed prices on its fastest microprocessors yesterday, trying to clear out older product lines to speed the transition to its new Pentium 4 chip. Intel, the leading maker of chips for personal computers, cut the price of its one-gigahertz Pentium III by 42 percent, to $268 from $465, when bought in batches of 1,000. Slower Pentium III chips were reduced 20 percent to 31 percent. Computer manufacturers buy the chips to power their machines. An Intel spokesman said the company hoped to be shipping more Pentium 4 chips than Pentium III's by the end of this year. To accelerate the transition, Intel also discounted the Pentium 4 processor, released in November, 18 percent to 21 percent. Chris Gaither (NYT)

title: Revlon Debt Relief
description: Revlon Inc. said yesterday that its main unit had agreed to pay a $1.6 million fee and higher interest rates on its loans to be released from requirements that will free up some cash and make it less likely the company will default on the debt. Under the terms of the amendment, Revlon's lenders, led by J. P. Morgan Chase & Company, will permit the company to sell plants it is closing and retain the proceeds rather than pay down bank debt. Revlon said last November that it would cease manufacturing at plants in Mississauga, Ontario, and Phoenix, Ariz.; shift production to Oxford, N.C., and lay off more than 1,000 workers in an attempt to bolster profitability.

title: HOLIDAY SHOPPING COMPLAINTS DECLINE
description: Shoppers who made purchases online this holiday season were spared one of the biggest headaches of last year -- late deliveries. A review of complaints lodged with the Federal Trade Commission and Better Business Bureaus suggested that Internet retailers were better prepared to handle holiday shipping commitments in 2000 than they had been in 1999, officials said. F.T.C. officials said fewer complaints were filed about late deliveries this year, in part because online retailers ''toned down'' their promises and strengthened inventory systems. Jodie Bernstein, the director for consumer protection at the commission, said that ''at this time last year, the F.T.C. had already begun investigating more than a dozen online companies.''

title: Metro Business Briefing; OPTIMISM FOR NEW MEDIA
description: Despite recent signs of a slowdown in the new-media industry, computer and telecommunications executives in the New York metropolitan region said in a survey that they were optimistic about the industry's future. The survey, conducted by the New York New Media Association and released yesterday, was sent to 2,373 executives, 152 of whom responded. Respondents predicted an increased emphasis on wireless, broadband and interactive television technology in coming years and said they foresaw replacing some full-time employees with freelancers. They ranked cost of space and quality of telecommunications services as the biggest problems with operating in New York, and cited the quality of the work force as a top benefit. title: DISPUTE OVER UTILITY BUYOUT
description: The European Commission, the administrative arm of the European Union, warned the Spanish government not to try to block the proposed $3.2 billion takeover of a Spanish utility, Hidroelctrica del Cantabrico S.A., by Portugal's largest utility group, EDP -Electricidade de Portugal S.A., without permission from Brussels. ''The European Commission has exclusive competence to review mergers that fall under its rules,'' as this one does, said a commission spokeswoman, Amelia Torres. Spain claims jurisdiction because EDP is 31 percent owned by the Portuguese government, and Spanish law requires Madrid to rule on deals involving state-owned companies, a provision that has set off disputes with the commission in the past. European Union rules allow member states to intervene in deals that affect national security or media pluralism, or when they have a fiduciary interest, but Ms. Torres said the proposed utility merger does not appear to fit any of those criteria. Paul Meller

title: PRIVACY BILL OFFERED IN SENATE
description: Senator John Edwards, Democrat of North Carolina, has reintroduced legislation to protect the privacy of consumers from software that monitors their online activity, Under the bill, companies that use ''cookies'' -- small files containing identification numbers -- to monitor user behavior would have to disclose what information they gather. ''Technology makes our lives easier in so many ways, but that convenience can compromise our privacy,'' Mr. Edwards said. The bill, which was first introduced in October 2000 but died without action, would require businesses to let individuals know what information has been assembled and provide a way to correct errors. Recent efforts at establishing federal standards for Internet privacy have floundered because of industry opposition and the Clinton administration's preference for self-regulation. Andrew Zipern

title: Metro Business Briefing; BIDDING FOR TWIN TOWERS
description: Boston Properties and Brookfield Financial Properties, two of the largest commercial landlords in New York, have joined forces in making a multibillion-dollar bid for the World Trade Center, the 10.6 million-square-foot complex in Lower Manhattan. The two real estate giants, as well as Vornado Realty Trust and Silverstein Properties, will submit their final offers today to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which owns the complex. The bids for a 99-year lease are expected to reach $3 billion. A final deal is expected to be negotiated by the end of the year. In 1998, the Port Authority was hoping the complex would fetch $1.5 billion. But its value soared because of the rising real estate market and better management of the complex, where revenues rose from $317 million in 1996 to an estimated $371 million last year. Charles V. Bagli (NYT)

The purchase would connect Wisconsin Central's 2,850 miles of track in the Midwest with Canadian National's 15,000 miles, which run across Canada and south to New Orleans.

title: Reckonings; Smog and Mirrors
description: A couple of weeks ago, in one of his first statements about the California energy crisis, George W. Bush placed the blame squarely on pollution controls: ''If there's any environmental regulations preventing California from having a 100 percent max output at their plants -- as I understand may be -- then we need to relax those standards.'' But his assertion was swiftly contradicted -- not just by environmentalists and California officials, but by the energy industry. A spokesman for Houston-based Reliant Energy, which operates four Southern California plants, told The Los Angeles Times that assertions that environmental regulations were holding back power production were ''absolutely false.''

title: INTEL CUTS CHIP PRICES
description: Intel slashed prices on its fastest microprocessors yesterday, trying to clear out older product lines to speed the transition to its new Pentium 4 chip. Intel, the leading maker of chips for personal computers, cut the price of its one-gigahertz Pentium III by 42 percent, to $268 from $465, when bought in batches of 1,000. Slower Pentium III chips were reduced 20 percent to 31 percent. Computer manufacturers buy the chips to power their machines. An Intel spokesman said the company hoped to be shipping more Pentium 4 chips than Pentium III's by the end of this year. To accelerate the transition, Intel also discounted the Pentium 4 processor, released in November, 18 percent to 21 percent. Chris Gaither

To her entire family we extend our heartfelt condolences. title: Enslaved in Modern Africa, but Daring to Break Free
description: A slave who can read finds a book in her master's library. It's the chronicle of a former slave named Udu, and she realizes it is the same story her grandmother used to tell of a brother and sister abducted and separated forever. The tale, perhaps from her own ancestor, stirs her longing for freedom; eventually she dares to escape.

title: MORE RESTRUCTURING BY ING GROUP
description: Continuing a restructuring announced in November, the ING Group said it would sell the United States operations of ING Barings, the investment bank it bought in 1995, to ABN Amro for $275 million. At the same time, ING said it would fold the remaining ING Barings operations outside the United States into its European commercial banking division. As a result, 1,300 employees of ING Barings in the United States will transfer to ABN Amro; an additional 1,000 people around the world will be laid off, including 500 employees in London. ING said the reorganization of its Barings unit, which it bought for $:1 plus the assumption of $1 billion in debt after a trader, Nick Leeson, racked up $1.25 billion in losses, would result in 500 million euros ($458.7 million) of annual savings. Suzanne Kapner

title: COURT LETS ICAHN'S OFFER FOR RELIANCE DEBT PROCEED
description: A federal appeals court ruled yesterday that the financier Carl C. Icahn's tender offer for the senior notes of Reliance Group Holdings could go forward. A two-judge panel of the 2nd Circuit Court of Appeals refused to extend an order that blocked Mr. Icahn from buying more bonds of the troubled insurance company. Last week, the appellate court issued an order temporarily stopping Mr. Icahn from acquiring the bonds. ''At this point, we're free to proceed,'' said Mr. Icahn's lawyer, Theodore Altman. The tender offer expired at 5 p.m. yesterday. Under the tender offer, Mr. Icahn sought to buy $40 million worth of the company's senior notes at 17 cents on the dollar. He already owned 29 percent of the company's senior debt. If Mr. Icahn was able to obtain at least one-third of Reliance's outstanding debt, he would be able to block any restructuring plan.

title: CONTAINER MAKER TO CLOSE PLANTS AND ELIMINATE JOBS
description: The Sonoco Products Company, which makes containers for food and consumer products, said yesterday that it planned to cut 487 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force, and close some plants to reduce costs. The company, which employs 19,000, won't fill some vacancies or replace retirees, a spokesman, Allan Cecil, said. Sonoco will eliminate 235 of 4,000 salaried positions and 252 hourly jobs. It said the plan would cut costs by $25 million to $30 million a year. Sonoco, based in Hartsville, S.C., said it would close or had closed plants in Shepherd, Mich.; Jacksonville, Fla.; Spokane, Wash.; Jeffersonville, Ind.; and in five overseas locations. It also will close its can plant in Benicia, Calif.

title: Wrong Way on Energy
description: In his opening days in office, President Bush has taken on a number of issues such as taxes and education with discipline and an appearance of growing confidence. Perhaps for that reason he believes that California's energy crisis has given him the hot hand for rolling back environmental standards and pressing his shortsighted campaign to open the 1.5-million-acre coastal plain of the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge to oil exploration. It hardly signals a balanced approach to put Vice President Dick Cheney, also an oil man, in charge of a task force aimed at developing an energy strategy to reduce America's ''reliance on foreign oil'' and ''bring more energy into the marketplace.'' Mr. Bush made clear that legislation asking Congress to open the refuge would be an essential component of that strategy.

title: JAPANESE CONSUMERS INCREASE SPENDING
description: Consumer spending in Japan rose in December for the first time in three months, government data showed. While wage earners' household spending declined over the entire year, households spent 0.8 percent more in December than the month the year before, even as their income slipped 4.0 percent, causing some to believe that consumer sentiment may be on the mend. Households have been cutting down on their clothing and furniture budgets while increasing their spending on telecommunications equipment like cellular phones and the Internet. Miki Tanikawa

title: Meeting Is Set for Fox and the Bills
description: John Fox, the Giants' defensive coordinator, planned to meet with Buffalo General Manager Tom Donahoe late today to discuss the Bills' vacant head-coaching position.

title: Estate Tax Is Fair
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.C. Champs Get Together for the Last Time
description: Early today, when the Giants arrived at their lockers for the last time this season, there was a commemorative football embossed with the Super Bowl XXXV logo inside every stall. It was one of those white, ceremonial footballs -- the kind used for getting autographs. And with great zeal, the Giants immediately scurried about the room to get their footballs signed by their Super Bowl teammates.

title: BAT TO BUY BACK AUSTRALIA SHARES
description: British American Tobacco P.L.C. said it would buy back from investors the 40.5 percent of its Australian unit that it does not already own for 1.11 billion Australian dollars, ($605 million) in cash, a premium of 28 percent on its closing stock price yesterday. The offer includes a dividend set for Feb. 28. The subsidiary, British American Tobacco Australasia Ltd., dominates the region's cigarette market with a 45 percent share in Australia and about 80 percent in New Zealand and Pacific island nations; it had about $1 billion in sales and $39.7 million in net income in the first half of its fiscal year. But the market is shrinking, especially in Australia, where smokers have declined to 22 percent of adults from 30 percent in the late 1980's. Becky Gaylord

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  COHEN, MARILYN
description: COHEN-Marilyn. Died peacefully on January 30th, 2001. Surviving are her deeply loving husband, Max, her adoring children, Ellen and Ronald Murphy and Donald and Diane Cohen; her four adoring grandchildren, Emily and Jared Cohen and Alexandra and Joanna Murphy; and by her brother and sister-in-law, Alan and Bobby Mirken. She will be fondly remembered by her many very close friends. Services Thursday, 10 AM, at ''Riverside-Nassau No. Chapels,'' 55 No. Station Plaza (opp. LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Visiting hours Wednesday, 7-9 PM.

title: Long Before Verdict, Lockerbie Changed Airport Security
description: WASHINGTON, Jan. 31  The destruction of Pan Am 103, along with subsequent bombings and other suspected terrorist acts, produced a profound change in airline security long before today's verdict.

title: Agency Clears Texas Cattle In Quarantine
description: The Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that 1,222 cattle being held in a Texas feedlot had consumed a small amount of animal feed that contained the ground-up remains of other cattle, a violation of rules designed to protect the American food supply from mad cow disease.

title: Qatar Oil Minister Is Predicting a Price of $20 to $22 a Barrel
description: CAIRO, Dec. 30 (Bloomberg News) -- Crude oil prices will probably average $20 to $22 a barrel in 2002, a level that will help the economies of energy-consuming nations, the oil minister of Qatar said on Saturday, a day after OPEC agreed to cut production.

title: EARTHLINK BEATS ESTIMATES
description: EarthLink Inc., the second-largest United States Internet service provider, lost less than Wall Street expected in the fourth quarter but warned that slowing subscriber growth could result in a bigger-than-expected loss in the current quarter. Excluding merger and acquisition costs, the company posted a fourth-quarter loss of $52.2 million, or 40 cents a share, beating Wall Street estimates by 11 cents. EarthLink had a net loss of $25.9 million, or 22 cents, in the comparable period in 1999. The company completed its $1.4 billion merger with its rival MindSpring in 2000. Revenues for the quarter totaled $286.8 million, up 44 percent from a year earlier.

title: Paid Notice: Deaths  POLLACK, BERNARD
description: POLLACK-Bernard. Our dearly beloved dad and grandfather. Husband of the late Judy. Brother, uncle, friend, adviser and colleague. Died January 29. Donations to the City College Alumni Association. Services at Sunset Chapels, 1285 Northern Boulevard, Manhasset, Noon, February 1.

description: A Critic's Notebook article yesterday about ''Survivor II'' on CBS included an incorrect day, from the network, for an online chat at CBS.com with Debb, the first contestant voted off the show. It is scheduled for today at 3 p.m.; it did not take place on Monday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Bouncing and Sliding as Musical Instruments
description: Many dancers were seen in new roles when the New York City Ballet presented a choreographically varied program on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Political Wrangling Over Nuclear Plant Intensifies in Taiwan
description: HONG KONG, Jan. 31  Taiwan's political stalemate hardened today, as the country's legislature voted to reverse a decision by President Chen Shui-bian to scrap a partially-built nuclear power plant.

title: Yellowknife Journal; In Far North, Fabled Dogs Come Bounding Back
description: With howling and yipping rising from behind chain-link fences, a noisy dog kennel in an industrial suburb here is an unexpected place to find a species bouncing back exuberantly from the brink of extinction.

title: Article 2001013192428731872 -- No Title
description: January 31, 2001

title: Faith Succeeds Where Prison Fails
description: This week President Bush began work toward a central goal of his ''compassionate conservative'' domestic program: the support of faith-based social services. Liberals have already sounded the alarm about weakening of the wall between church and state.

title: As Fed Convenes, Gloom Deepens : Consumers in U.S. Lose Confidence
description: NEW YORK  Confronted by withering consumer confidence in the U.S. economy, the Federal Reserve Board is widely expected to reduce interest rates by half a percentage point when its two-day meeting ends Wednesday, a cure likely to revive American growth but possibly at the price of encouraging a spendthrift society.

title: Article 2001013190824829814 -- No Title
description: By BOB TEDESCHI

title: Rangers' Sather Offers No Excuses or Answers
description: On the morning after a nightmare, the Rangers' president and general manager, Glen Sather, agreed that the Rangers had hit rock bottom Monday night in their 7-2 loss to the Atlanta Thrashers.

title: PITNEY BOWES ISSUES EARNINGS WARNING AND WILL CUT JOBS
description: Pitney Bowes said yesterday that it would eliminate 700 to 800 jobs and reduce its first-quarter and 2001 profit projections because the country's economic expansion is slowing and the company's technology is changing. Pitney Bowes, which makes postage meters, expects a first-quarter profit of 52 cents to 53 cents and a profit for the year of $2.35 to $2.37, its chief executive, Michael Critelli, said. The company, based in Stamford, Conn., plans the job cuts, which represent about 3 percent of its nonsales staff, as part of a reorganization it will announce later this quarter, Mr. Critelli said. The company also announced its fourth-quarter results and said it earned $148 million, down from $178 million a year earlier.

title: Federal Court Will Not Pursue Diallo Case
description: The Justice Department will not file federal civil rights charges against the four New York City police officers who were acquitted in state court last year in the shooting death of Amadou Diallo, United States Attorney Mary Jo White said today.
